Not the most polished game upon initial release, but since patch 1.5, which is when I started, reckon this is one of the best realized and most immersive cyberpunk experiences one could get. I come from being a fan of the genre since original Blade Runner, Akira/Ghost in the Shell, and all William Gibson's books among others. Can safely say that every hour I've sunk into this game was without regret, despite whatever publicized shortcomings. It also stars Keanu Reeves.

Despite this game possibly being a shadow of its potential self, it is still the best story, character game at the time of this review. It could have been the game of the decade, but I think it came close to GoY with the 1.5 patch.
Yes I know they missed a boatload of contents that was promised, but quite frankly I don’t care nor should anyone who enjoys the great SP game.  What is also important is that CDPR has not given up on the game and there are future patches planned for the PC.
The story is great, the characters are amazingly well developed. Voice acting for female V is unparallel. I strongly recommend playing with fem V.
City is amazingly detailed and immersive.  
Graphics is well optimized and even earlier cards can get some impressive visuals. 
Here is what’s not working well:
-	Lack of interaction with the city
-	Bed driving model for vehicles – driving with keyboard in first person is atrocious. 3rd person is ok.
-	Combat Balance – you clearly notice it once you reach lvl 30 – almost no combat challenge.
-	UI, inventory management – very fundamental and hard to keep track
-	 Just that feeling that something is missing in the game. I would say CDPR release the game with 70% of contents and it feel s that way too.
Most above can be fixed with Mods. I highly recommend to check Nexus for latest. 
This review is based on the 1.5 and 1.6 patch play.
Botched release redemption nearly complete. Devs have patched A LOT of the issues so the game is playable now. Definitely give it try 👍

I've been playing since day one, and I have to say that while the game is not perfect, this has been a really great experience. The world and characters that CDPR have created far surpassed my expectations. It's easy to get sucked into the game and not come out until you've finished the story.

I think this game has a lot of negative stigma from it's awful launch, but CD Projekt Red did not give up and they have continued to fix the bugs, and add new content as well. I've played this game multiple times through, and every time feels completely different. Shout out to the people who haven't abandoned this game, players and developers alike.

I've actually played this for significantly longer than Steam reports as I also owned the game on GOG when it originally released, so I've gotten to experience the game from each of its various stages of development.

For all of its troubles and tribulations and shortcomings brought on by overzealous marketing and corporate mismanagement, Cyberpunk 2077 is a game I love tremendously. For what it lacks (as of this review) in the open world, it makes up for with a visually spectacular setting and a very engaging storyline. I also think the combat is an absolute blast, especially with the rebalancing and enhancing that's gone on over its patch history. 

There's way more that can be done to make the game even better (my personal requests being overhauling the police, more side activities to do in the world like the arcade game and the interactables in the apartments, more apartment customization), a number of features promised in the marketing are still absent, and what happened with its launch should never be forgotten. 

That said... most of the core problems that weren't to do with fundamental design decisions around the game have been addressed. What's here now is a really solid FPS / RPG in the vein of the modern fallouts (3, New Vegas, 4), but with vastly better gunplay. If you're looking for a new GTA / Red Dead Redemption type of world, this probably won't satisfy the itch as it stands.

This game is shaping up to be really good. It's a shame that all these features that people have been wanting in the game (that were promised in the game day one) are only just now coming to the game. If nothing else, CDPR has at least shown they are willing to work hard to make up for their mistakes and mismanagement of this game. As of the time of this review, the game is mostly bug-free, and plays much more like an action-RPG than a linear FPS. CDPR has just stated they are bringing an overhauled police and vehicle combat system, as well as other updates to cyberpunk soon. The new expansion, "Phantom Liberty" looks great, and I'm excited about Keanu Reeves reprising his role as Johnny Silverhand. This was a pleasant surprise. in about 8 months time, this game won't be really good. It will be one of the best sci-fi games ever made.

There  is a workaround for it.
However I am not sure that is the cause of the freeze.
The fix is a nuisance to perform but I will do it and see if that fixes the freezes.

i bought this game even though it had received a ton of negative reviews due to its many bugs and glitches at launch. after now about 70 hours and finishing the story in a slow-paced manner (i love to take a lot of time for exploration), i can confirm that it was worth it!

there still are a few bugs in the game. sometimes traffic just stops, all cars simply stay where they are for no reason, npcs sometimes slide up stairs without moving their legs, objects or vehicles spawn or despawn right in front of you or enemies dont show up when they are needed in a mission, forcing you to load your last autosave.

but still i loved cyberpunk, especially the character writing and artwork is remarkable. i created a female v with the corporate background story and my decisions led to a romance with judy alvarez and "the star" ending. suffice to say i have never been more emotionally invested in a pc game before. i just wish there were more social options, for example to go on dates with your romance partner or to meet friends at restaurants or other places in night city.
i love judys character writing so much, she has to be one of the best written pc game characters i have ever seen. such a bummer that you can't spend more quality time on dates with her, the moments when v and judy were together are just SO CUTE. 

the visuals are amazing and performance-wise the game also chugs along nicely. cd projekt has integrated a lot of modern optimization technologies to ensure that the game WILL RUN smoothly as long as your rig meets the requirements.

combat mechanics like gunplay and melee are nice as well. there are lots of different weapons with individual features and stats to choose from, you can upgrade and craft weapons as well as sell them or dismantle them for parts. looting is fun because you sometimes find really cool stuff when taking down enemies.

even just walking around night city digging through random places is rewarding in itself because there is TONS of loot scattered around everywhere. you can find so many awesome details as well, the multiple layers of the city invite you to dive in and look around. sadly, the number of stores you can visit is limited.

character customization is one of the features that cyberpunk was praised for at launch and you do get a lot of options BUT and - this is a big criticism - there is a  APPALLING lack of cool fashion items for V. 

this is especially infuriating when you see all the incredible outfits that the npcs (especially mox gang members) are flaunting around the city. you get to choose from some old shabby tank tops and pants that look like a herd of cattle used them as toilet paper before they landed in a dumpster behind your local goodwill. here's wishing that cd projekt figures out that players would love V to actually LOOK cyberpunkish when it comes to fashion items.

overall i'm still satisfied with the game and i hope that the devs keep on patching the few quirks and issues that still remain in this product. also i hope for some content updates, giving players access to more (and cooler looking!) fashion items, maybe more cars and more businesses to enter and buy stuff at.

thank you for taking the time to read this review. stay safe out there, choombas

I like the open world concept. The main story is great, and it can be played by gamers who like role play type games or it can be played by people who like to grind and try to find all the stuff or complete all the missions.

I hold this game up on the same level as I do New Vegas.  Came out buggy, the console versions were unacceptable to the point of being possibly illegal, but its a very fun world to inhabit that feels alive and has a really vibrant modding scene that makes the game a 10/10 for me.  I will admit that the choices you get to make are inferior to New Vegas, but the world is just as high concept and full of unforgettable characters and stories.  If you want to try out some mods yourself, I recommend this mod pack, which installs and configures a ton of mods for you with minimal effort, all designed to work well together. 
 https://next.nexusmods.com/cyberpunk2077/collections/iszwwe

Has its moments. I will be playing it more for sure, but honestly... 3/5?
+Combat is fun, stealth & tech is very viable but melee is more fun and becomes op.
-Most of the "content" IS forgettable fetch and kill quests.
-Level-tiered gear, makes everything you have useless, regularly, as you progress.
-Main quest / story / whatever has not been enjoyable thus far. Feel forced out of my character into the edgy punkish (and anticorporate) V the devs imagined, dialouge doesn't fit what I want to be, the bonus options from your background and skillset are rare, having no actual effect and basically you just do whatever the other npc says / wants because reason. Avoided it like the plauge out of disdain.
-Traffic is suicidal in game. Motorcycle advised for getting around stupidity like the AI sitting at green lights for 4 cycles, then you're going around them and their AI updates and decides to finally move and ****ing crash into you, the audacity.
-Crime system, may as well not exist. The only crimes you can do are harming civvies and straight up attacking the police. Walking about 100m away clears all crime status and there is no lasting bounty.
-There is no faction rep system. Kill hundreds of gangsters, wipe out their leaders they still won't know who you are, try to retaliate, or even stop respawning on every street corner. Attack corporate convoys, patrols, installations whatever? They couldn't care less.
-You can't interact with the world much, sit down on a bench, hack a vending machine for free soda or a traffic light to watch the chaos unfold, sit back and view things along the pier, help npcs you just rescued from gansters, most buildings are inaccessible and don't really exist; you're just a walking war machine waiting to get back into combat.
-INT stat. Useless. I have absolutely no points in it, could still buy a big cpu stick it in my head and use all the advanced quickhacks like suicide, system reset, squad-wide memory resets, security deactivation, etc. If they required it for hacks instead of just having a good processor, or required you to have a higher int to equip a better processor, maybe.

I guess if you set the bar extremely low upon release, all you have to do is release a few patches and the crowds will praise the game as being decent with less bugs than expected. 

This game is a clunk-fest. The dialog is 100% real cheese, the gunplay is subpar, and the world is a complete facade. Scripted events pull the player out of the "zone" due to how the NPC's reactive to the situation. The AI combat is just laughable; there is no way that anybody who has given this game a positive review hasn't in multiple instances laughed, or held back laughter, while in the middle of combat. It is just absurd! To test this out, just watch an AI teammate react while in combat mode. Cover? Nah, they'll just blaze straight in, unless they have targeted the enemy through a cement staircase at which point they will just aim at the ground and not move. Or maybe once an enemy has been fully alerted, go stand right next to them and listne to them talk to themselves. Or maybe dump five live grenades and watch a group of enemies run straight towards them. 

Other things I really enjoy - you are tasked with taking on a building full of enemies, what if half of those enemies use the exact same dialog? What if they continuously ask you to come outside when you are the one outside and they are indoors? It's fun watching an NPC play an arcade game while the game says insert coins. How about waitresses that will rotate to the same table over and over doing nothing. I liked how my AI teammate would disarm only to walk around in combat stance with no weapon. Or the scripted driving events where you are the passenger heading to a mission and the driver is hitting every obstacle in site. 

Well that's just off the top of my head. I've attempted to play this game three times now and just give up each time after 10-15 hours. 

AAA title that is just trash, doesn't stand up to what was promised and certainly doesn't stand up to anything near the quality of other big budget games. The fact that Assassins Creed has much better combat, AI interaction, flow, and general open-world believability is hard imagine but it's true, Look at something from Santa Monica Studios or Naughty Dog, and this is basically at about the level of Saints Row 2. 

Hate to say it and I know the creators had a lot of passion but they bit off way more than they could chew. Time crunch, money crunch, and generally an uphill battle to get the game were it is at now. It must have been disheartening releasing this game knowing clearly all of it's faults. Clear as day but in way to deep to do anything about it.

Still relatively small issues when it comes to textures and such. Like binoculars not in hand and then magically appearing when Panam is scoping the radio tower, see through faces on the local conspiracy theorist, but other than that it's more than playable. Running on a 3090 ultrawide.

During the first 40 hours it is amazing, then it becomes just good. Don't feel like playing it again, not that kind of gem unfortunately. 7,5/10

I have beat cyberpunk 2077 and I really must say, If the game released as I played it, NO DOUBT it would get at very least game of the year nominated. If you have 70$ to spare and want to play a game that is without a doubt a really good time I can safely recommend cyber punk. At max graphics (4k resolution) with Ultra ray tracing I was still getting 50+ fps I turned the resolution down to 2k and put the ray tracing on high and was getting 100+ fps in even the most dense areas. If you have a decent processer and gpu I would highly recommend playing cyber punk. Final score 8.7/10

I tend to want to actually play a game for some time before writing a review, and I also tend to not jump into any game/tech right after it hits the market simply because I know there will be issues.  So, to start, did CDPR mess up in the beginning and release a game that was simply not ready for prime time?  Indeed.  Do I feel like they've redeemed themselves with what the game has in it as of today?  Yes for sure.  Did they actually deliver on what they hoped to do and "promised"?  Not quite, but that is the reality of gaming industry.
Cyberpunk 2077 is definitely a step in the very right direction for the genre and for this type of open world gaming.  It has a great set of characters and fun game play for anyone who is coming to this game with fresh eyes.  Anyone expecting there to be new content thrown into the game like some others (Genshin I'm looking at you), then this isn't the game for you.  Its a story that you get to play, with little stories that take you into the lives of those around you in Night City along the way.  As all good stories go, there is a beginning a middle and yes, an end, and that's ok too.  I'm all for replaying a game, but don't think that you will have much wiggle room in those replays as its not that kind of game.  Should you play it?  Yeah, its a fun game.  Am I looking forward to a follow up game on a new game engine?  Oh yes.

Ich brauche hier nicht anfangen von Bugs oder Designentscheidungen zu faseln. Weder zu nicht erfüllten Ankündigungen oder übersteigertem Hype etwas sagen müssen, weil das schon zu genüge vorhanden ist. Es geht mir wirklich und ausschließlich um das Game an sich, ohne Politics oder Marketing.

Ich hatte Cyberpunk entgegen gefiebert wie viele andere auch. Doch habe ich mir nicht ein Video oder einen Post zur Entwicklung angesehen gehabt. Vielleicht gerade deshalb, bin ich mit dem Spiel so glücklich. Das Kampfsystem ist herrlich ausführlich, variabel und wunderbar animiert. Crafting, Vehikel, Apartments, Soundtrack, Dialoge und Map sind alle mehr als nur zufriedenstellend. Die Welt von Cyberpunk lebt. Und gerade das haut mich jedes mal aus den Socken. Von Verkehr über Passanten zu Stadtvierteln, alles ist in sich harmonisch und authentisch. Allein dafür laufe oder fahre ich gerne durch Night City.

Natürlich gibt es Dinge die mich persönlich stören. Die Mainstory ist solala, fast alles an Story hat einen bitteren Beigeschmack und viele Dinge wären besser etwas mehr als nur angekratzt worden. Oftmals wünsche ich mir dass ich mehr Freiheit hätte, manchmal reagieren Charaktere völlig unlogisch und so weiter.
Aber hier muss ich den Machern von 2077 etwas entgegenkommen. Denn sie haben trotz aller möglichen Kritiken, immer zu ihren Entscheidungen gestanden. Dann haben die Romanzen eben geschlechtliche Bedingungen und dann sind die Enden eben so offen wie sie sind. Das gesamte Spiel ist in sich konsistent und damit vollkommen richtig, so wie es ist.

Zuletzt muss man dazu sagen, dass es noch immer dann und wann ein Update gibt, daher würde ich behaupten, dass für mancherlei Kritik zu Release gar kein Grund mehr besteht.
Cyberpunk 2077 ist eines der besten und lebendigsten Open-World-RPGs.

Firstly: I'm not a huge cyberpunk fan - the genre held only passing interest for me, but I was looking for something new to do and gave this a shot. I'm profoundly glad I did; the early press was so bad that my expectations were extraordinarily low. I have never been more wrong in my life, and that includes a stripper ex-girlfriend who slept around.  

For all the rough publicity - fair though it may have been - at launch, CP2077 has turned into a high-quality, multi-faceted CRPG with perhaps some of the best character writing and voice acting yet turned in by performers. I started singling out voice cast for their roles, but as I did so, I realized I'd be listing most of them. By far, CDPR managed to salvage gold from a disappointing launch, and it's on the strength of the performance by the voice actors and well-written, multi-faceted, human characters that really shine for me. 

The graphics perform well on my mid-range system, running all at max but saving on ray-tracing. The controls are smooth enough, but there are mods - especially for driving - that make it even better. Frame rates are smooth, and transitions between areas are completely fluid and transparent. There are times - especially riding a motorcycle in the desert - that just feel so viscerally solid that you almost wish the road would go on for hours. 

The story... is compelling, but for me, was slightly disappointing, if we're being honest. I would have loved to continue in Night City for an indefinite period of time; driving and listening to music really is that enjoyable. It would have been nice to see random events pop up after the canonical "end" of the story - but without spoiling it, it's logical enough that there aren't. 

Prepare yourself - if you've even a shred of empathy and compassion - for some heartbreak. There's genuine emotion and feeling in a lot of the actors' performances, and CDPR translated those exceptionally well to the digital actors. There are no games that I can think of off-hand where the character you're "speaking" to makes amazing eye contact with you. CDPR pulled that off here, and it's breathtaking in its effect.

If you're a fan of the genre and can appreciate a well-told, well-acted story, I really do think you ought to give this one a chance. If you're not - like me - and just looking for something to engage you enough to lose hours - you really can't go wrong here. Not now. CDPR has done well here, and I hope that you'll give this one a chance. 

No regrets, choom. This one's nova, and well worth the eddys.

Cyberpunk 2077 is, like the human beings that produced it, and that it portrays, simultaneously beautiful, and flawed, and paradoxical. It's a game of brutal violence, and genuinely tender character moments; of beauty and squalor; of complex moral choices and simple grinds. Like the Witcher games that form CDPR's other major franchise, there are few clear-cut moments where you can say, "What I did here was definitely good, and will have no bad consequences for anyone who did not deserve them." The best you can hope for is that you learned something about your character, maybe about yourself in real life (corny as that may sound), along the way.

The biggest hint I'll give (although by now, this game has been talked about so much you hardly need hints from me) is this: make a point of actually befriending every romancable NPC, Even if you have no intention of **romancing** them, make friends with them. As far as I can tell, every quest for these NPCs is available even if you just befriend them, including some of those tender personal moments, that help you feel that, despite your character's plight, you're not alone!

Cyberpunk 2077 is a flawed masterpiece. The vision and atmosphere are some of the best I've seen in a game. The narrative is always at least serviceable and sometimes excellent. Gameplay is mostly fun, though the side gigs in particular do start to feel repetitive eventually. I've spent plenty of time in the game and am still discovering all sorts of hidden treasures. The larger narrative about the powers that be in Night City, which mostly doesn't impact gameplay, gets darker and more fascinating the deeper you go and provides plenty of fodder for (fingers crossed) future DLCs.

Then there are the bugs, which aren't gamebreaking like they were for some on release but range from amusing (e.g. objects randomly flying into the air without being touched, cars buried in the pavement or driving along a few feet above the ground, NPCs standing in midair over roadways) to annoying (e.g. ambient light randomly gets so bright I can't see anything, especially after dark in remote areas). There are other things some players may find annoying, like the truly baffling vehicle physics, but I mostly find these quirks fun.

If you don't mind the bugs, this is a game well worth your time and money.

Matrix meets Blade Runner meets Fight Club meets Grand Theft Auto! The once long awaited role-playing SCI-FI action that set out to both capture and define the essence of cyberpunk at a whole new level is now (patch 1.5) practically impossible to disappoint. 

Forget the early critical reviews, this game is nothing like Dec, 2020. Bring your curiosity, imagination, and plenty of free time to the table and this game will do the rest. Even on the mid range PC, this game shines without skipping a beat. But don’t let the eye candy distract you for long. The action can be intense, the drama convincing, the characters uniquely developed, and story arc absolutely epic. Save often and be honest to your character. Entertain no spoilers as you enter. A heart of TL;DR can ruin this for you, so don’t go there until you played through at least once.

There’s no clock so feel free to take your time. Explore as much as you can and appreciate the nods and Easter eggs when you see them. Otherwise, the city does not spare you: You will be touched, you will be surprised, you will question your values, and you will take the job anyway. Do you proceed with mercy or vengeance? Sometimes you decide, sometimes you have little choice.

If you seen the trailers then you know he’s here and in no small part. Whether antagonist or protagonist in your point of view, you can experience the many nuances of Silverhand/Ted/Neo/Wick in a memorable character befitting the genre Keanu Reeves help define. This is an interactive aspect of the story line, and I must leave it at that.

Bugs? Yes, plenty, still. Some are annoying, some hilarious, others you pray CDPR will never fix. None are deal breakers and that leaves plenty of immersion and detail for player to experience. If you were let down by the technical flops of an earlier release and left half-way then I encourage you to patch and start a new game. Don’t leave sour and don’t leave this hanging.

Even years from now this game will be remembered as the bar raiser others will have to surpass.

I played cyperpunk on ps4 when it released and it ok, filled with bugs but i've played worse. I returned to this game on 1.5 release on pc and can say for sure the game is wonderful. I followed the hype but waited till 2022 to get this game. Whatever happened at launch seems to be fixed with patch 1.5, majority of the bugs are gone. There are still some but I've been able to fix these small bugs by reloading a saved game. For example one item was missing when I was rushing out from Arasaki tower, a keycard, that was needed for elevator. I saved and reloaded the game, then the item appeared and was able to progress forward. These need to be polished out but it did not break my game experience as I was able to progress forward after reloading. Another issue I've witnessed is the AI of other drivers on the streets of Night City, they seem really stupid sometimes.

Now if we talk about the game as a game, this is mind blowing stuff. Night City is really gorgeous looking place, full of filth, gritty characters and all sorts of things to discover. The game looks really good, probably one of the best visuals in a game I've seen for a long time. I really hope that the DLC for this game comes out soon, feel like there is potential for more of side quests or things to do around the Night City and hope that the game producer delivers on this. Regardless of the minor bugs that are still there, this game appears to be worth the hype and certainly is a recommended experience.
So much better since all the updates, this is how the game was intended. Must play for any free-roam future tech lovers.

First and foremost, the game works like it should've at launch as far as functionality goes. Finally. 

But the biggest issue I've found with it is that I just don't care, and it doesn't make me care. The city is full of NPCs, but feels empty. Interaction with most of them is limited to pushing a button once you manage to get absurdly close and trigger the prompt to hear a line or two of canned dialogue. The story is interesting but stilted, and though the devs clearly put a lot of effort into making the supporting characters pretty, it's all veneer. I didn't care about them like I cared about the herbalist and her attempt to save the griffon victim in the Witcher, or the room full of hostages in Human Revolution. I didn't find myself interested in seeing what happened after I made decisions. Things, including people, are just sort of animatronics that move the story from one play to another.

The gunplay is good, but finnicky - if you generally play with a gamepad, don't. It's far too frustrating, and I ended up just using mouse/keyboard. Not a deal breaker for me, but something to be aware of if you care about this. 

Driving is atrocious. I walked across the city and wasted time instead of taking a car because the controls are so absolutely awful when it comes to steering. I avoided any driving like the plague. 

Mods do a lot for this game, but I didn't find myself invested enough to take the time to get more than a few before I let it go. 

In a game that feels like there should always be something happening or something to do, I shut it down one day and just never felt compelled to really pick it back up. If there were an option for "indifferent," I would've picked that recommendation, but I marked this as recommended because it functions correctly, and though it may not be my cup of tea, you might like it. But honestly it feels like an uninspired mess of great ideas that never got the time necessary to craft them into something that mattered.

Cyberpunk 2077 is a rather good game I just don't play RPGs well. The game has a very memorable and honestly amazing story. Most of the mechanics are great like the shooting and the hacking, especially the hacking. Throw all the cool cyberware you can use on top and the combat is very enjoyable. The art direction of the game is great and the environments look great most of the time, sometimes the environment can be a bit boring. Overall the game is fantastic but there are problems to it such as there is simply not much in the way of recreational things to do, annoying parts you have to force yourself through (some of the braindances if not all), the flashback scenes, and of course the MANY BUGS IT STILL HAS. 

I have played the game day one, it somehow feels buggier than ever. 2020 it felt fine for me with an occasional hiccup, now in 2022 I keep seeing cars and people getting sent into the sky, I touch a car and it flips, the map flashbangs my eyeballs now, sometimes the cool side missions dont work anymore, I have had to restart several times to get the most out of this game.

Even with all that I still do recommend the game but I would wait for a sale, currently in its state of bugginess it feels like a $45 game then a $60 game. If it didn;t have the bugs oh definitely $60.

Side note: Go watch the anime Cyberpunk Edgerunners, it was the best 4 hours I spent binging a show.

Amazing game. Perhaps not everything the hype made it seem like it would be, but that was never going to happen. Most of the controversy and people sobbing about bugs and performance came from console players trying to play the game on more than a decade old consoles, and a bunch of mob mentality that caused other people to blindly parrot the same slogans without actually experiencing them personally. The biggest mistake CDPR made was even bothering to try and release the game for those consoles, not that it didn't run well on them. This game aimed to push video game graphics of our time to their limits, it was insanity to think it would function on those ancient machines.

Waiting for the latest updates was completely worth it. I enjoyed game through it's entirety. Yes there were some glitches here and there, and they weren't ever game breaking. The ocassional T pose was present but again nothing major happened. I am currently on a game laptop and it ran good. I did crash a couple times but that after a heavy play through and it worked perfectly after that. 

I don't regret buying this game I would recommend this to friends to play. It was worth the wait and worth the time I put into it so far. I'm on my second round of going through it and I can see myself sinking into this game. DLC, I'm waiting for you now.

Initial Response:

A fun action packed open world game that provides you with a narrative regarding the life and death of a sole being in a trans-humanistic world that goes beyond and above with its story of Johnny Silverhand and his vehicle, V. The gameplay is there but the story needs to be expanded on and increased in order to provide characters that are involved with the game and its main story missions. The initial release would be most demanding because of the lack of Quality of life checks that did not allow for immersive play or the lack of mechanical checks that would allow the game to be good as it is. I won't go into detail here about what was bad or good. We kinda already know.

1.5 Release:

Pros: 
Major Bug Fixes and preventative measures for continued gameplay.
Inventory System is pretty much fixed with a few probably needed gear update with either all craftable skins and dye coloring and maybe a transmutation system.
FPS checks out pretty well on a 3070ti in general
LOVE the gunplay still and the much needed mods makes it more fun

Cons:
Cops seem to be still broken and don't "respond" like it would be expected like in GTA....They still magically show up.
Story Updates desperately needed: Expansion, Free DLC, a bit of re-writing of side characters of Evelyn Parker or like Victor and Jackie of course. More origin story references. I like the dialogue responses but its not enough. I feel like the Corpo and Nomad backgrounds you should at least be somewhat known in the scenes of those two backstories. 
MORE MAXTAC- I got sold on the game back in 2011 with the first trailer and we honestly needed more of them. 
More modifcations: Gear and cyberware wise. I feel like they had more than enough information and sci-fi to implement more cyberware into your character, as well as possibly change your appearance like gorilla arms and such. 

The game has bugs there and there....floating cars like I was in Interstellar for a moment or something.

The game needs mostly its story updates. CDPR got bumrushed by investors and had to make dangerous compromises it feels like. This is no excuse of course but I fail to see how one can go from the Witcher 3 and than get slammed on this.

The secret to enjoying games is to not place unrealistic expectations on them. Learn to love experiences for what they are, not what the internet wanted them to be.

I bought this game on sale for half off, after the worst bugs and glitches were patched out. And I have had one hell of an experience. The journey through night city is an adrenaline packed adventure, littered with suprisingly deep character interactions filled with emotion and humanity.

The gameplay was fun, the city was a sight to behold and a joy to explore, the soundtrack was fantastic, and the characters were the absolute best thing about the experience.

I only experienced two game-breaking bugs that were easily fixed with a quick save-reload, the rest of the glitches were honestly just hilarious to witness and gave me a few good laughs.

In the end, this game made me feel an intense range of emotions, made me feel for the characters that I interacted with, gave me adrenaline rushes during combat, and gave me a good 107 hours of enjoyment. When the credits rolled I honestly found myself wanting more, so I'm gonna return to night city eventually, because I truly enjoyed this game.

I want to say that I didn't play during launch so I didn't have the bad taste in my mouth that a lot of people (rightfully) had. This game is a lot of fun but has its issues.

Game play is smooth exactly what you want from it. Guns are smooth and melee is viable if you build for it. 
Story is really freaking good! I don't want to spoil anything but honestly just take your time and enjoy it and make sure you are using all of the dialogue options to get all extra options out of the way, plus its just nice to be able to flesh out the lore of the world.

Glitches do happen for example every time I start a new game after the prologue there is a cutscene that is full of montages. I have still not seen it because every time it tries to play I get a bunch of headless bodies standing in a T pose gliding around the screen with audio behind it. They aren't often or game breaking but things like the character models losing animation is pretty common (most of the time when I talk to an NPC the audio comes out but their mouths or bodies are stuck in an idle animation.)

TLDR;
Good story and game play that will take you as long as you want and be enjoyable the whole time but has some performance issues on most devices but they don't tend to be game breaking.

It's honestly not a bad game. Despite what reviews said in the past the game is still genuinely playable. Story is good and feels like a really good variant of other rpg's mixed together for a very positive experience. I didn't pay full price for this game. However it doesn't feel like its a rip off at full price either. Fantastic game all around regardless.

Right, lets get the obvious out of the way first: Although the game has seen plenty of patches to fix the worst of the glitches (and they have fixed alot of them), its far from perfect. There are glitches, some of them break the immersion and some are very subtle, but they still exist.

With that out of the way. Cyberpunk 2077 is one of my favourite games i have ever played. The world, the characters and the protagonist V are all super well done and they all feel like people, not NPCs. The world is depressive and dystopian, but yet so beautiful. I dont know how they did it but you will learn to both hate and love Night City, which is a very shared feeling in the game world it seems.
The different story arcs including the main storyline are also done with care and love, and you genuinely feel for the main protagonist V as their story is told. The different skill trees you can unlock and work your hours into feel distinct and interesting, and they make for unique and fun gameplay.

And if that didnt sell it enough, Keanu Reeves has a major role in the whole game. He and CDPR put their heart and soul into this game, its very easy to tell.

Before I say anything, check the time played. 143 hours. I finished every side mission, bought every car, rented every apartment, found all the tarot signs. I highly enjoyed this game and did not feel ripped off in any way. That being said, here's everything wrong with it.

1. I was under the impression that the bugs were mostly fixed, especially for the PC version. If that's true, holy crap, I don't know how it was even playable before now. This games is more buggy than initial release Fallout New Vegas. Just expect several bugs per mission. I'm talking things exploding randomly, things popping into existence, textures not loading, t-poses, people riding invisible motorcycles, sunglasses floating in front of your vision, text boxes and ricochet lines that won't go away until your reload, loot and people that sink into the ground. Heck, the final boss got trapped inside a door and I the only way I could beat him was to throw 100 grenades in the general area. 

2. Night City is huge but that's not necessarily a good thing. The city is completely lifeless. And by that I mean it has no personality. Not one inch of it memorable. I couldn't tell one you the name of one location. I know exactly what Megaton looks like in Fallout 3. I know exactly what Sanctuary looks like in Borderlands 2. But all of Night City is basically a generic template. Which brings me to the biggest flaw...

3. Everything Cyberpunk 2077 does, some other game has done better. Cyberpunk was supposed to be this revolutionary new game, filled with things we had never seen before. But GTA does open world better. Borderlands does loot better. The Witcher does characters better. Far Cry does combat better. Deus Ex does body modification better. Fallout does everything better. Everything in Cyberpunk is a not quite as good version of something we've already seen.

4. The music is garbage. The vehicle call feature sometimes spawns your vehicle somewhere you can't get it. The lore isn't worth reading. Every piece of garbage has its own hit box, which means driving through it is like driving through giant LEGO pieces. There aren't that many weapons. There is no 3rd person, which means if you want to see yourself, you have to go into photo mode. 

5. The fist fighting side quests are some of the worst quests I've ever played in any game. The mechanics are so broken that any punch the opponent throws from anywhere within a mile radius hits you for half your health. I wouldn't even have bothered to finish them if I didn't figure out that you can just shoot them before the fight and still complete the quests.

That being said:

1. The voice acting is phenomenal. I met a hundred characters and every one of them sounded exactly how they should sound.

2. For all its bugs, the game is still fun. Especially combat. The story is intriguing. The side characters are interesting. If there's a DLC with Judy, I'll probably buy it. The fact that all the side characters dropped off the map after their story was told made me sad that I couldn't see them anymore. Even Jackie, who was only in the intro, left an impression.

3. 143 hours. This in no way feels like an incomplete game. I had a blast. I rampaged Night City, broke some hearts, partied hard, saved a few robot cars, changed a few lives, and let an old rocker have a few more years in the spotlight. They'll be talking about me for decades. I have no regrets.

This game has some pros and cons to it:

Pro: number ONE; Johnny Silverhand is with you 100% of the time, and it's Keanu Reeves at his best with him.  It's great.
The city feels good, and each area of it really pops.  Areas feel unique without feeling like you just walked into a new area so the scene changes now.  
Combat is fun, by the halfway mark, you'll have a style down based on your character.  It'll work, somehow.  Super stealth hacker knife expert?  Or just... punch things?  So many inbetween but they all feel capable. Except for stacking everything in to Gorilla arms, then you just can't die and you laugh at the fragile meat sacks.
Characters are fun, likable, or effortlessly detestable, and you'll get to interact accordingly.  There's rarely a time when you have a problem that has an option you wouldn't take.  

Cons: cars suck.  Seriously, the driving in this game feels awful.  
The map is hard to navigate because places aren't named, you kind of have to guess where things you want to see are, and it prevents good exploration.
Characters are great!  You'll be able to interact with... seven of them.  I know it's not a game where you're supposed to "make all the friends" it's actually story over open world, but I wanted more characters to chill with.
You'll make an awesome character, that you'll only see in the pause menu... 
I never found a good reason to get in trouble with the police and take on Max Tech... real missed opportunity.
There's not "enough" things in the city to push you to explore every corner, which is sad, because holy crap it would  be nice.
There are locked doors in the city that do nothing, and can't be opened, and it makes no sense.

In the past decade of gaming, this has been on of the most powerful stories I can remember. The characters, the music, the backdrop of Night city. This is one of the few games that keeps bringing me back over and over.

[h1] General Opinion [/h1]
I have ended up enjoying the game, a whole bunch more than I thought I would. (60+ hours on my first playthough, as of writing this) 
A bunch of quests seem to start off as "by-the-numbers", but end up taking a massive, surprising turns.
  I've enjoyed most of even the most "basic" side quests.  I often feel myself getting drawn into the world, and caring about even minor characters.

Combat is promising, but not quite there.  It usually boils down to how much DPS your weapons have. (I use the monofiber, sniper rifle, smart AI pistol combo).   The enemies are either far too easy, or deal far too much damage. Either you mop the floor with them, or find yourself continuously healing. Netrunning/hacking is still always fun though.    Stealth runs are more fun, but there really is no advantage for going stealth over aggressive. (Save for maybe 5 quests that will net you some extra cash, but honestly not much more).

The Romance quests are surprisingly detailed.  I found myself genuinely caring about some NPCs, and their wants and needs.   I actually grew attached to Judy, and wish there were more romance scenes for the characters.


 For those of you who are familiar with the commerical spoilers, it still hits really hard, even when you know it is coming. I found myself calling his number, even 40+ hours of gameplay later, hoping he would pickup. A lot of the characters feel really fleshed out in this game.

The NPCs often feel very genuine and authentic.  I even HATE Johnny as a PERSON (not as a NPC), but I can still empathize with him.  He isn't just some random "by the numbers" character.  He actually seems like a real person, who I even found myself agreeing with sometimes.   He isn't designed as some random character you are supposed to hate/like.  He feels like a real person, despite being an asshole, still has his moments of genuine insight and humanity.

For my first playthough, I ended up playing someone who romanced Judy, and found myself genuinely invested in her quests, and upset when things didn't go her way. I was also surprised to find out that certain characters have actual preferences, like real people do.  still feel embarrassed for hitting on Panam, and getting shot down. (So much, that I reloaded to avoid said situation. XD )

I didn't just grow to "like" the characters in this game. I became ATTACHED to them.  I honestly wanted to help them, and learn more about them.  Cept for Joshua... Guy creeped me right the hell out.

The writing/character development is really THAT good.  A lot of the quests are seriously thought provoking. I honestly found myself conflicted between certain actions in the game.  There are actually quite a few non-black&white, clear-cut decisions you can make in the game.    
 They don't feel like random NPCs who "you are supposed to like or hate". They feel like real people.  Story-writing and voice acting at it's best.  Still wish I could go the romance route with Claire.  :P 

[h1]BUGS[/h1]
I've run into a few irritating bugs (mostly during the Racing quests, where you suddenly hit invisible objects, or have enemy racers literally spawn right in front of, including at the finish line).

But I've only encountered 2 actual game-breaking bugs.

[spoiler]
One is at the GIM, where if you fight the Animal boss before checking the van, which results in all 3 doors locking you out, to progress the quest.

The other was when I fought against the Voodoo Boys. There is a small room you can walk into, and the doors will close behind you. If you don't have enough Body/Lockpicking, you are stuck permanently. 
[/spoiler]

I ended up downloading Vortex and using the wall-clipping mod to escape both glitches.  Haven't touched it since.

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
A really fun world to explore. I WANT to see  and meet the people in this world and see how they tick. I WANT to play the different lifestyles to see what is different.

But the bugs... the freaking bugs.  There are quire a few small ones. But still enough to jar you out of the game-world.  T-Pose walking NPCs,  hitting random invisible objects, beating a heavy-weight champion at a boxing match, because he got stuck on a chair (Can we say "Gut-punch at Body 6"?), waiting 2 minutes for a stupid NPC van to drive up to a spot... It's all there.

The game's world feels very authentic and amazing. Combat is kind of wonky, but still enjoyable. Storytelling is freaking AMAZING! Even IF you try to go asshole/jerk route, it still flows pretty well.

I would still recommend grabbing it on a major discount, though.  I mean 40% or more type of discount.
Story and World building in the game are really good, but the combat, and bugs especially can make it taxing.

Still, give it a try, if you have the spare cash.

This game is one of those games that you tend to play from time to time, the game has many bugs and the graphics are really demanding, but on the other side those graphics are demanding for a good reason. I feel like the story, setting, and realism of it all (if you don't count the bugs) really sends a message about reality and how a sad and horrible future like this could be very real someday, if it wasn't for the game breaking bugs it could probably convey this message a little better. Honestly if you're actually invested in the story and game go ahead and buy it but if you're just looking for a cyberpunk themed combat experience this is not for you. Also PLEASE make sure you have a decent computer for this, your small 2012 refurbished eBay school computer will explode in your face if you try to run at high or medium settings.

Bottom line, if you enjoy sci-fi action, and don't mind the cyberpunk aesthetic, this game, well, it's pretty great. 

There are few games with this thorough of a story. Doesn't hurt that it's a story that I really enjoyed. Sure, there are better stories out there, but the integration of this story across many, many aspects of the game is very fun. You never know when you're going to stumble across a tidbit of information that matters.

The voice acting is top notch as well. Seriously, I can sit back and enjoy fem V's roller coaster of emotions for hours. Great acting! Even when the visual scene is boring, the voice acting pulls me into the story, big time. I really hope that further DLC offer more voiced lines, or even a full prequel game that explores V's life before Night City. Cherami Leigh made an awesome V, I want more. 

The game itself is a fun shooter, with some RPG-inspired options. Your choices can make a difference on the little things, but there's no way to drastically diverge from the author's intentions for the main story, you end up in the same place in the end no matter what. I wish I had more control over which of my allies I can bring to the final battle, if any. At the very least, I wish my actions made more of a difference to who survives; spoiler alert, one of your acquaintances will die at the end, and there's nothing you can do to stop it.

In the end, I am a huge fan of this game. I enjoy the base game play, happy to run around the map for hours just taking it all in. Mods are your friend if you are here for the story more than the action, as you will have to manage some gang wars in order to keep the story flowing.

I say again, if you're excited for a good story, pick up this game. If all you want is a shooter, well, it's fun, but not as robust as the dedicated shooters out there.
I strongly recommend installing mods from nexus.

GTX 3070 and a AMD Ryzen 5 3600XT Cyberpunk ran absolutely fine on pretty much full whack details with Ray Tracing off, Ray Tracing on was impressive but dropped frame rates to 30fps or lower so that was off.

46 hours on the first play through, no mods - I didn't do all the side missions or explore even some of the main side quests. I knew I'd be playing this again but, we'll get to that shortly... here is what I thought (apologies for any minor spoilers here, there won't be many)

In terms of character build, my go to is a stealthy play style and wanted to be a Corporate sneaky hacker... and we'll get to that shortly as well...

First impressions of the game are like woah - really ambitious world building. Night City is a triumph of design, full and rich in design. Easily one of the best city sandboxes I've played in. There is some goofy stuff going on occasionally, cars magically driving into the floor and stuff like that, but it's generally ok, nothing I have not seen before in other city sandboxes.

Driving around the city - as cool as Night City looks - is not always that fun however. I couldn't place my finger on why but ultimately I concluded it was because none of the vehicles were that interesting or varied. I mean, there are a lot of vehicle types, and they all look the part, but driving them felt a little flat and underwhelming. I generally stuck to one of the first vehicles you get, a motorbike, simply because it was the nippiest to get around when I needed it, or fast travelled.

One very nice touch with the vehicles is that you can summon any you own at any time - I appreciate this feature greatly.

So let's talk about missions. In typical open world style we've got main  missions, side missions and what I'd call side-side-missions, to which there are a few variants. 

Side-side missions are a mixed bag; Steal something, rescue someone, kill someone etc. I found these quite fun, kind of reminiscent of Deus Ex HR side missions in that there was always more than one option for the player to complete it. Being a stealth hacker with knives these were no problem - even if it kicked off I was able to mangle through it.

There are also these missions called Cyberpsychos where you've got to either kill or capture a person who has gone a bit mad from all the mods they've installed up their arse - These are fun and varied in that each one have a different 'thing' about them - one might be a sniper, and one might be an invisible katana wielding ninja, you get subtle clues just before the encounter. It was interesting to get some background on the person afterwards (like context as to why they went crazy) I challenged myself to capture these guys instead of outright killing them - which unfortunately doesn't make a huge difference (as far as I could tell anyway)

Ordinary side quests are to give you depth to some of the other main characters in the game - I hardly explored some of the characters, like Panam I think I did the one main quest and never spoke to her again. I intend to on the next play through.

A frustrating part of the character interactions linked to the side quests was that I found 'V' as your character, sometimes was completely off point with some of the dialogue choices. Most of the time you're a hard arse, but other times, out of no-where, you're almost too empathic and caring, I disliked this inconsistency and it actually became quite distracting at times. It felt like the game was not letting me play like I wanted to play.

The main mission and overarching story of the game is -ok- I'm not sure if the point got lost on me or I was distracted by other factors but I found the main plot was alright. During my play through I had to reload a save from one mission due to a bug, where a vehicle I had to tail ended up inside a wall and couldn't move, but otherwise I never found any other game breaking bugs. There are a few other glips like enemies seeing bodies through walls, or reloading a save and enemies are 'alerted' for no reason - nothing that really caused me a big issue though.

I found the gunplay pretty good. There is a decent selection of weapons. I tried sticking to my throwing knives and katana loadout mostly but you do need to shoot sometimes and the game encourages, even forces a shootout sometimes. Guys dodging bullets in realtime Matrix style, the first time you see it is like - holy sh*t that looks good!

Quick hacking during a fight is pretty awesome too - even if it is like casting digital spells, it still felt cool to overload a guys optics just before stepping out and slicing his head off - Never saw it comin'

What I wanted to say about a stealthy play style; You're not particularly rewarded for being passive or stealthy. It's also not possible sometimes to stealth certain sections - although oddly stealth is really encouraged a lot of the time. There is even an optic camo mod that really helps you out in this aspect, but you should know stealth is not the primary mode of play in CP2077, IMO. Shooting is.

I have to talk about Keanu Reeves' role in Cyberpunk as Jonny Silverhand. I genuinely thought it was some sort of marketing gimmick, a celebrity endorsement, that he'd play a small 5 minute role, and boy I was wrong - His role in the game is probably one of the strongest out of all the characters. [small spoiler in the remainder of this paragraph] Anyone who played Batman Arkham Night, where Joker appears to Batman in the environment, makes comments or jokes, or gives an opinion on something - this is a lot like what Jonny role is for a large part of CP2077. Even in small side quests he can appear when you don't expect it, and has lines of dialogue that are sometimes humorous or insightful. Sometimes he just appears and is looking at something. I can't talk too much about this character as he is tied into the main story line, but I was really impressed with his dialogue and voice acting throughout. [end of spoiler]

Character development to me, seemed to be broken - From what I understand, if you invest points in a skill tree, you should get more perks for that tree, but I never did. I only ended up with about 5 perks and couldn't seem to add any more points into that tree. This was especially obvious with the ninjitsu tree, I unlocked everything I could, it was practically my main weapon (a dagger and a katana) yet I never seemed to be able to progress it any further than the initial unlocks. Next play through I'm going to figure this out.

There is also a crafting aspect to the game, which I can honestly say I never used. I can't really see its place in the game, seems a bit pointless when in every fight / mission you'll likely find a new weapon which is better than you're old one. You can also upgrade your weapons and clothes and stuff - but again, I was never short up upgrades from people I'd just killed.

So to sum up... This is CD Projekt and they gave us Witcher. They clearly worked hard and attempted to deliver something big, and anything following Witcher 3 would be extremely difficult to top.... I can't make excuses for the initial release of CP2077 and I certainly have not found CP2077 to be as impactful or profound as Witcher but despite its flaws, its definitely a good game. I would recommend it.

The game has it's moments. Graphically stunning, good concept, good development and crafting elements... But there are many bad moments too. You cannot help but notice how rushed it is. Like many I was kind of expecting more in terms of augmentations and some of the gadgets that were first shown early on in development, such as climbing on walls with claws. Even though the game wasnt exactly what I wanted its a good game with a fun world to explore.

Full disclaimer: I was not there for the seemingly bumpy start. There are certainly some things to iron out, but on the whole I must say it did not disappoint!

Here's a quick sumup:

- Deep and varied storyline, albeit a little short for my liking. I've only played through once (Nomad) so far, but I will gladly play it again with a different start!
- Stunning graphics if your rig is up for it!
- The combat system is great as it allows for great variety in how you want to play the game, adding to the replayability

- Purchasing new vehicles feels a little too strict for my liking. I don't feel there's a reason to limit in the way the game does; by being offered to purchase them once you've completed a number of gigs/events for leaders around the city
- Although I appreciate the variety in the combat system, it does lack in cuztomisation in other parts of the game. There is for instance no customization for vehicles (at time of writing) and very limited possibilites for apartments (the latter I mind the least). It would be really cool if had the options to actually use the workbenches already located in the apartment though, whereas now it does feel a quite bare.
- The city at times feels incredibly empty! I was driving down the highways for quite some time and only ever saw 3 cars max. The city centre works fine for me, and it's often packed with people - it's where the city actually feels alive.
- I experienced a few bugs along the way and while they're not really anything to be upset about, I don't particularly enjoy watching NPCs or mission characters flat out disappear! Only by scanning I could see the mission characters at least had fallen through the ground into the vast nothing. I would recommend saving your game before starting a new Main Mission or Side Job, just to be on the safe side!

The negatives does however not outweigh the now positives for me. The game had a captivating storyline to me, but I reckon I'll wait for my next playthrough until they've done a bit more patching.
While not without its faults 2077 is over all a good game for those that have the hardware to play it.

The epitome of "what could have been" but also at the same time a cautionary tale to give developers more time. This game is still terrific, albeit not what we were promised. It does scratch the open world itch, as well as full immerse you into the world. The characters are fantastic, the side quests are oftentimes strange, and the world has so much life. If the game could have at least launched with what the 1.5 patch fixed, then this game would be very very well regarded. 

The launch definitely rocked CDPR's reputation, but the product now, at least to me, redeems them a little. I will be more cautious with my next CDPR hype train, but I'm sure they will too.

Cyberpunk 2077, The setting and story is amazing. One of the better sci-fi games out there. The characters are rich and mostly (not all) believable. But the looming detriment to the player is the game's mechanics, some clunky systems and overall how it (game play) can fall apart towards the end of the game.

There are bugs that can create frustration - like enemies attacking while stuck under the ground. Driving off-road can/will feel messy. Cyberware that doesn't have clear ties to certain perks/skills or attributes. Successfully using stealth weapons/skills against enemies and alerting an entire mob to your location. Character freezes, quest crashes, NPC glitches, and so on. But with that being said, Night City is an amazing place to explore and adventure in. The voice acting is good, the action is very good - though I would have liked it a little more had there been an option for 3rd person view while using melee. A lot of the missions are very well thought out and I LOVE how I really felt a part of the culture of Night City!

Cyberpunk has an amazing story and the setting is truly a marvel. There are issues, but open world games are extremely hard to make (Fallout, Elder Scrolls, No Mans Sky etc.) and I believe despite the bugs this game is an underrated gem. It's not perfect, but I think it adds to the charm. People today are way too hyper critical and we sometimes forget to just have fun! Cyberpunk IS fun! Give it a try and support the future of Cyberpunk.

I was hyped about this game for years. I was skeptical about it when it launched. So I waited a year and a half to play it so all the bugs got worked out. I am not an RPG kinda guy but boy, this game has consumed me. I love the "cyberpunk" genre and I think the storyline is amazing.
saint's row meets deus ex, rage meets far cry, shadowrun meets the outer worlds.
It's actually playable with old hardware... i7-4770K with GTX 1080 at 1440p. I've seen RTX enabled graphics IRL at 1080p with an RTX 3070. Honestly, I didn't need it to enjoy the game.

After putting in near to 600 hrs on the base PS4 the moment it launched on the 10th of December in 2020, and now after purchasing it again for PC and clocking in at almost 400 hrs so, I can honestly safely say this is hands down one of the best and my favorite game and let me explain why. [b] SPOILERS LIKE HEAVY FUCKING SPOILERS READ AT YOUR OWN WILL [/b]
[h1]The Story [/h1]
This is the main reason I was interested in the game and pre-ordered it. It is no doubt the best story I have ever experienced in the whole entirety of my gaming career of course, you got RDR 2 (second best to cp2077 for me), TLOU, The Witcher and just many other fantastic games out there the reason cyberpunk to me is far better than the ones I mentioned is that this was just an engaging roller coaster of emotions from feeling happy to pissed, being loved then just straight up fucking depressed. I fucking adore how the game does this to me I have never felt so many emotions in one game RDR 2 did this to me but Cyberpunk took it to a whole other level. So firstly the premise of the game you play as V a customizable character from head to toe who is a merc accompanied by his/her best friend Jackie, Jackie informs V of a one in a lifetime Job a heist guaranteed to go flawlessly with a huge reward it's a simple job all you have to do is Gain access to the penthouse of the CEO of one of the enormous corporations in the world and steal a Biochip that is in its trial phases what could go wrong? EVERYTHING after almost being caught to thinking youve escaped and then actually being caught a battle through the building to escape in one of Night Citys most courteous chauffeurs, Delamain an ai controlled cab company that provide you a premium bulletproof escape with drones hunting you down shortly realizing you best friend needs medical assistance immediately delemain refusing to do so then your best choom dying right in your hands after meeting up with dex and being double crossed the chip Jackie gave to you by putting it in your neural socket revives you and now you got one badass but a goddam fucking pest of character for the rest of your journey, Johnny Silverhand who is taking over your body but that's the chips doing not his Now you gotta figure out a way to get rid of this chip.
[h1] The Characters [/h1]
OH BOY the characters are fucking top notch in this game there never was a dull moment with any of the characters during my journey in Night City. Every character was so well crafted I did not think id be so emotionally attached to these characters even if they weren't in the game for long they are all made beaitifully from the phenomenal voice acting to their facial animations each character is unique and got their own story to tell. I never would have imagined a game would make me this attached and in love with its characters, let me make an example for one, Judy we all know Judy weather you have or havent played the game if you have been in the community you more than likely have heard about Judy, so Judy is a romancable character for your character (female only) she's a lesbian, getting to know her personality see who she really is and what she does is beautiful, its remarkable the character development, once the main part of the romance arc happens its just such a beautiful mission and this is where you get to know all about Judy, her past life, where she grew up and such, its such a beautiful moment in this game shortly there after you have a very spicy intimate scene with her, the morning after is adorable she asks you what last night meant and if you want to move in with her and the messages you recieve from her later through the game is just amazing this game even made me feel like i was in an actual relathionship for example the other romance option for female V is a detective named River his storyline is fantastic and once it got to the romance part i felt bad denying him but if i chose to do it then i wouldve felt bad for Judy cause it be cheating (even tho this isnt a thing in the game) on her but also if you play her storyline she was such a likable character and it be just fucked to do that god dam id never thought a game would make me feel this way especially with certain endings and how your romance character will react some are just dowright heartbreaking to one juts being fucking depresing.
[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
Gunplay honestly feels fucking unique there are always different ways I can approach enemies, guns blazing, hacking, stealth, and just straight up fist fight all of them it's great to be able to do this and let me touch on gunplay for a sec, there's a few ways you can go about this longrange, up close and personal midrange or mix them up still another thing is sometimes during gunplay I swear id be playing it like if it was DOOM, just running up with a heavy ass shotgun blowing heads off gun butting the guy behind tearing off his torso with a shotgun to the chest then jumping over the next guy and blowing his back out also the hacking route can go a few ways full lethal hacking to being a distraction artist, there are so many ways to approach your enemies.
[h1] The Environment/Graphics [/h1]
Don't even get me started on how gorgeous this game is if its anything everyone can agree upon with this game it is how amazing the game looks and just the detail and the glorious landscapes and the city, the city is always bustling with life, like there are alot of npcs like alot (for me atleast) also differnt time of the day also changes the amount of npcs or just the location, every district is unique with its looks and people for example in the more downtown part of the game where the high end clothing stores are you are going to see npcs that are wearing more buisness like clothes also more high end vehicles, the dessert or known as the badlands is just a vast wasteland with what youd expect to see out there vehcles built for the environment and not alot of people. Night City is hands down easily one of the most stunning cities in a game to date no argument required.
[h1] Audio [/h1]
Cyberpunks sounds are just on another level, from the ambiance to the music down to each engine and startup of every vehicle, each gun variant sounding different form punchy to techy. The music is just unbeatable. It's got something for everyone from Jazz to fucking Metal, and a lot of the clothing you can wear all have their own sounds. There is so much detail its actually underappreciated, its just an eargasm.
[h1] Side content [/h1]
 There is a decent chunk of side missions to do some feel like they're part of the main story, but they aren't It's just side missions then you got your side jobs they are the same thing but it's just for cash so it is what it is. Every game has it. 
[h1] End Game [/h1]
Well there is really no end game basically no matter the ending you die so there isn't anything for you after completing the game some people hate that in games which is fair but if you played the fucking game idk why you'd be mad but doesn't mean you can't play the game anymore and have to do another run through the game takes you to a save before the ending so you can finish up additional content or just continue exploring about or try the other endings.
[h1] Final Verdict [/h1]
Cyberpunk 2077 is a gem of a game. Yes it has a lot of flaws and problems but it is a one in a million some people may say how or why well did you read my review? The game is addicting, entertaining, has a gripping story, amazing environments, phenomenal characters and just an all-around great game to play, it constantly sucks me back into play even tho I've 100% this game way too many times than id like to admit. solid 8 to 9 out of 10

I originally got this game on release for PS4 Pro and dropped it in a few hours after realizing that Sony's jet engine simulator of a console was no match for this game.
...Also my character looked like a bad Joker cosplay.

Got this game on PC since I figured my new system could probably run the game better, so I left the console to continue burning up delicious fried eggs, and waddled over to the mod shop of the internet.

To my surprise, mods have carried this game from the pits to the moon, I've installed over 120 mods so far and the game looks and plays like a dream. This game seems to take mods really well, surprisingly.
Reshades, the FSR 2.0 mod, and modded ray tracing to hit around 100 FPS make this game look incredible, breathtaking, if you will.

There were so many missing features at release, but I can't really think of anything major that's missing at this point besides a proper lengthy intro chapter with Jackie.
Wanted flying cars? There's a mod for it.
No transit system? There's a mod for it.
Wanted system feels bare bone? There's a mod for it.
Clothes look like something out of a dried up flea market? There are mods for it.
Hate censorship? Plenty of mods for that.
Granted, they're mods, so they may not be up to absolute AAA standards, but they get really close.

Aside from the occasional miniature adult NPC T-posing with their head up the exhaust pipe of a Veyron, I'd say this is an easy buy (and a redownload for those that jumped ship).

Pros:
--Big, open world
--A lot of cool builds to test out with various playstyles
--Multiple different endings to get the one that feels right for your playthrough
--Motorcycles are amazing to drive around on.
--When the graphics are working, the game looks amazing

Cons
--Randomly get FPS crashes, so the game struggles in some spots. I have a 3070 ROG and sometimes the game would drop me down to 12-14 FPS either because there were a lot of things going on or just for the hell of it.
--You can reset perks, but not attributes. And you can only get a limited amount of levels to your attributes. Which really hurts when you want to test out other builds.

Overall, I had a lot of fun playing it. Do yourself a favor and buy the Kusanagi motorcycle--you won't need anything else.

I didn't buy it when it came out. I waited almost 2 years to play it and I encountered zero gamedecisive bugs. Some glitches here and there, but nothing all too serious.

The game itself is stunning. I've never seen anything more detailed in my whole videogamer life. The detail that went into the city is gorgeous. The story is really entertaining, it's the first time in my videogamer life, too, for me to completely (and I mean 100 %) play a game to the end in every regard. And I would play on for some additional hundreds of hours, if there would be content (one of the flaws of this game is, after the story ends, there isn't really much to do left, you for sure can wander the city, but there's not much enemies left and no real challenge possible).

One huge flaw - as always with console prioritized games - is the driving. Devs, for whatever reasons, didn't implement mouse-steering, so your cars (if you don't use a controller) fly from left to right within a ms, making it very frustrating to drive in the game. I really can't understand what's so damn difficult to think about PC players as well and code some sort of mouse-steering. Can't be that difficult.

Anyways - all in all, this is a game, easily getting into my Top 10, rather around the first than the last places. It's insane fun to play this if you like cyberpunk (I play CPR as tabletop as well) and in general if you like this typical futuristic Blade-Runner-esque feeling, cyberware etc.

Highly recommend this game.

For the current price at 30€ in the Steam-Store and even as low as 15€ on some key-shops, I can recommend this game alone for being a great sandbox and its amazing graphics. The cutscenes, music and some side quests are also very good. Overall, the main story is solid and interesting, but doesn't quiet manage to deliver a mind blowing twist. You get great value for the money, the game just could not keep up with the extraordinary expectations.

Thats's especially true for the combat system, mission design, skill tree, hacking and looting. And because of these deficits in the main aspects of gameplay, I can not recommend Cyperpunk 2077 as a great RPG. The open world looks amazing, but unlike Elden Ring, there is not so much where you really feel the urge to discover. 

But play it as an interactive movie, a city-sandbox and don't forget to try out the photo mode for amazing screen shots and I guarantee you, that are not going to regret the investment. I would give Cyberpunk at least 90/100, it might just not be what it initially had tried to achieve and what the fans had hoped for.

Also, at least for the first 20 hours, when I played it without being conterminated by the common negative consensus of the reviews by players, it managed to keep my hopes up high and felt at first like it could really be the promised big thing. First start and character creation already made an amazing impression. Then the pace of the intro and polished cut scenes.  All the small features and fresh ideas that hinted a lot of potential. For example, the brain dance was an astonishing game mechanic as well as a story theme that they should have made much more use of instead of those stupid hacking games. 

Give me an expansion with just 20 hours of well designed brain dance puzzles where the character whose memories you are reliving are moving across the whole city, interact with more NPCs and the covered times pan is longer. Paired with some philosophical questions that technologies brings up (I am sure in 2077 there are going to be at least a few rare specimen among mankind who can come up with better ideas than recording porn and crucifications...), the right mix for a great Cyberpunk-game that can revive that legendary Matrix-feeling is so near to grasp!
Totally worth it if you pick it up on a sale, great story and aesthetic, not a single bug in my two playthroughs, just wish there was more content :(

Overall worth it.

I loved the first version even with all the snafus.   deleted it.  bought the update and am  broadcasting my playthrough on www.streamlabs.com/getacustomone/home or just on twitch at www.twitch.tv/getacustomone i love this game.  the graphics are stunning beyond description, the environment is vast AF,  cars handle well,  narratives and sub narratives as well as sense of actual environments with people doing their thing.  also i really loved the combat and difficulty of play and opponents different combat techniques - from gang banger, to cyberpunk to Arasaka or  Militech or nomad, cyberpschos, etc   the world is dense with different characters and an Exceptional narrative that beats most movies hands down.  it's like Johnny Numonic meets Robocop, mets BladeRunner meets John Wick  but heavier on constant rage and combat and exploring hundreds of more characters with an in depth minute than most movies can conquer unless in a 9 to 12 hour trilogy movie.   yup.  pretty epic.   didn't pick up "SKIPPY" until i had solved pretty much everything in the last play through.  couldn't stop using the AI pistol the rest of the game.  that was my go to. Buggy launch notwithstanding this game is incredible. You will still occasionally see bug but for me at least most of these seem to spring from my old hardware straining to keep up with my abuse of it. Hop into your favorite 1000 HP Mad Max looking monster and roar across the city at 200 mph and watch your computer cry as it strains to keep up with the city you are burning through. The soundtrack is amazing. Never before has a cello been so powerful in leading a battle theme as you charge into a mega corporations worth of cyborg ninjas and mechs. Standout songs include "Resist and Disorder", "The Rebel Path", and "Not Fade Away" 

Total area wise the game space is quite a bit smaller than other open world games such as GTA 5 and the like, however very effective use is made of most of that space. Particularly in the badlands where clever layout and mission design conspire to give it a much larger feel especially when in mission. There are a few large open areas that are unused, I suppose this was to give them places to put in expansion material but I couldn't say for sure.
