This game's a tough one to review, we all know how it shipped in December of 2020. So I'll jump right into it with this: I played this after patch 1.5 and I do have mods installed (will mention it when relevant) and I will review the game accordingly.

Let's start with the visuals. Aside from the blurry anti-aliasing that I masochistically kinda grew attached to by now, this game is extremely impressive. The sheer complexity of the city's layout alone turns it into an actual character of the game. The whole place screams and breathe "future", "technology" and "society gone extreme". All the use of neon colours and bright holograms just gives it a very vibrant nature. On top of that, the game is very loud, so many noises going off at once, cars, rockets, gunshots, wind, rain, people, advertisements, radios, the list goes on and it makes it all feel alive. 

Sadly the feeling of aliveness stops there. The random NPCs in the city are like mannequins, they don't do much else than walking or standing there with an item in hand. Where are the routines and the complex population we were teased about? In another city, probably. 
Traffic is also terribly bad, NPCs' cars stop altogether the moment you're not driving anymore, and traffic lights automatically turn green when you're near them, it's a minor detail but once you notice it you never can unsee it.
The police is laughably bad at it's best, and downright pathetic at it's worst. Had to install a mod to fix it, that's how bad the experience was.  
The combat AI is not the best, all the enemies feel identical to each other, with little to no defining trait from a faction to another, unless they have that cyberware that go whoosh whoosh to rush at you. Only the combatants from Maelstrom and Animals behave differently from the others who are just meatbags with guns really.
The gameplay feels flexible but still restrict you just enough to feel like you'd need skill to get good at it. I love the fact that the guns has a very noticeable amount of recoil, often in other games they feel like lasers. Cars behave strangely, and the steering mechanic is either too low or too high, so I had to install a mod to help with that too.
The hacking mechanic is the highlight of the game, and for good reason, it feels extremely satisfying to build your character to be an expert netrunner that can kill anyone with just a line of sight. The environment and props are specifically thought with the netrunning mechanic taken into account and it shows.

Obviously, let's not forget about the bugs. They're drastically reduced now, and outside of the occasional NPC standing two feet above the ground in the middle of the road, or a car that spawns halfway into the ground, you won't see much. And the bugs you'll see aren't game breaking. Some are annoying, like the bug that removes all sound effects, or the one with the menu sound effect that keeps playing during normal gameplay. But nothing a quick save, going back to the main menu to restart the game won't fix. 

The music is [b]phenomenal[/b]. The rock tracks give you old garage rock with great futuristic twists, the electronic music feels like it's coming from another planet. Sound design is top notch, cars sound great and guns do too. Voices sound crisp and deep, you sometimes really feel like they're right next to you.

Now, to the story. 
Let's just say it's kind of a mixed bag. Lots of cool impressive moments, lots of incredible atmospheres and ambiences. The story itself, though, is another deal. 
As said in the first sentence of the review, there's a lot of Cyber, which immediately makes this game strike me as a spiritual successor to Watch Dogs, but the trademark moral and political stance just isn't there at all. The neons and cyborgs all look cool, sure, but the cyberpunk genre is inherently a satire of the societies it depicts, and a true anti-capitalism/anti-corporate vector for its messages. Here, you barely mess with the corpos and when you do, it's not to hit them directly, it's just because they happen to have something you need. 

Currently, I only have reached one ending so that's what I'll judge for now. The ending I had was the one where you're [i]up there.[/i] I really hated how this ending suddenly reminds itself it's part of a cyberpunk game and decides to go all self righteous when the whole game missed that specific message. 

The secondary content is packed but the quality is very variable. Some quests are amazing, some take 2 minutes to complete with little to no effort. There's a lot of events scattered around the map and if you get distracted easily, you'll end up turning at 5 minutes car ride into a 40 minute adventure of violence and gritty action.

Now let's go over what is by far the best aspect of the game: its characters.
Let's start with V. V has this perfect balance of sassy and serious that makes them extremely likeable.
Jackie is probably one of the most interesting guy in the city, while he has some "pure" ideals like simply wanting to be financially safe and enjoying a nice bike ride, he also have a very ambitious side to him, not hesitating to take risks for his dreams, and he obviously like having a little thrill while he's at it.  
Dex is the perfect job giver, you trust his jobs are gonna pay well but deep down you know he's gonna turn his back on you any second.
Claire is amazing with her bartender vibe, she reminds me a little of Jill from VA-11 Hall-A: Cyberpunk Bartender Action. She's fits well as the face of the Afterlife.
Rogue has seen some shit and it shows, she's that hard-to-earn-her-trust kinda boss, but once you get into her inner circle, you know she's got your back.
Kerry has a great character arc and is overall a very likeable guy who just kinda lost himself for a long time.

And the elephant in the room, the one and only, Johnny Silverhand. Keanu Reeves did a stellar job with him. He's despicable, admirable, filled with anger, but has that relaxed vibe to him, he gives no fucks about anything, he's ready to do anything to further his goals, but win him over and he's gonna be your greatest ally. Just overall a larger than life character, really. Truly iconic already.

So, after all that. Is this game still worth it? Yeah, it is. But only to someone who can manage expectations. This isn't a cyberpunk GTA game, this isn't a sandbox. It's a role playing game, and a imperfect one at that. But it's still an absolute blast.

As odd as it is to say, the best part of this game is that it's a great time sink; Making an all-powerful protagonist, doing every side quest, exploring an open world, and generally being a walking force of nature, while slowly edging your way through the main story. The side quests and "gigs" are pretty good; Your choices matter, interaction is nice, and though combat can sometimes be repetitive, you can always just try things differently. Challenge yourself to be completely nonlethal; Stealth your way when you're mainly built for brute force; Build up your perks that stray behind because of your usual play style.

Your character's build will ultimately fall one of three ways - basically either brute strength, deadly ninja, or tech wizard - based on your choice of cyberware (particularly your operating system) and attributes, but even so, nothing stops you from just picking a different approach. A generalist may not be all-powerful, but can redistribute their perk points at will. The main drawback is the level cap; You will never master all attributes at once. Pick two that are most important to you. Carefully curate the rest.

Lastly, say what you will about the game's strange world design or dialogue, it's pretty freakin' cool to be a tech-hacking cyber ninja with a non-lethal shotgun that shoots smart bullets targeting your enemy's kneecaps.

Spent 300 hours in and around Night City. I would say I got my money's worth. I will replay it again, so that will be 450 hours.

TL;DR: 2077 doesn't have the replayability or mod support of a Bethesda game, and is not as fun of an open world and lacks multiplayer compared to a Rockstar game. 

The game ends and there is no end game. There is no reason to jump back into Night City after you clear the map and complete the main story line unless you are starting over, which will probably be old after my third playthrough.

With FO4 and Skyrim, there is an endless stream of new content and gameplay changes thanks to good mod support. I've never actually hit every point of interest in any one of my playthroughs of these games. Cells respawn, and there are the maligned Radiant quests (but hey, at least there is something). 

With GTA V and RDR2, the open world can still be fun after you beat the main story. Plenty of good times to be had just blowing stuff up and killing cops. Unlike 2077, it's a lot more challenging to 100% the map or get gold on all of the missions. Not to mention the beast which is GTA V online.

Anyways... I hope the modding scene for this game blows up, and I hope CDPR adds multiplayer or some kind of challenging end-game component because the action is actually fun and the game looks great. It has potential.

Love this game so much. Played it for 265 hours on my base PS4 and was already amazed, but on PC it's a whole new Level of art!! I adore Night City, it's always worth coming back, love the NPCs, the atmosphere, the Quests, the Music, everything fits in perfectly. I can not realize, how some players are not dragged into this, but me, as a totally Story-Player I will always be thankful for CDPR for creating this work of art. For me it is a true masterpiece - beyond any doubt. <3

This is probably my favourite game since CS:GO, Skyrim and Civ 5 sucked me in all those years ago. I've played through the game a few times, got most of everything done and keep wanting to come back for more. I LOVE this game, it just sucks me in and I can't leave until I've romanced Judy again and rode off into the sunset with Panam.

The game looks amazing, feels great to play, the progression and levelling system feels good, the music is incredible, Keanu Reeves is incredible, the main story is super engaging and many of the side quests are great too. I am a sucker for cyberpunk as a genre and now definitely want to give the TTRPG as well as Shadowrun a go too.

Though there's still some bugs present, including weird vehicle physics, occasional T-Posing and some HUD disappearing acts, the game is generally pretty polished and up to snuff. It is now as it should have been on release gameplay-wise.

There could, and should, now be updates that make infinite playability and replayability feasible with things like RNG Fixer gigs, with lots of space for expansions, for example in Pacifica, as well as more accessible verticality. I would also love for there to be expansions that, well, expand on the ending choices, giving us a little context for what happens next, as well as expanding on some of the relationship choices and potentially giving us access to more big jobs to take part in.

If the rumours I have seen are true though, that doesn't look likely to happen with CDPR switching to Unreal Engine and a supposed recording confirming only one expansion, coming in 2023. I really hope this isn't the case as the game is definitely in a good place now, and could really thrive with some expansions and support over the next few years. If CDPR decide to abandon this game it would be a real shame, but I hope they pull a No Man's Sky and redeem the reputation of CP2077 and I'm hopeful for a sequel once production for The Witcher 4 is complete as there's massive potential for the world of Cyperpunk.

Long story short, if you've been on the fence about the game, like the genre and/or want a solid story in a visually stunning world, definitely give it a shot, I can't recommend the game enough, though you might want to wait for a sale. HOWEVER, if you are expecting a finished, polished experience at AAA price, and, understandably, can't appreciate what is there past the botched launch, still present bugs and general lack of finish beyond the main quests and bigger side quests, I'd give it a miss, unless it's on sale for a good price.

I really hope CDPR don't abandon the game and consider a sequel in the future. I love the setting, love the atmosphere, love the music, love the story, it's just 80% of the way to where it should have been. Stop the crunch, announce games when they're ready next time.

I only played this game after the major overhaul.  This game is a lot of fun, with many unforgettable characters.  I enjoyed the game more when V was female. The gameplay is fun, though lacking in variety & depth, No Flying vehicles, no Amphibious vehicles, no air combat, no amphibious combat, less depth blunt weapons combat, no Vehicle Customization, less gun customization, & little things to do other than combat & collectathon.  But for what it has it is fun nonetheless, how much more if added those missing or disregarded features & contents.

All in all, the game is atmospheric & immerses me as a player in an idea of Futuristic city from the 80's 90's perspective whilst providing a Wonderful Story & world to sniff through. 

I rate it an 7.8 out of 10. 9 or 10 if those missing or disregarded features & content are added in an upcoming update/expansion.

18 months after release, over 280 hours invested and.... I'm still unimpressed. The last patch was in March, and a recent leak from a financial call at CDPR revealed that we're getting effectively 1 DLC before they stop working on the game altogether. I'm still waiting for the vehicle AI that was shown off to us 4 years ago in the 2018 promotional material, the writing and choices that were promised pre-release, the features that were promised to us over and over for years and were never delivered. We certainly got *a* game in 2020, but it was not the 2077 we were promised, and now it appears CDPR has given themselves a pat on the back and are calling it 'good enough'. Hopefully they release a devkit for RED Engine so that modders can make this the game it was supposed to be.

I have to say, this is one of the best video games ever conceived by anyone. The gun play is as realistic as if you were really there. The feeling of the gun in your hands will give you the biggest dopamine rush of your life. The story and side quests will lead you into tearful and impactful moments. Now, there is one thing I have purposefully left out until this point. Johnny. Silverhand. Voiced by Keanu Reeve. His performance as a badass hero, trying to take over an evil corporation is as if you are playing an action movie (Which you are). 


All in all, Cyberpunk 2077 is the best experience you will have if you buy it.

Despite the nice update(s) the game received it's still buggy as can be. I did a new character cuz I wanted to refresh my basic game knowledge and get a new backstory going. Low and behold Character mouths don't move half the time, my F button randomly turns into an Equip Weapons hot key when talking to NPCs without going to the hot key menu, car/gun sounds are gone during scenes, AND on the intro to showing you Night City my character did not load in and NPCs were T-Posing/drifting their way down a sidewalk. 

I want this game to be good, the gameplay is fun, but the bugs are ruining it for me. If you're looking for just gameplay go for it it's not a bad FPS/Driving game. This game is absolutely incredible! although It was released in a rather poor state (even on PC), you can't take away the fact that this is the kind of game you will play once in a decade. Characters, Story, World detail, are all top notch. The fun factor of the gameplay-loop FAR exceeds anything found in The Witcher 3. After playing through the whole game I came out extremely satisfied with main story, but at the same time I just want Cyberpunk to continue! It's such an amazing world. I still hope we will see many DLCs that will fill this expansive universe with even more detail and content.

One thing I have noticed is that many players don't understand what kind of game Cyberpunk 2077 is. Many seem to play the game as a sandbox GTA game, however I found much more similarities with an immersive sims, where player expression is key to the whole experience, and Cyberpunk delivers in that regard. You can take on missions in many different ways/styles depending on the character build and how you approach missions, and you are rewarded handsomely if your talk to people in missions, read logs, messages as well as the lore about the different areas, gangs, characters etc. (which are displayed as "cards" in the journal menu for each mission). However, by doing so, I JUST WANT MORE! You might feel underwhelmed, like you haven't been able to explore the world completely after the end credits roll. But I really think that has to do with how big and detailed the world is. It took me ~90 hours to complete the game and you can't really squeeze more gameplay out of a AAA production than that. But the world is there to facilitate so much more content. So many more stories to tell

So please CDPR, don't abandon this game. It is a homerun, a 10/10 in my book. (which doesn't mean "perfect", but rather "as good as they come")

TLDR: Is great game, amazing characters, amazing story, fun play! Some bugs still be, has come a long way! 

Was there on the launch day, buggy gameplay, incredibly lacking features, immense disappointment. But after a year and a half (and a massive update), decided to give it a try. It's an incredible experience. 

The side quests all feel alive, it's not a nameless settlement/person needing your help. Each one typically begins with actual call from someone, giving backstory and motivation to help them, or the people involved. 

Each "gig" builds on the world, either through re-occuring characters that you'll meet throughout the game, or dropping a little bit of lore in dialogue or terminal readings. 

The story and characters are all fairly amazing, and, for the most part, are voiced fairly well. The gunplay is fun, though the game suffers from a classic leveling system of characters and weapons. You might come across a side-mission that is way above your level, and get one-shot immediately. So you'll have to be mindful of how you approach things, and watch your DPS. 

What we didn't enjoy, however, was the lack of dialogue that seemed to be missing. Like Grand Theft Auto V, you will get into vehicles and talk with people on the way to destinations. The difference being that Cyberpunk does not build on those moments like GTA V, which will sometimes have you parked outside of the objective so you can listen to the rest of the dialogue play out. 

Instead, Cyberpunk conversations last only for a few moments, very very rarely lasting the entire trip. The game will give you an option to skip the rest of the ride when the dialogue is over. This is unfortunate, as the game has hella lore about the world at every corner. But really hides the backstories of the characters you work with to key moments, rather than casual small-talk. 

Overall:

Cyberpunk is BIG fun, and you should definitely give it a try!

Cyberpunk has it's roots so far up so many nerds butt's (as does Witcher 3) it would be impossible to make such a massive game and not get over-hyped and have the product under perform. I was on the hype train. I couldn't get enough material to watch and read, and most of what I was seeing kept me excited. I had trust in CDPR, as well as the massive and talented team they built for this production.

When I booted the game up finally (after several delays), I knew the game, regardless of how polished it was, was a contender to become one of the best and most engaging RPGs to date. Right away you're put into an incredibly detailed and beautiful render of a cyberpunk metropolis. *High Tech, Low Life* They nailed the aesthetic of this game in every way. And they nailed the music and sound design as well. On a production level, I am truly blown away. Night City has to be one of the best looking open worlds ever created. 

I got the game at release, and played through a decent amount of side quests, but I really wanted to experience the main story line without too much distraction. I thought the main story line was solid, and it's clear there is a ton of side questing to get done if you want to stick around Night City. It did, however, feel strange to stop at the last quest before the end of the main line, just to keep playing that character longer. It's one of those 'no turning back' quests, and I wasn't sure about the new game + content, so I kept that last quest hanging for a bit as I did a bunch of other side questing. I had fun.

{EDIT as of patch at 6/7/22: The crowd system and traffic have been overhauled. It's not perfect, but it's better than the below statements} Now, unfortunately, I am a gamer that really pays attention to the matrix of a game let's say. I work in game development myself, and I really pay close attention to the finer details of what's under the hood. This is where the game let me down. For all the beauty, so many things are skin deep. When I play a game this immersive with such a high fidelity, there are things you expect. I expect a crowd system that works. I expect a crowd that is diverse, doesn't repeat noticeably, and stays it's course when I turn around. I mean, I won't even hold it against CDPR for not making each and every pedestrian 'have a life of their own', and tasks to carry out--which I believe was touted early in a development interview. But I do expect a solid system that doesn't cull the NPCs out willy nilly. You can catch it quite easily. I think they just gave up the crowd system and said screw it. As beautiful as it is skin deep, it is quite repetitive and broken. 

As is the police system--one of my most disliked features of this game. To me it feels absolutely necessary with the level of immersion and world-building this game boasts, to have a fleshed-out police system. Do something appropriately illegal in this game, and the cops will just spawn right behind you and start shouting and shooting. It's ludicrous this unfinished system was allowed in the gold version of the game. If I had my druthers I would have had an additional delay to simply input this system fully. GTA has been doing it pretty well for a very long time now. Why can't this game have it? Makes no sense, I'm vexed, and I want to forget about it. Also, while we are on the topic of systems in the game, the traffic system was shallow and broken as well. Another fault I didn't understand being allowed to sit at gold. At surface level it was fine, but pay attention, and the AI is oblivious.

Aside from those immersion breaking bugs, I still had a really sweet time cruising Night City. I'm running a system based around a 2070, and I was able to play it with DLSS on High raytrace, and get decent FPS. It was really quick to change from raytraced to not, so often when I was walking around just exploring, I'd set raytraced on and go. If there was a fight or a driving quest, I'd turn RT off. Pretty quick and easy, and I'd gain like 20fps. I'm sure systems running 3090's are going to be loving how well everything runs and looks.

If you are at all a fan of William Gibson, Phillip K Dick, Mike Pondsmith, Blade Runner, or any number of sci fi films through the 80s and 90s, you're going to enjoy this game.

After watching a fantastic Cyberpunk doc on YT, I'm back installing giving it another go. It's been a hot minute, so let's see what they have in store. 

Updated review as of 11/10/22

I think the new patches have been fantastic, and the game is looking, running, and playing much better than it's earlier stages. I still think it can grow and improve. I think Night City is an absolute must keep for future content. I want to see more doors open up and more quests. I want more more more. It's one of the most beautifully rendered CG environments ever created. I'm bumping up my score to 8 or 10 (used to be 7 of 10).

This is a really good game as of today. Did it live up to the hype? no. The story sequences, the characters, the combat, the gameplay, theyre all solid. I really enjoyed the main story line with Johnny(Keeanu), it almost feels like a block buster sci fi movie at times. 

Ironically, games like this always fall short on a few notes. Character customization visually is pretty limited. The cyberware upgrades are very lackluster. For reference, upgrading your "Augments" in Deus Ex was more fun, more interesting and more fundamental to the gameplay in that game. Cyberpunk seems to fall into the "all audiences" category at least when it comes to gameplay. Everything else is without a doubt, "Adult" LOL. 

This game is extremely fun to play, which made things a huge disapointment when I finished the main storyline, and side quests, which I was expecting to be more of in such a "huge" open world game. But when you get down to the brass taxes, the game is pretty shallow in comparison to how big it is. I maxed out my character in "Street Cred" and no longer receive missions like "gigs" and "jobs". Its so ironic, that game devs make a game so big, and so grand and bla bla bla, only to halt you as the player from continuing to enjoy the game they worked so hard to create. 

In summary, If you get this on a sale, and you know for a fact that your System can run it smoothly on at least medium settings it's definitely worth it. The Cyberpunk world is very well done, soundtrack is awesome, the story will draw you in and the gameplay will keep you coming back for more.

This is a good game, but nowhere near what they promised it'd be. Do your research and know what you're getting yourself into like I did, and you'll love it. It isn't exactly a AAA experience (more like A and a half), but it isn't horrible like many make it out to be; it's a good RPG set in a pretty fulfilling open world, with decent gameplay and good graphics. The story isn't half bad, although Johnny Silverhand's character is a bit.. lopsided? In one cutscene he'll like you, then in the next V will mention that he's kind of a dick. It's very inconsistent, and fairly messy. The open world is a lot like this, too - cars will spawn on top of you while driving down the highway, and you'll encounter the exact same NPC walking down the same road at least 5 times in one walk. All this being said, the gameplay itself is very fun and nicely rewarding, especially once you unlock the double jump. The team has also made many improvements and changes to how certain stats work, which has greatly improved the game. 
TL;DR: While the game is good, wait for a sale. Do your research and determine if you'll have fun with a buggy (yet fun!) mess of a game that is Cyberpunk 2077.

At first, I bought this game on a whim during a sale. I had no attachments to Keanu, have still never seen the Matrix, so the hype went right over my head as did the screwed up launch. I knew nothing about the game, okay? At first, buggy launches and not playing with my controller right irked me in all the wrong ways. Once I finally got it working, though...

I hated it.  The mechanics confused my slow lizard brain.  I flatlined more times than I have in real life. Then I figured out how things worked... and suddenly I'm obsessed with this well-crafted, albeit flawed game.  Suddenly, it's two am and I've been reading shards for the lore for the past hour, wiki up on my other monitor. I have 500 hours and counting, have done every gig, every NCPD side gig, and three different endings, one being the secret ending.  I'm excited to see what they'll do with story expansions given how varied the endings are. I loved the characters for the most part and was sad when I had exhausted things to do with them.  There's one particular set of missions I replayed a good dozen times trying to save a certain character from certain doom. I need a prequel of Johnny's life during the Mexican conflict, a spin off with Yorinobu, and another three story expansions all preferably before 2077. 

Tl;dr:
Johnny T-posed for dominance in Arasaka, 20/10
Buy this game or rogue AI will consume your soul.

Okay, first of all, let me point out: this game was released early due to player demand (including literal death threats). It was released with a lot of bugs... which they have devoted themselves to patching ever since. Cyberpunk 2077 is possibly one of the best games I have ever played. For those wanting a fair description, imagine a combination of Witcher 3, Grand Theft Auto, and Arkham Knight. The open world setting is massive, and disturbingly realistic. The characters are genuinely interesting and the voice acting is superb. The gameplay itself is fun and engaging (especially now that the bugs have been worked out). This game is VERY much worth getting, particularly on sale.

As a person who loves the concept of cyberpunk, from the atmosphere and world, the lives that we infer they may live, to the violence as money takes hold of more and more people, I think this game brings a lot of that together. During launch day it was definitely a flop. There were many bugs; game breaking, the graphics weren't optimized, and it was very obvious that, this game was released in pressure from the community. However, as the years have passed, there have been many changes. The bugs no longer interfere with the game as heavily as they did before, the graphics have been updated, guns and items polished up, vehicles mechanics, driving, npc behaviours, and much more that you can only really feel while playing this game. Now I won't sugar coat it, it's  not what it was intended to be pre-release, but its a game thats still worth playing. Now this may be a biased review, but I will put both the pros and cons I see from this game. 

Pros:
Atmosphere..
It's beautiful. You may be thinking to yourself, is it really beautiful from what many people have said where there are headless npcs. Yes, of course, that's the best part. Jokes aside it truly is. I've ran about 80 hours into the game, and I can tell you, I don't think I can bored of the city. If you wanted to play a game, which brought the future infront of you, and made it realisitc. This is definitely it. As you drive around the city going from gig to gig, you will feel it. You feel the changes in districts, you feel the changes in atmosphere, the lives of the npcs, the buildings that surround you, even the parts that lay inside the buildings. They way you hear the news buzzing around you, telling you about the corrupt world that refuses to change. The way the npcs talk about trying to get out of their rough lives, thinking that maybe they've finally found a way out. The quite empty roads, to the gunshots in the distance, to gangs picking on innocent people; as the neon lights truly fill the street. The immersion is one that's truly taken from granted, and as you finally leave the grasps of the city, you can feel the quite hmm of the badlands, still crawling with action, and a thirst to find a way out. 

Storyline.. 
Each character you can truly feel. This game has been awarded story-rich for a reason. That's what it was made for. For you to get the feel, as a person working in corporate. Or starting out from the dumps, as you progress the story you feel every bit of the city. From the people you interact with, and people you change paths with, you grow more and more attached, wanting to spend more time, learn more, as to how did they start off; how it's so different for every character you meet, and how they got to where they are now in this buzzing city. You yourself, as you travel, fight, discover, explore, you can feel your own character grow, and your own sense of self blends into the choices you make throughout the game, and maybe how you would be in this world if you lived here. It truly is beautiful, and only something you can grasp when playing this game.

Cons:
Now there are always pros, and there are always cons, some games have more than others. I think cyberpunk, has its cons, its not the worlds greatest game, but it's not something that doesn't make the game not worth it. 

BUGS... :_)
Yes yes, bugs are there, they have been there from the start. BUT NO, they aren't game breaking. CDPR has got, a lot, and I mean a lot of backlash for the buggy game they released back in 2020. However, I can say this much. Their game, is still, in my opinion, perhaps one of the greatest games ever made. They have spent, a lot, and I mean A LOT, of time fixing these bugs. From yes, the headless npcs, to you being chased by T-posing mobs, to even your car flying from a hit from, who knows what. It's been handled very well. You still encounter bugs, like for my case there have been times where the perspective was stuck in story mode while actually playing the game, which was fixed just by me going to main screen and coming back. As well as me driving really fast into yellow barricades, and them getting stuck in my car, which would send me for an inception time flying experience, which was actually a nice refresher seeing something so silly. It wouldn't stop me from playing the game, or have me miss out on something important. It still kept me going, and gave me a good laugh here and there. The bugs in this game are very subjective. If you are the type of person who's gonna bawl over a bug you found and never play the game again, thennnn... maybe you shouldn't get it, but if you aren't like that and don't mind your car flying every once in a while, and can even get a good laugh from it, this game will definitely give that you. The bugs are there, always have been, and always will be, but they don't outweigh the other aspects of the game, still making it worth your money.

Storyline..?? 
Yes, I talked a lot about how this story line was beautiful, and it is, my only problem with it, is that it's too short. There are plenty of side gigs and fun people to meet, explore, and things to do, but the main storyline is short, and that's one thing I definitely wished was longer. CDPR is adding expansions and it's been rumoured that we will be getting more things to do while we wait for the expansion, but it's still short. Side missions can last from 5 minutes to anywhere around 30. I'm still playing the game and have more stuff to do, but the more I play the more I enjoy how well this game as been made. As for CDPR, they've done great, not what was promised, but none the less respectable. 

Conclusion:
In my opinion, this game has improved a lot since it's release, and will continue to improve in small ways making the game more fun. As for expansion many players still wait to see what will happen with that, as well as future updates. But the current stage the game is in, it's beautiful, and worth trying. However, my only thing is that I would recommend getting it on sale. Is it worth the whole $80? Maybe not, is it worth 40 tho? 100%. And as long as you are enthusiastic about the world, the concept, of cyberpunk, you will come to love the game and what it has to offer. However, if you are playing for it to have the same level of depth as elden ring, choose elden ring. IT definitely is, something different, and something truly worth appreciating. 

If you decide to get this game, have fun playing. Chooms :D

Well built game, with a good main story and great visuals. The game mechanics feel plausible and sufficiently detailed without being difficult to enjoy. The game has a handful of bugs related to how things spawn, but it hasn't really affected my gameplay.

The voice acting is impeccable, and all the motion - from cars, to pedestrians, to facial expressions and gestures during conversation - is quite enjoyable, aside from occasional clipping. The world initially feels natural, rich and varied.

But after a time, the game feels fairly hollow. Nearly all secondary quests fall into 3 categories - sneaking past everyone, incapacitating everyone, or killing everyone, and they all begin to feel the same unless you are following the details conveyed in the written text of "shards" (CP2077's equivalent of books).

Tertiary situations and exploration are basically pointless grinds just to buff your character in preparation for your main questline. The rich appearance of the city fosters a curiosity to explore that is almost never satisfied, as quite literally 99% of the buildings have nothing to discover, and, save for a few main-quest buildings, the few entrances that can be found offer no uniqueness or reason to return to them.

This is genuinely great cyberpunk from a literary perspective, imho. Even if not every idea in it is the most incredibly original, it explores ideas hypercapitalist efforts to market and own the soul and gives you the chance to take a brick to the system, and I can't imagine anything more cyberpunk than that. Multiple endings based on your choices, including a pretty awesome secret ending. Some fave criticized the 80s cyberpunk aesthetic, but I pretty staunchly defend it. Not only is it cool, but I think it speaks to the zeitgeist of the 80s, this inflection point of decisions society made in that decade that sent us on our current trajectory toward an increasingly real cyberpunk reality.

Also the game is pretty darn fun, looks gorgeous, and the bugs of launch are more or less patched out by now. Soundtrack is superb, really great cinematic feel to the gameplay, awesome characters that stick with you. Still waiting on some promised features, but the modding community has added many of those back in to some degree or other (more challenging netrunner enemies, vehicle combat, improved vehicle handling, street vendors, the metro, etc.). One of my all-time favorites.

When playing games, I have 2 very strict criteria for judging it as a masterpiece.

1. Do I feel the need to play "The Touch" by Stan Bush during the final boss fight? Does it feel worth it? Does it feel like the game play leading up to that final moment was worthwhile? If yes, then move to the next criteria.
2. Do I feel the need to listen to the Star Wars Ending Theme during or after the credits? Was the game so moving that I can express no other joy as to having been through that experience than to play such an amazing track? If yes, the game has achieved masterpiece status.

I started playing this game during my exams and it was something to behold. It was still broken and glitchy as hell. There was not a single session that I didn't fall through the map while driving. But if you look past it's technical flaws, and think of them as part of it's charm, this game was an experience. During my first playthrough I was tempted to 100% it. And I came damn near close. The world was bright, big, and expansive. The story was spectacular, with deep and heartfelt characters. There was an amount of zany chaos, balanced out by tough decisions that actually mattered. There was not one area of this game that I thought was lacking. I am stunned at just how much I love this game. And my favourite aspect is that you aren't a God in this game. You're just some dude (or chick!) and life ain't bowing down to you. You ain't the chosen one, or some divine being. You are you, trying to get through life on the streets without dying. It felt oddly grounded for a game set in such a strange fantastical world. Though I need a break now, I look forward to replaying it in the future. THIS is my personal Best Game of 2022. My only question moving forwards is: When can I have more?

TL;DR: It's broken and glitchy. I love it. You might too. Easily my top game of 2022.

Edit: 

After about 45 hours, the buggy programming came back. This game is still fucked up with tons of immersion breaking bugs. Cars being stuck halfway in the ground, driving around. NPC's stuck in the ground, walking around and talking to you with only the top half of their body visible. NPC's walking in the middle of road, stuck in the air, holding up traffic. Interacting with objects on a table or box could send nearby stuff flying all over the place. The weird thing though is that it seems to be mission specific, and pertaining to the mid-late stages of the main story line in particular. 

The cyberpunk style is really cool. The armor/clothing bring a lot of sexy flair with the chrome, latex, leather outfits you can put together. The side-gigs are engaging with lots of story and cinematics and so is the combat. Infiltrating a compound and single handily clearing a place is fun with ninjitsu/hacking skills. Combat with cyberpsychos can be interesting and fun.

This game is a lot of fun now. After they've done a lot of fine-tuning and polishing, they've found a unique game play signature that's can be defined as a simplified & stream-lined Fallout/Skyrim in terms of crafting, combat and story-telling + GTA-styled driving around. A lot of cars have been added to the game world. Weapon mods have been slightly improved, which makes fighting with them cooler. Hacking has been improved and there's a lot of places where you can use hacking at now. The different class perks really come together now too; such as body for health regen, cool for stealthing, technical for hacking, reflexes for weapons. Previously I said it was boring but this game is a lot of fun now. Only after playing for about 35 hours did I find one of those immersion breaking bugs that are so annoying that it takes your mind out of the story and becomes the only thing you can focus on. I haven't encountered any CTD's except for when I was rewinding a BD with my FPS set to 120 but maybe it's just because my computer isn't that great but I do play on Ultra with everything set to max. 

I'd rate it in the high 90% range.


*PREVIOUS REVIEW *

I *barely* recommend it because the real-time combat and story sequences are fun and engaging. 

They put too much effort into things they shouldn't have and not enough effort into things they should have. 

They should've kept it simple and just focused on giving a solid, fun game play and cinematic story. 

BD's (brain dances) are lame story sequences where you have to find clues so the story can be revealed. It's kind of like trying to find your socks before you can go out and play. A lot of boring hunting and searching but you wish you could hurry it up so you can get back to the good part.

Hacking reminds me of Watch Dogs, but lamer, and they aren't all that fun or all that useful, which allows you to sneak up on enemies who are caught unaware or temporarily disable cameras. Sneaking up behind people to kill or knock them out is simplistic because enemy AI is about as aware as sloths. NPC's you're travelling with always alert you when they're near, which is like every room you enter, which is annoying. It's not integrated very well and you can sidestep the whole hacking/sneaking portion of game play if you wish and just go into a mission by throwing grenades, with guns-a-blazin'. 

It's a giant sandbox where you can go anywhere and do what you want. You can own cars and drive them yourself. Driving feels like Grand Theft Auto and is mostly lame. it's not a very interesting element of the game that costs you money if you drive poorly. I'd just turn auto-drive on and forget about it. There should be more fast travel points. 

Character creation is a nice feature and nicely done in this game but why did they even put it in if you can't see your character during the important story points? Only their hands are visible. Only time you can see your character is when they're looking in the mirror so 95% of the time, the character creation is pointless.

There's no auto loot and a ton of pointless minutiae to pick up in every room. It ruins the overall experience having to worry about pointless junk you need to pick up so you can disassemble or sell them later. 

I heard there's addons you can get for this game to change some features but I don't like messing around with addons. For one, you can't really trust them. For another, I think a developer that relies on 3rd-party developers to create creature comfort features are counting on the (free) community's hard work to help polish their game. It isn't right. 

The core product should be polished and in the best, most immersive, most balanced experience when it's put up for sale. It's a personal preference but there's a ton of great games out there that don't use 3rd-party addons *at all*.

Wow... best game I've played in years, by FAR.

I got Cyberpunk 2077 on sale after reading a few reviews of how much it has improved since launch, here's my take;

Graphics- Beautiful, seriously amazing. I still look in awe at how beautiful the graphics are in this game. The expressions on characters faces, to the amazing lighting. 

Story- I could not stop playing this game, I will likely go through it a few more times just because its so damn good. 

Combat- Play this game on hard at least! The combat is great, enemies are tough and you can die easily. It makes for a great challenge, and a fun one!

Sound- Also amazing. 

This is a game I felt the excitement with that I have not found in many games to date. 

Fingers crossed they bring it further along with some DLC.

I would 100% pay full price for this game, its that damn good. Enjoy!

I have 30 hours into the game so far, so this is an initial review...

   Do I recommend the game...Yes! I paid half price when it was on sale, so I am not sorry I purchased it. I'm playing on the PC with patch 1.52.
    For the first couple of hours, my initial reaction was "what the f**k is going on here?". The graphics are good, but so far I'm not real impressed by the music score. Maybe that will change as I get farther into the game. I do like the interactions which go on between your character and other characters, like when I sat down beside Misty and was talking to her, or laying with Skype in "automatic love". It makes the game seem more real. I also like how some of the dialog choices you make have real consequences. I'm used to playing MMOs where most times the choices you make are irrelevant. 
   Now some quirks I've noticed: The first street thug I attacked 'bounced back' several feet after I made a few shots. I've seen people walk through crates. So far only seen one person do a T pose on me :-). I think it is funny when I call my motorcycle and it pulls up and stops right in the middle of the road! You would think they would have it pull to the side of the road. Had to laugh one time my bike pulled up and mowed over someone crossing the street! I've read many people don't like the driving, but I have fun driving down the road, and try to act as if I was driving in real traffic. I haven't tried this yet, but I'm guessing driving would be easier to control using a gamepad and not the keyboard.
   So to wrap up for now, this is an interesting game to play and do look forward to getting back into it each day.

To mis-quote Doctor Paradox: [i]"From their quaint Wroclaw village office, everything must look all nice and pretty in 2022... but they're wrong. Cyberpunk 2077 is still just a rusty car with a fresh coat of paint, a heap of dog s**t spritzed with perfume."[/i]

Yeah? Well not anymore! [b]I have had just one single crash and very few glitches, since v1.5, leaving it running 24/7 some days![/b] [i](if you were wondering how 250-ish hours but only 100-ish playing, that's how.)[/i] If this v1.52 was the game that was released, without the refunds and apologies? The world would look a whole lot differently for the future of CD Projekt.

Sadly it feels a bit empty after a little while, so many interiors you can't enter, so many areas just greebled and not a lot of development or content creation. *If* what they sold us on, they ever actually deliver, why, this [i]could be[/i] one of the best games in the history of computer gaming, even though it's not original - not at all, and it's not a very good representation of the Cyberpunk universe either. And then they stuck a lame driving sim on top of an adventure/shooter RPG. Just --- [i]whaaaat?[/i]

I know they've committed to "fixing" it, and we do expect some of it, but it's over a year on and the damage is done. And we know we're not getting what we expected, we just won't at this point, the odds it'll get even more side gigs is iffy to me, content creation costs money, and we know they lost a lot of it! I expect we'll have some paid expansions soon enough.

([i]another game we were promised a huge expanse of nested multi-choice / shades-of-gray and the whole game comes down to just a couple yes-or-no choices, very similar to what Obsidian and "The Outer Worlds" did to us. - I trust no one anymore, you eff'ing corporat liars in marketing can all get flatlined by faulty Mr Stud penetration for all we care. 

PS: That's sarcasm, I don't wish harm on anyone. I know you guys get actual threats, and I am sorry about that and hope they're just threats of frustrated people who lost money investing in you. Maybe don't lie so much to falsely inflate your sales and customer/investor expectations?[/i])

Am I bitter? Yes I am. But still, for what's here, [i]it's a hell of a lot of fun[/i].

I'll leave you with the contents of one of the shards in the game (there are dozens of "life is short, get on with it" references from beginning to end, it's a theme on life and software development moreso than anything to do with V's experiences):

[b][i]The Consciousness Curse[/i]

Man dies the way he was born; soft, weak and helpless. Death, the one
certainty in this universe of chaos, can be both a tragic end and a release from
suffering. It can come as an unexpected twist, or as a beautiful, crowning
counterpart to a life well-lived.

The curse we have as humanity, the only living beings in constant awareness of
death, is out inordinate focus on the fact. How much happier is the life of the
gazelle that escapes the cheetah's clutches, thinking that it evaded death once
and for all, than the poor soul living out his days knowing each step inches him
closer to the void![/i]
Playable and enjoyable.

I have played this game for a little bit since its release. I think it's been great since the beginning but obviously needed some work. The update really made a big difference in the game for me, especially since it let me sort out the interesting questlines from the ubisoft style quests. The story really is phenomenal and is what makes the game. However, this is its greatest weakness. Replaying the game is stunted by having to go through the story every time, which sounds like it should be a good thing but after a while, it's not a significant enough change for more than three or four playthroughs. Overall, I would recommend this game to people who want to sink everything into one playthrough and really commit to a certain build (as I have found all are viable). My only gripe is the boxing missions are near impossible unless you go for a strength build.

I'ma be honest, at launch the game was shit. It was laggy as hell and felt like I was playing half a game. But after a couple months they fixed most of the shit, most of the lags were patched and the story felt fully fleshed out. Sure, there are still a few lags here and there, but they're generally fixed by reloading the game and rare enough it's not an issue. Aside from that, this is possibly the best game I've ever played, I'm on my third playthrough, 10/10,

Has its fair share of bugs, but the game world is so fleshed out with mythos and backstory and interesting characters and quests, that it really doesn't bother me that much. The most annoying part is the hacking minigame, because no matter what, there are times when you just can't hack the highest tier due to the randomness, and so you have to exit out, then try again, then exit out, then try again, etc. until you can find the right path to hacking it. It's not skill-based, it's purely based on what random number generators put on the screen for you.

Other than that, love the game.
great story line glad most bugs are fixed now can truly enjoy!!!!! too bad cdpr wont resume multiplayer project

Extremely conflicted on this one. I love the story to bits. I love the general feel of the game. I love so many things about it that it feels unfair to give it anything but a positive rating. But still, there are so many things that bug me (no pun intended).

Preordered it, played it on day 1 on a mid-range laptop, luckily did not have many issues except for a few people T-posing here and there. Back then I was extremely optimistic about its future, I kept telling myself that they will turn it around.

And there comes the part that bugs me. The post launch support has been weird. Now I must admit I did not follow it very closely, but shouldn't we already have gotten our DLC? At least one of them? With so much content cut out of the game, I expected them to patch stuff back in with DLC's, but the content has been oddly absent (again, if I am mistaken, please correct me). Instead of going full Hello Games on this one, CDPR feels absent and half-hearted about it. 

And if this game remains the most story-rich and immersive what-if of the gaming history, I will be so pissed...

Yes its first release was very rocky  and no game should ever be released like that but now with the recent updates and care from CD Project Red it shows that this game is making a comeback. The story and world are incredible alone with combat not being game changing but certainly provides players with a few new takes in the world of Cyberpunk. its an 8 or arguably 9 out of 10

This game offers satisfying combat mechanics for a variety of different combat styles, an interesting/compelling main storyline and a wealth of side quests to keep even the most hardcore completionist occupied for hours. It falls into some of the traps you'd like to see RPGs with voiced protagonists avoid (such as railroady dialog options, overly angsty delivery and the occasional "I would never say that" moments), but there is still plenty of heart in the story and choices in your path to the ending to make up for those shortcomings.  This is a solid AAA title with an unfortunate, but well earned, stigma that is well worth the price of admission. Give this one a try, Choom, and welcome to the major leagues.

I will not for a moment defend the disastrous launch of Cyberpunk 2077. It simply should not have happened. However, I will say writing this game off completely because of the launch undermines what is, at times, a very enjoyable experience.

Do I believe this is the best game ever? Absolutely not. Even without the bugs, I think it falls short in a number of areas. For example, in my pursuit of attaining all achievements for this game, my final hours involved repetitive grinding for XP and cash through shooting the same enemy spawns and looting their knives to sell at vending machines.... which was annoying because I had spent the prior 120 or so hours doing fun quests and side quests. To have my final moments of the game reduced to a grind fest was disappointing to say the least. What I'm trying to say is, the world becomes completely baron after you complete everything.... sounds somewhat obvious I know, but I would have at least hoped the game still felt alive with repeatable open world activities, rather than one-offs as part of a quest.

Take street racing for instance. It's reserved only for a handful of quests, so once you complete them, they never appear again. It would be way better if street races could be accessed any time if you need a quick buck. Increasing the variety of activities to do in the open world is something this game needs more than anything else in my opinion. My only option for grinding XP and cash shouldn't be attacking the same enemy spawns and looting their knives over and over....

That's only if you're going for 100% completion however. I imagine most people won't get to a stage where you have to do repetitive grinding, as most of your cash and XP are earned during quests (and there are A LOT of quests). Whilst I don't think freedom of choice is as strong as it should be (the game does at least give you the illusion of choice) most of the quests in the game are compelling enough, with plenty of variety. Characters are distinct and well written, even if one character in particular has their story cut way too short.

Combat is strong, with plenty of customisation options to tailor your play style, whether it be run and gun or stealth. Driving could be better, as cars become very unstable at high speeds. They need to feel more planted to the road so you feel more confident throwing them into corners. Some vehicle customisation for a future update wouldn't hurt either.

The major selling point of Cyberpunk is the story. Even if you don't bother too much with side quests, the main story provides a lengthy and memorable science fiction extravaganza. There are multiple endings too. It probably helps to know a bit about the Cyberpunk lore from the tabletop games, though I wouldn't know myself. Finishing this game, at the very least, has compelled to look into the lore.

In summary, Cyberpunk 2077 is a good game. I'm reluctant to call it great, because I do feel that the open world needs more attention to truly immerse you in Night City. How much you factor in the woeful launch when playing is entirely up to you, but if you can for a moment discard the immense negativity that this game initially received, you might just find an immersive role-playing adventure in here somewhere.

7/10 - Buy it, but only when it's on sale :)

Cyberpunk 2077, where do I even begin?

Before I go further in depth about Cyberpunk and it's 'rich' history, I'd like to begin by saying that after patch 1.52, the game is great! I have over 200+ hours on it at the time of writing this review, alongside playthrough's of each life-path and gained several of the endings. Despite it's rough and rocky launch, Cyberpunk has proved itself to be a good game. It's narrative and story are great, followed by amazing voice-acting by Gavin Drea, Cherami Leigh and Keanu Reeves. Their voices and the charisma of each character really helps you enjoy this game's narrative that bit more. Each character has a great piece of character development, providing that you've played their side missions. The characters, and hell, even side-characters in this game are amazing. Not to mention, Night City, being the immersive, buggy mess it is. If you're willing to look past the bugs, this world has amazing and expansive lore that goes outside the game itself. It's so expansive and immersive, I could be stuck in it for hours. It's fully fleshed out, and feels like something that would be real, instead of being a flat boring 2D world. For example, some of the advertisements within the city promote a band whom you can actually see, visit and complete a mission for. Each big location has its own lore too, which is very interesting if you care to read the data shards found within the game. If you're willing to look past the multitude of bugs, Cyberpunk is an amazing game, and I'd highly reccommend that you give it a shot.

There were launch issues, we all know that. Don't let it discolor your perception of the game now that it's been over a year and things have been ironed out. Initially I tried playing Cyberpunk 2077 on a Windows 7 machine, and crashed at least once an hour, and it ran like absolute horror. Upgraded to Windows 10 and it worked perfectly, and once it did, it was a dream. I've put 700 hours into it at this point, working on my seventh playthrough, different styles each time. They've released content patches addressing balance issues and crashes consistently, invalidating my previous 100% crit build, but have clearly strived to keep the game enjoyable and versatile. Each build feels different, and you're given enough points to spread out a bit. The updates to the map system have been amazing, with each new patch specifically addressing areas that might have been weak in the game. Backstory dialog options are always great, and really let you grasp the difference between. They refined the gig system, which are essentially side-side quests, and made it much easier to differentiate quest types in the Journal as well as on the Map. I've always loved the cyberpunk -genre,- but Cyberpunk 2077 embodies it in a way that none else have, and that's speaking as a Shadowrun fan. Cyberpunk 2077 is easily one of my favorite games of all time, and that's placing it ahead of the Elder Scrolls and Fallout franchises. The writing is amazing, even small conversations between random NPCs that make you laugh or listen in out of curiosity, as well as piecing together plot from picked up shards.

4) Accept that this is kind of like Metal Gear Solid: V Phantom Pain (huh, funny coincidence, that) in that the game isn't necessarily representative of what it should have been. Even in the early days of Cyberpunk 2077 I thoroughly enjoyed the game.  There were bugs of course but I did not experience anything game breaking. I don't feel like I ran in to many situations where my characters were incapable because they weren't built a certain way.  There was always a way through it.

There are some downsides of course.  I don't think this game nailed a cyberpunk environment.  For some reason the developer thinks cyberpunk means the trash collectors went on strike because there are trash bags piling up everywhere.   There was lip service to the corporations being in control of everything, but that didn't translate meaningfully to the feel of the game.  Half the encounters in the game are to help the cops so not very "punk".  The endings are just disappointing.  

All that said I have played through the game with 4 different character builds and enjoyed it thoroughly.

Forgiving buggy beginning (PC) it has been over a year, and I love this game. I have played through many times, different paths with all of the endings - great sound track, amazing story, gorgeous graphics, and mods galore (great for spicing up replays). Nine thumbs up!

The deck was stacked against this game, right from the start. Pushed out earlier than it needed to be, dev team crunching hard, marketed as the next best thing since sliced bread. And in the end what did we get? A cyberpunk narrative filled with a lot of heart, a lot of humanity; a humanity hard to see, beneath all the grime and chaos, but it's there. An apt metaphor if I've ever seen one. 

The 1.5 update in particular really assisted in helping sculpt the game into a better, more structurally sound, and gameplay-balanced place. But even before that, so much of the story, the characters, the atmosphere, and music were already so expertly crafted, that these elements now get to shine even more than they already did. Initially a 7 out of 10 game with several 10 out of 10 moments. To reconcile all this now, it finds some center around an enthusiastic 8.5 out of 10, maybe, even though arbitrary review scores don't matter. What does matter is how you feel, and I love this game. In spite of its flaws. That's how I feel.

When faced with death, with surviving it, being born anew, what do you decide is most important to you? Love, togetherness, the chance at a hopeful horizon? Glory, spite, and the desire to leave the biggest mark you can? Or is it persistence, survival, the need to remain - no matter what it costs? It's a decision we all must make, and it is in how we save ourselves, that we define who we are in the world around us. 

Be who you are, freely, authentically, without recourse. Live. Live while you can. And remember: Never stop fighting. 

p.s. yorinobu did nothing wrong

I have been here since Day 1 and there is so much to tell about this game…

I experienced the disastrous launch this game had and saw the tremendous backlash CDPR faced, but it was well deserved: they have become the very thing they swore to destroy.
The marketing team in charge of Cyberpunk was given free-reign to promise everything and nothing to the players. Thanks to that, they were able to build an incredible hype around this game, but completely failed to deliver on so many promises…
I think players should have seen it coming. The hype was so high, that even if CDPR delivered a game that was mostly bug-free and worked perfectly from day 1, it still would have received a negative press from the players.
I can’t help feel sorry for the artists and the developers who worked on Cyberpunk. 
CDPR, in its rush to get this game out, lost a golden opportunity to deliver one of the best game in history.

Now about the game itself, we can all agree that this game is no GTA. The gameplay and the open world might feel somehow lacking compared to what was promised or compared to other games.
I can understand people arguing if Cyberpunk 2077 was good or bad, or saying that this game was wasted potential, etc. 
But what nobody can't deny is that Cyberpunk is an absolute masterpiece in terms of story writing, world building, music, voice acting, art, ambience and experience.
You will feel drawn by this dystopic world (that is not far for ours on some points) and by the characters you will meet during your journey. This game is going to touch your deepest emotions and some of the scenes will hit you hard by making you think about life, death, suicide, friendship, love, etc…

The players who loved this game are still waiting for CDPR to redeem itself just like Hello Games did with No Man’s Sky. More than 1 year has passed and the recent patch 1.5 fixed a lot of thing, but I think it is not enough.

There are still bugs, part of the gameplay feels clunky and the weird game pacing still bothers me: you are slowly dying during Act 2 but still find time to do side gigs? 
Also, I can’t help but think that there is definitively some content missing in Act 1. Come on CPDR, we want a whole arc/act with Jackie and not just a quick cutscene with him: the game flow would have been much better if the entire main story was put at the end of the game. The game starts out as normal, but you don't get the montage and the time skip. Instead, you are allowed to explore Night City with Jackie. You can buy your first car, move out to your own apartment, and do jobs for the various fixers in town.
And once you get enough street cred, you get a call from Jackie letting you know that he has a sweet gig lined up that would take you to the big leagues. When you talk to Jack, you can choose to start the job, but Jack will tell you that there is no turning back after this, and the game will let you know that it is the (first) point of no return. The game then plays out normally, starting with meeting Dex.

Overall Cyberpunk 2077 is a good game. Now that it had some real bug fixes and that its price went down I would highly recommend you to give it a try. However, I still feel like this game should only be played on PC or on the new gen consoles.

There was always massive hype about this game leading up to launch, and there have been disappointments in the game off and on since. If you are like me and love the Cyberpunk genre, however, then this game does at least deliver on the world, and is being updated and improved along the way. The story is very rich and engrossing, and the game-play (especially since the 1.5+ update) is very good. This game may never equal the hype that was heaped on it for years, but it is fun, engaging, and can be modded to get it closer to that ideal.

Despite the chaotic launch, this game re-ignited my passion for gaming. The city aesthetic, the dark and twisted underlying horrors that await you juxtaposed to the bright neon lights in the city put into perspective just how it feels to be in the future where corporations rule over all. Gameplay-wise the gunplay is smooth, and the transitions between quests, missions, and side affairs are well defined. This game is just pure awesome. Can't wait for it's future content!

It's been over a year and even after 1.5 patch the game has tons of bugs. Some can even soft lock the game were you need to reload your previous save or use cheats to fix it without losing your progress. When bugs happen so often that you don't know if its a bug or that's by design. It's just sad. I wanted to like this game, i really did, but this is just bad.

Simple things like for example mouse cursor on in game PC's disappear and you have to navigate it blindly.
After reloading a gun it starts shooting automatically for no reason.
Audio problems, one person talks loud as hell, the other is silent, or there is no voice audio at all.
Simple stuff like reflections, police cars rear lights sometimes become brighter than the sun to the point where you have to turn on first person camera while driving cause you can't see anything.
Radio in cars doesn't change or start playing properly, there were times where i have to stop the car, get out, get back in, then the radio station changes.
When you need to use a MOD to fix multi-core performance issues so it uses all the cores and actually boosts your FPS you know the game has serious issues.
The fact that the bug that was on launch in 2020 still exist in 1.5 where when you're driving normally you suddenly get yeeted in to space for no reason is mind boggling.

I can go on and on about bugs in this game, there are plenty, in the end, is the game worth it?
Not really, don't waste your money unless you really, really want it and its on a sale 50+% off.
Is it playable? Yes, but its not acceptable giving its been over a year and the game feels like its in Early Access. It's just sad.

I played it when it originally launched and passed it in 2 sittings i was so exited(haven't touched it sense), now bought it on steam(to keep my games on one platform) after 1.5 was released hoping its better, but it kinda was a waste of money.
Gonna finish my second playthrough and most likely never touch this game again, maybe in 2077.

Highly highly recommended. The game main story is good, but I think some of the side missions and Gigs are a lot more fun and interesting. The characters story and development is excellent. There aren't too many games out there with great storyline for the NPCs, and Cyberpunk does. After logging over 70hours into this game I have genuine appreciation for the depth of the character development. I hope the next installment of GTA takes notes and do a better job with the main characters and NPC's. It truly is a game changer. WELL that was the good... The bad for me that stood out was the vehicle driving mechanics. The cars are terrible to drive, and the motorcycles are best way to get around town quickly, but they have some serious impossible physics when interacting with other vehicles and objects. Second issue with this game is the the road network. I seem like the city and play area was laid out then some intern at RED was given the job of creating the road network. The layout is terrible and follows no logic or pattern at all. Also, while the cars handling are terrible, it would be nice to have upgrade options for the cars and apartments... That gripe aside, it is an awesome game, and if they make a part two, of take it online like GTA, I will be among the first customers.

Night City is glorious to behold and there's so much to do it's crazy. The main story is superb, as are many of the side stories. The missions with Panam in particular. But if you just wanna have an eve fuckin up some punks and blowing off steam, you can, and it's fun as heck. Combat is awesome and only gets better as you get your stats up. You can be quite creative! The game is complex, but not off-puttingly so. There is a pretty steep learning curve initially and it's not always clear what it's trying to teach you, but you get there soon enough. You'll spend a fair amount of time in the menus crafting, upgrading, swapping and changing.

Yes it's not without it's issues, but nothing major for me. The odd graphical glitch here and there but nothing like on other platforms. And yes if you wanna crank the graphics you'll need a beast of a gfx card and even then 4k is a pipe-dream. 1440p is the best my 3080TI can do getting ~65-75fps with RT/DLSS-Q on.

Something that very few people mention... the sound in this game is badass and adds so much to the immersion. Plus some of the weapon sounds give me goosebumps. That feel-it-in-the-chest duuf duuf duuf duuf, mwahahaha.

This is one of the few games i completly fell in love with. Nightcity is simply breathless, in my opinion no other games surroundings are this complex and detailed. The characters make you wish you had the chance to know more about them, the weapons, cybermods, clothing, vehicles all so vast and detailed. Theres times i felt myself just driving the highways to the wastelands changing the radio with no where to go. When a game can take you somewhere like that its an amazing thing.

Before anything, got the game at 50%. Obviously my perception might be affected by it, so make of that detail whatever you want.

If you are considering buying this one, I know what you are thinking. Yeah yeah, the game that promissed everything and fell short. I know, the whole internet knows. But you know what? The game is fun alright, bunch of stuff to do, and the approach you choose can be very different.

You can build yourself to be a master of melee weapons, katanas, an invisible cheeky breeky mofo that deals everything with knifes to the skull or silenced guns, a gunslinger, rifleman, a Neo style slow-mo bastard, a hackerman that doesn't even need guns, whatever. It all feels different, gives a lot of replayability options.

The game looks beastly. Seriously, creating a city with a setting as particular as a dystopian future, that feels massive and believable as the one here, is not something you see everyday. Sometimes I just walk or drive around only to sightsee because it truly looks amazing.

The story, the side missions, all of that is very immersive. I can get if you prefer this type of games in 3rd person, but quite frankly, it wouldn't feel the same if it wasn't in 1st person. Plus, depending on how you build your character, you may have different choices on certain missions, making each re-play slightly different.

In terms of bugs, well I got the game after patch 1.5 and I've only experienced 3, nothing game breaking. Fairly standard amount for any game and two of them were quite hilarious. Picture the first cutscene but everyone is on T-pose for the first seconds, then you call your motorcycle just for it to fly by the Corpo Plaza overpass and crash land on a car. Third one I fell off the map, but it just re-spawned me a few meters away. Nothing game breaking.

Don't even get me started about the music, I'm already trying to learn these badass Samurai songs.

I could keep going on and on about the things that I like, because once more, this game is damn fun. Clearly it was the foundation for a masterpiece that couldn't be everything that was invisioned, with lots of promises that couldn't be delivered because of corpo bs, but thats a whole different story.

And for the record, I'm that type of person that doesn't care about games with story, or open world, or single player in general because they somehow bore me within the first few hours of play. But this one, this one's got that special touch to it.

Seriously hoping they keep adding stuff to the point that it gets closer and closer to what was promised, not only because I'd like to see this game be everything that we expected, but also because I'd love to see a continuation to it.

Not to dunk on console players in any way, but I never had major issues with the game even upon launch - well, after the second QoL update anyway. The lingering bugs were more of the endearing, comical, Bethesda variety (IYKYK), and the general experience was pretty solid. Fast forward to the 1.5 update, and I start to see what the devs meant by "this is closer to the game we wanted to release to begin with." MASSIVE quality of life improvements, tighter gameplay with almost no gameplay-affecting glitches in sight (I almost miss random NPCs T-posing atop moving cars they're supposedly driving), some actual ludonarrative consistency in the secondary attributes of loot drops (how were combat boots supposed to help you quickhack faster?), and many other welcome improvements. It was a good game before - aforementioned comedic glitches notwithstanding - but I would say this is finally a game that justifies nearly a decade of development hell (oh hey, didn't see you there, DNF). If you haven't scored this title yet, buy it, and encourage any console bros you know to give it a shot. It's safe for them now. But still give them crap on general principle, because PCMR. Also, Judy is love, Judy is life, Judy is best girl. Play as Fem!V and romance her, you will not regret it.

I recommend to anyone that has been on the fence about trying the game to try it, and enjoy the good aspects it has to offer presently. I think its worth it.

[h1]Not quite breathtaking, but in it's own way, still a most excellent journey.[/h1]

Dismayed by the original release, and the multitude of bugs that were revealed in its wake, I actually waited a year to purchase the game [spoiler]on sale[/spoiler]. By then, some of the bugs had been cleaned up, but not all. The ones I found were more laughable than annoying, though I saw the frustration of early purchasers and pre-orders. 

Once I started playing the game, though, I really found myself hooked on it. The world is beautiful and immersive, and the characters well-written and acted. [spoiler]As a dude who grew up near East LA, the Valentinos actually reminded me of some folks i knew.[/spoiler] 

The cars are all unique and varied, except that they all handled like ass. I love that the new update gave V more options for apartments. Having hubs in the different districts is super convenient. 

The story was wonderfully compelling. Coming to terms with death is no easy thing to write about, and the team at CDPR did a great job of it. The NCPD gigs do get a bit redundant, though. If you've seen one pack of gangoons, you've seen 'em all. 

The music is pretty good, and 'Never Fade Away' and 'A Like Supreme' is are two of my new favorite songs. There's a vast selection of weapons for every taste, and with the cyber-arm mods available in-game, there's a variety of options for melee fighters as well. 

All in all, I'll probably end up re-playing the game multiple times because I enjoyed it so much. Yes, the criticism is well-deserved in parts, and overall my biggest gripe was the lack of options after [spoiler]you meet Hanako at Embers. Once you decide on a path, you're stuck.[/spoiler] There are multiple endings, with only one of them feeling anything close to hopeful. That aside, to me Night City is worth visiting time and time again because out of all the neon dystopias, only this one and the Los Angeles seen in Blade Runner feel real to me.

While still a little rough around the edges patch 1.5 finally shows what I believe CD Project Red's intentions for this game were. Having played prior to 1.5 the most recent update made me feel like I was playing a completely different game.  If you're looking for a story deep shooter you cannot go wrong with the future of 2077
CDPR, why bring politics into games? This is the place where we gamers runaway from rl struggles and now you've ruined it.
