Just buy it. Keep in mind though, this review is something I have been working on since before the big patch recently. 
I bought this game back in the beginning of February-ish, and I immediately fell in love with it. I have played about 50 hours into each of the three versions of the story, meaning I played through pretty much everything at least twice. I have seen inside and outside of Night City. All the gonks and chooms alike. 

The music is what I have to talk about first. I am a big music lover. My favourite headphones at the moment are my ATH-M50x's, with my laptops built in dtsX sound. With or without those, the music and the sound are top-notch. But with them, I was LIVING in NIght City..sure, there were some spots where audio was off, or missing or something, but overall it was 99% perfect. People walking, talking...hearing people in other languages talking about everything from itchy dongs, to financial portfolios on the news. Hell, even the advertisements are kinda spot on lol! If you don't love the music, then you are not even a person. Seriously, it is one of the biggest things for me. So many games have trash music, or just basic standard....meh music. just meh... But this game, you can tell some people were working really hard to set the mood...and baby MY EARS ARE MOIST AND READY TO BE PENETRATED BY THOSE GOOD VIBRATIONS!!!

Weird visuals aside, the game is magnificient. Yes there are bugs, but in my personal experience, most of the bugs are either really common, and you learn how to avoid them...For instance, stairs on the various water-towers around the city would let me fall through the stairs RIGHT at the very top, so i just learned that if I was sprinting or if I jumped, it was no longer a problem. But aside from that, the only issues I seemed to have happen a lot involved items being visible, having the "pick up" option show up but the item can't be picked up. Seemed to only happen to a handfull of food items, never weapons/ammo/armor or key/quest items either. Honestly, there are not so many game-breaking bugs that everybody kept talking about. 

_______________________________________

After big patch:

Kind of just the same as above, but now the police are far more obnoxious....The one thing I loved, that being the police being easy to evade, was changed. I know it is a weird thing to complain about, all things considered, but I was having fun mercing some gangsters...police officer showed up, I was about to leap with my Mantis Blades...and well, certain animations may or may not have played out with the officer being the star of the show....allegedly! next thing you know, guns are sprouting from the walls and there were so many officer-shaped objects on the ground for about three city blocks...then I just exploded. Don't mess with the police in this game, they will explode you.

Buy it, play it, fall in love with it...
Visuals: 9/10. There were quite a few visual issues.
Music: 69/10. Best music, best audio. 
Gameplay: 8/10. Highest I have ever given a game like this.
Character Creation: 6/10. 7/10 for adding dicks and tits without shame. But let me look at myself while I shower. Genuinely not for perverted reasons, literally just to say you guys are the only game that does it.
Driving: 6/10. I have played a lot of NFS and a bit of Forza...gotta say, only a couple of vehicles in this game feel like they drive, and trust me on this...I DROVE EVERYWHERE, or ran. I barely used quick travel at all. The car I felt like drove the best was the "Javellina" or the all-white version of Caliburn in town. Oh, and the Shion Coyote drove like a miracle with mouse/keyboard and controller. I liked a motorcycle, but I can't remember the name. Its the only purple one with a back-support seat as well.

Waited for a while before I jumped in the pool and got this game. I knew my rig could handle it, but wanted a few patches in before I started. That being said, not a fan of the FP perspective to be honest, but, its more than acceptable. Still a few graphical glitches here and there that pop up on rare occasions, even on an RX 5700 card but smooth for the most part. So much like Crysis back in the day (the original one not the remastered). If you're rig can run it, you're in for a treat. How does it compare to Witcher 3? It doesn't. The FPS makes game play quite different. The attributes, there's almost too many, like the designers had too much coffee and couldn't decide what to cut. Story and characters, so far not too bad. They are interesting, unlike the cut and paste (aka boring) ones in The Outer Worlds. So if you thought W3 was a 9 or 10. This, might be a 7 or 8. Still not bad for a first dive into the whole cyberpunk world. Remember Witcher 1 wasn't exactly stellar, story was good, game play was so so. Hoping CDPR can keep it together and learn from this to keep improving on it and create a sequel. Be a shame for them to fold from one game because they felt forced to rush by the industry and especially greedy investors. Learn from Blizzard back in the day, release games, when they are done.

4-21-22 (100+ hours)

FInally finished my first playthrough of the main plotline...
There is discussion of the multiple ways the game can end, and it does have a "Fallout-style" (at least the path I took) where people whose life you affected leave you voice messages.

The last 30 minutes of the game was no combat, not even really deep conversation...just...a lot of introspection.  The decisions I made both before, during and after the main questline finale were, to me, deep, meaningful choices.  I took a few minutes to decide what I would do as V...not what I'd do as a "gamer".  I came to terms with my decisions, and they weren't light choices.

A shooter RPG-lite that many times during the game gave me quests and decisions that I wanted to review mentally when I wasn't playing.  To me, that's as good as it gets.  The ending has opened up even more plotlines/lines of thought ...this game does a good job of covering the bases of many of the issues "cyberpunk" as Gibsen wrote it.

I'm pretty darn happy and will continue to play as well as roll new characters.





3-31-22 (57 hours)

Finding the game is full of in-jokes, movie references, and lots of little treats for the player spread across the huge map.  I originally thought this was going to be a more graphical Deus Ex, but it's more like a GTA on steroids.  The huge neighborhoods, with something around every corner, evident cultures, emergent gameplay, etc.  Deep skilltrees to create the play experience you like.  Non-linear gameplay allows you to just drive around and listen to music, be a bounty hunter, or engage in the dozens of npc questlines, all without touching the main questline.

There are few things I find lacking:  one, is the ability to get trapped in an area with the only way to escape is death and reload from a previous save point, and the skill system lets you reset your perks, but not your base attributes...so your first playthrough, if you don't know what you want to do will create a number of wasted points.

All in all, this is a game where you can do what you want, with a skilset that you want, using gear that you want.  The combat experience is excellent (stealth it out, cyber it out, or go in guns or knives whirling...you decide).  The characters are very fleshed out and full of...character.  The world is the most living I've seen in a game yet.  Great all around.

Do get a powerful, current PC before jumping in though; that will make a huge difference to your gaming experience.


Was okay with an 15 and a 1060, but with an I7 and a 2070, this game is like watching a movie.  You really can't get the immersion with an old PC.  Great story, interesting characters and I didn't mind letting the conversations unfold.

Purchased the game when patch 1.5 released, so I have no real experience with the game that came out at launch. However this game has become one of my favorite games of all time. I'm a massive fan of Skyrim and have put numerous hours into that game on multiple platforms and GTA is one of my all-time favorite game series; somehow this game has been able to merge my favorite parts of the two series and blend them into one very large, very beautiful package. The world is so incredibly immersive and expansive, in my 36 hours (at review) I feel as though I've only explored a fraction of what this world has to offer. There have been a handful of bugs in my time with this game but nothing game breaking, and in a game with this much going on, it's a miracle it runs as smooth as it does with as few bugs as I've encountered. I would highly recommend this game to anyone looking for an immersive RPG with an engaging story and an expansive open-world.
Good game. Couldn't live up to the hype, but still good.

There are still minor bugs here and there but are usually pretty easily remedied with a quick save and relaunch. But over all I very much love playing this game. It's been a mental saving grace for me while the real world goes to crap. Could it be a lot more than it was? Absolutely. But I still have a blast playing it and running around. Story mode is pretty quick to roll through and that's why I do believe we could have gotten more. But even despite being short, it's still very good. 

My biggest wishes, were more content in the way of customization. More tattoo options, body scars, body types, more control over piercing combos. Stuff like that. I'm definitely very glad they patched in the ability to change your appearance later if you want that was a big thing a lot of people had issues with. But these are all pretty minor requests in the grand scheme of things. Basically I'm a sucker for a real in depth character creator, and will basically spend hours in just that if I can.

Let me start by "im playing since 1.5" i really don't know how bad the game was before, but i think every game now is the same thing, a disaster when they lunch and then little by little the game gets fixed, examples: Wolcen, No mans sky, FFXV, Borderlands 3, etc etc etc...

Now the preface is over i will continue with the review:


- The whole scene of the game feels like hand carved, it's like a massive diorama, i don't know how to put it in words, but the amount of details this game has is overwhelming, every little thing is modeled, every little detail is looked after, obviously if you look really hard you can see some flaws here and there, but if you compare it to any game out there, i think cyberpunk actually nails it, and for me is more than enough.

- The gunplay is awesome, it's like Doom / Destiny / Borderlands had a child. And melee combat is just muaaaah chef Kiss

- The soundtrack, awesome and with incredible variety, first time i spent much time in a game and don't turn off the music.

- Immersion, this game makes you feel the threats, the shots, in simple words, im kind of the gun frenzy fps player, this game made me take cover, think beforehand encounters, scan areas etc etc...

- Graphics, thou im not running it on RTX since i don't like DLSS, makes everything blurry, this will be given from an ultra-settings perspective, and honestly i don't feel like RTX is necessary, maybe im old school i don't know, but the difference is not much, the game simply looks awesome in either way.

- Controls, so far only thing i think needs improvement is on how motorcycles and some cars feel when turning, aside from that, everything is spot on.

- Story wise it made me feel like when I was young and playing FFX for the first time, it’s like you are playing a movie and you are the main character, most games have lost that but cyberpunk takes it a step forward and slams you Keanu in the face and some plot twists that are really awesome, the game tends to give you some mind fucks from time to time. To resume it, you feel the story and you live the story.
Heck even this game made me make a review, to make justice to it, and with just 60hrs on play im not even half the game because I’ve been immersed doing side quests that are actually good and content from the map…

Regarding Bugs only one so far i've encountered is the epistrophy quest, can't progress after pacifica, west side encounter with the thugs, and a bug with the phone that sat me back like 30min of gameplay to a previous save to fix it.

So to give it a final score, here is a less talky review:
5 Stars / 5 Stars

I can understand the root of bytching that the initial release of CP2077 raised. That doesn't mean I agree with it. The game itself is much better than bytching suggests. Well, fuck you all. It is not perfect but I like it. 

I can see a tendency of overambitious game projects that after a time become NoManSky-ed by the mean of being constantly fixed, patched, improved and enhanced to fulfil promises, to the point of delivery. Well, as long as these games are worked on I'm okay with that. I'm not going anywhere.

Cyberpunk. Genre. Deus Ex approaches the thing rather from the cyber, CP2077 rather from the punk side: less peddling with tech and more action. The very unfair description of this game would describe it as a cross between GTA, Deus Ex and some typical UBIsoft map-puzzle action game to some extent. But as a whole it is none of them really. Where it is outstanding in my opinion is the story line and the way it is put into the vivid game world. Also it has cyberpunk veteran Keanu Reeves whose presence is implemented a pretty cool way I think. The game world is massive and stunning. If you ever wondered what would be around the corner in Blade Runner that the movie never shows, here you are. I spent many hours just to look around. As for a game it is a quite decent fun RPG so yes there are bugs consequently. Do you remember Skyrim, Witcher, Fallout New Vegas or Fallout2 if you are old enough? All decent RPGs have complex worlds that mean bugs. As for performance it was tagged as a resource hog but as far as my experience goes the PC version was playable even before patch 1.5 and after that it improved nicely, running smoothly even on my modest RX570+Ryzen5 system.

Yep 1.5 was an important step. There are things that are sort of shady still, for example handling of vehicles. It is improved much since the first release but it still feels off*. There is no sense of weight. Even decade++ old GTA IV has more definition. Actually GTA IV is a much better driver considering physics than GTA V in my humble opinion. Well, who cares. No one will read this anyway.

* I kept CP2077 on ice for a while and checked again after 1.52 patch and vehicle handling seems to be singificantly smoother. The Radeon brown tint bug changed to Radeon green tint bug but dark textures still look much better. It may sound a little sarcastic but it is not, I really appreciate the new patches and looking forward to play coming DLCs. I hope CD Project Red will create something like the awesome Witcher 3 DLC pack.

Okay Okay... Yeah i know the game started off shakey and bad and buggy and borderline unplayable. Hell, i got the deluxe edition day zero and had a bunch of problems myself. Now before i start, i do have a slight bias as i have a pretty low standard when it comes to games. If it looks cool, i'll play it regardless of how bad people say it is and probably like it a lot myself, as with this game. I genuinely loved this game. I loved the sheer size of it and the world it's built upon. The voice acting, the characters are all so rememberable for me. The immersion (bugs and glitches aside) was fantastic. I felt like i was in this world in the future that realistically could make sense. The gameplay mechanics were really fun (recommend for pc play only as i didn't find the console gameplay as fun or thrilling). The cars were super cool. Going to go ahead and add Reeves cause he played his part well and i was very thrilled to see him throughout the game. Anyway, i recommend for those with really beefy pc's and a good amount of patience. I find the replay value pretty damn high as you have different paths to take, different dialogue options that matter. All very exciting. 

I'm also waiting for new game plus to start the game over with my endgame gear.

Good-looking graphics, cumbersome user interface, great music. BIG learning curve when it comes to using the commands. Not all of your available options are displayed and you may have to flail while pressing your physical buttons for things to happen on-screen. Do you enjoy hyper-complicated skill trees with 1/3 of upgrades doing nothing to impact the overall game? If so, this will stroke you nicely. 

Doing a blind playthrough on "hard" difficulty is accurate; having to replay sections due to dying is to be expected, but beating a challenge after a hazard or enemies don't spawn . . . I'll take that as a sad, lowercase win to progress the story along. 

Cool, you've learned how to stealth kill with a tutorial within the first ten minutes of starting the game. However, I never was given the option to stealth kill and had to used weapons and make noise to murder. After two days of playing, in real life, the option to stealth kill somehow un-bugged and turned itself on -- frustrating. Some area-specific N.P.C. enemies will spawn forever, so, lame. Also, don't stream this game due to the pervy nude sex scenes that cannot be skipped . . .   

Play if you have time to kill and like single-player, slow-paced stories, that have too much going on without much resolution -- like a junior Game of Thrones -- or a more depressed Grand Theft Auto game. Speaking of story I have no emotional investment in what is happening, and I honestly forget about most of the characters or what they contribute to the game's progression when they are not part of a current mission I'm completing.

Nothing could live up to the hype, but the game delivers a fun experience with good gameplay, a solid story, memorable cast, amazing visual design, and plenty of side missions.

At first I was kinda disappointed, expecting a lot more overall depth in side quests and environmental story telling, like Witcher 3. You can somehow feel the game was rushed a bit at the end, a lot of unused opportunities story wise etc. But that doesn't mean in any way this is a bad game, the story is intriguing and some of the side quests are absolutely phenomenal (The Hunt / Paralez quest line). Although, especially the Paralez quest had me like "that's it?! I want answers, who or what is behind this!?", talking about missed opportunity...  Gameplay mechanics are solid, hacking is quite fun and gives lots of options. Graphics wise, the game is simply stunning, if you have a rig that's capable of RTX with decent frame rate this has to be one of the best looking games out there.

I didn't encounter many bugs, even in the first version of the game, guess I got lucky on that part. After patch 1.5 the game should be a LOT more solid, shame that the game wasn't in that state at release.

Overall, Cyberpunk is a must if you're remotely into story driven single player games

what can i say about this game? well a lot i guess, but ill try to keep it relatively brief...
is it everything i wanted? no (would love more cyber options, and more in depth hacking), but its pretty close if im being honest with myself. and stylistically its a loving realization of the old school pen and paper rpg ive played so much of over the years. little things like books on shelves being actual source materials, to all the characters and storylines, and even brand names and silly future80s styles. its just dripps cpunk chrome goodness!

but yes, there are still a TON of bugs! i hit a nearly game breaking one within the first 2 hours of the game, but luckily was able to get past it by skipping an optional objective.  also got stuck in a building once that i was able to sneak into through a window but then could not get back out of. luckily i have good save discipline and was able to load a previous save to keep playing, only losing about 20 minutes of exploration and looting.  the whistle quickhack doesnt work most of the time, and there have been a number of times ive tried to hack nodes for rewards only to get nothing despite breaching all three codes (no xp eddes or anything)... seems the stealth hack track is still quite buggy and that is the run im going for, which is annoying.

but for the most part the game DOES work, and is even pretty fucking great! and to some extent i can live with the glitches and bugs as being somewhat appropriate to a world that is so technically integrated, and also filled with hackers and malware (the very fact that you can hack someones eyes and its "covert" because they are like "damn! again?!? thats the 3rd time this month!" is proof of this).

but wholey shit! the game looks AMAZING (especially at 4k ultra ultra raytracing settings on a 3080ti), and i use a controller to drive and k&m for everything else, and the transition between inputs is smooth and tight. the characters are all compelling and well animated/voiceacted/mocapped, so that you genuinely get invested in them and they are not all just quest givers or one dimensional good/bad guys. 

all in all, i definitely recommend the game, bugs and all, but i do hope they fix more of them.

This game has a lot going for it.  The world building is comprehensive, characters unique and varied, side quests are not mere filler and the combat can be a lot of fun.  It is clear that CDPR put a lot of effort into creating a detailed environment to explore.  I have particularly enjoyed wandering around the city listening to random conversations between npcs that are surprisingly detailed, and seeing the small details it hard to reach places.

During my various play throughs I have not experienced any significant bugs, glitches or crashes.

My biggest complaint is the character Johnny Silverhand who is foisted on the player fairy early in the game.   He is the central character in many unskippable "interactive" cut scenes that, while mildly interesting the first time, are a tremendous pain on subsequent play throughs .  The first such cut scene takes over 35 minutes to get through even spamming the skip dialogue button.   As the player is unable to respec abilities (only perks can be changed for a nominal fee)  I have restarted from failed builds and thus waded thru this cut scene numerous times.

I think the game would have been much better if Silverhand was an actual antagonist or opponent rather than a cancer the player is saddled with.

One thing the game is missing is a more challenging difficulty  setting.  The current "Very Hard" setting is not  very taxing and by the time the player is lvl 35ish (out of 50) most content in the game is fairly straight forward to get thru.

This game gets a bad rap sometimes, which can be deserved in certain circumstances, though my experience has been a good one. It is very much recommended if you want an experience, and not just another way to shoot some NPC's and rack up the kills and stats, though fun can be had in this area as well!  The Modding scene is pretty spectacular, if you are into that sort of thing, with a lot of options for customization! This game definitely requires a rig that is up to snuff, especially if you plan to play at any of the higher resolutions and detail levels.  That said, it is totally worth it if you have the capability!  

I have played the game through to the end three times now, and every single time, I have found another reason to like it, and it continues to deliver!  You WILL be disappointed if you rush through, from mission to mission, just trying to get to the endgame, and I would argue that you will completely miss the point of the whole work if this is how you play.  A huge amount of effort went into the creation of the world, and much of the story. Take your time, be meticulous, and spend some time exploring, 'living' Night City a little!  Explore the alleys and underpasses!  Actually Read the data shards scattered all over the place!  Watch the sunset over the city skyline from the hill or top of the penthouse once in awhile!  Let the enormity of it all and the attention to detail sink in, and you will see what I mean!

There is also some opportunity to explore your humanity a little in the context of the situations the protagonist experiences throughout the story line and game play, if you care about that sort of thing.  You are given the choice to act how you choose, and it gives you a chance, if you allow it, to explore yourself, your actions, and your feelings in situations you most probably would never want to find yourself in normally.  You'll find yourself loving or hating, even empathizing with certain characters as you play, and learn more about them and their lives as the story progresses.

That said, this game does deserve some of the criticism that has been leveled at it:  I think expectations were set very high initially and in some ways it does fail to deliver on much of the hype.  Also, there are still, to this day, some minor compatibility issues and gripes about some aspects of the game, but overall I have had a very good experience, especially with the latest update (1.5 as of this writing).  Most crashing I have experienced is the result of corrupted files, and if you check the forums, you can usually figure out what other things can lead to crashes, so there are solutions if you find yourself in trouble.

Still disappointing. I was sold on it going to be a deus ex mixed with open world. but in the end I got a very by the numbers open world game with leveling in the vain of something like dead by daylight. Not what I wanted, and not what was sold to me. well some story missions do have some verity in terms of how you handle the content. it really just makes me realize that it would have gotten that feel better if they skipped out on that open world and just did level based. but we'll get to that

Well the game can look as pretty as it wants to me gameplay will always matter more. I rarely mod older games to look "better" since art direction is what carried it. tho I will say even on low settings the world has a really good sense of style and does a great job at getting the scale of a cyber punk mega city that is build on top of itself. that being said, if you do have the gpu and cpu to run it at a high level: fuck me the bloom is stupid. form my point of view it screams "movie" and not "REAL" tho since we see the world so much through   fake eyes in the game that works out? there's moments where it's really pretty and other times where it's just- everything feels too clean and ends up being this more fake feeling world.

Now- for a little background for me: I have animation, cgi, effects and film background. well I work more as illustrator now, I still have a pretty good eye for this do to me having to work as clean up. So when it fails that speaks to me more than anything else. for people with eyes not as well trained it might not be an issues. and I'm pretty sure it won't be.  but this is a subjective review as all good reviews should be.

But lets touch on this open world. and more over how you get around it. cars handle aweful with a keyboard and mouse. I couldn't play on launch, but if this is how they handle AFTER the patches they still have a long way to go. if you don't mind running shit over and driving crazy than it's fine. but if you like to drive- you know- normally. there's not much you can do. the camera keeps resetting to a stupidly low angle to the car the car auto hard brakes and keeps doing it when I didn't want it to. there;s also no REAL brake. just backing up. so stopping at a light as me looking like I'm trying to parallel park going forwards and back. the AI and lights- don't work together. I'd often see them ignoring it outright and soon I just did too. If there were more control of your car like switching gears or some way to fucking brake so I can control my hard turns I might enjoy driving my car.

and open world side missions are so- bad too. not all are still I had one where I had to save a ripper from a gang. I sneak in from a vent system, only to be spotted in side the vents with combat starting right away. in fact steal REALLY needs a longer delay. if someone knows you are there the whole fucking place will just know straight up. meaning you are either in stealth or not. even if the dude didn't fight his gun or did anything load they will all know. and seemly never forget. so you have to ghost all stealth.

lastly lets talk about leveling and gear. fuck me is it annoying to dump loads of crafting supplies into a weapon only for it to still become so out classed that you'll still need to abandon it. and fuck me is it annoying how badly put together the leveling is. why give use the choice to stealth when you are just assuming it's going to fail?? Why not make skills that let us- you know- not fail? why does quickhacking have to share buffs to doing said quick hacks with CRAFTING quickhacks??? shouldn't that be under fucking crafting???? why is there a fucking skill called 200% efficiency when it gives a 2.5% armor buff to crafted clothing. how the fuck will 2.5% even fucking matter are you taking the fucking piss project red?? you made good skill trees before why are you failing now??

and speaking of disappointments: the story. in case you still wanna play it I won't spoil it. but out side of some order you don't get a lot of choices on how stuff happens. it's disappointing coming from witcher 3. and will likely never change. if it does some how change I'll sure look like a jerk. but there's no way they can get all the actors back in and redo all the voice lines and do anything major. and The co-lead of silverhand really just ended up making me like corpo. I'm shocked anyone fallowed him cause he lost all charm in how he talked and treated people.  stuck in this moody pre-teen bullshit where he can't explain his feelings. and in fact V often stuggles to do the same. tho that's also cause I had to guess how they would say stuff. "Question their motives" could be V taken a back and wanting to get filled in in a chill way, or it could be them questioning the persons whole fucking ideal and acting like they are bullshit. Like V knows the other party better. and without something that can tell me what tone they are going to take I have to roll the dice every time.

I think the game is in a state were it's more than playable and I can safely say there's just some core design ideas that hold it back from being more than a 6/7 out of 10 for me. and more than 3 or 2 if I wasn't willing to take it for what it is rather than the deus ex open world I was OG sold on. a lot of lies that are still not added in. Making it at lest work at a stable fps with new houses isn't going to fix that.

I'm sorry for any typos. I'm making this fresh off the game and with out a second draft. wanting to get my feelings out in a raw way before I forget.

I feel like this game should come with a surgeon general's warning:
Game breaking bugs may commence, do not expect to have an immersive experience. Will I continue playing? Yes, but only because I paid for it, I dont think I can get a refund now, and Im off work at this point, so might as well continue playing it for a while until I cannot stand the bugs at all. I've also played worse....

The game breaking bugs include(but not limited to) sprites phasing through walls, doors, furniture, and even their own clothes. So far no audio issues and only one major crash(the first time the game loaded it crashed before it got to the main menu, but loaded fine the next time), but the visual bugs are incredibly distracting and I cant help but wonder if they are intentional comedic relief intended to lighten the mood.... still not sure.

Other than that, the gameplay itself is decent and has potential and the voice acting is also fairly good, soooo.... Get it on sale.... is my advice..... But honestly $30(what I paid) is too much. This is more of a $20 sale item or preferably less. Devs need to pull their head out of their ass, fix their game, release an expansion to apologize to their fans, maybe more modding support, etc.... THEN maybe this game would be decent. They dropped the ball hardcore and really need to make it right before Ill give this game a thumbs up. 

Again.... Yes.... Ill continue playing it because I've played WAY worse games, but some of those games turned around and made a really amazing product by listening to their fans.... This game has not done that yet, and might never do it at all....

Ok last review till next major patch, I have 10+ hours in the game now and my last recommendation stands.  Basically if you bought this for $30 you paid a good price and it's recommended.  Anything above $40 I wouldn't buy the game because in my honest opinion it's still in beta and you dear player are paying for the privilege of being a game tester to report their bugs.  I really REALLY wanted to just click the thumbs up button and delete my previous reviews b/c maybe I was too hasty but in the past 6 sessions (which accumulated my 4+ extra hours of gameplay) The following bugs have been found (with many more that I'm sure I forgot.  These are just the humorous ones that I remember)

1: I accidentally hit a brown sedan and popped it's hood, all cars became brown sedans with their hoods popped (have screenshots) 
2: While driving on the bridge on my motorcycle thinking "you know what this game isn't too bad I was wrong" the bridge deletes itself and I fall through the world
3: Bartender from afterlife offers me a ride back, I say "no thanks" she drives off well 50 feet or so, and then decides to un-merge with her car which drives 50 more feet, she's floating in the air and the car is just there for grabs.
4: Accidentally rear-ended a truck today, merged with it due to wonky collision detection, the truck takes me for a ride till I can swing out from it on my motorcycle.
5: Several quest bugs, thank god for forums and people who post helpful information.

Again as I've said in all my reviews I really really hope they keep working on this game, the story is engaging and immersive, the city is beautiful.  
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

----------------------------------1.5 patch initial review------------------------------------------- 
HOLY WOW... I don't know what they did with the update but it basically turned this game into a virus.  Game constantly was running on my computer for two days (I just bought it and only played for 2 hours) now I have 13 hours of game time.  If I didn't have a 5 min sleep timer on my computer this game would have been playing non-stop for a week.  After trying to 'actually' play the game today it would not launch and was stuck on "update queued".  After several troubleshooting attempts I just decided to uninstall the game... (short version) I had to restart everything just to be able to do it.  (long version) It wouldn't uninstall from steam, it had no processes running but was constantly running in the background (verified every time I tried to exit steam) the game didn't appear anywhere on any of my drives.  (Fixed it) Full shutdown required, and instant uninstall.  After a 2 hour re-install the game works again... I'll change my recommendation if no further issues happen in two weeks or so.

Contrary to some, I enjoyed this game at launch, it had some interesting gameplay mechanics and high quality graphics, using the latest technologies. PC Gaming is about pushing the hardware limits and despite its flaws, this game tried to do that then.

Unfortunately, the developer decided to butcher the graphics quality in the recent 1.5 update. Whatever the settings, the game looks blurry and every surface looks like smooth plastic (the roads are particularly bad). Before that, you could clearly see close details from walls and objects, but not anymore. Everything looks blurry as you close in and it breaks the immersion, which was the main quality of the original game.

The "next gen" consoles are from 15 years ago in the PC world, and they shouldn't have degraded the PC version quality to please the owners of those overpriced living room heaters. One thing that those consoles could have brought is better parallelism, having 8 cores, but the game engine still use 2 or 3 cores at most, which is another fail.

shit game.... better off spending your time on a completed game that has the content that was advertised it would have.
A whole lot of shinny and cool looking things to hide the bitter truth that this game is has fuck all content or function.
the player cant interact with the world except through the main quest or side gigs.... you cant do shit.
you cant explore a random CBD sky scrapper, or a shopping mall, there's no sub-level or sub-systems to explore, there's no verticallity... you cant fly in a vehicle even though you see heaps of them flying around accessing higher levels of the city.

I'm not going to harp on things other chooms have already mentioned, so i will simply note something about combat. (combat is the bangers and mash of the game)
its just a boring spray and pray shooter essentially
there's no incentive for being stealthy, crafty, or extremely efficient at killing... there's no 'fear' meter for enemies, every single mission area you enter ultimately is completed/cleared the same way... just kill everyone, the fastest way to do that is to get the biggest gun you have and spread that american freedom. its the fastest and easiest way to clear and complete an objective. there's no draw back or disadvantage by going loud and just sending everyone in the area to the afterlife.
the enemies don't call for back up, the police don't come to suppress the firefight... 
no bonus points for being sneaky as i said, no tactical advantages for using hacking or other unilateral interdiction tactic, there's no reputation mechanic in game so enemies are not intimidated or fearful of you.... depending on reputation or even fearful of the amount of cyber-ware enhancements you may or may not have... i think you all get the idea.

underneath all the shinny and amazing looking city/world.... its just a boring shooter wrapped in a RPG story line.

other games that are years older have more player interaction , and react to the players actions and choices than this game does.

there are a lot of problems with this game, i have only mentioned 'some' of the bland issues with combat within mission areas... i didn't even mention how stupid it is when your walking down a street, casually exploring the city, walking past a couple of random gang members that are just standing next to a street light or in front of a shop... talking to one another, then they automatically start trying to kill you because you walked past them...

don't even get me started on that rediculousness.

this game needs to be fixed.... in reality it shouldn't have even been released when it did, it didn't even work on XBOX or Playstation at release if my memory serves.
Clearly this game was victim of board room politics and economics.... rushed to meet a deadline for release to turn a profit for the people that paid for its creation.

I am getting over developers releasing games that are not finished and receiving money from there customers for a product that is no where near what was advertised.

It has been a wild emotional ride, but after a few updates, I can now support and suggest this game.

It will never be the game I want it to be. You will never be able to pick up everything and throw it around like in Valve's Havok engine. You will never be able to customize the vehicles like you can in Forza or play with the guns like you can in Metal Gear. You'll never be able to rearrange your apartment or build secret forts in alley ways. You'll never be able to design and position your own tattoos or color your clothes. All of the MMO-esque multiplayer-oriented social and immersive things I wanted Cyberpunk to have will never be there. That will always leave a sour taste in my mouth because I long for them every time I play.

But. If you DON'T care about those things, what's left is still good. The story, graphics, optimization, GUI, voice acting, length, guns, clothes, exploration, collection, audio (you get it). Everything that's not customization or immersion is great. While not revolutionary, what's left is a solid experience.

Ultimately it boils down to being an open world sci-fi loot n' shoot with a bitchin' story. The RPG elements, alternate story angles and mod support give it decent replayability, but singular map and story and barely any social or immersive "extras" there will inevitably be a point when the environment becomes stale and it will have to be shelved while we all go back to playing multiplayer games.
I wish  this game had more time before it was sold.

[h1]REVIEW - English[/h1]
---

[b]A DECADE OF DREAMING ABOUT THE RELEASE OF THIS GAME![/b]

The wait was worth it! 


It's like playing Blade Runner. But much, much more special.
Cyberpunk 2077 is amazing in every detail.

Especially with the latest update, 1.5, Night City feels much more alive. The architecture, the population, the lights, the weapons, the vehicles,... Beautiful! I never tire of capturing the screen. It's a masterpiece.

And the script? The amount of rich and intelligent content dialogue is unbelievable. Literally, you play a movie (or a parallel life o.O). The characters are so captivating, the reactions are so well done... there's no way you can't be impressed. And the romance then... hmm? ;-)

Addictive! I just finished the main story, and I'm so freaked out that I want to play all the endings before I play normally again.


That's it!
This is a fan REVIEW! Of course the note is 10!!!

Yeah, there's some funny bugs. It's really not that bad especially if you've played anything by bethesda. I'm nearly 40 and I don't think I've seen better writing than in this game, ever. Not just quality, but quantity. Feels like everyone has a story, even a random shop with no quest attached. And it's all VOICED, and voiced REALLY WELL. The city is ALIVE. Every single alleyway and building has a unique feel, and usually something going on. If my choices don't matter (and a lot of the time, they do), I can't tell. Every dialogue I choose or don't choose something feels like it has story-changing consequences even if it doesn't, a complete 180 from Fallout4's "No" option just being a sarcastic yes on the next line. 

And it's beautiful, and it's huge. And when I spend 10 minutes trying to figure out how to get on top of some geometry just for the scenery or fun of it- I find something! Usually not just trash either. It's fun to play, the missions don't railroad you into a style, the settings menus have so many options-- so much work has gone into this thing and it is very clearly there right down to the alley trash. If you can only see the negatives, please just compare this to the endless sea of shovelware by AAA studios that have come out over the past 5 years.  Cyberpunk 2077 is of a standard I've not seen in decades. Thank you

Just to be upfront, I bought this on Steam at launch, it ran like crap so I got a refund. Then I saw it was on sale for GOG Galaxy for like $20 so I got it there. I wanted to try that loader anyway so why not. 

IMO, the game was pretty good for the first couple of hours I played it. Not great, but pretty good. It does seem over bloated and so distracted on trying to be hyperbolic on the whole cyber punk shtick, that it gets lost on trying make a good game. It's just too much of everything. 

The whole coming from nothing and being this respected mercenary/bounty hunter type role was pretty fun. But it was wasted with most of it being a montage. THAT should have been the whole game.But it seems they were so focused on trying to force Keanu Reeves into the game. I liked it less when he shows up. It just becomes another cliche early 2000's "OMG everyone is after us and I'm going to die" story. 

The game-play, the world, the characters, the story, the side quests were just not worth the time investment for me. If you just want to raise hell and break everything while laughing at raunchy ads, then OK, you might like it. I seem to be in the minority of not liking it, but I just felt it wasn't very good. It was cliche and trying too hard to be unique instead of just being a good game.

I was a person who bought this game within the first couple of days. Found ways to argue out of glaring issues with controls, and frame timing and NPC glitches and TERRIBLE car handling characteristics and  falling through freeways and getting my first stuck in a wall and dying as a result of it. Growing pains, I said. Performance wasn't that bad, but that's coming from someone with a well above average rig (3700x/3080).

Gave up quite a few months go and told myself that I would return once the smoke had cleared on a few updates because I wanted to believe they would see the light eventually. 1.5 update drops and that's the moment I decide I will reinstall the game and give it a go with fresh eyes.

Last two days I havent been able to launch the game, no matter what I try. I think it finally broke me, I'm uninstalling and committing it to a waste of 60 bucks.

My advice? You're going to spend a lot of time TRYING to love this game, navigating around technical issues that just suck the fun out of the experience.  If that's your idea of a good time - then have at it. But if you're an adult with ever decreasing time to game, and get intensely frustrated when your play windows are dominating with troubleshooting instead of playing, then do yourself a favor and and skip this one. At the very least, don't pay full price for it. I just... can't anymore with this game. Its like that breaking point moment in a relationship when you realize that issues you hope you could work past are simply too far gone.

Been here since day 1, and I am someone who came from the PS4 version of the game. This has been quite the journey from its horrendous launch to where we are today. Ever since launch I have enjoyed the game, though I do acknowledge that it is completely unacceptable how this game launched, and no video game should launch how Cyberpunk 2077 did. I'd say that this game has been "playable" since its 1.3 updates, but it wasn't in a state where I could fully recommended this game to others due to it still being in a worst state than early day Skyrim or the likes. Now here we are, the 1.5 relaunch update has brought us the "next gen" update to the game. Whatever you want to actually call this update, it brings the soft overhaul to the game in terms of stability and actual feature and mechanics rebalance to make the game far better in its design, and thus making it feel better to play, along with its far improved stability. The game is now at a state where I could fully recommend it.

The game is still far from being perfect, as certain play styles far outclass other play styles in terms of combat, especially melee combat, as its still pretty stiff and a bit of a button masher at times. Content still feels weirdly distributed around the map with some areas being far more dense in terms of content than others. Any other complaints I have would just be nitpicking at the game really. 

There is a lot to like about this game. The characters do feel genuine in who they are and what roles they play. The combat and stealth in most areas feels good or great mechanically and in execution. Traversing the world is never really a chore, given the amount of different vehicle types, the large number of fast travel locations, and general movement speed when on the ground thanks to the not terrible stamina amount you have along with the very basic parkour system you get access to. The decent variation in quests has a mix of combat, detective work, or even stealth retrieval, sometimes a multiple of styles. Depending on which skill tree you spec in, it actually changes a lot of how you approach each quest. You can go in stealthy, or go in guns blazing or fist swingin' if the quest allows for it. The driving was alright before the 1.5 update, but it is now incredible how much better it feels to control in the 1.5 update given the new types of driving options you have. There is a large variety of cars and motorbikes you can obtain too, and you don't even need to buy any to have good options. You can good a good selection of vehicles by just doing the main campaign.

I really genuinely like this game, a lot. It is far from perfect, but it is really fun to play. If you were unsure about the game before, but were thinking about jumping in with this update coming out, you should play it. I highly recommend the game now. It is a lot of fun, and is now in a far more acceptable state now.

After a severe launch and a rough year, 2077 delivers a rounded, fun experience. The style pops right off the screen and the dialogue is sharp. Night City's calling, choom--better get to it.

I love this game with all my heart. I love the setting, the characters, the story, the music, the everything. I didn't buy into the hype, I just heard it announced, saved up over the years it was in development to buy a good gaming rig, preordered it, then played it largely bug-free and enjoyed it. I don't take responsibility for the publishers' over-hyping or over-promising of the game and I'm sorry if you had a bad experience with it, but I love it and I would recommend it to anyone.

Despite all the problems this game had at launch, is it still worth it? Yes.

The storytelling in this game is amazing and truly immerses you in the universe. The writing of the characters you meet, and V themselves, is believable and feels in tune with the setting. You will come to care deeply about each of their fates, and struggle when you can't find perfect answers to everyone's problems. Its engaging, funny, cutting, and heart wrenching all at once. And in the end, you will have to find peace with the endgame path you take. Or, play the game again to experience them all! And you will want to, in no small part thanks to the gameplay.

I can only speak for my own experience, but the gameplay is super punchy and really helps you build up to a power fantasy. At the start of the game you will be using cover and healing constantly, fearing to engaging in fights and being terrified of punching anywhere above your weight. Yet by the end, you will be leaping in against legions of forces with nothing but a pistol, popping off headshots and dodging bullets, as badass as Johnny Silverhand himself as the game slowly builds up the tools you need to gain that level of confidence. The guns feel incredibly good to use, and can be customised throughout to fit your playstyle. But there's also a whole path for those who prefer melee combat that i've yet to explore. But that's sure to be damn fun too wielding a Katana or cybernetic gorilla fists, or retractable mantis blades and mechanics for blocking, dodging and parries.

The level design must also be commended highly. Every mission and side quest has multiple approaches you can take. I played a high reflexes, cool charismatic character. This allowed me to talk or fight my way past scenarios others might be cautious to engage with. But there were many paths and routes blocked to me that could be dealt with by being a lot more muscular, or having a higher intelligence to hack past. Yet i never felt like i was being blocked from engaging, i just had to think my way around it and always the game delivers smart thinking. 

All in all, this is a must buy for those who can run it. Its worth experiencing through in its entirety at least once, if only to see what somehow manages to be Keanu Reeves most emotive and interesting acting performance so far.

Although a lot of people shamed this game, I really love this one.

To express my thoughts I can describe my experience by the next list of subjective facts:
1. The first game which I want to play again after ending!
2. My first playing the game was before patch 1.5 and I faced to different bugs, graphical disadvantages, dumb AI and unrealistic physics. In spite of this I've just ignored a lot of them and received a huge cyberpunk sci-fi experience.
3. As an "oldfag" of sci-fi movies of 80th I've received incredible feelings. :D
4. I finish game. Then I uninstalled the game. After that I was trying to choose the next game to play but I couldn't do this. As a result I've installed the Cyberpunk 2077 again and currently I'm starting the next new path right now :)

Flawless performance on PC, characters that you actually end up having an emotional investment in, which can be quite rare in games these days, plus there are some really engaging missions (and some really messed up ones that hit you in the heart). I am just hooked on this game, tons of variety, you can get at the very least 3 different replays of the game before you get too bored thanks to the different paths and mission outcomes that are possible, similar to Mass Effect.  

My only complaint? Once you get anywhere near level 20 it can be a bit too easy with certain weapons and skills, even on max difficulty settings. I'm more in it for the story line anyway so it's not that big a deal. 

Some of the conversations with one of the main characters, Silverhand really gave me goosebumps as well, the sound design during those conversations/cut scenes can hit you pretty hard. 

If you loved Skyrim, Fallout, Mass Effect, The Witcher, Dragon Age Inquisition etc, you'll definitely appreciate Cyberpunk, great value for money despite the god awful launch for console players. (or perhaps you might be one of those that had very high expectations for the game? I went in blind, purposely didn't follow any of the development so I was very satisfied with what I got)

I'm probably biased because I like the aesthetic of cyberpunk universes (ironic because they portray a future that I vehemently hate) but this game has captured me.  I was one of the ones that wanted it from a long time ago, and naturally it wasn't what they promised but I'm pretty easy to please, admittedly. I like pretty graphics.  I went and got a 3070 just to play this game. One thing that makes games really good isn't the graphics or the story, but rather the connection between the action onscreen and your input device.  Done right, a game feels visceral and the blows punchy.  Some games have this in spades (like Dying Light) where the perspective combined with an intuitive control scheme and perfect response to your input pulls you in to the game, like you're not even holding a controller or using a mouse/keyboard. I like the feel of Cyberpunk in that respect.  Something about having the gorilla arms and savaging someone about the face with my bone crushing punches fills me with exultation. Helps me get rid of stress, I feel.  Plus, I mean, Keanu Reeves.  I'm straight but, damn... I know my wife would agree. I recommend reading through the cyberpunk TT game manuals that come with this game (yes, they're in the files if you look, in PDF form) - they help flesh out the world.

The first game that truly pulled me in for a while. 
Most of the bad press came from the console launches. While I experienced a few bugs, it was nothing major and was quickly overlooked. 
This game has a great story, great soundtrack and a great world, it certainly fits the genre of it's namesake, perfectly I would say. 
I've got to say, not many games have had me just going for a walk thinking about a conversation I just had, thinking about what to do. This is the kind of world that lingers in my mind, this was almost dangerously immersive for me.

It took me awhile to buy the game, I was swayed by people who were vocal and critical, mainly by the bugs. I decided to bite the bullet as I really desperately wanted to play it. I’m so glad I did. 
Are there some things I’d like changed? Sure. I wish we could customise our character after making them, I wish we had some added perks depending on the background we chose but I understand why that wasn’t included.

Honestly kinda fun. I don't feel ripped off, but I did buy the game at 50% off.
Some parts of the game feel unfinished, or at least very sparse. Weapon customization is basically non-existant, crafting exists but is fairly pointless. Levelling some skills flies by, but others are painfully slow.

Enemies animations can break if they are not on level ground, making them very hard to headshot or sometimes even hit. Luckily this doesn't happen too often. Items also sometimes get stuck on slopes/stairs, becoming unlootable. Sadly this is a bit more common. But honestly unless you go to sell after every bit of combat, you'll won't really care about most of the loot anyway, because your inventory will be full.

Weapons, especially early game, increase in power rapidly, meaning there is little point to improving/crafting weapons, just pick up a better one. This is compounded by the fact that the cost of improving your guns damage increases seemingly exponentially, but the gun on the ground will still have 2-3 upgrades more dps at times without this added upgrade cost. Armor has a similar problem, but felt even worse for me since now I have to choose between dying faster or looking like a low level WoW character. And also the unique guns are generally massively better than anything else, so there's even less purpose to crafting. And you also are showered with healing items at every turn, so unless you are rushing into every combat headfirst and chugging meds nonstop you'll have lots. I think I had 150+ each of the first 2 tiers of healing items.

The story is decent, some of the characters are fun, but most of your playtime is likely going to be spent fighting random goons in the streets. But the combat is pretty good, so even just running around doing that is not bad. The enemy combat AI is dumb as bricks though, generally they just sit behind cover popping out one by one to take some potshots. If they do push on you its generally just one enemy who runs in the open to get gunned down, and their buddies just stay behind cover and watch them die. Generally deaths in combat for me happened from getting bored and running into a room with 4-5 people and trying to rush them without using cover. The AI may be stupid, but bullets do kill you.

The least satisfying part for me is driving. It could partially be because I am playing on KBM instead of a controller, but the cars handle terribly. I have to press the direction about half a second before I hit the corner, then let go about halfway through my turn. Because every car handles like a 300 foot long cargo ship. The motorbikes are a bit better, but still very slow to respond. I find myself running 500+ meters sometimes because I can't stand driving in this game. Oh and when you call for your car, they do love to cheekily run you over when you get near them. Even if they've stopped for a few seconds first, they sometimes randomly lurch forward to knock you on your ass and take a little bit of your HP.

I didn't get pulled into the big hype for the game, so I am not as burned by the unfulfilled promises. But I would still say at full price the game is not super worth it, but at 50% off or better, it might be worth picking up.

A true masterpiece.

The gameplay is also great you can either run in guns blazing or take the stealthy approach. there is also tons of weapons and armour to find around the world which can all be modded with sights and mods that add stat bonuses. 

The story is also great is revolves around your character "V" and their rise to the top as a mercenary. the story does a great job keeping you engaged along the way. 

Its a shame on release that CDPR did not get enough time to polish out the bugs but as of now its seems the game has defiantly improved from its launch state and it will be interesting to see what DLC and updates CDPR bring out in the future.

9/10

A complete mess of a game, but still fun.

The characters and the story are the strongest part. The main story is surprisingly short though, especially compared to the amount of sidequests. Exploring and doing all of these sidequests ruins the pacing of the main story, and defuses the sense of urgency that you're supposed to feel about V's situation. The main story is strong; the side stories are hit-or-miss.

The city I have mixed feelings about. It looks amazing and can be very immersive to walk around in, but upon closer inspection it ends up feeling empty and hollow. There's very little possible interaction with the environment, and it fails to convey the impression of a city that's actually alive and bustling with activity.

Gameplay is clunky. I tried a number of different playstyles, but eventually they all ended up as a mediocre shooter. Stealth and hacking are technically possible, but in practice neither viable nor fun, especially in the early game. There's a ton of unnecessary and confusing RPG elements thrown in the mix that could have easily been streamlined without detracting from the gameplay at all. Eventually I ended up just mowing everyone down with a katana, which was at least somewhat satisfying. Enemy AI is a joke. Driving is just "meh". Every room you enter has a million things to pickup (often trash) and every enemy drops a bunch of loot, making your inventory a complete mess if you're not constantly managing it.

Bugs... I played on 1.31 exclusively and I did not run into any major gamebreaking bugs. Instead, there were many, many minor glitches, mainly involving perplexing AI behavior or the physics system spazzing out. Some of them were quite funny, provided you don't take the game to seriously or hope for any real immersion.

Performance was fine, but then again I do have a beef PC that far exceeds the recommended requirements.

Overall, it feels a lot like unrealized potential. But it does have a strong story, interesting characters, and a gorgeous city to explore. I never went very far on the hype train for this game, so it wasn't that difficult for me to just enjoy it for what it is right now. It can be good fun, just not always in the way the developers intended.

This game feels incomplete, rushed to launch and cut short on content.
Finished the game and all gigs on the highest difficulty and still unable to unlock the latest Perks.

I really hope the next update will start adding substantial amount of missing content, and not just be another "bugfix" patch. It's been more than a year since the game come out. I refuse to believe your team spent over a year just fixing bugs. That would be embarrassing. 

We want more interactivity, more customization (hair salons, plastic surgery), better AI, better police (car chases), expanded romances, with options to actually interact with them at our apartment and in the city. Why can't we invite the romance option to our apartment to shag? Or kiss them or hug them or do ANYTHING with them after their quests are completed!? They all just stay in their apartment or camp, and repeat the same few lines of dialogue. Give us a more interactive Night City. Let us actually sit and order food at restaurants with animations... you know, like those that ALREADY exist in the game. Let us go to night clubs and sit and have a drink, let us interact with dancers at strip clubs. Let us have those one night stands you talked about years ago and showed in the E3 gameplay reveal. Let us interact with furniture more. Let us sit on chairs, benches, let us lie on our bed without having to go to sleep. Give us a lot more MEANINGFUL side quests, with branching stories and the ability for us, the player, to influence the direction of those stories, and fewer boring "gigs", the ability to purchase more apartments etc etc etc.

Next, do SOMETHING to fix the HORRIBLE pacing and the irritating sense of urgency. 

After the mission to rescue Sandra, have Jackie just text us the next morning telling us that he returned the car to us, and then just let the player decide when they want to call Jackie. Maybe I don't want to meet him the very next morning. Maybe I want to explore that first part of the city for a few days, and then call Jackie after like a week. This leads me to my next point: 

LET US REFUSE TO ANSWER PHONE CALLS! What's the point of giving us the 'answer' button, when we MUST answer each time!? Let us refuse phone calls, and then later call the NPC at OUR convenience.
Have the NPC/Companion/Fixer etc. call us, and if we refuse, they can just send us a short message saying "Call me back when you have the time." Maybe I want to call them in 2 days. This would fix A LOT of pacing issues, and not make the player feel so stressed out, like they always have to rush and do these jobs quickly.

I was barely able to explore the city, without feeling stressed out, because I had these urgent jobs and the YOU KNOW WHAT from the main quest always pressuring me. Like, I never felt right just exploring, knowing what was happening to V. I knew that I should not be prancing around a beach, when I had the URGENT main quest to do. Ignoring it felt stupid.

Next, fix the way we interact with Johnny. After that first night when he reveals himself to us all angry, he and the player are in A REALLY bad relationship, right? So, then the very next morning we get a phone call from Goro to meet him at that diner. If we go there, the convo we have with Johnny flows natural and V is angry and mistrustful towards him. However, we also get a call from Delamain that same morning to go get our car. So, if we go do that first, V talks to Johnny like they are already friends, which is super immersion breaking. Fix that somehow. Let Johhny start appearing only after we've done the first few main quest missions or something.

Also, I don't know if it's just me, but the journal in this game is terrible. It's close to being useless. Like, most of the time it doesn't even tell you what the mission is, who gave it to you, or why you need to do something. It just has some clever little monologue by Jackie or Johnny. So, if you decided to leave some mission for later, then, when you finally decide to do it, but you've forgotten what it was about, chances are that the journal will tell you nothing useful. Rewrite that, if you can. 

Man, I could rant for hours. Oh yeah, expand on those few endings that are such obvious cliffhangers. Give us at least ONE good one. Man.

This is not a game for everyone. I think the insane amount of divisive press surrounding it speaks to that plenty. But just because it's not for everyone doesn't mean its objectively bad.

Yes, there is no escaping the fact that the game is patchy, rough around the edges, and requires more interactivity and content, period. Yes, there are promises CDPR made that they did not deliver, for which they should absolutely be held accountable. Yes, you have to rely heavily on the modding community to prop up what they can until the devs release more updates.

But if you can look past all that (and I know that's a tall order) there is something downright magical about this game. I play games predominantly to experience their stories, and Cyberpunk boasts one of the most beautiful, emotional, mature stories of the last decade. I'm talking characters that put Mass Effect to shame. I'm talking atmosphere that puts S.T.A.L.K.E.R. to shame. I'm talking a soundtrack that... well, it at least gives DOOM a run for its money. And I say that as a diehard fan of all three of the above mentioned! This game breathes life into a world that I simply cannot get enough of, that I keep coming back to no matter how many bugs I have to fight through on the way. Not since the original days of Bioware has a world and its lore and its characters felt so mesmerizing.

Cyberpunk 2077 at its worst is not great. Sometimes it's downright bad. But Cyberpunk 2077 at its best is not just good. It's breathtaking.

I stayed away from this for a year, hoping that CDPR would fix most of the bugs and performance issues that plagued the game at release. I also recently got a 30- series RTX card and, wow, this game is beautiful - the city they've created is truly astonishing. It gets that sense of stacked verticality that most open world games set in cities really struggle to reproduce. The atmosphere is incredible. It feels worthwhile to explore every corner, Yes there are still bugs, yes the illusion isn't perfect, but it reminded me of the feeling of freedom I got when I first played Deus Ex back at the turn of the century.

EDIT after around 40 hours played: I would still stand by most of this. The city they've created is something to behold in terms of atmosphere, sound and visuals. HOWEVER, a word of caution that the bugs are still common and over time they DO disrupt the illusion the game creates. I still regularly see car bodies disappearing and people happily driving around a chassis with wheels, or people glitching through objects, or buddies you're doing quests with getting stuck on tables and the like. 

There's also the exploration... While you're doing quests it absolutely feels worth exploring every nook and cranny. But when you're back in the open world you rapidly realise that most of the buildings are empty facades. I get that they couldn't make an entire explorable city but unfortunately you'll very quickly not bother exploring Night City and simply go from point A to B to complete the next quest. Sure there are occasional things that happen as you're travelling around (assault in progress, gang fights and the like) but beyond that it's honestly not massively different from, say GTA 3 or 4. 

Having said all that the side quests are varied and generally well-written - as has been said many times before they're honestly often more engaging and surprising than the main questline. There's one I did recently with River Ward about kidnapped teenagers which made use of braindance, investigating crime scenes, collecting evidence... AND actually made a difference depending on what skills you'd invested in. It also didn't end up in a firefight where you gradually whittle down bullet-sponge enemies.

All in all, it's still a recommendation for this game, just a qualified one. Try to get it on sale if you can.

Cyberpunk 2077 is a great game, ripe with flaws and bugs but the positives heavily outweigh the negatives. This review won't focus solely on why it's great, but why some people hate on it.

Exhibit A, Post launch consensus. The launch of this game was disastrous, it was crawling with bugs and performance issues, I had a mid-high specs PC at the time and the game would fluctuate from 20-40 fps at medium settings, only being playable at low settings at 30-40 fps. Since then the game has changed, a lot, the major bugs have been ironed out and the performance is night and day, I upgraded to a new PC and the game runs at a constant 60 fps (I have it capped, it goes up to 70-80 fps but I prefer a stable 60) at max settings, my old PC runs the current game at 50-60 at high settings and around 30-40 at max.

Exhibit B, Post launch "reviews". When the game first launched it was hit by a wave of angry reviews, and most of which were angry for good reason, but with a big following comes a big responsibility which many big reviewers refused to bear. Many big reviewers complained about how the game was too short and lacked content, those same reviewers then stated that they played none of the side missions which make up around sixty percent of the game. If you have played The Witcher 3 (W1 and W2 don't apply here, their side missions aren't as integral) you would know that some of the side missions are integral to the story, in Cyberpunk this is more so the case, the side missions are completely essential and a reviewer should review the entirety of the game's content, not a third of the game's content.

Exhibit C, Gameplay expectations. Cyberpunk is an RPG, not the best one but a step up compared to many modern RPGs, this is coming from an avid RPG fan with hundreds of hours on Deus Ex and well over a thousand hours on TES:3 Morrowind, those are what I could think of at the top of my head. Some people were coming into Cyberpunk expecting a classic RPG, if you have played any of CDPRs other games you'd know that that is certainly not the case, it's a much more modern RPG which I certainly don't prefer but the game was never supposed to adhere to the hardcore RPG crowd. Most people went into Cyberpunk expecting GTA5 with more colours, they were also disappointed because the game was far too complex and non linear when compared to a very linear, laid-back game such as GTA5 and disliked the combat because they couldn't make a proper build.


Review:
Cyberpunk 2077 is a strong title only being held back by the lack of polish and unfulfilled potential, this game had the potential to present many unique concepts that aren't really explored much, ranging from simple concepts that would have been cool to see such as fully six dimensional movement in vehicles and third person perspective, to more impactful gameplay features such as heavier emphasis on world interactions such as trade, industry and transport, a reputation system that carries onto the interactions with specific factions and finally and most disappointingly, an actual faction system. 

While Cyberpunk is certainly better than the majority of games out there today, most of which are compilations of "unique" ideas that don't really go anywhere and are most likely derivative of an older title that is infinitely better (I'm not-so-subtly referring to all the max payne rip-off shooting galleries and all games in a similar vein) and is a step up from the increasingly popular extremely linear structure of gameplay and narrative present in many games and on the other end of the spectrum, the structure-less design of other open world games, it falls short from the potential it had, this game could have been a lot better and the more you play it the more it shows. 
The game has been fixed but Cyberpunk's greatest issue (especially on pc since it wasn't as dramatically bugged at launch as the console version) remains to be it simply not being finished. The game was "technically" in development for eight years since it was revealed in 2013 and released in 2020, a logical estimation would be that development started in 2012, but the actual development time was only a little over a year since the project was repeatedly scrapped, meaning the Cyberpunk 2077 that was released is not the same game CDPR planned on releasing initially. This meant that many gameplay features and planned ideas were never completed and were thus simply cut from the game completely.

Conclusion:
Cyberpunk 2077 is a fantastic game and the backlash and hate the game faced may not be what the game or the devs deserved, but it is certainly what the corporate side of CDPR deserved for publishing the game when it was so clearly unfinished. I commend the devs that have been patching the game since launch, the contrast between launch and now is truly night and day. I also want to give praise to the modding community, there are some absolutely fantastic mods out there, even if you're not a fan of RPGs and want the combat to be less focused on RPG mechanics there's even a mod for that, mods are adding and refining many aspects of the game and the community has grown to the likes of that of Bethesda's titles.
