***UPDATED 07/2022*** Patch 1.52... Thank you CD Projekt Red for ruining the parts of the game I enjoyed the most.
1. GOOD: The map updates were great, especially the configurable filters.
2. GOOD: The ability to track Fixer missions complete vs available is nice; and so are the gifts they give you when you finish all of them.
3. GOOD: You fixed the Pacifier resistance mod. Thank you.
3. BAD: You retcon'd the skill system and equipment qualifications so much I couldn't use weapons and armor I had customized and used for over 300 hours of gameplay.
4. REALLY BAD: You so completely NERFED armor and armor mods, that my armor (after 300+ hours of play) is now at half the strength it was, and I can only craft defense mods half the strength I could before. Why the hell would you do that? You don't nerf gear in solo games. You only do that crap for game balance in MMO and PvP games. That was a true knucklehed move.
5. RIDICULOUS: You overbuffed MaxTac and Border Patrol so much they dodge every bullet if you have agro'd them. 

Number 4 has ruined the game for me. As I said below, I've completed it multiple times already, and there is no infinite playability because fixers don't generate random missions - once you finish their mission queues that's it; and standard mobs and mob hideouts/dungeon crawls don't respawn. So messing with NCPD MaxTac, and Border Patrol were the only remaining fun. EXTREMELY disappointed. Time for me to uninstall. >:-(

***ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW***
I have played through Cyberpunk 2077 four times, male and female, all three character choice types (Nomad, Street, Corp), and each available ending. I like the gameplay mechanics, the city and story are really really good. The music kicks ass! However, as a player of the original pen-and-paper Cyberpunk 2020 and Night City this is based on... this ain't Cyberpunk 2020.

What I think they got right::: Combat feels very balanced, and the variety is good (melee, ranged, etc.) (though I wish you could hire NPC henchmen and build a team that can level with you - netrunners for overwatch, solos, snipers, etc.). Weapons selections, and mods are excellent. Vehicles are fun - though I find motorcycles are most efficient for travel. Scale (the game environment is HUGE). Ambiance and environment can get really immersive.

What I think was okay, but could have been much better::: Interpersonal relationships. Don't get me wrong the main NPCs are outstanding. The movement, script, etc. - great. But the people on the street? not much there. There were definite opportunities for the developer to integrate enhanced relationships with various NPCs - Rogue, and many in the merc underworld; The Us Crack girls; Jefferson Peralez the mayoral candidate (his quest reached a climax, and then just quits - very disappointing). Cops? No sources of intel/friends on the force to speak to for info on gigs, personalities, or other info. The Talent/Skills trees are okay. Too many skill bonuses to select from only enhance combat capabilities when you are doing special actions like slides, and melee functions that don't really match my play style. In general the Talent/Skill system is good though, and does make a difference for many needed functions like hacking, crafting, and others.

What I think they got wrong::: Fixers. Mission assignment. no Infinite playability. Lack of character customization - No ability to visit a salon and change a hairstyle, or get a tatoo. No ability to alter the physique of your character - on the female character you can change the breast size, but that's it. The male character can change penis size... really? That was necessary? I've played over 250 hours and those features are needed maybe 2 minutes on screen; and the clothing system? Really? Especially for the outfits you craft yourself - you should be able to pick the colors. Can't believe I can go to a high-society corp clothing store and spend $3000.00 on a shirt, but can't pick the color of the cloth.

Cyberpunk 2020 was about immersive role playing. Going to the fixer locations, negotiating your price, building a team, developing enemies (watch your back), and allies and sources for intel and gear, as well as fixer missions, and growing your rep with factions.

Cyberpunk 2077 is a very playable, and fun game, but would benefit greatly from a better mission system, respawning mobs, and random/infinitely spawning player-leveled side missions and gigs. I have played every side mission, every gig, bought every car, and finished every NCPD and other on-map alert and there is literally nothing left to do but cruise around hunting gangers, and screwing with Arasaka, Militech, and NCPD MaxTac. ...and WHY don't MaxTac mobs drop gear? Same for the border. No drops?

I'll keep playing it, because I like it, but I'm praying for some serious DLC coming soon, and some game mechanics fixes to allow greater infinite playability.

I just downloaded and started playing CP2077 a few weeks ago and I'm totally hooked.  Apparently I missed the rocky phase of the release and started at patch 1.31, which I believe has significantly reduced the level of frustration earlier adopters experienced.  In keeping with the high bar set by Witcher 3, the game is well crafted, intermixing a powerful and complex story line with a broad variety of side missions which help the player to gradually build their familiarity with the game mechanics while developing their skills and refining their combat techniques.  

This is a complex game, with a wide variety of settings to pick from.  There are skill-tree decisions and story line options that can potentially change future outcomes and endings.  For some, the complexity will enthrall and for others it will be a turn-off.  This isn't really a hack and slash game by design.  To enjoy the entirety of the game ecosystem, it will be beneficial for you to have a more cerebral play style, but there are provisions for you melee types as well.

If that's your thing, you can always play "John Wayne" style and approach each confrontation with guns blazing and swords slashing.  There is a whole build type called "Sandevistan" to support that mode.  IMHO you will miss out on a lot of the nuance designed into the game, which combines elements of stealth, strategy, melee and weaponry but that's a personal choice that is nicely supported.  There was a lot of thought that went into the weapon upgrade and random drop logic to prevent out of level scaled damage.  This helps keep the combat challenging and engaging.

Don't expect everything to be spelled out for you.  There are some key gaps with respect to providing a basic understanding of the play mechanics of weapons and cyberware.  You WILL get the basics and you should expect to learn the fine details from actual combat/gameplay, supplemented by input from forums, etc.  There are some clunky bits in the UI, like how to find quest based shards and how to manage inventory or apply mods.  There's no way currently to flag your weapon favorites to prevent them from being sold or scrapped out of your inventory, which can be frustrating when you are selling off the HUGE amount of low level weapons you accumulate as part of each combat operation.  There are a hundred different types of food and drink, but all with the same stats, which is a lost vendor/crafting opportunity.

CP2077 is visually stunning, particularly at ultra rez.  Clever attention has been paid to the visuals and audio queues, with an absolutely amazing complexity of detail.  NPC movements, reactions and even the ubiquitous (and often humorous) presentation of graffiti are presented.  There are even a few cars with one headlight out because yeah... people still don't pay attention to their rides even in 2077.  Also be warned that there is a lot of sexually suggestive graphics/content and a LOT Of F-bombs flying around.  2077 is a raw place sex, guns and drugs and street violence are the norm and victimization is part of the story line.  I find it adds a level of "realism" to this dystopian vision, but if you find that offensive... don't even bother with this game.

Bottom line:  If you like a complex game with a gritty and amazingly detailed playing field, aren't squeamish about mature topics and are ready to enjoy a complex, evolving action packed story line, give Cyberpunk 2077 a try.  Now.. where was I......*Opens Journal*

Impressions: Overall this was a very positive experience Cyberpunk is a fun game I had a blast the story is compelling the world is beautiful and the characters have depth. I spent a lot of time exploring and trying all the different options. Do yourself a favor and bump up the difficulty it does make it more satisfying as you progress the game gets a lot easier a little too easy towards the end. Graphically if you have the right system ray tracing on or off it looks good so 1080 I'd say go for it. Driving could be better but sometimes it's fun just to drive through the city and look at all the scenery. Riding motorcycles is the most fun in my opinion and it's one of the few times you can see your character. The biggest disappointment with this game is knowing what it could have been.

Gripes: It would be an all time great game if they just finished it. Most annoying issue is that it is often difficult to lock onto objects when picking up an item. This is such a basic game mechanic and it's the kind of feature you don't think of as a feature till some messes it up like this.  T-poses I can live with it's random and not much of an issue for me but the glitches did make some serious moments laughable. It's hard to know how much more I'd have enjoyed this game if it wasn't breaking up some pivotal moments.

OK, it's going to be a long one. So I bought this game, one year after the whole release drama. I thought some time had passed and some hotfixes and patches were released, so i said to myself "let's give it a go."

First of all, I recommend this game. I'm not one of those guys that plays a game for 100+ hours and says the game is not good. But let's make something very clear: it's January 16 2022, and to this day, the game is a big mess.

For starters, this game does 2 things very well: tell a story and build an immersive world. That's pretty much it, that's the whole 2 reasons why i think this game is great and you should play it. Forget about if this game is an RPG shooter or an open-world game, that's secondary. Let me explain myself:

1. It's narrative is amazing. Side stories, main missions, lore, everything is told in a fascinating and appealing way. The game sets the mood for some really grim situations. That's what I'm saying when I told you this game can tell a story. A matter that is directly related to this is the quality of the main story. I'm no writer, but I can say I liked the overall story, but this is something I would put to debate; whether this game has a good story or not. It's the way this game presents it and evolves it that makes it an enthralling experience.

2. The level of detail of this world is confusing. Because it's interactivity falls short against the overall design and art concept. The world is beautifully crafted. Design of buildings, clothes, vehicles, guns, products, it's all amazing. Soundtrack is out of this world, graphics quality is incredible. It really creates an immersive world where you really feel a part of night city, but then again interactivity is quite poor.

In terms of game mechanics, it's not there yet. The lack of classes makes it messy, gunplay is the most attractive feature of combat and stat leveling really feels lackluster. It just feels like a very fun pew-pew game. And that's a good thing, really. 

Customization is a huge problem, basically because at the time is non-existent. You can't change styles of clothes, or cars, or guns, or anything really, so that's a huge let down.

I think the RPG gameplay and the lack of customization is what exposes the real problem of the game. We all know about it's buggy and glitchy state, but if we take that out of the way and see the game for what it is, you can realize that the big problem with this game is it's confusing classification. It's not really an open-world game like others (GTA, Red Dead, Saints Row, you know the bunch) and it's not really an RPG. CDPR made a very ambitious game, and like I said, it's a fun, enthralling and nerve wracking experience, but it's not as interactive as an open-world game or as mechanically deep as an RPG. Still, gunplay is actually great, so you can't really delve so much on it's gameplay problem because it's not that big of a deal.

So I really recommend this game, i really think it's a next gen game and I encourage you to play it because you'll soon find yourself obsessed with it's narrative, it's fun combat and amazingly crafted world... when bugs are not still a big issue. I powered through the whole game getting constantly heartbroken at the numerous immersion breaking bugs or glitches, because let me promise you something, you will find bugs and glitches, and they will ruin your experience. I'm certain of it.

So yeah, make yourself a favor and play this game... once it's patched and fixed a little bit more.

TL:DR: Buy only at a steep discount. Not worth the $60 price tag. 

Only buy this if it goes on sale. The $60 price tag is far too high for some of the issues/glitches in the game.

I enjoy the game and the story so far. However, there are obvious glitches that appear each time I boot up the game to play. It's hard to go 15 minutes without seeing some kind of visual bug or glitch (T-posing NPCs, delayed texture loading, etc). I'm surprised that these issues that were in the game at launch are still in the game.

There are several things in the game (or not in the game) that disappointed me when I found out abut them. Vehicles are not customizable (bummer), the driving mechanics are fairly poor (if feels like you're driving on ice sometimes), and some areas are soft-locked due to the player's level (power enemies essentially lock you out of an area until you are ready, but the game doesn't readily tell you this until you get insta-killed by them). The police AI is also severely lacking and sometimes Night City feels just kinda... empty. 

That said, I love the combat in the game, there is ample customization/crafting options for weapons/armor, and the story is good (so far in my play through). 

Overall, this is worth a buy, but only at a steep discount. Do not pay full price - you will be disappointed. I got Cyberpunk 50% off during the Christmas sale. If I had paid any more than that I would have been disappointed and may have gotten a refund. This is a $30 buggy/early access game being marketed as a $60 AAA game.

In its own way, Cyberpunk is a genuinely great game. Unfortunately, because it looks like any other crime-based open world game, it's easy to compare it to superficially similar franchises like GTA and conclude that the game *isn't* that great. I can sympathize with that point of view. NPC and driving A.I. are somewhat simplistic, there still isn't much customization or stuff to interact with in the city in the way of mini-games or other typical open-world time wasters, and there are still some bugs here and there.

What makes the game special is its depth and maturity as a narrative experience. This is a narrative-driven game through and through that just so happens to exist in an open-world city. If you can divorce yourself from the duplicitous marketing and play the game as it is best played - as someone role-playing an existential crisis of their mortality amidst struggles with relationships and the self in desperate times - Cyberpunk is beautifully haunting. Quests are quirky and varied and intelligently confront so many different themes like personhood, PTSD, loneliness, freedom, depression, suicide, rape, and murder, and choices feel like they have emotional weight even if they don't alter the trajectory of the main story as overtly as choices did in Witcher 3. The voice acting and character writing are significantly more interesting and nuanced than most games can ever claim to be. Characters feel and act like multi-faceted people instead of just cliches. Even small bits of dialogue feel compelling instead of the typical perfunctory exposition so many other games deliver.

This game is also under-appreciated for how much poignant philosophy it includes; there are so many easily missed, fascinating details about corporate imperialism and its tools of technological determinism for what it means to self-identify as a person and live a meaningful life. Details in various forms across the city concerning the alienation, violence, and consumerism of a society in decay  create a blend of dark humor and real despair as you play the game. Every time you bother exploring the crevices and corners of the world, the game rewards you with more depth in its lore. Everything from written shards explaining people having 80-hour work weeks to news programs mentioning a public figure being vilified for demanding social benefits for people crafts a vision of corporatized dystopia. You feel it everywhere, and it's really affecting.

Don't get me wrong; as fun as it is to play through, as a technical game, its issues do occasionally detract from the experience. That does not change the fact that as a total narrative experience, few games even come close to its accomplishments.

If you go in expecting a fun action RPG with great story and lore elements instead of GTA: Dystopian Edition, you might see the genius of Cyberpunk past all its technical flaws.

Just finished in 2022, and worth the time imo. Yes as an RPG it has some room to live up to the best titles in terms of choices and consequences -  the ripples of the player as the game progresses, with multiple distinctly different outcomes. That said the actions you take do have smaller ripples and the game isn't quite as good as displaying them when you play the first time, but which you can see in later play throughs.. The endings do have some very different routes and outcomes but it is not a mass of bespoke endings. Still the endings I felt were very powerful, more on that in a bit (no spoilers obv). In terms of play styles, weapons, skills and perks, it has great depth. The world is also quite big and there is a good amount of stuff to do as bigger side quests, local quests and random ones etc.

Where I think this game gets some serious points over many many others is the story and the endings genuinely do make you feel a wide range of emotions. The choices and consequences on the story are one major part of top tier RPGs, the other is the how the actions you take make you feel. For people who loved the emotional ride and ending of games like KOTOR, Witcher, Mass Effect, Dragon Age etc, this game can absolutely deliver that. It's got some pretty hard hitting messaging about life throughout the game (if we're being honest) and with the endings in particular.

Admittedly, I can see them being more poignant for people who have lived a little themselves, I'm sure the average teenager will not take it in. It can be a bit trite to say a game is art, even among gamers, but this game really is imo, it has messaging, layers, deeper meanings and parables everywhere, like any literary classic. 

That said, no spoilers, but I genuinely felt this is a top tier game for hitting you right in the feels, and making you think. Right up there with my memories of finishing some of the greatest RPGs of all time. Definitely worth a look imo if you need a solid RPG.

All in all after this review I think you need nothing shy of a good PC setup and this is one beautiful open world story rich game to explore.

GAME OF THE YEAR CONTENDER?: DON'T BELIEVE ME, READ ON!

I bought this game the day it came out. It wouldn't load until about 2 days after. It still deserves its chance to be GOTY. I want to tell you about this game and why it shouldn't get as short shrift as it did on initial release:

1. You're buying on PC. You need a good PC (my rig can't even load it but I play on GeforceNow just fine) but you will experience FAR FAR FAR FAR FAR fewer issues than the folks who bought it on last-gen consoles.

2. It's not perfect. Don't expect it to be. It's an open-world game much like Skyrim and I have some 400+ hours playing Skyrim and despite the bugs I loved both Cyberpunk and Skyrim. Just don't expect it to be perfect: I have to reload my game sometimes to make Johnny's Pistol able to shoot while aiming, and at launch I saw way too many folks in a T-pose in the bars. The most hilarious was calling a motorcycle. It would drive up to your position then upend itself because the recall/delivery physics seemed to not be in connection with one another. At least on PC, they've fixed it mostly. It is what it is. Skyrim got game of the year awards from nearly every publisher.

3. THEY FIXED IT. Kind of, but mostly good. As I mentioned in (2) the bugs you see in YouTube videos are mostly in last gen console releases. I would say 90% of the panning the game (deservedly) got on release was from people playing on old hardware. No, CDPR should not have even released the game in that current state, put you shouldn't worry because you're here on Steam.

4. ACCEPT THE BUGS. It's pretty well fixed on PC now, but there are bugs. Just remember how much we all love Skyrim despite it.

5. YOURE PROBABLY NOT GOING TO GET TOO MANY IMPROVEMENTS IN THE FUTURE. Yeah...the saddest thing for me is not getting any official expansion DLC or anything. It seems like the response to bug repairing on old hardware is taking up most of the team's time rather than developing new content. I wish they'd scrapped it on older consoles and just given us GTA2077 but what're ya gonna do?

6. DID YOU LIKE BATTLE ANGEL ALITA/GUNNM? Play this game.

7. IN THE END IT'S GOOD. Bugs? Yes. Bad launch? Yes. Not quite as fleshed out as it should be? Yes. Best Game of 2021 (It came out December 2020, technically, if you want to complain). Mostly yes, unless you're a hardcore strategy fan when you should be playing CK3 but they delayed released all year too. Worth $60? Hard to say definitively. For most folks, no. I'd say $40 on sale would give you a good time worth your money. I know this review is on Steam so we're all PC gamers here but *absolutely do not recommend to your friends on last-gen consoles to buy this*.

*Edit and spoilers ahead, for the few dimwits it might bother*

-Prologue Footnotes-
1) I stand by my first review of the game, expressing how it was disappointing half baked rich kid's GTA experience posing as an RPG with no real choice with too much filler content and so many bugs to boot mostly caused by the "revolutionary graphics" and the engine's physics, also pointing out how GTA SA/Saints Row 2 did some of this game's concepts alot better.
2) I wish steam had a 1 to 5 or 10 rating system, because this game falls flat in the chasm that is a "lukewarm" experience, alot of potential, but all around boring and pointless.
3)  I did not want to buy this game originally, nor did I care to finish it, almost felt compelled to refund it after the first act, but I felt like I needed to press on, this was to be an experience, a study of sorts, so I kept on going accepting the inevitable and it's consequences.
4) I am a general media consumer (books, movies, series, cartoons, comics, music) that demands quality and/or personality.

Some might argue, with my total played hours (170, more or less) that I've had my money's worth. However, as mentioned before, this was, in a way, a sort of quest to achieve Nirvana. What is Nirvana? It is when you realize that no matter how many times you re-incarnate in the hopes of achieving a better more illuminating life, it is pointless, therefor, willingly cutting yourself off the cycle of birth death and rebirth. Twisted sense of humor aside.

-The Pros-
1) The game looks amazing during a storm of any kind or during the night or during sunrise in the desert or on the beach.
2) The combat system is responsive.
3) The inevitable demise in one shape or another of the main character is interesting.
4) Graphics are amazing.
5) Driving the "akira" motorcycle in first person is the way to drive in this game, quite a rush.
6) Game has a lot of vertical, especially when you buy one of the leg upgrades.

-The Cons (brace yourself, the list is long)-
1) The graphics took too much priority on the project at the expense of everything, especially game stability.
2) The difficulty system is your typical damage sponge system instead of realistic damage and improved AI.
3) Various game breaking bugs during quest prompts or cut-scenes.
4) The characters were not fully developed and felt like hollow shells in service of the script.
5) The execution of the story felt rushed, unpolished and uninteresting.
6) Too many filler quests, not enough story driven quests
7) No car dealers or garages. Seriously, wouldn't have been a bad Idea. The idea of this "available used cars" per "fulfilled contract" is weird.
8) Cannot try outfits before buying them, also, overall, outfits lack variety and are ugly.
9) There are narrative arks, 4 to be precise with some minor details, with 2 extra directions per arks. Yes, what you do or don't do will reflect in an end cut-scene, but overall, this game's choices and possibilities and scenario play-out are flat, predictable, uninteresting and honestly, not real choices.
10) Voiced protagonist : some people might think the opposite, voice protagonist means more engaging... Wrong, it means : it is more expensive budget wise to keep the same actor highers to do more lines, it means less possibilities in story deviation, it means a harder time for a player to project themselves as the character.
11) incomplete arbitrary broken skills and attributes.
12) Unnecessary and poorly developed romances.
13) Driving in general (akira motorcycle in 1st person perspective aside) is unpleasant and clunky.

The reason for my opinion isn't the game itself at face value, I've seen all of this and then some in previous titles yet enjoyed myself. My problem with this one is : the price and the lies (look up the history of it's PR campaign). In all good conscience, I cannot recommend this game unless on sale for 15.00 USD. What I mean to say isn't that it is a bad game, instead it is merely that I see the potential, but must live with the disappointment : 5/10 OR 2/5.

Cyberpunk 2077 is just on the cusp of incredible potential. The game once again showcases CDPR's knack for brilliant storytelling. This is one of those games where not only is the main story super immersive, but even some of the side questlines get you equally sucked in. There's a lot to talk about, so I'll try to break it into a few columns.

STORY: 
You are V, a mercenary for hire in Night City. When you [spoiler] botch a job with your friend that activates the construct of Johnny Silverhand in your conscience, [/spoiler] you are pressed for time as you hunt to find a solution that may save your life. As you dive deeper into Night City, your struggle transforms from something personal, into something much larger against a world that is dominated by corporate infrastructure. The main story is quite captivating overall, and while it definitely falls a little short in Act I with some of the introduction content, it ramps up quickly as you move into II and III. There are a huge number of side quests and gigs to complete around the city, a lot of the side quests prove to be captivating and a nice break from the torment of V's struggle in the main story. A lot of the gigs and POI's feel like busywork at times, but they are nice pickups if you need eddies or upgrades.

GRAPHICS:
Honestly, despite controversy, Night City is beautiful. Admittedly, you need a pretty tough PC to run the game comfortably. I am on an RX 6600, with a mix of medium/high and ray-traced lighting enabled, and it's been a perfect combo to keep at or above 60FPS. I believe the game has some sort of minor memory leak, as FPS dips a little lower after playing for an hour or two, but restarting the game fixes this. Optimization is not perfect, but there are a pretty wide array of options to help run on a decent variety of hardware configurations. 

GAMEPLAY:
It's about what you would expect considering the nature of the game. The first person perspective is a nice change as opposed to what Witcher 3 was like. Gunplay feels satisfying, but definitely could be better. Unless you scavenge a lot and get super involved with crafting, you'll find yourself using variants of the same few weapons throughout most of the game. Skill trees are really wide and diverse, and can even feel a little overwhelming in the beginning, but you begin to hone in on what skills you like as you take on more quests and understand the mechanics a bit more. The hacking is a neat little feature, but it takes a minute to figure out cyberdecks and such things. It's definitely a little more involved than say Watch_Dogs was, for example. Vehicles are... just okay. Driving feels fine, it gets the job done. 

Unfortunately, there are still a preeeetty big variety of bugs & glitches in-game. Between Steam and GOG I have put in a few hundred hours on this game, and have not had anything game-breaking, but there are small things that become an annoyance (i.e. objects glitching into cutscenes, visual noise, issues with vehicle spawns, etc) but you learn to overlook some of them. This is an area that could use improvement, though. 

Overall, Cyberpunk 2077 is a deeply immersive experience that is soured in some ways by the limitations of the bugs and glitches it continues to face. The story is rich, and will suck you in pretty quickly, and will keep you coming back for more. If you are patient with the story and the gameplay, you will begin to fall in love with the potential that CDPR has enveloped this game with, and though it may have faced a rough release, you can see the vast amount of care that was put into what exists in the game. Hopefully it will continue on its roadmap to improvement so more and more people can enjoy something that was clearly worked very hard on.

This game is extremely fun, and at least to my knowledge after two playthroughs (admittedly, I haven't played the last mission on either playthrough because I literally just don't want the story to end because it's that good haha) I feel like they have patched out at least 90 percent of the game breaking bugs as I haven't yet encountered any. WARNING: SPOILERS

TLDR: don't spend a lot of money on it and don't expect it to be fully finsihed, devoplment was deffintly rushed but i'd recommend it if you want a time killer with amazing(but buggy) graphics and a even better main story. Do be warned it will crash a lot on lower end computer though.

Two and a half playthroughs in and I still love it, BUT and a big BUT, there are some issues. And since GTA 5 is the only other game I can really compare it to I will be using that comprison a decent amount. And keep in mind I purchesed Cybperpunk while it was on sale so I'm looking at it just for it's marriets.
P.S I have dyslexia so some spelling and grammar issues will be present. 

THE GOOD;
I'm going to talk about the good first as there is a little bit more to go in depth than the bad. 

For one as a LGBTQIA+ member it feels so much more inclusive and welcoming than say GTA 5. There is something for pretty much everyone and the community is so much better. 

The game play really can be what ever you want, my first playthrough I blasted through and killed everything and was done in less than 20 hours. My second I took way more time, I looked through night city, I figured out how to actually be stealthy, I romanced Judy, I talk with Silverhand alot more, and I could go on. The playthrough I'm on right now is to visit things I never payed attention to and get the secret ending, and so far I've decided to pump my strength stat and barely used my guns. 

I love the fact that while what you wear does affect stats you can all so wear what you want and upgrade it. Along with the fact that clothing has alot more meaning and even if you cant join the gangs in night city you can dress like and get along with them.

And on the note of gangs they all feel so much more alive, the chatter between gang members feels like they are not just bullet sponges. And all of the gangs have unquie styles and motives. It's very diffacult to mistake one gang for another. Even with scavs and malstrum looking similar far away you can tell them apart easy up close.

Even on easy and normal the action is lovely and bosses still pose a threat espcailly if you havn't fought them before. The cut scenes do feel a bit odd at times and Judy's BD tutorial segment should be skipable, but other than that they are generally great.

The main story has made me shed a few tears once and tear up alot, the relationships with npcs are great and quests you expect to be short boring quests can turn out to be a whole lot more indepth than you thought. And things I thought they wouldn't go through with showing like the quest line with River Ward end up being insane and it feels like you are in a horror game.

THE BAD:
I'll mostly be talking about surface issues that as of time of review could be fixed/improved apoun.

Cyberware could deffintly be better, and i'm talking mostly in the phyical changes area. It was a MASSIVE let down that I could not chrome myself or get protechtics, I do understand that these are large diffaculty to put in and not super important but I hope that you can at least do this in the multiplayer. 

As many other reviewers say, the back ground paths don't really matter. They make some diffrance but the street kid path changes virtually nothing and the corpo path has the best opening and best diologe choices (in my opinion, but than again this entire review is my opinion) and the nomad has a great bond with Jackie (when I get to panamas quest line I will update you) but other than that it really dosn't change much.

And the cops don't do much in the game.

AND THE BIGGEST PROBLEM, the bugs and visuals. For one you can't turn down the quality any lower than low and even low looks amazing but breaks my computer. But I have seen the fallowing bugs:

-Panam hold her rocket luncher after fireing at the AV
-everytime i'm in a car with a NPC they're skin flickers in and out of exsitance
-Panam T-poses while in the tank sometimes
-Corposes stand up and do idle animations like they are alive
-T posing enemys when the walk up and down things them
-Adam Smasher standing still during a portion of the fight
-Falling through the map (only happened once but still)
-If I change through menus to fact it crashes my game
-Shadows T-posing
-Infitent falling after hitting a curb while running untill i jump or stop
had a rough launch but it has improved a  ton if you like looter shooters give it a go

This is a hard review to write, I genuinely wanted to like this game.  Great plot, great graphics (when they work) and a good time.  Why not recommend it?  It's still pretty buggy, and you can see the great game underneath, but it's still not there.

The positive side of the game.  The plot is A-One, fantastic, like good cyberpunk harkening back to William Gibson's Neuromancer from 84, the game asks some pretty heavy weight questions behind the glitz.  A permanently wired society is part of that equation, and no more starkly does the comment Gibson made in a documentary seem more relevant here "Technology is man's way of pretending to be social meanwhile perpetuating his loneliness", something to that effect (It's spray painted in the movie "No Maps for These Territories" on an underpass).  You are extremely connected but very very lonely.

Graphics, when they work, are stellar.  Game physics, when they work, are stellar.  Graduated skill tree is great.  Going to the ripperdocs (something my kids take to calling all doctors now) is interesting.  Hacking seems quite natural in the middle of combat.  The cars are pretty awesome as well, you can see Bugatti Veyron's/Audi concept vehicles pointing through the custom game models.

The bad.  This game is buggy cheese.  I couldn't finish it, one quest that requires a specific sequence of saving then loading at an early point in the game basically killed the game for me.  I leveled up thinking I could go back and finish.  I did, game borked, one quest that prevents the sequence for finishing, a quest that won't activate until that quest is done and the final confrontation is all dead.  So I roam Night City a feared vigilante buying all the cars.

Drive to fast, game can't keep up (I'm on an average machine that being said, it's a ASUS ROG 4 years old) and you dive into the nether world.  Run too fast, game can't keep up.  Wrong angle, can't pick up the dropped item.

Quests are pretty hum ho.  Interesting where stealth is a greatly rewarded option is good, moving the game from mid range to much much harder.  The overall quest variety is pretty run, kill, steal for the most part.  It would be nice to have quests where you don't have to pray and spray to finish.  Build something, start a festival, have better talk me out of the situation options.  

MY BIGGEST ISSUE:  I don't know why game developers, and CD Projekt Red isn't the only, choose to have an entire illicit and graphic option to the game.  Seriously public nudity, hookers, strippers, sex scenes adds nothing to game.  Where Duke Nuke'em from back in the day had strippers it was a novelty, maybe occasionally fan boys liked to see some boobs.  But a system of hookers that I can solicit and then use.  It's depressing to think this is a feature in the game that adds nothing to the game overall and detracts from playing with certain people.  The nude model choices as you clothe various armor and guns is dumb.  

Maybe I'm just old and jaded but it's out of hand and doesn't do anything in a sex saturated society anyway.  Plus I'm sure the time the developer took to making a sex option would have been better spent , say releasing a finished game.  

Or take it the other way, make the sex solicitation a part of the game system where you can buy and sell your body for money.  At least then people can learn the depressing and harrowing adventures of sex workers and the dangers of sex trafficking instead of glorifying the act of being a John.  At least I can have homosexual encounters including heterosexual encounters I guess is a step in the right direction.

Final Verdict: Don't buy this game, wait until it's patched at least version 1.6 or higher.  It's still far to goofy to play in the state its' in.

Edit: 1.5 is pretty decent.  Still the cars are goofy when driven however overall certainly improved the overall game play.  I'd still wait a patch or two, but if you want to long haul and see the changes, getting this now is alright.  The endings are quite bitter sweet.

Don't believe what YouTube and the news told you last year. 

This game is a 9.5 out of 10. 

The world is the best written I have ever seen for a video game. I'm talking better than the likes of Final Fantasy X and Horizon: Zero Dawn. The voice acting is incredible. Your character's story is nothing short of one of the best character narratives ever seen in a game. You ever do a deep-diver on a famous comic book character? Like Wolverine? Deadpool? Or Spiderman? Like really gone deep into their lore and seen their most spectacular moments? That is what V's Story feels like. 

Nothing feels watered down, nerfed, or censored either. This game doesn't feel like it's trying to be safe, sanitized, cater to a particular narrative, or be politically correct and that is SUCH a breath of fresh air in this day and age. (Side-note, this game was green-lit and started production almost a decade ago... We may never see anything like this again.)

The setting amazing as well. Night City is one of the most spectacularly executed worlds I have ever seen in a game. And that's not a surprise, the creator of the Cyberpunk franchise Mike Pondsmith has been writing this material and this universe for 30 years and it definitely shows. And the fact that he signed off on most everything in this game... Is a really beautiful thing. 

Keanu Reeves as Johnny Silverhand is literally breathtaking. He's deranged and unhinged but the more you see the universe he lives in and the more you learn about him, the more you understand why... He's just not psyco for psyco's sake, he actually has reason for it. He does do some terrible and inexcusable things but... Damn if it he isn't at least well written and interesting. 

Now, the only major flaws- 

The bugs- Yes, they exist, but in it's current state, it's no less buggy than most open world games. I had one side-quest bug so I couldn't complete it on my second playthrough. I had the occasional random item I couldn't pick up, but it was never anything important.  And I had one or two wonky cutscenes where characters would T-Pose over two playthroughs. That was it. That was literally it. 

Now... The real flaws... Combat- 

KEEP YOUR DIFFICULTY ON EASY. Why? Because the moment you turn it up LITERALLY EVERYTHING turns into a bullet sponge. And it's not just early game when you have crap guns either, it's literally the entire playthrough that'll be like that. You see that "Moderate" danger job on your police scanner? Yeah, every single enemy takes 15 bullets to go down. And the "High" danger ones... You'll run out of ammo fast doing these even on normal. And the really annoying part is that it TAKES FOREVER. I got to the point where I could do moderate danger jobs no problem but I just got tired of literally everything being a 10-15 minute firefight. It was annoying, so I turned it down. I'd definitely call that a balance issue... 

And I have more knit picks... The guns weren't quite futuristic enough for my taste. Okay, I know we're not THAT far into the future but some more lazers and Star Wars-esque blasters would have been appriciated. Again though, this is more of a knit-pick than a real issue. The guns that we got are really damn cool and the futuristic ones that are there are rreeeeaaallllyyy good. Yes I was mildly disappointed, but what was there was just fine. 

Also, I din't much care for the melee combat either. I ran Monowire and while it was supposed to be the "highest damage" melee implant... It felt lackluster. Especially since I had actual baseball bats that were more powerful, and Katanas as well. I felt like since implants are such a big deal, that they should be HELLA OP, and not feel like a regular pocket knife. 

But again, these are knit picks. 

This game is AMAZING. It's the best game I've played in years and judging by the circumstances surrounding it's creation, we're not gonna see anything like it again for a long time... 

Play it. Just play it. The media lied. It's amazing. Play it. 

Thanks for reading!

There's bits here and there to love about this game, but they reside in an ocean of problems.  It would be almost understandable and forgivable, if it weren't for the fact that a year later, nothing done post release has improved things.  Specifically I mean, Janky physics, poor animations, no graphical optimizations whatsoever, side storylines that just stop (I'm looking at you Mayor), lack of meaningful choices (in a game where your choices "matter"), and forcibly linear missions (which limit usable builds on higher difficulties).  I'm sorry to say this game has been a mismanaged mess on par with EA's Anthem.

CDPR should take this as a lesson, substantially downsize your marketing team and focus on making good games.  You should have had more developers than corporate cheerleaders involved.  It's clear the PR engine oversold this game and it's equally transparent they misrepresented the game willingly.

I've long since stopped buying games on release. Partly because of the plethora of bugs new games seem to have these days, but mostly because I'm cheap. And I don't generally follow the hype leading up to a release either. (Many YouTubers seem to enjoy nothing more than ruining shit for subs and views these days.)

What all of this means is that I had very few expectations, picked up the game for 50% on Steam in December, and went into it with patch 1.3 from the get-go, on a 5 year old PC (i7 & Nividia GeForce GTX1080).... and I'm enjoying the @#$% hell out of it!

Does it have bugs, oh yes, there are bugs. A car here and there floating two feet of the ground, which you can get into but can't drive. A invisible car in a junk yard that hopefully one day I'll be able to scan and check under the hood. The odd roll of eddies I can't pick up, and -rarely- a character's hair, clothes and skin textures glitching during conversations. 

But none of this bothers me too much. The musical score is excellent, the characters are likeable... Judy, Panam... I'm looking at you... and the storyline keeps me engaged. The city is beautifully made, and I've run into some truly hilarious conversations between NPC's while exploring on foot.
It's a great game. This is up there with the Mass Effect series. Can't wait for the DLC.
It has it's problems and disappointments but overall it's a really good game. 7/10 normally with a good PC to run it, 9/10 with mods.

Visual wise, it's hands down the best looking game I've ever played, granted I have hardware to run it at max settings. 

Good main mission plots, but side missions were much more interesting to me. The choices you make during the entire game play doesn't really seem to matter for the most part. You do get different endings at the very last mission, but still it's no RPG.

The city atmosphere, ambient sounds, combined with the visuals really makes it immersive, at first. It was disappointing to find that most buildings and shops cannot be entered and they really are just there as eye-candy. It would've been amazing to be able to enter tall buildings and go through each floor, but I understand that would complicate a lot of things. It's still pretty interesting to just walk around or drive around the city without interacting with anything.

The game has been out for a year now but there are still lots and lots of bugs. Most of them are minor bugs that are pretty funny to encounter, but there were several actual bugs that were game breaking and required reload. Was originally going to give it a negative review due to that but the side missions changed my mind.

Here's the list of bugs/annoyances I've encountered during my full game play v.1.31

- gun not firing while ADS (required reload)
- engaging in combat while driving in certain places, with no enemies around
- cops on you for every little thing, good luck driving somewhere without hitting a ped.
- nothing happening after 'waiting a day' for sidequest (time skip)
- NPC dialogue talking over each other
- certain NPC dialogue staying on screen if you walk away from them before they finish (reload fixes)
- audio bugs
	- radio not playing in certain vehicle
	- NPC dialogue not playing but can see subtitles
	- very quiet dialogue then very loud all the sudden and quiet again
	- no engine sounds, no door closing sounds, random.
- V's shadow T-posing
- objects floating 
- trees glitching out
- cars running into each other and merging
- unable to pick up things that I am hovering over, picks up other thing near it instead. (very annoying)
- terrible GPS guidance whether by walking or driving. keeps changing path and the lines don't follow the 
   road
- minimap being too small & zoomed in
- absolute clusterf- of the map.
- too dark in some places even with RTX off
- too bright while in first person mode in car rides
- NPC riding invisible car/bike while the actual car/bike is 10 ft in front of them
- FOV zooms in after waiting, reload fixes.
- Summoned car spawning in road above/below you if standing on multi-level road
- Summoned car not driving (destroying it and re-summon fixes)
- Summoned cars spawning on top of each other then popping out
- Weird shadow/graphics glitch that shades everything dark and continues when looking around
- Lots of minor visual glitches and getting stuck in random places

I love this game and look forward to future content and patches.  V's story is elegantly neo-noir, the supporting characters are engaging and empathetic with fully fleshed-out personal story arcs, and the world is rich and beautiful.  The subtle details are jaw dropping-  the reflection of light from a worn ceramic tile facade for example.  I've *seen* those tiles in *our* LA and could almost feel the layer of grime on the ones in Cyberpunk.  A random NPC kid sitting on a sidewalk.  He's playing with a gun and hides it under his jacket when you look at him.  The glow of neon through fog and cigarette smoke.  

Yes, there are bugs.  Yes, the vehicles are... tricky.  (adjust the steering gain in the settings and don't brake and turn at the same time)  Yes, the attributes and perks haven't yet hit the sexy synergy of The Witcher 3's system.

Yet.

If TW3 is any indication, CDPR will continue fine-tuning Cyberpunk for years to come and their efforts will be well worth it.

There's a lot of things that can be said about Cyberpunk 2077, and while I know that the release was a rocky start to say the least, I can happily say that they've patched up a lot of the game, and if you, like me, weren't particularly hyped up for the game before initial release, you'll enjoy the game just fine. Though I should say, the beginning of the game itself definitely feels ambitious compared to the rest and imo you will always pick up traces of these aspirations no matter what happens, and that will detract on some level from the enjoyment of the game, though not nearly to the point where it's unplayable/unenjoyable, it'll just leave you wondering what could have been.

I definitely did enjoy the game, but there are a few critiques I have that bug me, and considering it's easier to talk shit about things than it is talk good things about them, I'd like to get them out of the way. First of all, the story definitely feels, I'll say largely inspired by, Tales from the Borderlands, both are dystopian futureworlds where you play as a corpo/streetkid and have to deal with a charming and famous terrorist being stuck in your mind after a high-tech USB you insert into your cybernetic brain and they try to take over your body, one of your characters fall in love with a pretty and overprotective nomad girl with braids, one of the main characters has one fully metal arm, both are critiques of capitalism, and so on. I had kinda realized this shortly after the game released, long before I had bought and played the game, and while it turned out to be kinda true, saying they're the same story or that Cyberpunk appropriated the story mostly from them would be inaccurate, both stories have very different tones, character arcs, and endings, and you can tell this was meant to be a lot more tragic, artistic, and heavy. But it still ended up distracting me at times, and this is kinda what I meant with aspirations earlier.

I'd assume they were gonna have entirely different stories for each life path previously, would it have different, more inspired stories, because frankly as epic as the game is, sometimes I feel it takes itself too seriously, I've only played as a streetkid so far, but from what I can tell, the existing story would work best for either corpo or partly streetkid, nomad should just have been completely different tonally and be more about family, honor, contrasts to different ways of life, and traditions/abandoning them (this would be serious but not nearly as heavy and depressing tonally as the existing one), imo a lot of the later half of the story really works for the streetkid, as well as the very beginning, just not a lot of the parts in between, well except for the fact that imo the tone is completely off, for a streetkid it should almost be nihilistic, snarky, sharp, and somewhat light-hearted on the surface but perhaps the deepest and most depressing one, the flow of the story again works for them, imo the best ending makes the most sense for that character also, but yeah. I actually think the existing tone works best for corpo, and tbh the story itself too, though that's partially because I think the other two should have one downright happy ending among others, whereas corpo one should be pretty tragic overall. I doubt they can make major changes to the game and the story at this point, even with DLC, I personally kinda hope they pull off like a "Snyder's Cut" version of the game basically after a while where they release a version of the game that feels more like how it was advertised, but frankly as long as they keep giving the game support, DLC, content, bug fixes, and etc. I don't even care at this point.

I have a few nitpicks that I wanted to mention that I felt would have made the game better. Firstly, I didn't really like the overall plot and ideas surrounding the biochip and shit worked, and frankly considering as I said with regards to similarities to another game, they really shoulda relegated that main story to one background only and gone in different places, but that probably wasn't the plan for them, and it is what it is, and frankly I enjoyed Johnny's (Keanu Reeves' character) company enough in-game that even I'm eh on this. Kinda wish they also had different voice actors for different life stories, maybe it's too much but I feel as though having like the current guy for corpo, idfk Troy Baker for streetkid, and someone else for nomad, as well as with female counterparts, would have made it a lot more unique and interesting to play, but again might be asking for too much. Something else people kinda have issues with (myself included) that has translated over from the Witcher 3 is that you don't get to spend that much time with a lot of the side characters outside of their character quests, which are fairly short, and while I kinda get it, it doesn't really change the fact that it feels weird to not talk to Panam for so long and then just end up at the end of the game, they didn't really give enough time for some of the relationships to really build, and again what's there is alright, there just could be more of it or done in a way that is more satisfying.

Speaking of Panam and the end of the game, one of the biggest issues I might have with this game, and this is truly bizarre imo, is the side quest limit, or well, the lack of clarification on the game's part. What I mean is, the story isn't particularly long, and basically by the time I had arrived at the point of no return, ie the endgame, I hadn't been able to do a lot of the sidequests with Panam, Judy, etc. and initially I thought it was bugged or something as just doing more jobs didn't seem to work and the old reputation of the game didn't help, but I realized over time that basically you can take on only a particular number of side quests, and if you don't finish those assigned to you at the limit, you can't get new ones, and frankly I actually wouldn't really care otherwise if they had just FUCKING SAID SO CLEARLY EARLIER lmao. But yeah, it's w/e.

Anyway, now I'll go through some shit that I think is praiseworthy, and while this might seem shorter than my critiques, it's easier to criticize something wrong than it is to praise something right or well-done. On a technical level, outside of the bugs (of which most are gone but there are some here and there), this game is awe-inspiringly beautiful, mostly graphically but also to some extent in parts of the story too. The writing is pretty great and on point, ngl some parts of the story are definitely a bit too abstract even for my tastes but overall it's great, the characters are complex and interesting and dialog is good, though. I like the weaponsplay and to some extent melee combat, and I really wish there was more platforming involved in the game, not necessarily a vital part of it but a bit more of an option than it is now. Something else I really like is that you always do missions and play the game your own way, you're usually given multiple ways of doing something and I really loved the fact that they give you, the player, a lot of freedom with how you want to play, you can go in hard or stealthily, and play to your strengths (or weaknesses if you want to improve a skill) and yeah, I'd say everything outside of melee combat, which imo is a bit awkward at times and needs a little bit of work, is pitch-perfect in terms of gameplay. The missions, the gigs, and so on are fun and interesting to do, and traversing the world doesn't really get old, the game design imo is quite well done and kinda would give Rockstar's pretty much dead game design of having the player drive everywhere or call a taxi a run for it's money. The music is amazing, my main complaint would be where's the punk or the hardcore section cuz for a game named Cyberpunk it doesn't exist, but other than that there's not more of it/types of it, it's great. Overall, great game with flaws, 8/10.

I love the game and the characters, although I wish there was more options to the game, I would of liked it if you were able to save all of your missions and play each completed mission all over again, instead of saving each mission you want to be saved so it doesn't go away, other then the bugs I really enjoy this game, so far i'm still playing streetlife and I just enjoy it a lot and i'm really liking the interactions with all the characters, Judy is a personal favourite with her charming appearance, on going personality and accent, couldn't ask more for an engaging fun game

It's been nearly two full years since Cyberpunk 2077 launched, and I would say that at this point the game is finally in a healthy state.

Around the one year mark, I made a reveiw on the game voicing my concerns and dismay about the state of the game. I was excited for this game because I was a fan of CDPR. I played through all three Witcher games and loved every one of them. I knew this game had "trouble" at launch, so I waited about a year and bought the game on a half-off sale. I knew that the game had a couple of patches released that fixed some issues, but I didn't know just how bad it still was.

I sunk around 50hrs into the game before I decided to right a reveiw. I was upset that one of my favourite developers had hyped us up on false promises, and released an unfinished product, but I still wanted to give the game a chance.

A full year later, at this point in time I would say that *most* of the issues I took with the game have actually been fixed, so I feel the need to update my previous review. Regardless of community backlash, CDPR never gave up on the game, and has worked tirelessly to udpate the game into somthing close to what the original vision was.

Are there still issues with the game? Yes, but not nearly as many as before. Is the game? Absolutely, Cyberpunk 2077 is now one of my favourite games. Would I pay a full $80 CAD for it? Not at launch, but now in it's current state I probably would if I wanted it bad enough. I would encourage people like me who were originally unhappy with the game to give it another shot.

However, the storyline, graphics, and atmosphere of the game world was enjoyable enough for me to deal with the occasional game crashes and t-posing NPC's.

A lot of the side stories are very cool too, I plan to play again and do most if not every side story before the last main story line mission. the voice acting is incredible, so far I played as the female V and her VA is nothing short of amazing, one of the best I've ever heard, you can tell she put her heart and soul into it, it's sounds so friggin believable. I plan to play as the male V too, but I gotta say make sure you play the female version also, you really don't want to miss out on her quality VA, it truly is amazingly well done. Not taking anything away from the male voice acting just haven't heard it yet.

There are multiple endings, I got a pretty good open ended I think, I was told have fun with Johnny and do every mission you can with him and his old pals, and the ending will be better for you, well, mine was a decent ending I think, though I have no idea how it will play out in the DLC. 

In any case this game is harsh and the ending can leave you thinking wtf, did I win, did I win glory, what will happen now? It's a bit harsh the same way game of thrones is harsh, when it comes to death, I don't want to spoil anything, but I think this game is more about the journey and the adventure, and it is quite epic, rather than the ending. With that being said, I do hope the DLC goes in the direction I think it will.

The ending is definitely a huge teaser, the kind that may tick you off a bit because you're not sure exactly what just happened, but I hope in the DLC they give us total closure, one way or another, you'll see what I mean when you finally beat it, and you'll probably  be thinking what I am, god, I want to know now, stop with this anticipation already! Regardless, this game is amazing, if you like open world games, an intense story line, engaging characters with great voice acting, if you like sci-fi, get this game, you'll love it.

Most of the bugs and glitches that were incredibly abundant, have been fixed.  That said it has a real Rockstar game feel to it, like a very enhanced version of Red Dead 2.

The game - when it works (which is rare) - is pretty good. That said it crashed the first time I opened it, and has crashed maybe twenty or so times since then in the eight hours or so that I've been playing it. I've had to bug fix three or four game breaking issues where the game CTD without warning at certain points in the main story. Looked them up and they are bugs that have been in the game since launch and still aren't fixed more than a year later. 

If I hadn't tried so hard to get it to run based on how good I heard the story was, I would have returned it. Even on sale it isn't worth the money because it crashes so often.

Despite all the bugs and shortcomings that I am not gonna enumerate here (trust me - there's a lot!), I still love the game. It's one of those games with a story that so captivating - I don't know if I could compare it to Mass Effect, but it comes pretty close, in terms of how you grow attached to the game characters - it's refreshing! There aren't that many games out there that make you FEEL something about the game characters.

I've re-played the game, what, like, 2-3 times now, as different characters? And still - there are quite a few moments in the game that still make me choke up.

There have been a lot of negative comments about the game - and most of them are well deserved!

BUT!

Lets just stop griping about the technical aspects and marvel at it as a work of art! The music, the sound (yes, it supports Dolby Atmos, and if you have the equipment - you absolutely MUST turn it on!!!), the visual style, the voice acting, the characters, the story ark - all top notch! Technical department comes short, of course, but then again - look at HalfLife! People loved it for the story!

Of course I would love it so much more if it was, you know, actually FINISHED! But technical aspect is not all that makes a game a GOOD game.

I really, truly hope that CDPR hires competent developers (I hear they're hiring modders - good choice!) and finally makes it a game we've all been expecting for so long!

Is it still buggy? Yes. Is it unplayable? No. Is it worth playing? definitely. While Cyberpunk has a fair few issues that can be noticed, it still packs an enjoyable world filled with a decent story and great characters. And riding through the illuminating night city into the desert wasteland is without a doubt a true experience. 

It can not be overstated that the world in Cyberpunk is atmospheric and rich with personality. I would though argue that the intro (1st act) to the game is pretty bad in intriguing the player and plainly is not that fun. Do not assume that the intro reflects the whole game however since the main part of the story is a great experience. That experience is especially enhanced by the characters who are greatly written, humorous and interesting.

The most glaring problems will be a few glitches, t-poses and crashing that may happen. While for me I never experienced any crashing, even on ultra settings, there were a few instances of t-posing and characters glitching into each other. Other than that I didn't notice any major problem with the game in my 20+ hours and the majority of the bugs were located in the beginning and disappeared midway through the game.

In the end Cyberpunk is a mixed package but delivered when it matters most: in gameplay, story, graphics and characters. It is a flawed gem for those who love open world dystopian rpgs.

This is my third review for this game and none of them have been negative. This game is phenomenal and has so much potential for the game and future installments. 

In the beginning I never had experienced any issues with bugs glitches or anything and at this point they are dedicating all resources to this game and dropping support for previous gen, (which was probably more than 2/3 of the negative buzz around it.) 

The story is great, the characters are great, the graphics are incredible and so is the art style. 

With the release of redmod and a massive dlc in 2023 and continuous updates based on community feed back there is no reason you should not get this game. 

Mixes funny, dark, sad and gruesome story elements with characters and world space. From the cyber psycho encounters and back stories about corpo shady ways they deal with NC citizens to the side characters you randomly end up loving. There’s tons to do in this game. 

Not to mention the brain dances and shards that really are interesting and I hate reading in games, terminals in FO series for example. 

This game does a great job at creating the world and makes me hopeful for the future. 

If I had to describe it with 3 others games it would be dystopian future Witcher, gta and fallout pulled into one. 

Overall I would give it a 9.5:/10 and highly reccomend buying this game but CHECKING THE MINIMUM AND RECCOMENDED HARDWARE. If you have a system that can run it. 

Can’t wait for more from this game and I just started playing it again.

A shadow of what it could have been. Throughout your time playing you see little glimpses of what the game was supposed to be, an amazing in-depth RPG with one of the most beautiful and detailed worlds to date. But what you get instead is a barren wasteland of content, laden with bugs and glitches, many of which have been in the game since Day 1; all crammed into a game now marketed as just an "Action-Adventure".

An example of one of the many bugs you'll encounter. if you press any button whatsoever while answering the phone with Delamain (and I believe this can happen with other people too), his face will freeze in the top left and you will never be able to use your phone again. The ONLY fix that worked is to reload a previous save, and if you haven't saved for a couple of hours, you're SOL. In addition to this you can't interact with almost any part of the world, dialogue choices have little effect, AI t-pose constantly, Police are essentially non-existent since they've been reworked, driving is horrible, character customization is worse than decades old games when it was marketed as revolutionary and complex, locked to first person only, etc, etc. As a whole the game just feels empty and "dead", unlike competitors such as RDR2 where it feels like you're a part of a living breathing world. And really I cannot understate how many bugs are still in the game, it genuinely feels like what most games would consider to be a Beta version, instead of a year + since release.

And to top it all off, the devs are NOT making it better. The roadmap for improvement is continuosly pushed back (I think it has been revised 3 or 4 times now, each time simply moving the deadlines back), and each patch brings little to no changes whatsoever. The best that I can say about this game is the scripted cutscenes/missions are usually quite good, and visually it is stunning. I would not recommend that anybody buy this game now or in the future, it has not received the No Man's Sky treatment since release and I doubt it ever will. What a disappointment coming from the company that made The Witcher 3.
Catch it on sale and totally worth it, needed some patches at release but definitely worthy of the hours I put in.

Overall:
It's a very beautiful game with very interesting and somewhat touching storylines, with a lot of gray areas and interesting pointers, although the game fails in many aspects, and can be quite challenging to play (I'm not talking about difficulty). If you're looking for an interesting experience in a world that sometimes feels a little to real, join us, and enjoy. However, if you're looking for a well-optimized and enjoyable GAMEPLAY experience, you might want to choose something else. All in all a beautiful but irritating game.
- Rating: 6.5/10
- Recommended Purchase Price: $25,- and below

Pros:
- The game world is absolutely beautiful and well put together.
- Capture mechanics allow you to capture the beautiful world.
- The characters are well fleshed out and often feel like real people making real decisions.
- The story is very interesting, even if it feels a little short.
- Mechanics allow you to take both a combat-focused and stealth-focused route to many missions.

Cons:
- You cannot change your appearance, once you're done making your character without mods (except aparrel)
- Glitches and bugs often occur, ranging from simple ragdoll and movement, to teleports and sudden un-aggrevated combat and performance spikes
- Movement system and keybinds make the game frustrating at times (tapping the key once makes you move slightly; tapping it twice dodges you out in front of an enemy you're hiding from)
- Combat is an overcomplicated numbers game, forcing you to get better gear rather than becoming better at the game
- Enemies don't scale with you (at least not according to what I've seen). Instead they have set attributes and then the game "guides" you around the city, matching your level to the enemies (missions have an indicator telling you how challenging they are for someone at your level)
Incomplete but still great.
400+ hours in and I still can't get enough of the city. Sure it has bugs, it can be janky, but for pure open world fun in an aesthetic I adore it can't be beat.

Game is generally fun and many of the characters have fun dialogue, but it's really more of a looter shooter than the RPG it should have been. 

It feels silly to loot 15 of the same exact shotgun from the corpses of your enemies only to scrap them all to upgrade your own weapon, which also is the same shotgun. The weapon variety is weak and I feel like the game should have focused on cyberware utilities rather than upgrading weapons and armor. Many times, the only difference between two items is the stat numbers associated with them. They could have accomplished this by having one version of every weapon, maybe with one iconic version of each, and then letting skill, nethacks, and special abilities decide the rest of combat. 

Weapons aren't the only thing that there are too much of. Consumables litter the world of Cyberpunk. It makes sense that food would be readily available with the vending machines and whatnot, but they added so many different kinds of consumables that all do virtually the same thing. Meanwhile, some restaraunt owners will tell you about a specialty item they serve, only for them to sell the exact same crap the vending machine sells outside with nothing at all that separates them from other restaurants or vending machines.

Trying to play only as a nethacker is lame because higher level enemies will have insane RAM costs to cyberattack, and many enemies even at lower levels aren't connected to a network anyway. I feel like there should have been an implant of some sort that functioned like a PAN or WLAN that would circumvent people not being present on a network. Police, for instance, aren't hackable at all.

Because Cyberpunk is purely about damage numbers and upgrades, it's basically impossible not to get OP. The only thing that can really kill you are explosive propane tanks and cars, which for some reason deal infinite damage. By the time you reach the "no turning back" mission you should be able to crit on at least half of your shots with whatever gun you use primarily, and one shot kill the majority of enemies you face. It's more fun to just hop in a car and ram enemies, but your car will blow up if it gets shot at in combat at all which also happens to be the second possible way for you to die.

UPDATE after Edgerunners came out (which is an amazing anime btw, I'm impressed, and also after we got shows like Rings of Power, Edgerunners is like a breath of fresh air, like the purest air you can find) BUT:

After all this time, this game still has incredibly annoying bugs, like "Roach" still comes up flaming and hitting other cars or I get stuck by hitting some pole and I can't move my car so have to go away and try to call vehicle again. Not even getting to how stupid the AI continues to be, I expected full force development on this area after the huge backlash this game had at launch, but no, they don't care, traffic is dumb af, same as you'd play a 2000s game. I can compare the AI with an amazing game that came out 20 years ago, Vampire the Masquarade: Bloodlines, it was absolutely amazing back then but 20 years later we still have the same brainless NPCs hunkering down on the street for no legit reason. 
To give some example: I was trying to park my car on a sidewalk marked with a parking spot and a guy continued to walk into my direction so I stopped the car and tried honking. That did nothing, as the guy continued to walked unaffected until he hit my car and performed an animation as if I hit him instead and everyone in the area started panicking. 
On the other hand, I was walking down the street when a guy suddenly fell from the building with blood on the pavement and all and NO ONE on the street said anything. Yeah, makes sense.

Shame on you CD Projekt for not working on this idiotic AI behavior that completely destroys the hard-earned immersion. Completely lost all hope that this game will ever be as amazing as they first announced it.
But if you consider it to be a 2000s game with upgraded graphics, great story, great characters then yes, sure, it can be enjoyed. If you expect a next gen game, you'll be disappointed, sorry!

[b]tl;dr[/b]
First, I gotta ask the haters what other futuristic open world game with driving is better? The game pretty much came out as early access but this game is still amazing nonetheless. Don't let haters make hyperbole out of the bugs when the story is top-notch and the gameplay is enjoyable albeit you do need a good PC to enjoy the most out of it. Even 30 frames isn't enough to fully enjoy combat but you can easily beat the game no problem at 30 frames.

[b]Review[/b]
I beat this game with my old PC with a processor at least 1 generation below minimum requirements for the game and still got about 30 frames with little to no bugs (none game breaking) and still enjoyed the game on very hard difficulty. Then I played it my new PC and enjoying every little detail about this game on my quest to 100% and lore dive everything. Anybody complaining about unplayable bugs at this point needs to fix their own hardware rather than blame the game. Yes, there will be bugs but nothing that breaks the game (unless you're intentionally trying to break the game). Just ask yourself what other futuristic openworld rpg with driving mechanics are there?

-It's Skyrim in the future except with a much-more fleshed out character rather than the blank slate that is "dragonborn". Both of these narrative choices have their own pros and cons but for Cyberpunk it was smart to give V some personality with the player nudging V in a certain direction similar to Geralt in the Witcher series.
-Good gameplay, nothing revolutionary but a very solid experience. Whatever you like will find your style in both fashion and gameplay.
-Great story like seriously the one of the best of all time. I can't talk highly about how good and interwoven the characters are with the foundation for future content to be made which I hope for and will preorder in good faith.
-Bad Launch, that's corpotism and overhype for you. I came into the game with realistic expectations in terms of gameplay and graphical quality and I was not disappointed.


First of this is one of the best stories ever told in the history of video gaming. There is this and one other game (Red Dead Redemption1/2) are both games that could be adapted to high quality cinematic shows. That's how amazing the Cyberpunk story is. All endings are amazing. What I did was make a save right before the point where you decide between all the endings and replayed each ending from that save point. It was one of my favorite gaming experiences in history.

Still worth the AAA price-point. CDPR had to release this for two reasons 1)Stock investors getting greedy and wanting to push out a title for the holiday season and 2)the hype was building too damn much, any longer and people would have had the expectation that this game would solve world hunger and help you graduate college. As seen from launch reactions people already were expecting as much so in my opinion CDPR should have waited but I'm thankful I can at least try out the game earlier than expected and still enjoy it thoroughly.
Phenomenal. Curse the haters for influencing me to wait as long as I did. It's meeting my loftiest expectations and more.

I have honestly never experienced game breaking problems.  Great game, not perfect, but, did anybody honestly expect perfect.  The launch was, obviously shit (even though I had few problems) but now you have no excuse not to play the game. 7.5/10

I think the developer did a great job creating a game that was fun and enticing, with a great story that's easy to follow, but you can also go off on side missions which are just as fun. The only downfall is I wish it was open world/multiplayer but other than that this game is a blast.

After yet another play-through of the game after the 1.5 update which is essentially the game after yet another year's delay with extreme player testing and feedback. I find the game to be the same, it's an amusement park ride just like an Ubisoft game. All the money is to be on the screen for you the player, hence why anything worth seeing is plastered all over the map with markers, there's nothing to discover outside of what someone at CDPR wants you to see. This means there's nothing to discover years later by accident years or so later beyond easter eggs or things individual devs hid from everyone they work with or total accidents. There's no natural discovery since you're always following quest markers or being bombarded with calls to do a job you happen to be near as you make your way though the city. It makes things what ought to be entirely happen stance like the full metal monk or the talking vending machine feel off, because you're led there by the nose if you use the map for your next job.
It's like S.T.A.L.K.E.R. . Masterpiece, that promises too many.
