Did a 100% playthrough (all side quests, gigs, etc). I bought the game at the 50% sale that I've been waiting for because of all the bugs and problems at release.

THE CONS
The game still has some glaring and annoying bugs, some still gamebreaking (Delamain bug). A bunch of items just can't be picked up. Zooming in on traffic in the distance still looks god awful because you see the cars are just horrible looking "props". Driving on roads outside of the city just emphasizes this because cars appear in the distance but as you come close to them they disappear right in front of you cause there's barely any traffic outside of the city. My car still sometimes got stuck (mostly in the junkyard). Parked cars levitating in the air. NPCs appearing as if they're driving without their vehicles loading for 2 seconds. Live dialogue and phone dialogue happening at the same time. Items NPCs are using becoming clipped inside them. And so on. All this on a last-gen PC (5900x, RTX3080, 32GB of ram...)
The city sometimes feels empty, like nothing's happening. NPCs sometimes act strangely. Raytracing is cool and pretty, especially when roads are wet, but a pretty city can't replace a living city, and sometimes parts of Night City just lack... stuff. People, quests, traffic, anything.
The police is... just very bad. They start attacking you for no reason. Driving a car slowly and peacuflly? Yeah, gonna attack you. Trying to save civilians from some thugs and just passing over them with your sniper scope? Get a warning immediately. If you get a star, the police still spawns basically right on top of you. If you run away without killing any police and then come back in 40+ hours of playtime to that same spot again, you better be sure those same cops you spawned ages ago are still going to be there waiting for you and starting combat as soon as you appear nearby.
The gear aesthetics system is horrible, but I guess this doesn't need explaining to anyone who's played. Sometimes you really do end up looking like a clown just because you want to equip the best gear available to you at the moment.
In short, I'd say even this amount of bugs, problems or missing content is still unacceptable for a AAA game, but that's just IMO.

THE PROS
But hell, the story is actually so fucking good, especially toward the ending. I found the prologue kind of lazily shortened and unimpactful, but the rest of the story actually makes up for it. The amount of endings possible is amazing. Sure, not all your choices in all your quests are important, but man, the choices for the various endings are very impactful. When it ends, you just feel sad it ended and you're just hungry for an expansion-type DLC.
The city, despite of its many obvious flaws has so many beautiful areas which just suck you in. Just architecturally speaking, the city is convincing, impressive (both ugly and beautiful) and huge. It lacks more "life", not sure how else to put it. But man, the areas that do have life (the center of town, the park around Arasaka tower, the memorial around the tower, the industrial areas, the slums etc) are absolutely stunning. 
The music is amazing and I think anyone can find a radio station for himself. Storyline music takes the cherry for me though, especially the outro music, after all the important NPC "phone calls".
I'd say the world of CP has so much potential, it's ridiculous. It also makes me realize, even as an ungrateful gamer, how much love and effort has been put into the game. Even more importantly, I do think in many regards this game was too ambitious to be without any problems. Yeah, the CDPR corpos screwed the audience and the devs (as far as I can tell), but even 2 more years of development might not have made this game trully "finished". 
I do hope, however, that they do keep working on it and bring out all the potential it has. Fix bugs, add basic content, add some more life to the city and add more DLC storyline quests, this game can be truly amazing. Right now I'd give it a 6/10 and I can't recommend buying it for the full price. I bought it on half price and I'd say it's barely worth it. All of that combined plus the fact CDPR straight out lied about what will be in the game prior to release means I can't give this a "thumbs up" on Steam.

I didn't have high expectations going into this game but after 10+ hours i can say that this game is kind of addicting to me and i really really do enjoy it. The game play is very enjoyable and the story can be very moving.

I've been waiting for this game for many years. When i first heard about it i was sucked in immediately. I looked up the old tabletop references, waited for every teaser and trailer, and got the guide on release. I love this universe and the stories it holds.

That being said, after 100% and 1000+ hours of gameplay, this product falls very short of what was advertised. It's buggy, missing features shown in trailers, and after a year it has failed to get much better. I still have high hopes for what is to come, and truly believe this game can one day be one of the better RPG's of this era.

Why I recommend:
-The game world is admittedly shallow, but the writing and lore are deep. From finding notes on side missions, crimes detailing the events prior to the jobs and violence of those deceased or involved, to articles and "books" detailing the world and its politics. even the little things on the T.V. in game give you info on more of the world outside of Night City.
-The music is SO good. The fight music, radio, and the score. Even through all the hate this game has received, in my opinion, they nailed this and there is a reason this game was nominated for music if nothing else.
-The ability to hack as a whole works very well, and if you take the time to see your surroundings, you'd be surprised what is hackable. You can use these powers to not only harm your enemies, but confuse, immobilize, and even fool into falling into traps. It is a great feature to make you feel like a spell caster similar to other RPG genres.
-The crafting system is tedious to say the least, but it allows you to maintain weapons and clothing you find to be your favorite to be viable deep into the game. I've seen people wear ridiculous outfits for the stats and mods they can hold. If you craft the necessity to do this goes down tremendously.
-Finally, the story itself. It is well written, exciting, and dark. The characters are brilliantly portrayed. Although many complain that what you do doesn't much change the outcome of the endings. The way you interact with key characters you meet will change how they view you in the end game credits. I.e. if you were rude, cold, all about business, a friend, and how far down the line of quests you went with them.

Where you might find disappointment:
-Driving still has a lot to be desired. You can not shoot out the window of your car. Chase scenes and scenarios are non-existent. (well there are like two but still). Evading the police is as simple as getting in some wheels and driving a few blocks.
-The police A.I. is trash, even I can not speak any good to it.
-The game has gang like factions that you basically have no interaction with other than, pew pew, bang bang, zap zap. Here and there you have a side quest or story mission where you interact, giving you a small hit of role-playing with these factions, although they're few and far between.
-Performance of the game as a whole. (one day that might change.)
-The U.I. and menus are poor and take some getting used to.

In all I had a great time playing Cyberpunk. If you allow yourself to be immersed, explore, take time out to do some shopping in the world for gear and equipment, you will find stashes and Easter eggs that will tell of these little stories i spoke of at the beginning of the review. This game is far from perfect, and i wish the developers the best on making this game what marketing promised. Until then, buy this game at a price that seems fair to you. At this point I'd say no more than 30 USD, otherwise there is a possibility wishing you spent that on another game.

TL;DR
Cyberpunk is far from fantastic, but it is not terrible. Do not waste good money on it, wait for it on sale or buy where it is on sale. Features are to come, it will get better.

This is a *great* game.

Is it worth its full price? Hmmmm, no. 

If it's half price, buy it without regrets. Honestly the soundtrack is worth this game at half price. It's worth it just to grab a motorbike and fly around the city without fear of becoming a ticked box on an organ donation form, taking in the sights of this fantastically mapped out and put together city.

Does it still have immersion and game breaking bugs, 1+ years after release? Yes. Yes it does. 

Items spawning just underneath terrain textures so you *can't quite* get them? ✓
Terrain textures visually fighting over which gets to grace your screen with their presence? ✓
People and vehicles suddenly cycling through a kaleidoscope of colours for no reason? ✓
Game suddenly freezes and crashes with zero warning? ✓

Honestly, a game as ambitious as this, which is totally open world and filled with all kinds of little side-show curiosities, deserves a pat on the back. There are entire games that are sold *purely* around the driving mechanics that this game has. The firefights are more interesting, the action elements are better and the "open world" is a vastly more interesting place to explore than either GTA V or Fallout 4. 

I don't regret buying this game for one second.

While the history of this game is infamous, the nature of how the game came about is part the reason of how the game should also be played. Its based on a paper based TTRPG and not a JRPG - so part of the experience is how you choose to play. Its far closer to games like GTA than it is Final Fantasy, with a vast open world and a great setting. 

The main story lines lead to 5 different endings and yes, the choices you make only change that path so much. But the vast amount of side quests, sudden instances and achievable achievements is what has entertained me so much. Memories of cruisin' down the beach in Vice City listening to 80s classics has now been joined of screamin' down the main highway on my bike listening to Samurai.

Is it glitchy? Yes, but not so that its unplayable - yet to play a game that didn't act odd at some point.

But what is fun is to play how the character thinks - TTRPGs are all about immersion, and if you immerse yourself in this game you do get rewarded. A streetkid living by codes or an ex-corpo turned renegade out for revenge.. make the "Open" part of the world your own narrative and you will have fun.

Plus you get to meet a talking gun.. whats not to like there?
It may not have been what it was all hyped up to be but, it is still a good game with a great story.

After a year, I think this game is good. Still kinda runs like dogshit when you drive a car above 36 mph but runs fine when on foot. Sound and art design are the best part of this game. For example, some of the songs they made for the radio in this game has made it into my playlists on spotify, and Night City has too much detail and is easy on the eyes, especially while it's raining. The Writing and characters are a close second in the quality department. For example, I replayed through half the story as a woman just to bone Judy, and it was totally worth it. And the dialogue between V and Silverhand is a lot of fun. This game is not as bad as people say. Just buy it while on sale or something idk.

This game has vastly improved.  Even before they started working on all the bugs, the story itself is really good.  Having played Cyberpunk 2020 (the table top game), for many, many years, I was excited to see how well they portrayed Night City.  Oh, my god!  They frickin' nailed it.  The city is vibrant and really amazing, it's very immersive.  It's not perfect, the general NPCs are a bit too touchy, especially if your car happens to run up on the sidewalk (even if you don't hit them, they all run in a panic).  And, your car IS going to run up on that sidewalk because the driving is pure shit.  I highly recommend a motorcycle (you can get two or three for free), they are much easier to control -- or... get a car with a short wheel base, as they are better at hugging the road.  Every other car feels like you're driving a tractor trailer rig on ice.

That said, the actual gameplay itself is a lot of fun, and you have multiple approaches, knock em out if you want the no kill achievement; gun them down with some really impressive legendary weapons, many given to you as quest rewards (or just sitting out in the world waiting for you to come find it; or kill them with one of the many melee or blade weapons (which is another thing the devs did right, cutting someone's limbs and head off with a katana looks and feels amazing (especially if you get the Cyberware that slows time in combat.

There are still glitches, and a lot of items you cannot pick up because it's fallen partially into the floor because of a clipping issue... but those are becoming fewer and fewer as the devs plow onward towards fixing the mess they made at release.  However, the title is definitely worth the current 50% off for the Winter sale.  I promise that, once you get the hang of it, you won't be able to put it down.  I haven't... and there are tons of games that I think look great, play for two hours, and then put away never to touch again because they're hot garbage.  Unless you're a pedant who simply cannot shut up about things like frame-rate drop (which I've experienced none of with my GTX 970 and 144 hz monitor) or the few glitches left to be repaired, Cyberpunk 2077 is nowhere near hot garbage. It's actually a lot of fun and I can't recommend it enough.

Updated to Positive review post 1.5 patch and AMD Driver update 22.3.2:

It works now, all my prior issues have been addressed. 

The gameplay is solid, its basically an open world version of Deus Ex Mankind Divided with more augs to play with although you can only use one at a time with the rest being passive perks. 

You will be gate kept out from using said augs unless you can find a ripperdoc selling that specific aug and have the pre-requisite stats to suit your playstyle. I don't mind needing the right stats my issue is the RNG nature of the ripperdocs inventory. I would have preferred if some ripperdocs had certain augs fixed rather than fast travelling around the map praying to RNG jesus to get the one I want.

The story is good, you fight evil corporations alongside Keanu Reeves aka Johnny Silverhand. The main campaign is short but the value is in the side quests, Keanu appears more in those and the loot from them is worth it.

The RPG elements are weak for roleplaying, it makes little difference if you start as a Corpo, Street Kid, or Nomad aside from an alternate starting intro. There is still some texture pop in issues but its fine the in game cars are cool to drive if not a little floaty.

All in All its worth it I'd say.

I'm reviewing this game at a time when it's on sale for $30, and based on that number you should totally buy it. It's not the nightmare people say it is, especially at that price. Yes, it was pretty broken at launch and yes, CDPR did make a lot of promises they didn't keep. Everyone else has talked about that though, and I don't want to. I'd rather talk about enjoyment per dollar. 

So will you get your money's worth for $30 on this game? I think so. It's got a decent little storyline, though there are some plotholes. Some characters you'll like and some you'll hate. It's got a ton of sidequests that can keep you entertained. The combat isn't next-gen or anything but the gunplay feels tighter than other gun-based RPGs like Fallout or Outer Worlds. It's a really good looking game and there are moments when Night City feels truly alive. You're gonna have some bugs, but you knew that before you read this review. I didn't have anything that totally ruined my fun. 

Is it worth $60? Maybe not right now, but pick it up when it's on sale. It didn't live up to the Christ-like expectations that people laid upon it, but It's not total garbage either like some would have you believe.

I waited a year to buy this game. After the fiasco of the game's launch, I said I'd finally cave when it was either 50% off or reached "very positive" reviews on the Steam store. I'm glad I waited, but I'm even gladder I bought it. It's certainly rough around the edges but it's not really much worse than any other open world game with a scope this ambitious, and it's one of the best games I've played in quite some time. 

The game's flaws are mostly minor and cosmetic in nature like odd shadows, flickering lights, weirdness with the interface, and occasionally awkward NPC movement. On the flip side, it actually runs very smoothly with 
shockingly quick load times and not a single crash in 80 hours. 

The side content can get repetitive if you're going to spend hours hammering every marker on the map one by one, so I'd suggest just experiencing it as it crosses your path rather than trying to tick off every possible box before progressing the main story like I did. You'll end up overleveled and overpowered pretty quickly, even on the hardest difficulty. That being said, it's worth experiencing for the story alone, which is excellent. Extremely well-written and acted with the notable but charming exception of Keanu Reeves' performance as Johnny Silverhand; the guy's just not a good actor, but you can't help but love him anyway. It also has far more depth than I've seen some people give it credit for; it has many divergent paths and endings and while it might not offer as much freedom as a true CRPG it's easily on the same level as genre classics like Mass Effect.

This is a classic example of a game that lost control of its own hype train and suffered too much as a result, and it should stand as a cautionary tale of how not to market a game. It was never going to live up to the impossible expectations it had built up, but it's still one of the best RPGs of this generation. The fact that I just finished the game and am already eager to start again is a testament to its quality. Just be prepared to appreciate it for what it is, rather than expecting it to be something it's not.

Gunplay is top notch, and even though the melee falls kind of flat, it's still a good deal of fun to run around wielding a katana or mantis blades. Overall, they've done a great job of bringing this game up from the trash pile it was at launch. Kudos

I really wanted to like this game. I had just upgraded my PC, ready for the hype-train to swoop me away.

I've probably played about half the game, loads of sidequests, upgrades, missions and so on.

The combat feels like the later AC games with either bulletsponges or cannonfodder, and no real sense of immersion. For example, the mantis claws looked so cool, but then you spam the mouse button while slowly grinding down an enemy's HP bar while flailing what might as well be butterknives at them, and it's just so lame. The combat is less immersive than AC.

The sidemissions are often grindy and samey. Fetch and carry, go and kill, etc.

The street-life is stupid, full of the worst kind of bots. Police spawning behind you instantly, and disappearing as soon as you drive 2 blocks.

I didn't feel invested in most of the characters and when I might be near to immersion for a minute, the bugs would sort that out fast.

So yeah, I didn't finish the game (same as the last 3 AC games) and I don't really feel compelled to give it another go. It's just not fun.

Honestly speaking, I was very hyped for this game before release. I built up so much imaginary gameplay in my head, and I was constantly thinking about all the crazy stuff I'd get to do. Well, the game comes out and I play it day one. And despite a few weird visual bugs, I really had a great time with it. Played it for about 6 hours the first day and had to force myself to go to sleep. I played more of the game throughout the weeks and kept having a great time. I seem to have been lucky in that I haven't gotten many of the bugs that players have seen. As of Patch 1.3, this game is way less buggier than before. It runs like a dream so long as you don't crank everything to Ultra, and the gunplay feels really smooth and precise, with a lot of variety in the weapons themselves. Love all the cybernetics you can get, although I do wish there were more to choose from, and not just rarer versions of the same augments. The story seems to be hit or miss with some people, but I found the main story to be engaging and enticing, with me constantly wondering where it would go next. And every single sidequest in this game is amazing. Literally the best content in the game is the side content, all of it is fun and unique. Oh, and one item I don't think anyone disagrees on is the music. Every song in this game is incredible, and with some good headphones you really get into it. Finally, the game is graphically stunning.With the right setup, Night City is so cool to just drive around and look at. I know I brushed over a lot of topics in this review, and realty there are plenty of super in depth reviews on YouTube if you want the detailed breakdown of the game. But I would recommend going into it completely blind, as it makes the resulting experience that much better. I highly recommend Cyberpunk 2077, you will definitely get your money's worth.

There's still a few minor bugs in the game. But overall it's pretty fleshed out. Comparing to RDR2 and Witcher3 we're definitely lacking all of the nuance and the tons of side quests you can do, but that's trying to compare to the creme de la creme. By itself, well worth the price. Looking forward to the expansion.

So if you've never looked into Cyberpunk, never heard about what it was supposed to be or how much of a disappointment it was. Then it's worth picking up. I spent 136hr playing it and don't feel like I completely wasted my time. Just let down.
But if you have any idea about what was supposed to be. Then your entire play through will be plagued with "Oh I guess that's just not in here." We were promised the world and got a functional, but buggy sandbox. The character creator was supposed to be something like CodeVein but we got Skyrim. Stuff like the laser wire not functioning like it showed in previews. Items like the laser katana or Max Tac uniform being in game but having no way to actually get them, unless you mod them in. The story being cut down so Keanu had a way bigger part in it. No amount of patches and bug fixes will change what it was supposed to be.

I'm gonna write this after the new steam post by CDPR for the year of the game, and i say that left a rea bitter aftertast, considering the how much time passed since the last patch and this is all they did for the first year of the game.
But leaving that aside, the game has a really good story and many different character, maybe it's not as free as it was promised, but you'll have a great variety of choises that can make different every run you play but not to an increbile level, it's not a game which rotates so heavily on your decision and it only has that many finales.
The combat sistem is good and there are differet archtypes of weapons and fortunally they fixed the swords, too strong and you could go trought the entire campaine with just that, you could even find the strongest mantis blade in a chest from the start of the game.
The world if surely unique in that you can't find something like this at least at the moment, the city is beutifull at any time of the day you watch it and is more lively now than it was at the start of the game at least even if it's not as it should've been from the initial promise from CDPR.
The music is fantastic, and i say that cause for a long period i listened to it even when i was not playing the game.
The developers surely didn't have the greatest luck with their launch, but neither did they fix that much of the game, one example of that are the cop's spawns, they still spawn behind you, just a little further.
Apart from a tecnic view of the game all i can say is
I loved the game even throught the bugs, that i didn't find in the early version if i have to say it i found more bugs with each new version but not that many to mine the expirience, i loved the story and characters so much i played and finished the game 5 times and with each type of character you can create.
Hopufully CDPR will come out with a new uppdate to fix at least part of the problems and the dlc(cut content) they promised us in the past, but for now i'll wait and say that this game, even with the bugs and the delays from the developers, is a good game and not as shitty as the community make it to be, yeah sure the burn from the expetative and hype was hard but that was mostly due to the great hype generated before the launch, and it's not something that happened only for cyberpunk, take any CoD or this year's Battelfield for example.
That was all i could say for the game, all i can add is to try the game if you feel you could like it from someone you know who has it or buy it, it's on sale at the time of this review, worst case scenario you can return it.
In case you'll play it, good journey to you.

I was super excited for this in 2020, but following the intensely negative reaction to its release, I decided to hold off on diving in. Now, almost a full year later, I finally felt good enough about the state of the game to make the purchase (the 50% sale helped too).

I have to say I thoroughly enjoyed it. Not the most mind-blowing open world experience you will ever have, but it never stopped being fun, especially near the end where you are so overpowered that the NPC's just become your little play things, even on the hardest difficulty.

There are still plenty of bugs in there, but none of the game breaking or progress stopping catastrophes that people were experiencing months ago. You'll often find yourself unable to pick up items around the world, as they have partially sunken through the geometry, but this never happened to me with a quest critical item, ever. I also got into a car once, only to sink through it and into hell, but the game popped me back out into the street after a second or two. Subtitles from ambient dialogue, and audio/visuals from uploading hacks will frequently become permanently stuck on screen, but will always go away after a quicksave/quickload combo, something that only took a handful of seconds on my SSD.

Very fun game with compelling characters and an interesting story, especially if you play out all the Nomad quests with Panam Palmer. Just don't expect any kind of game play challenge. Treat it more as a fun exercise in how to creatively lay waste to hundreds of enemies with your expansive tool set.

It wasn't until my second play-through that I genuinely loved playing this game (and played it fully once more after learning there were several endings). I felt my first run-through was extremely rushed, didn't care about character development, and was reckless in my dialogue choices (it could be because I chose the corpo lifepath and wanted to be a d*ckhead intentionally). But with my second playthrough, I genuinely loved playing as Nomad V (Streetkid is also fun) because I felt more relatable to my character. Once I got the hang of the game mechanics, weaponry, and battles, the game was much more playable and fun. I was also very deliberate in my dialogue choices the 2nd time around and it genuinely felt like I was playing Cyberpunk for the first time because of how many different alternate reactions and dialogues there were with all of the characters. It was like familiar territory that I took for granted the first time and played it with fresh eyes and a pair of skilled hands the second time). 

I also did more side quests this time around; there are some missions in the game that are heart wrenching and are absolutely MUST-plays aside from the main storyline (I googled 15 Best Side Quests You Didn't Know About).  The original soundtrack was absolutely amazing and wished there were more throughout. I enjoyed many of the "Radio" songs but there are some songs the game could do without.

Overall, if you bought the game and didn't play it because it was crucified during its release, please give it another chance. Many of the bugs have been patched and the game is very playable, I experienced no game-breaking bugs whatsoever but a few minor glitches like every huge game has. If you were bored the first few hours, give it another chance as it is slow in the beginning but picks up a lot of speed once you master how the game works and are intentional about dialogue. If you like RPG, hella immersive world, gut-wrenching and mesmerizing missions, and a enjoy a realistic, future dystopian world (that could potentially look like ours if we keep up the horrible practices that we employ towards our planet), this is 100% the game for you!

I've owned this game since launch, and have never encountered a game breaking bug. 

That's not to say they don't exist; I'm fairly certain every game has them.  There's a fair share of obnoxious bugs; mostly involving being unable to pick up loot items.  Never around a quest item, or anything unique.

I've also heard people say that this isn't really an RPG, that no matter what you say it doesn't really change the plot.  While this is true, it's also true of almost EVERY game labeled an RPG.  Dialogue rarely has major effects on plot.  I would say that with the various choices you can make in the quests that this is more of an RPG than most can claim.  Is it perfect?  Hell no.

Next to the open world and feelings of emptiness.  The world is HUGE, and there are TONS of hidden items, events, and even quests.  Can you walk up and talk to random pedestrians?  Not really.  Do they have interactions in the world to give them life?  Some.  That being said, it's the same feeling in GTAV or any other.  It's all scripted, and if you look for it, it's easy to spot the holes.

Visually and aurally, the game is fantastic.  It runs great, looks absolutely amazing (especially the NPCs), and sounds great.  The music and voice acting are superb.  I couldn't disagree more that you don't feel like you should care about any of them.

The story is fun, and by that I mean it's engaging, twisting, backstabbing, and lovingly relatable.  I'll leave it at that.

As you can see, I've spent over 660 hours on this game so far, and not once have I ever regretted buying it.  This is also my first, and possibly only review.  Honestly, I don't put much stock in them, but I did feel that this game deserves defending, even if no one listens.

Like many others, I hesitated to buy this game based on the numerous issues it faced at launch. I finally gave it a chance during the Black Friday Steam Sale, and wow, am I glad I did.

Cyberpunk 2077 is probably the best game I've played in 2021.

[h1] PROS [/h1]

[b]STORY[/b]: If you're patient through the many, many hours of dialogue, the story and character depth make for an incredibly rich experience. The "side" jobs allow you to add layers to several important characters, and I enjoyed these as much as the main story. The main story features several key decisions throughout that shape the player's outcome.

[b]SOUNDTRACK[/b]: I loved the original score played throughout the main story and will definitely listen to it outside of game. The radio stations were good, but each station only having 10-20 songs will lead to the in-game radio feeling repetitive without jumping around.

[b]GUNPLAY[/b]: There are a lot of weapons in the game, though there were only a handful that I really enjoyed - primarily a few pistols, assault rifles, and the sniper rifle you earn through the main story. I'll likely play around with other builds during future play.

[h1] CONS [/h1]

[b]REPLAYABILITY[/b]: While there are a handful of very consequential decisions V makes throughout the core story, they mostly impact the options available for the player beyond the point of no return in the game's ending. Most side jobs are shorter and more linear, and gigs and crime reports are mostly "go to this place" -> "steal this thing" OR "kill a few people". Once you've tackled these once, there's little incentive to want to repeat.

[b]DIFFICULTY[/b]: If you regularly play FPS games, Cyberpunk 2077 will feel like a walk in the park. Once you level and upgrade beyond a certain point, you'll melt basically everything in the game. I didn't mind this given my interest in the story, but the lack of challenge will likely deter people from wanting to do additional runs.

[b]BUGS[/b]: There are still some bugs present throughout the game, though none were game-breaking and were generally resolved by reloading. The majority of issues I encountered were related to vehicle movement and boundaries, though there were also a few rendering glitches.

When I originally played Cyberpunk a few months ago I wasn't the biggest fan. I thought the story was bland, average gameplay, and the overall jank the game has dragged it down for me. However, I did enjoy the world, characters, and RPG elements. And after coming back to Cyberpunk, I have changed my mind about this game. The story is great, the gameplay is incredibly fun, and yes, the game is still janky as hell. It can be a bit jarring at first but after a few hours in the game and with the help of a few mods, you'll soon get used to it and it will barely affect your experience later down the line. The world is phenomenal, I love the art style, world building, and activities in the world. However I do think the world lacks interactivity. Cyberpunk, unlike The Witcher 3 is missing a minigame. And as a huge fan of minigames in RPG's, this was a huge bummer as it doesn't only give the player more to do in the world, it can also help build the world and give it more personaility. Now i'm not saying the world doesn't have any personality. Far from it in fact. But it would help to introduce a form of board game like cards, dice, etc. But apart from that I think the world is almost flawless, I love everything about it. From the unique terms like "choom" or "gonk". To the layout of the city. It is so much fun to explore. All the activites in the world are a lot of fun to do and part of the reason they are so fun, is because of the gameplay. The gameplay I originally wasn't a fan of but I have changed my mind about it heavily. The guns feel really satisfying to use and considering this is CDPR's first fps game I think they absolutely nailed it. The quickhacking also adds a lot to the gameplay loop by encourging stealth and strategy into the combat. The skill tree is huge and also encourages different playstyles, I personally played more tacitcally and tried picking off enemies from a distance, but I also tried using the double jump upgrade with a shotgun and playing it like it was Doom. Both playstyles were viable and in general I think this game is pretty well balanced. There aren't many playstyles that stand out as too overpowered or too weak and the build variety is really strong. But now for the story, I personally love it. My biggest problem with the story are the choices, and how the mostly don't matter. The lifepath you pick is pretty much pointless apart from the first hour of the game, and a few unique dialogues. And while there are a ton of endings for the game, they are only decided in the last 2-3 hours of the game which I found really dissapointing. However the endings themselves are all really satisfying and wrap the game up nicely. But apart form the choices I think the story is actually really good. I love the premise and although at times the plot can be pretty confusing. If you stick with it long enough I think you'll really enjoy it. The voice acting and animations are also top notch. Probably even the best animated faces I've seen in a game. It's not as good as motion capture but it sure comes close. And the voice actors are killing it in their roles. V, Johnny, Judy, Panam, Evelyn, Jackie, and Takemura especially. The voice acting and animations really make the characters come alive and the great writing helps a lot too. But most people are worried about the bugs, and to be honest they aren't that bad. I think the biggest issue isn't really with the glitches but more the over janky-ness of the game. It's very rough around the edges and can be a little off putting at least at first. And while a lot of people complain about the driving I actually don't think it's that bad. There are also mods that improve it if it's really bothering you but after a few hours I got used to the driving and found it to actually be pretty decent. However my biggest problem with the driving are the cars themselves. More specifically the way you buy them. I HATE the system in place for buying cars. The way it works is, you get occasional messages from people that tell you they are selling a car, you don't get to pick which car it is, or even which colour it is. You just get messages showing you a car for sale and you can purchase only the cars you get in those messages. Why is there no dealership I can go to? It would not only be more immersive but way more convinient. As in game I can never choose which car I want and instead have to wait hours hoping I get a message for a car I like. It is frustrating to say the least. Also the cars have no customization at all. I can't change the colour or tune the car in the slightest. Another huge issue with the game is the AI. The AI is god awful and is one of the worst I've seen in a game period. They are incredibly inconsistant and will react to things they shouldn't react to, and not react to things they should react to. Its terrible and can ruin the immersion at times. And overall this game lacks a ton of systems that should be in place but aren't and it can be pretty off putting at first. One last thing I wanted to mention was the soundtrack. I fucking love the soundtrack for this game. CDPR don't miss when it comes to their OST's and this is no exception. It really gives the game even more life and personaility. Wrapping up, despite the games problems, if you stick with it, give it a few hours and you just might fall in love with the world and story this game has to offer.

Cyberpunk 2077 is a great game and is worth your time spending in a beautiful world with fairly interesting narration/story-line and gameplay. The execution of the release was poor, I believe there was just a huge problem with the hype, both in terms of how the potential players dealt with it (by being really demanding and impatient) and the dev company responding and honestly looking like they wanted to profit off the hype before it died down (by rushing a release out instead of a complete and competent game product). Good for business, bad for image. 

They also made several poor decisions on other platform releases (like the PS4 and Xbox One versions for the game which suffered the most in player reception), it would've been best for them to not even try to sell on those platforms. But back to this review which is specific for this game on steam and pc.

The game has good and interesting mechanics. There are also interesting choices to make for the player. And the game play design is solid. The exploration elements/items/objects are also neat. The world, however, certainly feels very trapped in and small and almost sandbox-y. Initially, I wasn't hoping for the game to be a hack and slash (during the first few teasers), but they made it work really well and that is impressive. They certainly lived up to good RPG elements and really took us down a good cyberpunk age/aesthetic road of how we might imagine the world to be in such a time/era.
The crafting system here feels like a lost cause because of how the system has been made, despite being properly functional, there's simply just no real reason to use the system when you're better off looting and shopping for the stuff. Of course certain things you might only get through crafting, but there's still no real point to it (since some items in the same category and tier are equally as good or better when you come across them without crafting) and I think the devs could have used that time to spend it on other areas of the game and improve it overall. The Spiffing Brit has a good youtube video showing off an exploit to show how redundant the crafting system is and can easily be exploited for monetary (credits) benefits.

Ultimately, here are the scores and TL;DR.

Great game for PC, as of the current patch there are no major game breaking bugs and very few minor bugs that I know of. Personally have not encountered bugs since launch (except for a few minor ones). It is a good investment, it will give you a fun time if you're somewhat into RPGs and Open World games, don't get into it though if you can't stand the Cyberpunk world/concept. It certainly proves its worth as a Triple-A title.

I really, really wanted to love this game.

Unfortunately, I just can't.  I have tried 4 times to get into it and can't bring myself to.  I got the game on release, and actually didn't have too many bugs.  That first playthrough was my longest but only ended up being 6 hours or so.  I just... Lost interest.  Every playthrough since that one (started over again for each of the "game changing fixes") had been less.

Basically, I think this game tries too hard and dabbles into too many things at once.  Night City itself is a fascinating concept, but the game world feel empty.  All the NPCs that roam around are completely useless, making their unique and "futuristic" character designs seem silly to me.  The city is very large, so to immersively get around you need to either run around and parkour, which can be fun but takes a while, or drive... And the driving is TERRIBLE.  Also, you are constantly bogged down with notifications.  The mechanic of using the "phone" to call or message other relevant characters is realistic, but the number of notifications is just too much.  Seems like every 5 minutes I'm getting a text about a new job or a call from some character I met once and don't remember.
The story seems interesting but it didn't overcome the rest of the downsides.

Honestly the combat is pretty entertaining, hacking your enemy's cybernetics then running in with a power shotgun or katana just feels cool to me.

If you're going to focus on combat, this is a fun game.  If you're trying to just enjoy an immersive cyberpunk world that feels alive, then I don't think this is the game for you.

One of the best games I ever played. Preordered it, completed it with all the bugs and replaying it now year later. Didn't disappoint back then, nor now. Devs were just in a hurry, so nothing else to expect from a rushed publishing. Most important that game is being fixed and improved.
The plot is just brilliant, side missions are always interesting. Upgrading is interesting. Sound and music are top notch. Graphics excellent with RTX.

There are things that bothers me regarding the visuals. Rain looks weird as drops doesn't hit the wet streets, drops just disappear. I think RTX was implemented best in Watchdogs Legion, city looks very realistic. Other imperfections doesn't matter, perhaps CDPR will hear their fans out and improve those details.
Decent story and runs reasonably smooth on a RTX 3090. Definitely still buggy though, but nothing game breaking.

This game is really amazing. The atmosphere is immersive and enchanting. The characters are all well-developed. There are still a few buggy things like people walking through cars, but overall, it's great, and I hope the devs continue to iron things out and give us more DLC.

This is genuinely a great game. The writing, storytelling, and visuals are top-notch, and there is plenty of variety and content for gameplay. There are most definitely still bugs, and some elements of the game which seem irrelevant, but considering the sheer scale and level of detail, I'm not surprised that they couldn't flawlessly execute everything they set out to. I'm just appreciative of what's here.

I only was just, unexpectedly, able to get hardware powerful enough to play this beast of a game and so I wasn't waiting for it to come out for years, like others were. I think so many players were disappointed with this game because of the buggy release a year ago, and some unmet expectations. I can totally see how avid gamers would project their wildest dreams onto this game and be disappointed that it was made by lowly humans in the past decade.

Anyway, well worth the asking price, even if not on sale. I'm almost 40 hours in and I don't think I'm halfway through the main content yet, and there's hella more supplemental stuff I've barely gotten into. The visuals are stupendous, especially for some places at some times of day with certain lighting--it almost feels real. So worth experiencing. The whole experience is as immersive as I think a non-vr game can be.

The game will never be finished/fixed, no reason for CDPR to do that once they patch it just enough that people will buy it and they make a profit. Probably the only reason I won't recommend this game; however, if you can acquire it otherwise, it really is enjoyable with a few dozen community mods. Combat, driving, even the audio mixing are all terrible in vanilla, though I feel the story deserves to shine through the muck. It was a well-made, immersive production with fantastic actors and animators that truly carried the whole game.

As for how the game looks, I can't say much since my computer can only run 40 fps at the lowest settings. Night City was gorgeous and I found myself nostalgic to my first visit in downtown LA, but unfortunately its terribly underpopulated for its size. A mile wide and an inch deep, I didn't find much reason to explore beyond following "unknown event" markers on the map.

An amazing game, really doesn't deserve all the hate it gets. It's launch was dreadful and there are still a couple of issues, but the game has come a long way since then. The writing is excellent, the characters are deep and complex, the world is layered and the lore is fantastic. There are multiple approaches to basically everything, including options not presented to you directly (which I guess a lot of people missed). The combat is not revolutionary but damn good for an open world action RPG.

Brilliant game. Can't wait for DLC.

The game has been out for 1 year already, but it is still littered with bugs which break quests, get you stuck and overall break the immersion of playing in this world. The world itself is good, but technical aspects of it make it worse, like the way weather is calculated will lead to it being sunny 90% of the time. In 14 hours of gameplay I saw rain twice and acid rain once. Mods fix some of the annoying parts, but they can lead to even more bugs.

If you're going into the game thinking its an RPG - don't. It's an action story game with elements of RPG progression (skill tree). Choices that you make don't really matter and there is often only a single outcome of the storyline and/or quest. Lack of third person view and even barbershop to change your hairstyle halfway through the game makes it very boring from "dress-up" perspective. 

Wait until all DLCs are released, bugs fixed and community does all the work CDPR should have done in a form of mods and only then get the game at 50+% discount.
Not a bad game, just not at all what was promised. Blatant lies and false advertising. If you know nothing about CP2077 or its false promises, go ahead and buy.

This is not a bad game. It's just incomplete.

There's an underlying technology here that promises some pretty impressive things. With a good rig, this game looks gorgeous. Neon streets in the rain conjure some marvellously evocative scenes. There's been a lot of talk about technical glitches. I can say that with the hours I've put in I've only seen a handful of problems, none of which couldn't be solved with a quick reload. I suspect that most of the problems come from consoles. It's the same sort of problem VW Beetle owners might have if they tried to compete in F1 races - why can't I compete?! Why can't I do what these funny flat cars are doing?!

The biggest issue I would have is that the game isn't finished. While there are plenty of fantastic looking cars and cosmetics, there are severe limits. You are restricted with limited weapons, tech mods, mission types, rigid classes and abilities. You have limited ways to customise your character, especially in keeping the the cyberpunk ethos. Want chrome skin? Sorry. Want an arm mod that lets you hack doors? Nope. Want to steal a car to own it? Or put guns and armour on your car? Or have shootouts while driving? Nope. Hacking is also limited to a single type of repetitive minigame that gets old, fast.

The world also suffers from limited attention. Go through the game missions and stick to those locales in the centre of the city, and everything is fine: there're secrets and surprises and loot hidden in hard-to-get to rooftops. Go off the track a little, and suddenly that all dries up. Cool hiding places that should have something in them, have nothing. There are vast areas where there is nothing. Square kilometres of biofood warehouses with almost nothing around; hidden caves and ledges with nothing in them. It's quite apparent that someone started populating the world, then ran out of time.

Would I recommend this game? Yes. I think I would. Even as it stands, there's a lot in this game. And as I said, the underlying engine is impressive and can look gorgeous. There is so much potential here. You could almost consider this a tech demo. Or perhaps a foundation you have to buy, then buy more DLC to go on top. But who would ever do something as low-down and dirty as that?

Definitely not the game I've been waiting for, for the last 8 years, but still a great game. The game was released in a rocky state, but CDPR has been working on cleaning the game up. I did not think the PC version of the game was in the same bad state as the last gen console versions, but it definitely has it's bugs. At this point the game is quite playable, and also quite enjoyable. I'd still call ht my game of the year, even though I had much higher hopes for it in the first place. Did it come out in the classic fashion of modern gaming as a hot steaming pile of bugs and broken systems masquerading as a game in a trench coat? You bet it did. Should they have left it in the oven to proof rather than launch it in that sorry state? You bet they should have. 

But under all that mess is the makings of a great game, great character design and writing with good voice acting to boot. The quests and world are vibrant and really drag you in. You get invested in your own character and the world around it. Without the kinks I would even have slapped game of the year on it. To their credit they have worked on improvements already and more are scheduled ahead. 

This is a proper RPG in a market overflowing with a tsunami of bland battle royal shooters from a developer with pedigree in the RPG scene. As it stands with the updates and knowing that the developer is planning on getting this game the development it deserves I fully recommend it to anyone wanting a good story driven game.

While Cyberpunk had a famously rocky start, the game has eventually been patched enough that most people can install and run it without any game breaking defects. Despite it's rough launch, I think cyberpunk is a phenomenal choice. It might not have been the game that all the hype built it up to be, but it's better than most other AAA games being released nowadays. You can tell that no matter where you go, there was someone who but a ton of effort and detail into that part of the world all the way down to the highly detailed garbage on the street. No the game isn't perfect, it was a buggy mess that ran poorly on almost every device. However when the game ran smoothly, I found myself getting sucked into the world and genuinely enjoying the game. I'm only looking forward to future expansions and maybe even an online mode so I can roam the streets with my friends.

Alright, so I didn't play at launch, so I have no comment on that, and I'm running a powerful system, so at max settings I can really see and feel all the little bits of effort that have been put into this game. I have played a completely un-modded game.

Summary.
I can say without reservation that this game is not deserving of the hate. It's a fun, immersive and engaging roleplaying game. It's not GTA, it's not the Witcher. It's better in many ways and worse in many ways. As it's own game it completely stands up and is one of the better games I have played over some 30 odd years of gaming.

Pros: Combat is fun, fast and character development feels meaningful. The story is engaging and interesting, the narrative is incredible if you take the time to read the shards and follow the subplots and scandals of the various factions that control various parts of the city. The graphics, ambience and general immersion are (aside from occaisional visual bugs) great.

Cons: The driving is.. bad on anything except a motorcycle, and then it's only passable. Most vehicles you can't actually see what's happening in front of you while going up or down hills due to the extreme low angle and narrow viewports and there's rarely a moment when I'm driving a vehicle that I don't wish I could be higher or lower. The also handle strangely. Some elements (NCPD Scanner Hustles especially) can get pretty repetitive - though I enjoy the little snippets of story you get at the end of each, they do feel a little like busywork. The fist fighting minigame is not great, especially given it's functionally impossible without cyber arms, which the game does not explain at all.

Neutral. The game has a few bugs, most bugs can be resolved by loading a save or toggling a setting, but they are there. Not unexpected given the broad state of modern pc gaming but for some it can be a problem. To be clear, the state of bugs in this game is, I would wager better than the current state of many similar scope games that are much older.

It took around a year to finally get to a point where people could tolerate the gameplay or at the very best, have some fun with it. I used to be a big supporter or CD Projekt Red and looked at the company as a shining beacon of light in the money driven, corporate world of games of today, but I've lost my faith forever in any game company from this point forward. Whenever a company gets successful enough, priorities like passion and pleasing the end user get thrown out the window for profit margins. E.g: Riot, Blizzard, Activision, Ubisoft, Bioware, the list goes on and on. 

Yeah this is just a rant and I know it will change absolutely nothing, but this game was a massive disappointment for me. I had been hyped for years for its release and really did expect a masterpiece rivaling that of Half Life or Far Cry (my favorite single player games), but man, was I naive for thinking so. Thanks for the wake up call CD Projekt Red, my biggest regret is not refunding this game within an hour of playing it. 

Keep pre-ordering people, let's keep the endless shit storm of mediocre, broken releases going forever. But, remember, as much as it is the company's fault for releasing an unfinished product, we also need to accept responsibility for continually buying into their BS.

In the past are the days of Cyberbugs and now is a much playable game.

Pros
-Amazing and outstanding visuals.
-Good and inmersive soundtracks
-Main story is enjoyable
-Huge world with "Cyberpunk" genre well represented

Cons
-If you don´t have an RTX gpu, the biggest part of this game is gone.
-Spoilers: REALLY BAD AI.... more on next bullets
-Police is non existant. they are not wandering around the city but in scripted places
-Enemies are predictable and behave exactly the same
-NPCs are dumb and dead inside
-Collision boxes are weird
-Animations are the same over and over again (like getting hit by a car)

Cons conclusion
-This game got mayor hate because of the bugs and performance issues, when the real problem is the core game.... Remove all glitches, all bugs, all errors, make this run on any PC with no requierements...... its still a bad game with bad AI and a world that should be prime in living open corpo-world. Things other devs have done YEARS ago like police chasing you in a god damn police car, you have none of that.

My final advice?
Buy the game just as a benchmark of the raw power of your system. 
Use it to see the best visuals yet if you have the GPU for that
Play the main story in straight line to enjoy it. Avoid wander the city expecting open world stuff, cause theres none.

One of the best games of the decade (in my opinion, RDR2 and Cyberpunk 2077 are the two best games since 2000). This game scores above the industry average in every important group of parameters:
1) Gameplay. Combat and stealth are equally satisfying. There is no RPG on the market right now that is even comparable to the CP in terms of gunfights, melee fights, and stealth (e.g. while shooting in The Outer Worlds, which is #2 fresh RPG, is somewhat OK, there are ambiguous ammo types and too many indistinguishable guns). Smart weapons feel amazing, katana and mantis blades have an enormously satisfying feeling. Finally, stealth and hacking are super interesting. The overall gameplay: best in the industry (comparison: Deus Ex, Outer Worlds, Fallout NV).
2) Plot and world. Authors tell us an interesting story about death and one's acceptance of it. Not really Mass Effect level of drama or Deus Ex 1 level of conspiracy, but the deeply private and personal story. Side quests are, of course, amazing (River Ward's and Johny's especially). I, personally, liked the plot even more than I liked the plot in New Vegas. In addition to that, developers used the universe with developed lore, and the back story of Night City and NUSA is interesting to learn. Finally, every question mark on the map tells a small interesting story or shows a funny place. It feels great to explore the world. Of course, it's not the same city as in GTA 5, but RPGs never were really about super alive open worlds (e.g. New Vegas, Outer Worlds, Skyrim, etc.). The overall plot and world: best in the industry (comparison: Mass Effect, Deus Ex, Outer Worlds, Fallout NV).
3) Roleplaying. Roleplaying for me is about two things: 1) ability to adjust playstyle (combat-oriented, charming, stealthy, etc.) and 2) ability to express my personal feelings via actions/dialogs. So, 1 - playstyle. I see several possible builds here: assault rifles with dodges, tank with a shotgun, stealth with hacking. Not much, but in Deus Ex HR we had only 1 build that makes sense - stealth (combat is super awkward there), in New Vegas we had sniper, assault rifle, talker, melee plus a lot of room for roleplay with additional skills, such as repair or medicine. Outer Worlds and Assassin's Creed are nothing in comparison. Sub conclusion: good level, not the best (New Vegas), but above the industry average. Now, 2 - dialogs. Yes, that's true, you can only affect the plot so much, but honestly, it's not that kind of RPG that allows you to favor one fraction and destroy the other or that allows you to negotiate in every quest (e.g. New Vegas, Outer Worlds). CP is a more cinematic-like game, and in this sense, the only sensible comparison is Mass Effect, and we can affect the plot way more in CP. But what is more important is dialogues: every time I had an option that represents my personal feelings exactly, and all the other options made total sense (e.g. in Mass Effect you had two ways: adequate character and crazy cruel **** The most important part of the game - V's thoughts about Johny and acceptance of death - offer great dialog options, and I personally felt that I hear answers that resonate with me, the player. Overall: highly above the industry average.
4) Artistic execution. Music is awesome, all that rocker boy vibe is amazing, the city looks noir AF and rain and light works amazing in pre-designed scenes and just during any night free ride. In that sense, one can compare CP with RDR2, and CP at least slightly worse in terms of light and scenes. Overall: absolutely exceptional artistic work.
Final verdict: this game will become legendary and will stay together with RDR 2, New Vegas in the RPG's hall of fame.
Ignore all negative reviews - people just hate technical execution, but this is temporary, while all that I described is way more important.

cyberpunk 2077 has a crazy-detailed, mind-blowing world to mess around in. the story is packed with several characters, side quests, and awesome dialogue — there are thoughtful little things which pull the player right in. sure, it might be a bit buggy but i've enjoyed this game since the very beginning.

what i would like to see in future updates is an expansion of customization — appearance, vehicles, etc. getting implants and purchasing clothes is definitely a start. it may be a long shot, however, i'd also love to see some more content regarding the characters surrounding V. what happens to River, Judy, Panam? and why aren't there more rewarding/punishing aspects to the romantic side of things? how does V turn into the ultimate player by romancing several people in a single playthrough? i don't mind it, but it takes away from some of the 'realism' that part of the game aspires to demonstrate. 

that said, it's a great game and has a lot of replayability value. pick a different life path, you've got three choices. while it may not change a lot more than the intro and some of V's responses, you can choose to be the ultimate hacker or an absolute beast by acquiring perk points and investing into different abilities which can change the way the game plays, entirely.

9/10 also +1 for the naked-standing-on-my-motorcycle-in-the-middle-of-traffic glitch AND the insane armadillo clothing mod stacking glitch that literally made V invincible.

Updated Review:
Okay. Short and sweet, I've returned to Night City. I haven't seen missing thighs within the first 5 minutes (yes that happened), and I haven't watched waitresses walking around with invisible trays (yes that also happened). I HAVE seen invisible interactions (floating cigarette, missing people as part of a conversation, and instruments being played when they don't exist), but they're more rare now.

Now, CP2077 is a game I can play. All games have bugs. Would I like all of them to be fixed in this game, sure. Do I think they will all be fixed eventually? Absolutely not. CDProjectRed is already tasked with moving into other games as a focus, and they're coming out with DLC for this one. If you're writing DLC, you're less focused on bug fixes. But all that being said, I can stay about 70-80% immersed in Night City these days. That's a huge leap for 10-25% in my previous play through.

What I would want going forward:
The invisible issue, I believe, is due to asset cleanup at some point in the process. The invisible hand pan I saw in my recent play through was easily corrected by walking away 5 feet, and turning back around. The hand pan was visible. So something's going on with the player view asset management. That should be fixed.

Dialog can play on top of other dialog without waiting for the proper timing. That's... very jarring. Especially when you have the last lines from the previous dialog with the new lines of the new dialog, and you're trying to parse both at the same time.

Speaking of dialog, holy shit can you PLEASE change the default dialog skip button to NOT the same button as sneaking? I'm trying to have a conversation with someone, but I forgot to stop sneaking, and now I have to do the entire thing while hunched down like that's something normal people, totally not psychopaths, do.

Final Thoughts:
At this point, I'd recommend the game. It's got flaws, but they're easier to overlook at this point. I'd give the game a 7/10. Once I finish it, that may go up to a 8/10 depending on the ending. The last two points can't be made up until the bugs get fixed.

Still some bugs left to be squashed and, beyond that, I hope CDPR continues to polish up the games rough edges. First and foremost, of which, being V's character animations. I know it's a first person game but come on devs... if one of your selling points is jaw-dropping state of the art visuals, those realistic shadows are displaying a character model that is suddenly moving like some sort of marionette doll if you do anything other than walk in a straight line.

After playing for 148 hours, I can heartily recommend this game to anyone who likes a strong story-driven campaign (including a number of engaging and well-written side quests) and some fascinating worldbuilding. A must-have for fans of cyberpunk science fiction novels, e.g. by authors like William Gibson and Neal Stephenson. Also highly recommended for anyone who loves the Blade Runner aesthetic. In fact, two of the most enjoyable parts of the game are collecting and reading flavor text and just *looking around* and soaking in the atmosphere. In addition, combat and gunplay are visceral and there are a fascinating range of character builds that one can explore. 

There are a few downsides. First, this game isn't the best direct competitor to GTA, nor is the open world the main strength of CP2077. That being said, the game is good at what it does, and perhaps it was unwise for CD Projekt Red to market the game as an open-world GTA competitor, instead of focusing more of the marketing material on its actual strengths. Second, the filler quests are just that - filler! Thankfully, they are clearly marked (in blue), so it is easy to skip them if you want. Third, the game's tutorial glosses over one very important aspect for players going for a "stealth" character build: how the hacking and stealth systems interact! For instance, you'll want to disconnect an enemy from their LAN in order to stop them from alerting the other NPCs. You'll also need the "Memory Wipe" quickhack in order to perform an alarm reset, and it will only affect the entire squad (and thus be practically useful) at higher rarity levels. Finally, it's been argued that mechanically, the game is far from balanced. That being said, as a stealth/hacking focused player, I didn't really mind, because I had plenty of fun things to do and to experiment with, even if the swimming-related perk was utterly useless, and even if the Contagion quickhack was overpowered. 

That all being said, there's a reason why I've somehow managed to "waste" 148 hours of my life on this game. Despite the game's notoriously rocky launch, and despite the fact that it probably isn't the best direct competitor to GTA or to the latest hot "open world" game, Cyberpunk 2077's core strengths "sucked me in" and made for a very entertaining time.

[h1]Post-1.5 Update: A Big Step Forward[/h1]

While the biggest improvements for the "Next-Gen" patch were undoubtedly felt by console players, surprisingly, 1.5 brought a welcome update for PC players in the form of a better living world.

Check out my earlier review below - a lackluster open world USED to be my number one complaint. Not only is crowd behavior far more realistic (and denser), but gangs appear far more active, crime scenes investigations and medical evacuations pop up across the city, and even the occasional police chase stirs up traffic. Night City no longer feels like a police state under complete government control, but a bit more like a city where "legitimate" law enforcement is stretched thin and underfunded, while those rich enough to make a difference are also rich enough to avoid the problem.

If I could change anything, it would be more random civilians willing to go vigilante (it's fantastic that they added this but it still feels too rare), street vendors that actually sell food, improved social interactions with random civilians (these one-line responses still feel random and incongruous with the speaker's behavior), and perhaps more first-person environmental interactions. The last of these is more icing than cake if you catch my meaning. Fortunately, these are mostly additional content and tweaks to existing systems, not entirely new systems in themselves. The groundwork exists. I have little doubt that a year from now, these are the kind of additions we'll see sprinkled in.

If you have been waiting to jump in, folks, now's the time. Things are finally looking up.


[h1]Pre-1.5: Tarnished and incomplete but enjoyable[/h1]

TL;DR: a significant step down from The Witcher 3 in almost every way, underpolished and seemingly rushed, but one that still somehow makes for a memorable and largely positive gaming experience the first time you go through it.

I need to start this review with three big caveats: first, I played this game on a brand new RTX 3080 at launch, with very few bugs or glitches to speak of. Second, The Witcher 3 is one of my favorite games of all time, so I went into this game as a shameless CDPR apologist. So my first experience with this game was pure love for what it is, and an enormous amount of patience for what it wasn't. Your mileage may vary.

And third, part of why I took so long to write a review is because I have admittedly had a bit of an emotional journey with this game. For most of 2021, I thought for sure CP2077 would become something substantially better than the "early release version" it was at launch. Then around August 2021, I began to feel angry at CDPR for not living up to the potential I thought the game had, spending nearly all of their time squashing bugs I never experienced and saying virtually nothing with respect to new content or features. Almost a year after launch, I feel like I can finally write a balanced review.

In a word, Cyberpunk 2077 is inconsistent. A myriad tiny gems of greatness scattered about an enormous field of mediocrity, teasing you constantly with brilliant worldbuilding potential that almost never feels realized. It doesn't take long to notice the signs of a hastily painted over facade that fails to resemble the world its lore purports.

Take the city, for example. This is a hyper-capitalist dystopia with severe inequality and supposedly rampant crime. The game wants to tell us that the city sells the promise of making it big only to grind people up and violently spit them out. In many ways, the visuals and layout of the world really sell this. Different districts have distinct personalities. The grime, the glitz, the mountains of garbage, the rain, the dust all look gloriously detailed. So many clever details can be found everywhere, like makeshift hovels for the homeless, vending machines for guns, architecture and fashion that reflects history, culture, and varying income levels. Night City FEELS like a real place when you first arrive, especially as you watch MaxTac drop in from the pouring rain and zero a few unlucky criminals.

The thing is, this all plays as the background to game systems that don't reflect the setting. For one, if everything is privatized, bounties are all over the place, and rival corps run everything, what's with the exact same government-run police force having jurisdiction all over the city? Shouldn't corporate security be the de facto "police" near their buildings? Shouldn't gangs play that role in some neighborhoods?

Also, crowds don't react how you would expect if you can buy disposable guns from a vending machine. Maybe most people would still run, but I guarantee more than a handful would go vigilante in the hopes of bagging a reward. And for that matter, for a world with this much poverty, crime is remarkably infrequent. Sure, there's the occasional skirmish between gangs and the police, but where are the random, unscripted events like home invasions? The shoplifters who get mowed down by shop owners? You're telling me people are going hungry in the street, can get access to cheap weapons, and almost nobody is robbing one another?

The open world vs lore inconsistency is most glaring where scripted events never pay off in the open world. For example, your first job has you seemingly ambushed in the open world by a van of scavengers out for payback. This never happens again. When you go all GTA on folks, why don't MaxTac swoop in like they did in the beginning of the game? Why are there only two prostitutes in the red light district? Why is there only one romance option per sexual preference? Why aren't there any braindances not directly tied to a quest? Why is it so damn easy for V to get rich? 

Maybe this all probably sounds like nitpicking, and in a way, it kinda is. But it really feels deserved when so much of the game feels generic, only for you to stumble across a nugget of sheer brilliance. Not to spoil anything, but there is a series of political-themed side quests that are so far above and beyond every other side quest in terms of storytelling, the contrast really makes everything else feel disappointing. Also, one of the cyber psycho fights stands head and shoulders above the others for the mood it evokes, while most end up feeling pretty "samey".

Lastly, I can't get through a review without mentioning the main story, which is honestly the hardest part to review. The story overall is good. In fact, there are more than a handful of absolutely BRILLIANT moments that are almost worth the price of admission all by themselves. And Silverhand, largely thanks to Keanu's irrepressible charm, is almost certainly the best thing about the game. It all works very, very well as long as the illusion of choice is maintained and you don't notice how the game constantly railroads you through its themepark-style storytelling. And that's the part that makes it hard for me to review. The story is so good the first time. But once it loses its charm, there is so little else left... it's hard to ever want to go back.

To summarize, it's good, but not truly great. If you go in with the right expectations, you shouldn't be disappointed. Think Fallout 4 style missions (clear building, rinse, repeat) without the faction system, some fun lightweight shooting that might be a little repetitive, and a handful of decent surprises along the way.

The game had an undeniably rough launch, which is something becoming more depressingly common in AAA games.  However, after a year stability has generally improved (except perhaps on low end consoles). 

Once you get passed the issues encounter in an early game, you're left with a game that's fun to play. Night City is huge, with some beautiful sprawling architecture.  Some of the NPCs like Panam, River, Judy have compelling and immersive stories. For the reduced prices available right now, it's definitely worth your time and money.

The game is not without valid citique, though.  I think the game suffers from the scope of its ambition.  They tried to create something so large that it was hard to make it feel like a full, lived in place.  Some of the fixer quests and police scanner quests could have been better developed. And the game definitely becomes very, very easy at high levels. I also felt that the Cyberpunk theme was at odds with the fact that many of your quests are effectively for the NCPD. 

Still, having said all that, I found I've gone back for a second play through just to spend more time in the immersive night city environment.

Sure, CP2077 suffered from stability issues, most of that was CDPR attempt to port the game to console, the PC version was great already at launch. 

The real elephant in the room; I understand the pressures that come from investors and meeting schedules, it chokes effective measures to ensure quality. I find (personal exp.) that most consumers are willing to wait for a great product that's behind schedule, rather than a poor product that underwhelms in expectations at launch. 

That being said, I wished that CDPR had stuck to their early production statement: "it's ready when it's ready, and we will announce the game release when we're sure it's a quality product." Being beholden to investors and a public timeline screwed the team over something fierce. Delay of product is much more preferred than refunds. 

HOWEVER, with the hotfix updates up to 1.31, the game is decently polished already, meets expectations, and is overall a great game. With CDPR dedicating to fixing things and delaying DLC to ensure its viability and quality, they are making the right move. The game is and of itself incredible. Could there be things tweaked and more customization? Absolutely! But lets not throw CP2077 into the dustbin because of stability issues on consoles and a few bugs (remember Skyrim??) It's a PC gaming company after all and, we on Steam, all know PC is the Master Race of gaming. 

When a company has done the right thing by apologizing and issuing refunds and is actively working on fixing an already good game, I ask and posit that all Gamers alike should rejoice that CDPR isn't EA and DICE. CDPR doesn't put out products like EA does, and then not listen to their consumer base and call them idiots. It's no ET and it's certainly no Battlefield 2042!!!

overall, it's not a bad game. it's far from that. but is it worth full price rn? not at all. get it on sale. for half off, it's a very nice game, and i'm looking forward to how it improves with time.

Ultimately the programming serves to communicate a game, and unfortunately this game does suffer from some bugs (much less now) that detracted from that but also some of the design choices don't really stand up. But there's still so much left to love.  It can be a hard game to grade because there are lows but overall there are more highs.

If you like good stories this game is for you. If you like compelling lore, this game is definitely for you. The lore is based in a decades old franchise.

My biggest gripe personally, is the combat. The combat actually feels really good, there is good weapon variety, the stealth feels awesome. There are a ton of abilities and perks.  Its just not very well balanced. Some perks seem meaningless and some are nearly game-breaking. Hacking can make you an untouchable god that clears rooms without ever entering the building.  So, whether you will like it really depends on what you want out of it. Its not a well-balanced challenging shooter to overcome, but the combat serves to carry the game along and make you feel like you're in the environment.

Other than that, I don't have much to complain about. Its a beautiful world to go wander about. There are likeable and hateable characters that feel realistic and have realistic motives. There are rad cars, amazing music.   The story is really good. Lots of mysteries left for later too. Its just a blast if you let it be.
