Cyberpunk 2077 is the ultimate power fantasy. A video game that takes the best of modern RPG, first-person shooter, stealth, and the open world and masterfully blends it into a single product. If Skyrim and GTA V marked a before and after for their genres at the beginning of the 2010s, Cyberpunk 2077 is called to do the same from this 2020..
The gameplay could be smoother, there could be fewer glitches, but the story, atmosphere, and characters are all perfectly designed and make a perfect experience all on their own.
It's 30 bucks, sure, but if you've waited this long to buy it, may as well wait a little longer when actual DLC comes out, if that's still a thing.

I was one of the many people expecting this game for a long time I followed all the updates before the launch and I was mad exited for the game, so while I love the game because I was lucky enough to not have any mayor issues or bugs the game itself is by no means perfect or probably what a lot of people wanted it to be, personally I think the biggest problem with the game is the AI is really poor and could use a lot of fixing, however CRPR always delivers with charactes, quests, history and world desing and this game is no exception actually I think the characters in this game are the best npcs in any game ever they do feel like real people their interacctions and thier storys are the best part of this game. In more gameplay related things the shooting feels good all the guns feel different and the smart weapons are really interesting, the hand to hand combat is terrible though, I think even the the witcher 3 with it's mediocre hand to hand combat was better. The meele weapons however feel good not crazy good but still, It's important to highlight that this game is an rpg not an fps so it's no doom either still I think they really hit the nail in balancing both the rpg and the fps aspect an that's not an easy task, I would've preffered a more complex rpg system but that is just nickpicking 

So should you buy this game? Idk deppends on what do you expect from it, me personally don't regreat buying it.  I'm pretty happy with it and paciently waiting for more content

Теперь по порядку: в данной игре у меня около пяти сотен часов, статистику в стиме вы видите сами, а сложить два и два, надеюсь, способны. Играл в это творение я только с патчем первого дня и только на ПК, поэтому то, поочему это творение нарекли кибербагом - я не очень понимаю. Одни и те же баги, нарезки которых на ютубе, вставлял в обзор каждый честный обзорщик, и 70% которых было пофикшено патчем первого дня я не застал. Да, в игре есть технические проблемы, и понимая механизм работы закулисья геймдева, к великому сожалению обязан предположить что у игры есть и нерешаемые проблемы... Проблемы движка, костыли и спагетти-код, вызванные и общей сложностью, масштабом проекта и разработкой финальной части игры на удаленке - все это негативно сказалось на качестве исходного продукта...

И знаете что? Я не пропустил ни одного патча при игре, тестировал все, и именно ощутив на кончиках пальцев труд, который приложили разработчики для исправления - я поверил в этот проект! Хоть и не считаю справедливым весь тот хейт, который вылился на студию, но хейт был отчасти оправдан, на релизе игра напоминала раннюю бету, сейчас ситуация лучше. Даже при всех кадровых потерях разработчик способен вернуть себе расположение здравомыслящей аудитории, но вернуть ее проведением работой над ошибками!

Плюсы игры:
-Сюжет, сюжет, сюжет... он шикарен! И основная сюжетная линия это лишь верхушка айсберга! Часов 20 геймплея, а настоящее раскрытие глубины вселенной происходит во второстепенных квестах (ветки друзей, Пералесов), и конечно же, "Passion" - это один из лучших сюжетов в истории игровой индустрии! Колоритные, по-настоящему проработанные персонажи делают сюжет очень и очень запоминающимся.
-Музыка! Музыкальное сопровождение великолепно! На вкус и цвет, конечно, но... разнообразие способно подарить свою незабываемую атмосферу каждому моменту прохождения.
-Геймплей. Спорный пункт. Лишь спустя примерно 150 часов геймплея я понял, что киберпанк это не только лишь про "бегать-стрелять". Система прокачки открывает перед игроком гигантское поле для экспериментов (хотя на релизе половина возможностей элементарно не работала, лул). Различным возможностям прокачки я посвятил отдельный гайд, поэтому скажу лишь что игру можно пройти без убийств, и что игру можно пройти скипнув 80% перестрелок, либо с помощью острого языка (включая своевременное помалкивание), либо с помощью стелса. Да и боевая система честно говоря разнообразна, стоит лишь проявить фантазию.
-Стиль. У игры есть свой неповторимый шарм, атмосфера Найт-Сити, города где большие мечтатели могут свой путь начать, и где они же могут его закончить...
-Графика. Графика хороша, даже не на самых высоких настройках.
-Оптимизация. Моя очень скромная машинка является индикатором оптимизации игры - киберпанк возможно тонко настроить под каждую пекарню, если она вообще его запустит.
-Моды. Вообще моды для киберпанка заставили меня по другому взглянуть на моддинг. Если вам как камень в ботинке мешает какой-то конкретный аспект игры - скорее всего есть мод который что-то с этим делает. Однозначный плюс разработчику, который с первого дня запуска позволяет энтузиастам делать игру на свой вкус.  

Резюмируя все плюсы игры - она крутая! В ней много возможностей, если чуть углубиться во вселенную и геймплей - можно найти себе очень много развлечений, начиная от чтения чипов (если в 2к2X вы все еще умеете читать), заканчивая экспериментами с боевой системой. И на хвалебной ноте я все-таки перийду к минусам:

-Баги. Да, я тут говорил что их не замечал. Я не замечал чего-то, отчего у меня "упал" при игре. Баги есть. Сталкиваешься с багами раз в несколько часов, и как правило выручает элементарная перезагрузка бижайшего автосейва, что съедает 5 минут твоего прохождения. И несложно посчитать, что даже за свои 185 часов в стиме я потерял примерно пару часов прохождения тупо перепроходя локации после столкновения с багами, sad but true...
-Отсутствие хай-лвл контента. Если под пивас пробежать игру часов за 20-25, то этого минуса вы не заметите. Но погрузившись в игру и прокачку, после 40 лвл`а вы становитесь терминатором, а все бандиты Найт-сити, даже вместе взятые для вас не более чем обычные лещи. Автолевелинг в каком-то патче добавили, но работает он криво - все равно зачищать свой родной райончик, вернувшись в него под конец прохождения скучно. После сорокового уровня в игре только одна локация, которая даст про..раться даже бывалому киберпанку ([spoiler]Arasaka Tower[/spoiler]), а поиграв на персонаже 50+ часов хочется все равно чувствовать адреналин, хочется хорошенько думать и закидываться бустерами, менять скрипты перед тем, как вломиться в десяток врагов!
-Деревянный мир. Опять же из патча в патч ситуация улучшается, но не так быстро как хотелось бы. Вообще это самый обширный пункт, про который можно долго говорить, начиная от болванчиков-НПС, заканчивая локациями, зачищая которые они застывают во времени - и зачистив 10 часов назад какой-то переулок в центре города, возвращаясь туда ты испытываешь неприятное чувство оттого, что все, вплоть до следов крови от врагов на том же месте. Это не везде и не всегда, но все сюжетные локации точно отмирают, они пустые. Локации дополнительных квестов тоже, особенно бесит когда ты карабкаешься по вентиляции через 20 человек чтобы убить босса, тихо убираешь его, обещая себе вернуться разобраться с его приспешниками после накопления на ту нормальную винтовку... а задание закончено и все, локация становится пустой, ни бомжей, ни других бандитов. А если на том же месте устроишь кровавую баню - то по прибытии будет просто хотя бы интересно увидеть полицейскую машину или нетранера, допрашивающего местных. И кстати я так сконцентрировался на этом аспекте именно потому что на мой взгляд это одна из вещей, которые исправить невозможно в игре, мир слишком заскриптован (при этом после последних патчей, на удивление, я обнаружил что в некоторые зачищеные локации приходят хипстеры пить кофе, а в некоторые инженеры-работяги!).
-Еще как подпункт к хай-лвл контенту можно отнести лутер-шутерную составляющую. Нормальные и интересные шмотки можно только либо выбить по сюжету, либо найти в одних и тех же местах в мире. Просто добавить возможность чтобы из бандитов и корпоратов могло упасть что-то уникальное, чтобы зачистив точку интереса тебе могла случайно упасть эпичная шмотка с хотя бы двумя ячейками. А то серьезно, после десятого уровня и любого перка на деньги мотивация лутать локации угасает.
-Мало кастомизации. Ни тюнинга тачки, ни квартиру, ни даже прическу персонажу поменять нельзя. (Спагетти-код, все это крашит игру). Если это как сам факт будет добавлено в игру - это уже добавит ей привлекательности. 

Подрезюмировав и минусы: разработчики ими занимаются, хотя и не стоит надеяться что игра будет вылизана до уровня пред-релизных ожиданий. Впереди некст-ген версия и DLC, если с ними не будет фундаментальных изменений, о которых говорил выше - игра умрет и останется прикольным сюжетным проектом на 50-100 часов, если же будут предприняты осмысленные меры - то игра может обрести новую жизнь, новых фанатов, и снова зародить в сердцах массовой аудитории глубокое уважение к разработчику!

Написать этот обзор меня сподвигла 50% скидка: на текущий момент, даже со всеми недостатками - для такой игры это грош цена! За ваши кровные вы получите как минимум полсотни часов приятного экспириенса, музыка, графон, сюжет, юмора, персонажей и большого открытого мира. Так еще у игры есть будущее! Игру не бросили и разработчики стараются причесать игру, чтобы потенциально вы могли получить еще сотню-другую часов приятного опыта при следующем прохождении.

Закончу обзор теми же словами, что и начал:

ИГРА ЗАСЛУЖИВАЕТ ТОГО, ЧТОБЫ ДАТЬ ЕЙ ШАНС!

Look I'm gonna be honest, this game isn't perfect. Don't scroll just yet though because I want to explain, this game really wants to be the best out there, and honestly if not for the fact that people rushed project Red (and was sent death threats by people telling them that they would kill them if they didnt release the game), and that YouTubers who have the ability to make or break the future of a game were saying it was bad all because it had visual glitches and one or two glitches that caused you to reload to five minutes prior, this game would honestly be close to perfect. However, because of the actions of people who liked the idea of a game coming out fast and shitty rather than waiting a long time for a quality one, this game became what it is now. Also let it be know that Project Red regularly puts out updates fixing visual and quest related bugs. 

My thoughts all in all?
+'s 
Its a good game, with lots to do and a pretty interactive story and world that really make you feel like you're in the year 2077 the city is modled beautifully and looks like a real city.
 There is a good amount to be done with your character, whether its clothing, cyberware, or character features.
Tons of quests (some repetitive but if you don't like it don't play those quests)
-'s
 a few visual bugs and the occasional glitch on a mission that causes you to go back to a save from 5 minutes ago. 
This is the biggest con though, it doesn't run well at all (it's getting better) my 3080 with an i9 and 32 gbs of ram chugs on high-ish with ray tracing (i get roughly 35 frames)

That's my review, sorry if I got things wrong or you dont like my opinion (if you don't, then cry about it)

Cyberpunk 2077 is a game set in a dystopian near-future and I have done three play-throughs over the past year since the initial release. I'll admit that I'm probably more easily-pleased than most players and that, prior to this game, I was not extremely excited nor a fan of the genre, so I didn't have my standards set as high as someone else might have.

I have enjoyed Cyberpunk 2077 for what it is: A game with enough depth to easily stunt on a majority of AAA RPG's released over the past decade. This statement isn't meant to excuse the fact that game was riddled with bugs, that performance issues were common for console players (I experienced less issues with this release than I did with Skyrim ten years ago), or the fact that they under-delivered on what was promised. I would say that this game is every bit as equal in quality to something like Skyrim, minus some quality of life features -- but the issue is that they promised much and were forced to deliver noticeably less due to their corporate overlords (which, of course, goes with the theme of Cyberpunk).

I'm confident that the developers will salvage this title from the awful release. Currently, I would treat this game as an Early Access release and consider it as such -- because it certainly isn't finished, but all the pieces are there to enjoy the game and do a few play-throughs. Despite all of the circumstances surrounding this game's release quality, CDPR has enthralled me with the world they created and I'm constantly looking for something else to scratch that Cyberpunk itch, although nothing else does. 

This is certainly a game worth buying. If you're not comfortable with something that's essentially 'Early Access', I'd wait for a sale or hold off until the game has received a few more QOL updates. But in any case, I don't regret paying full price for it and I would pay full price for Cyberpunk again were it a new release.

I'm not even going to mention the quality of life additions...mostly because they are too numerous to list and frankly, I'm lazy.  I will say I was actually surprised how all of these little changes and additions genuinely make the experience much, MUCH more enjoyable on a massive scale.

So...yeah I'd actually recommend people play this now.

Original negative review:

Played the game at launch and despite the game being stable for me, the constant graphical glitches and T-posing NPCs wore me down to the point where I couldn't give a shit to keep playing.

1 year later and a few patches later I boot up the game...surely, SURELY they fixed the majority of the simple problems, right?

Play the corpo intro and 10 minutes in Jackie and V start T-pose gliding down the street with V missing his head.

Absolutely embarrassing.

Edit: I am unable to pick up 30% of the items (vendor trash, rolls of money) that are strewn about the floor despite the game indicating they can be picked up.  Tutorial mission improperly updated killing the scav leader.  I'm in the fucking tutorial and the game is already in an objectively WORSE state than it was when I played it a year ago. HOW THE FUCK DID YOU MAKE THE GAME OBJECTIVELY WORSE?!

It's a mediocre first-person open world shooter. There are almost no enticing or worthwhile characters or pieces of plot. The RPG elements are entirely non-existent (a choice at the beginning of the game that adds 5 minutes of flavour then and there and doesn't reappear except for once in the entire game for each choice). 

The gunplay/melee is adequate, movement can feel pretty decent at times and there are times where the combined use of both can provide a unique way to complete a quest. 

The open world is wide as the ocean, shallow as a puddle. It's a heavily varnished and perfumed turd. 

If you want a 5/10 FPS open-world game where you meander through a horrendous main plot that's entirely on rails, having zero impact to what occurs at all, then this game is for you.

I want to start by saying I am very lucky, and bias. 
I played the table top starting in 1999, to say I am a fan is an understatement.

I love this game, and I mean love this game. However, I do understand that I experienced this game with some of the best gaming tech money can buy, and that is a big point. 

The biggest thing for me is I played this on a CR G9, with a 6900xt. I almost played this game like VR. With that type of experience its hard to quantify. Which is why I state I am bias, and understand that I am one of very very few who can play video games on that level. 

Did it have some issues yes. 
Does it have bugs from time to time yes. 
Is it a video game, and all games have those yes. 

That is all I can really say, it was an emotional roller coaster, and I am beyond happy with what they have done.
This game isn't over, and has more coming.

Despite of several benefits like a lot of bugs, an imperfect world, stupid NPCs, etc., this game has already managed to hook many people even in the beginning. INTRO:
Truly a great game, it doesn't deserve all the hate it gets. Over-hyped? Sure, but most of that was people creating the fantastical unrealistic expectations in their own minds and OF COURSE they'll be let down. Most of the bugs have been patched out, however there are still a few that come from time to time. Anyway, onto my short reveiw.

WHAT I LIKE:
Replayability & Gameplay. I know that once I finish my current playthrough I will want to play again, but spec my character differently, and go for an entirely different vibe. Do I want to run stealth-focused with pistols, swords, hammers, rifles, sniper rifles? Sure go ahead. Do I want to focus on wrecking havoc through hacking? Sure, Do I just want to walk into every situation guns blazing not caring about being caught? I could if I want to. What I'm saying is there is a lot of flexibility in how you can play, which allows the actual gameplay to not become stale. Add that to the interesting quest variety and you've got a good combo to keep you entertained and curious about how things might go if you tried different specs and combos of upgrades etc.

Graphics are great, although I do feel like the characters are a bit stiff, some more than others. Distanced rendering can look pretty bad at times, but that's usually ok since the city is packed with detail.

Game runs great for me (144 fps with no problems on ultra). 

City feels alive in the right places. What I mean is that busy looking intersections are busy, and backroads and alleyways are appropriately quiet. There is less traffic in the outer regions and it's nice to see the attention to detail that went into all these "minor" qualities that contribute to the immersion and experience.

WHAT I DISLIKE/MEH:

There is no third-person mode, or even third person cut scenes, so even though you spend a lot of time crafting a cool appearance, you never see it unless you're in photo mode or the inventory. And oddly, the character model in the inventory seems very low quality (which makes 0 sense).

Customization in general. While there are lots of clothing options, guns, cars, and cybernetic mods, the game seems to fall flat on almost all of these. For example, you have a "face slot" and a "hat" but no "eyes", meaning if you find a cool gas mask or something that you want to wear with your sunglasses, tough. It's one or the other. There is no aesthetic customization for guns, cars and only limited cybernetics, which is kind of a big one. I was expecting much more when it came to cybernetics and synthetic body parts. Instead the system functions more like a "Recieve X damage boost/reduction etc" with no change in appearance.

The menus can be annoying to navigate, quests will switch randomly when someone new calls you, and the map is kind of awkward to use.

Overall, great gameplay, story is entertaining enough and the game has a lot going for it, but there are some obvious corners that were cut, which I hope are improved with future updates. A whole DLC on customization or a third person mode would be HUGE.

Even with the bugs that are still present a year after release, game's a fun trip. I waited for it to become more stable and less buggy, still saw my share of game crashes on an rtx3080, but overall the story was phenomenal.

After 100+ hours I must admit I've fallen for this game like I seldom do for a game. It has its quirks and limitations but all in all this game is just amazing. It's one of those games that's more of a journey, an experience, than a game. What I appreciate about the game is the story line, the beautifully created world. The characters are so well made, in every aspects. Clever use of narrative and story driving mechanics. The level of detail and attention to the small things that adds up to something immersive is second to few (I cannot say none, but almost). 

Some of my previous favorites that I've spent way too much time in is Fallout, GTA and Horizon Zero to mention a few. I'd say that Cyberpunk manage to take the best parts of all these franchises and combine them into one dystopian adventure. The story line and the carefully crafted characters are the strong points of this game. Also, I love the "in your face" attitude of the game with little compromise for the sake of double standards or what's proper and not. Refreshing.

Pros: 
+ Storyline
+ The characters
+ NSFW/L take
+ The world, large and wonderfully made
+ Overall experience with amazing immersion
+ So many wonderful details
+ Great variation in game play

Cons
- Still buggy
- Too linear (ironically)
- Too static world 
- Some unnecessary limitations

The linear and static feel is there because it doesn't quite match the quality of the large world, the story and the characters. The feeling of walking around in a non destructive static scenery is way too present. Despite being populated with loads of NPC's and vehicles. I constantly get the feeling of "oh, it could have been so much more!". But... that's because what this game does good, it does so incredible good that the rest stands out because of this.

Get it on sale. Compared to Witcher 3, gameplay-wise it's a fairly shallow looter-shooter with gorgeous visuals, some of the best characters ever portrayed screen, legit (but not game-changing) storytelling and world-building, hundreds of hours of sidequests and distractions (what did you expect?), yet somehow, the open-world feels shallow and empty. This game leaves little room for exploration, sadly. But follow the waypoints and quest markers, and you'll find no shortage of depth.

Overall, a decent 8/10. A few bugs still remain, but if you've got an RTX card and a couple hundred hours to blow, grab Cyberpunk on sale. Just don't pay the full $60, don't expect the Witcher 3, and you will not be disappointed.

Hot take but Cyberpunk 2077 is an absolute ride from start to finish. This game completely captivated me in it's world, it's people and their day to day life in a downtrodden, crime and corruption ridden city where dreams go to die. It's incredibly detailed world design and amazing sound design really allow you to FEEL Night City. It's a story from 0 to hero and you don't even realize it's happening. With a total of 4 different endings and a few collectibles hidden behind certain scenarios and such, this game is well prepared for replayability. I played this game the exact hour it released and finished it in 15 hours total UNDERLEVELED and with just a few sidejobs and quests done so, yes, there is A LOT to do, which I'm sure is communicated by my playtime.

As an RPG this game really really hits the mark for me. Lots of loot and looting, crafting, weapons unique to crafting, hidden weapons, and a whole host of perks to unlock. Even with my playtime I can't say I've reached max stats and all perks. The gunplay is as standard as it gets, although similar to Fallout 4 so if you liked FO4s gunplay you'll probably find yourself having fun with this title. And as with any open world game like Cyberpunk, you gotta have cars. The vehicles in this game are fantastic. Models have superb detail some even have details you wouldn't normally see. The texture work for them is also very high quality. The handling feels like GTA 5's but your car is less inclined to turn at high speeds.

In essence; Cyberpunk 2077 is a masterpiece and it's unfortunate development due to ambitions and time constraints + investors threatening to pull funding led to a rocky release and it's issues overshadowing what it was supposed to be.

This game has been getting frequent almost monthly updates since release and is much more stable than release.

My specs are a Ryzen 5 5600X, GTX 1070 and 16GB of DDR4-3000 and it runs fine at 50-60 FPS 1080p with 80% Static CAS mostly max settings with a few settings set to low such as Ambient Occlusion, which has no difference from Low to High but has a considerable FPS impact.

Do yourself a favor and buy this game.

Did this game have some bugs at launch yeah. Is it still a pain to run well, yup. Is the story really freaking fantastic and the characters amazing, absolutely. This game certainly has it's shortcomings but if you're looking for a cyberpunk RPG with a rich narrative you can't really go wrong here. Firstly, if your even remotely a fan of cyberpunk as an ascetic, this game hits the nail on the head, maybe more Ghost in the Shell grunge than Blade Runner's over sided buildings in the rainy sky.

I know for a fact that there will be a lot of people who will pick this game up, play for an hour and say, well there's no depth, there's nothing here. You might not be an RPG person then cause yeah, the story takes a while to get going, like most massive RPGs. It's definitely a narrative that needs a little time to breath. All the actors involved are amazing however. Keanu Reeves actually plays a full character rather than the cameo we're getting from Far Cry 6. I won't say he's the best actor in the game however. Keanu is playing the same old action hero, like Neo or Wick which is cool, but nothing new and I felt like there needed to be a bit more energy behind a lot of Jonny's lines then there was.

If you're comparing this game to GTA or Far Cry and disliking it cause it's not simply cyberpunk GTA clone, I don't think anything I say will change your mind. If you don't think the world is rich enough cause every NPC of a million in Night City doesn't have their own dedicated day night cycle, well personally I don't think that's a reasonable request, but if that's the kind detail you're looking for you'll probably still be disappointing. If you refuse to play this game due to the botched launch and broken promises due to nasty share holders, well more power too you, money is how higher ups notice issues. But there's also the argument of all the developers that poured their heart and souls into this game and how many people won't see their work because of the poor decision someone else made.

All in all, I 100% recommend this game, under the right conditions. do you have a decent rig, and are you an avid RPG player.

After the horrible release of this game, I decided to hold off until it was thoroughly patched and I had better hardware in my PC to really get the best out of it. Well, since playing it and completing it (main story and a bunch of side quests) and racking up over 54 hours, I can honestly say this game is just next level. It was unfortunate they released it in the state they did, because if they waited until now, then I could see this being one of the best reviewed games ever, 

The graphics on the highest settings are just mind blowing. Attention to detail, texture, physics on clothes and ray tracing are the best I have seen by a metric mile. 

Story was great, character development was fantastic and the combat/hacking are very polished.

Now the only drawback is the occasional glitch. That said, which game doesn't have glitches? I think no matter what CPR patch at this point, even if there is a single glitch, all of the armchair critics are going to jump on them and act like CP 2077's glitches are somehow less acceptable due to the launch.

All I can say at this point is this game has turned out to be one of my favourites of all time, and I have a massive respect for the CDPR team for finally getting it together and releasing the game it was always intended to be. Cannot highly recommend enough. If you are a fan of FPS, open world, RPG, sneaking, gun fighting, strategic play, then do yourself a favour and get this game.
For all of it's technicall problems, It's a decent single player game. Looking forward for updates.

Similar to a Bethesda games but with massively better controls and graphics. The level of detail on Night City is amazing, and the story is so engaging. I've heard a lot about glitches but I haven't encountered any; I assume it's for people gaming on consoles and toasters.

Overall a disappointment in my opinion to what was expected of this title.

Edit: After Cyberpunk Edgerunners and replaying this game, I am now saying it is worth playing. RIP David.

Awesome. Amazing graphics. Models are great, sound, music, gameplay. Love everything about it. If u love open world games like I do, u gotta have Cyberpunk 2077. Those people saying "I finished it in x hours", is like saying the same for a game of chess. Sure, it could take u few hours or a very, very long time. Depends on how u play. Bugs? Yes, a lot, altough less and less with every patch. I didn't find any gamebreaking bugs in 1.31 so far. It started as a mess, but they have been fixing it a lot, adding patches every now and then and have promised to continue to update it and add new content in the future, like they did for The Witcher 3. I mean, the possibilities are endless, they could add tons of things and I'm for one hoping that they will. But that aside, I think it's totally worth it as it is right now, I'm having a blast playing it. I'll take my sweet long time to explore the beautiful city they created and all it has to offer.  I recommend it to all who love open world games and a cyberpunk future and wish to take the time to really enjoy it. It sure can be improved and hopefully it will but in the meantime, I won't be missing one of the most iconic pc games (imho) while it is still relativelty new and it can still amaze me with it's gorgeous graphics. Cyberpunk 2077 is one of those few and rare games, I think, that mark the technological jump in pc games, that shouldn't be missed while it's still fresh. I've never missed one of those, and sure as hell wasn't going to miss this one. If you think even close to what I think about open world games, and have a good enough pc/vga to play it in ultra, get it while it's hot. You won't regret it.

Doing the first person doesnt work for me unless we are playing a VR game to make it emersive. Otherwise it just feels like a shooter game with some really great storytelling. Johnny is such a cool character and I love being able to play as female V. What I wish there was more of was Merideth. She is the hottest women in the game and we barely get any time with her. I would have enjoyed more missions and time to bond with her. I really hope they improve this game in time. It had so much potential to being an amazing action RPG world that we all could have gotten lost in for many years to come. This is the best game I ever played! Actually it was the best game I ever played until I played the Mass Effect Legendary edition. That game took the top spot. But Cyberpunk 2077 is a close second and after it there is a long gap. 

The city feels very much alive. There is lots to do and there are so many hidden details. You can really loos yourself in there. I know there is not as much traffic and pedestrians around as you would expect for a city of this nature but if there would be you wouldn't get anywhere in a reasonable amount of time so there is a good balance.

The best part and what really makes this game shine are the characters you interact with and the story telling. 
The story is better than many blockbuster movies and the characters are some of the most realistic and well written character I have ever seen. Only beaten by the aforementioned Mass Effect trilogy. 
All of this together with the consistent first person view (even the cut scenes are first person). Makes you feel like you are V by the end of the game. It makes every decision so much harder because it feels like you are deciding about your own life! On top of that you don't have forever to make the decision if you take to long the other person in the conversation will request an answer and get visually impatient. 

When it comes to bugs for me it never was that bad at all. I first played it a month or two after it came out and I did not have any more issues than with a 1 Year old Ubisoft game I played bevor Cyberpunk 2077. And the next Ubisoft game I played was so bad I went back to play another playthrough of cyberpunk 2077 (which I wanted to do anyways) because at least Cyberpunk worked!

I should probably mention that I have the hardware that allows me to play this game at max settings with raytracing on. Which makes it not only one of the best written games but also the best looking game I ever played.
It is for now still the only game I actually played through twice and I enjoyed it as much on the second time as I did the first time I played it.

I know I put YES on recommend, but I strictly recommend this game only if it's on sale, and even then it's a lukewarm recommendation. No amount of patches can deliver on the promise of Cyberpunk 2077, things simply do not feel right at all, it lacks a cohesive direction and vision to push it forward. 

The game design is at times conflicted, for example, Cyberpunk allows you to steal any car you see since it's trying to stick somewhat to rockstar open world conventions, But because it wants to remind you it's still an RPG, there's a stat check before you can steal them. But because the game can't stray too far away on that direction without recklessly flouting convention, you can also just shoot the driver and steal the car anyway without any stat check. But also because this isn't a game about committing theft, you can't rely on stolen cars without getting an instant wanted level as soon as a police literally glances at your direction, making stealing an inconvenience most of the time. It makes the whole feature feel completely redundant, why have it at all?

At other times game mechanics are completely half-baked. Nothing illustrates it better than how completely bonkers the cops behave. Any crime you commit will instantly materialize cops in front of you, and you'll probably die if you go against them, especially at low levels. But also cops literally forget about you the minute you enter any store, or if you travel 200m away from them. What seems like a bug has been raised to the level of feature, seemingly in acknowledgement that police doesn't work right in this game at all

The world itself also feels just as half-baked, even disregarding the walking mannequins populating Night City, the setting doesn't manage to connect, V reads emails in his computer and sorts through spam like it's 1997 and hotmail is the hottest thing in town, people use smartphones and send messages and voice notes in the same fashion as they do today (don't they have computers in their brains?), and apparently brothels have access to amazing imagining technology but it's used only for sex simulations and entertainment, like, would a brothel really invest in this kind of technology, especially in a world where poverty runs rampant and human life is a bit more negligible than today? Why wouldn't brain dances be monopolized by the surveillance industry? 
And why is the big bad corporation is so mysteriously idle throughout the whole game? You'd think it be important to make it seem like corpos are out to get you, because you hold the important mcguffin ever through most of the game, but they seem rather unconcerned with you just running about.

Just everything feels badly thought out, if this game exists, it's probably because some mighty will behind it literally crapped it into existence, but it feels like it has really no creative spark backing its own creation, there's nothing that it wants to say and it doesn't have the ambition to deliver anything that actually captures the imagination. At its best, it's a fun shooter with some crappy driving and nonsense RPG elements thrown in, but at its worse it's a bunch of busywork spread over a massive, empty set of bladerunner masquerading as a game.

That being said, I ended up putting 90 hours post-review. Whatever lack of agency the game itself lacks on its story, it's at least a little bit made up by having an extensive variety of ways to tackle combat. Not that any of them is particularly deep, mind you; stealth, gunplay, hacking and particularly melee have all been done better by other games, but at least this offers you all alternatives from the getgo, which is nice and makes combat feels not as monotonous as it could've been. Gigs are cool, they're little MGS-like outposts which you can tackle however you see fit (to an extent), and if you have a stealth build, i definitely recommend tackling the harder ones as early as possible to get some of the greatest highs this game has to offer. I also recommend doing the secret ending, probably the most fun I've ever got out of this game. Overall, it's fine. I hope that this game, as a beautiful and painstakingly crafted setting, doesn't go to waste. I want to do more in and see more of Night City in the future, either in DLCs or in sequels. I truly believe this has great potential still. As Tim Rogers said, it took them three tries with the witcher.

Despite the initial hiccups and bad press (not defending - it was a janky start) this is a game that grows with you.  Let the fact go that you can't get into a specific car because of a weird glitch and just take a beat and walk through the beautiful disaster that is this universe (not speaking about the game itself but the universe it presents).  

As someone who played Cyberpunk RPG on occasion back in the day, loved William Gibson's freaky creations, thought Max Headroom was pretty rad and even ran a Cyberpunk-based BBS (what's a BBS that you ask? Frontier internet is what.)  out of my bedroom with a ripping dystopian 2400-baud modem I can tell you that this is the world many of us wanted to walk around in.  

While GTA is gritty and dark at times, this is the end of the world.  We caused it ourselves and we're thriving despite our best self-destructive tendencies.  Heartless monuments to human endeavor gone wrong, innovative technology, escapism to the extreme and moral choices await.  This is a dire warning and an absolute celebration of what we are and could become.

Look ... we all know how poorly this game launched. I had been really jazzed about playing this all through the years'-long comeup, definitely riding the hype train, and based on Witcher 3 I felt that CDPR would deliver. Sadly, we know how that turned out. On initial release, seeing the bad press and the company's lackluster reaction, I decided to wait to purchase.

So we're now ... what ... eleven months from release? Bought the game for PC on sale and installed, filled with a sense of looming dread and some reluctance. How bad was this thing going to be? The interwebz would have you believe it's a real s**tshow in here ... but don't always believe the interwebz.

Has my experience been trouble free? Not at all. I've had a glitch or two, but really not Bethesda levels of glitchiness. My pal Jackie sank into the floor getting on an elevator once, and Panam t-posed on the back of my bike that one time. But for the most part? Golden. I'm 30 hrs in and I'm enjoying every second.

Story is good and combat is okay. Better when you get better weapons. It's not mind-blowing by any stretch of the imagination, but is it worth the price of admission? Yeah, it is. So don't believe the nay-sayers and the perpetual bad hype. If you had always wanted to play the game but hesitated on the news, I'd say just do it.

This game was a game of firsts for me. My first pre order, my first modern rpg, my first 500 hours spent in a game, my first long ass review no one will even read. But I need to talk about this game, because it´s that good.

The story touched me in ways I couldn´t have foreseen. Johnny's frustration with the system and the desire to change it, when there's really no clear or clean way to do so was incredibly relatable, and it put a lot of my thoughts into words. The story is good, not too long, which, paired up with some great side-quests, makes for a longer experience if you desire it. 

One of my favourite aspects of this game is the customization. For your build, and for your character. Being able to play as a woman, made to look like I want her too, with great voice acting and to have me able to choose her clothes, and choose the build, which can be anything from melee to stealth to guns to sniper rifles, was a major deal breaker. Yes the game is first person, and I would't have it any other way, as there's many moments that would only work in first person, but you know how your character looks, you hear her, you see her in the mirror. And as a woman, being able to play as one in game was great for my immersion.

The gameplay. Ah, where do I even start? There's a lot, a lot of options, so as you imagine there's some hits and some misses. The melee combat could use some work, and as much as I would love to use the monowire more, the execution of it lacks some nedeed complexity. But the gunplay is amazing, the details in the guns, the animation, the sounds are great, and they're just fun to use. The katanas are very good too. There's also a lot of cyberware, from your cyberdeck to the double jump legs, which opens a lot of doors for different builds. The stealth is fun without being too challenging.

The music. THE MUSIC. It feels like a love letter to music and rock sometimes. I can't listen to "Been Good to Know ya" or "Never Fade Away" without crying a little. The quality of the music really makes the world believable, they sound and feel like they were recorded there. 

I could go on forever, I really could. This game watched me grow. I went from struggling on easy with a very bad build to thriving on very hard. I know I love this game because it's message stays with me and I carry it and think about it on my day to day life. I loved it from the moment I read the description back in september 2020, and I love it now, more than one year later, because it taught me to keep fighting, even if the fight seems already lost. The game is not perfect, and this is not an objective review by any means, because objectivity is overrated when there's so much soul to be seen and felt every second you play it.

Honestly, bad launch aside, this is a great game. It's not perfect, but it has plenty of shining qualities that far outweigh the bad. I've played it on base Xbox One at launch, so yes I experienced the bugs and performance issues. And now I've experienced it on PC. 

The biggest problem with Cyberpunk 2077 is undoubtedly that it was undercooked, and that blame goes to the executives at CDPR, not the developers. There's a lot of passion and care bleeding from this game, but you can tell it hasn't been fully realized. Still, I don't think that makes the game as horrible as I've seen some people say. What we did get is pretty well rounded, all things considered. 

Pros: 
Phenomenal characters
Amazing main narrative
Great attention to many side quests/gigs
Striking visuals, feels truly next gen especially on a high end PC
Fantastic soundtrack/score
Great environment design (the verticality is a very nice change)
Generally enjoyable combat

Cons:
Stealth can feel pretty lacking at times, unless you're invested in quick hacks
Choices don't always give extremely visible impacts
More than a few undercooked gameplay systems
Player appearance customization is present, but for something in the Cyberpunk genre is admittedly lacking
Bugs (though many have been fixed by now, there are still some)

Overall, Cyberpunk 2077 is a game that (in my opinion) is worth the price, provides a satisfying narrative and game world to explore, but is marred at times by performing a constant balancing act between polish and a lack of it. Ranking it as a whole, I give this game an 8/10. With more time in the oven, I genuinely think it could be a 9.5/10 or 10/10. It bleeds with potential that was shut down by corporate influence, but not enough to ruin it.

Yet after a certain amount of time there seems to be little substance. Missions start to become redundant: go in this gang's den, have a shooutout, kill everyone, retrieve an item. Then repeat. So, I’ll stay straight up, I didn’t follow the development of this game at all. It came to my attention about a month out from release and I just bought it because I love dystopian stories and the game basically looked like Blade Runner. 

How does it look? I’m running the game on an MSI laptop with an RTX 2070 and I’m running an external 27-inch monitor. I’m running the game with most settings at the highest in 2560 x 1440 with some ray tracing enabled and the game looks and plays brilliantly. 

The bugs? As far as stability is concerned, I’ve had it crash twice in 500 hours, which I would have thought is pretty good 😊. Yes, there is the occasional visual bug but it’s no where near as bad as people make out and it hardly spoils the experience. Just because the Stormtrooper hits his head on the door in the background do you hate Star Wars? In the first 150 odd hours I had 5 missions glitch, which required me to reload and go back about 5 minutes of game time. Since then, I can’t remember a mission glitching. 

The story? I found the main story thoroughly enjoyable and enjoyed the array of endings. Many of the side quests were also very engaging and interesting. Some weren’t as good, but you get that in any games. Given the hours I’ve played obviously I think the game has a fair bit of re-playability. 

The strengths? Personally, this is probably the most immersive word/game that I have ever experienced. The cars, the clothes, the playstyles, and the voice acting. The female V is utterly engaging, and Keanu Reeves is actually quite enjoyable. The architecture of the city is completely believable and feels like a well lived in city, both beautiful and grubby. I just can’t speak highly enough of the world they have created, and I have completely bought in. 

Now of course people are entitled to their own opinion and that’s fine, but a lot of the negative reviews feel like the sort of review that some people leave at high end restaurants. You go and have an amazing dining experience then go home and read reviews where people are like “so bad I went to McDonalds afterwards”. Like c’mon, give me a break. Anyway, I’m looking forward to future content and spending more time in this magnificent world, one of my favourite games of all time.

And I mean a big sale, wait until its at least half off.  No point in paying almost $100 on a buggy unfinished game, with laughable AI that's 10 years behind the latest GTA game.  And the story, while has great voice-acting, ends up also being a disappointment.  It starts off strong, and ends up being a story where you barely care about the characters, and feels a bit like MGS 5, where it feels rushed and unfinished near  the end, like there's a lot of cut content that's missing.

Heck this ain't no GTA 4 even, let alone equal to older games when it comes to the open-world being believable or immersive.  The NPC's and AI just feel so basic.

Also, if you have a lower end machine, disable RTX.  It still looks fine.

One of the best rides of my life. Few RPGs succeed in capturing the beauty, the ugliness and the randomness of life so viscerally. Hours melted away like minutes and I am satisfied with my play-through and ending. A short life with Pan-Am is better than an eternity alone and bitter like Johnny!
Overall if your your looking for a game to sink around 35 to 50 hours in and has decent game play then this is for you also has a great modding community to improve on games features

This game is a lot more in depth than I thought. It's not meant for one play through and be move aside. I realized that every decision made changes the world around me. Everything from main story to ALL the side hustles and gigs (and possible reported crimes) just minor scale to large scale changes to the world. It will go unnoticed, if you just run towards the end of the game. However, if you take your time and explore and re-explore, you'll see causality hard at work. I chose to stick with this game, from presale, believing that the developers DID have a plan and stuck with it. My opinion is that it was worth waiting through the many bugs and I'm eager to see what new content CDPR will give us.

I've been following Cyberpunk since pre-launch and I was very disappointed to see just how un finished the game was at launch.  Over time the game has gotten more playable with patches released and some bugs squashed but my overall thought at the time of writing this (30th June 2021) is the game is very much still not finished.  In my opinion this could have been the best FPS/RPG to have ever been created but with a rush to market has meant a slower pickup and people not wanting to buy it has meant slower sales and more refunds.   I have encountered a few bugs since patch 1.23 that really breaks the immersion factor, examples:

1. Character models sliding on a dance floor instead of dancing
2. Character mouths stop moving but dialogue continues
3. Car models stop rendering halfway
4. Fallen through the map once
5. Continuous crashes back to desktop

In all instances a bug report was filed.

The roadmap for CDPR has changed and they are dedicating this year to (hopefully) fixing the game up good and proper because when it works it is a stunning game that has so much potential.  The story is rich, the voice acting is superb, the graphics are out of this world and of course Night City is a place I want to fully investigate, I could stay there for years!
My hope is by the time the free DLCs drop we have a very stable game that's a pleasure to play and be a part of, also it should go without saying but thanks to the devs for everything they are doing to put this game right.

While many have experienced many (even game-breaking) glitches and bugs (especially at launch), I personally have not. The game does feel too short and unfinished in some aspects, but it is seamless enough to not immediately reveal where the problems lie. The main issue seems to be thematic inconsistency and lack of gameplay variety in the end, but if you like the gameplay you're given, it's not going to be an issue. The thematic inconsistency, however, is difficult. Cyberpunk 2077 criticizes capitalism harshly and points out the inevitable conclusion of deregulation and right-libertarian politics, but it doesn't seem to offer anything better than "leaving" as a solution to its problems, nor does it show the systemic nature of the issues at hand. The campaign works as an emotional story about nostalgia, friendship, individuality and the nature of consciousness, but not as much more. 

I still enjoy the game, because the main gameplay loops are particularly addictive and the main campaign is done especially well. The presentation is also exquisite. It's worth 20€ in my opinion.

I wanted to rewrite my review of cyberpunk 2077 to give credit where credit is due. This game DEFINITELY needed some more time in the oven, and after several patches and updates, CDPR's initial vision for what this game was supposed to be is becoming much clearer. 

I really misjudged how complex and, frankly, broken a lot of the builds can be if you do your research.  Look up some of the character builds people have created on YouTube or Reddit, and you'll find there's some absolutely disgusting (and really fun) builds you can toy with. Wanna roll around with aim hacks, holding mouse 1 and headshoting everything in sight, zero skill required? You can do that. Wanna stop time and slash everyone to death with mantis blades, killing everyone before they even notice you're in the room? Go for it. Wanna infect all guards or hostiles with a digital virus that flatlines them in seconds? Do it. The world is your oyster and CDPR really gives you the tools to create the most broken character builds imaginable. 

While the story leaves a little bit to be desired IMO, it's the worldbuilding that is really the star of the show. If you remove the heist gone wrong elements and focus on the world CDPR is trying to show you, the game is really just about being a criminal in a dystopian future ruled by criminals. If you approach the game from that angle, everything becomes much more compelling.....

..Which I guess is the punchline of this review. Cyberpunk is really what you make of it. It's a game that only shows its full hand if you're willing to dig deep, and not everyone is going to have the patience to do that (I certainly didn't at first). Rather than being a game that revolutionized games going forward, I feel like Cyberpunk tried to combine a bunch of beloved gameplay genres and styles into one neat little package, and after the really rough launch and a bit of tlc I feel like it succeeded. I don't feel like it's a game for everyone, but it's a great game for some (including me). I feel like it's a game that's easy to misunderstand, and the technical problems didn't really help the situation. I recomend it to anyone that loves sci-fi, or classic 2000's era RPGs. If you can get down on deus ex, or system shock, this will be heaven for you. 

Also, the anime is great. Check it out!

I can't think of any other game that I have completed that has less replay value than this one. You're so utterly railroaded and without agency throughout the plot that it essentially becomes nothing more than a glitchy tech-demo once you've finished it the first time. Every time I reinstall it, it lasts about two or three hours in my Steam library before I just cannot be bothered to continue anymore, plodding through the puerile storyline and porky dialogue which you are forced to endure. I am completely apathetic now about this game and I think that, for a game that is ostensibly an "RPG", there's no worse condemnation than that. Think of "Kingdom Come Deliverance", "TES Skyrim" and "Fallout 3/New Vegas" and others like them. Now consider this; Bethesda and Warhorse are themselves notorious for bugs in their own games but, UNLIKE this game from CDPR, those games get a pass and are rightly regarded as classics of the genre, because the depth of involvement in the ROLES that you can PLAY mean that the way you uniquely affect the story of the GAME is almost endlessly enjoyable. I must have at least half a dozen play-throughs on each of those titles. I doubt I will ever again want to sit through the repetitious and dull mess that this game is. Certainly, it looks very nice on the surface and the gameplay mechanics are fairly acceptable, albeit very derivative from things such as VATS in Fallout and other Skill Tree focussed RPGs, but that scarcely makes up for the lack of heart and feeling of disconnection from the plot in this title. Pour masses of unresolved bugs over the top of this and it's an unappetising dish when you attempt to serve it again. If it goes on a special reduced sale, then maybe try it for the experience of the aesthetic, but if you want an RPG that will remain in your memory forever, try one of the titles I already mentioned, and if you want an open-world action title, turn to GTA V.

Even with the patches and fixes to performance and stability, Cyberpunk 2077 is still largely a dud, mostly because it feels like a cheap imitation of cyberpunk, rather than a game that was built on a foundation of it. The world and characters are beautiful, but also as shallow and glaringly artificial. Night City is beautiful, but it doesn't feel like a place that people actually live, so much as a prop stage.

The gunplay and stealth aspects are wonderful, but too often they take a backseat to a meandering, poorly written quest with dialog and voice acting that mostly ranges from boring to cringe-worthy. 

The game is also completely and hilariously over-sexualized in every way, from every woman dressing like a prostitute to highly-sexualized and misogynistic advertising *everywhere*. Also, the game initially had so many random dildos scattered throughout the world that developer CDPR had to issue a patch just to eliminate some of them. They're still everywhere, though. There are more dildos laying about in this game than there are rats in New York City. It's just so hilariously corny, like a bunch of edgelord teenagers on a video game forum spamming porn pics to show how rebellious and anti-establishment they are.

Basically the game has a lot of problems that patches and hotfixes simply cannot solve. I'd wait for this to come to Game Pass, or go on a deep sale, before I'd recommend anyone pick it up. It definitely does not deserve $60 of your hard-earned money.

It's been over 9 months since I've had the game and I won't deny that the game still has it's faults.  However, despite the bungling of CD Project Red, and the premature release, the game itself is engaging, dark, and filled with adult themes.  This game isn't for kids.    

If you take every cyberpunk trope, toss in some grand theft auto, add some RP elements, and then toss them all into a bag and mix you'll get Cyberpunk 2077.  Night city feels real, the people have their issues, the cops cant/wont help you, and the Corps are running the show.  You can choose one of three life paths, playing as V, who's down and out and trying to climb to the top of the pile of crap you find yourself in, all the while trying to make something of yourself, or leave at least leave a lasting impression.  Fade away, or die young and leave a beautiful corpse behind.

The story telling is deep, rich and full of potential,  The down sides are technical.  The game makers pushed the game out long before it was ready and they've been burned as a result.  But because the potential of the game is obvious, its hard to give them less than 3 stars out of 5.

Ignore the complaints, some just need to spread their negative nonsense. The game is being ironed out and it is fantastic. It will only get better and richer in it's depth, get it and play it. If you have issues talk to CDPR they listen. Absolutely LOVE IT

Despite the awful launch, CDPR has done a lot of bug fixing in the past year or so and if you're even remotely interested in that Bladerunner/retro-futuristic design, I'd say pick this bad boy up and give it a try. The story is exceptional in my opinion, the gameplay is meh(Melee weapons and sniping is the way to go if you ask me) and the graphics are stunning. That being said there are still bugs, though a lot more few and far between now. You need a pretty beefy PC to run it well, unfortunately. To give you an idea, I have an AMD Ryzen 7 3900x, 2x16gb(32 gigabytes total) Corsair Vengeance ram clocked at 3600mhz and an Nvidia GTX 1660Ti and I still get the occasional frame dip on a mix of medium and high settings. Weapon variety is dog shit, maybe 3-5 different types of weapon per category, a handful of shotguns, a handful of ARs, a handful of SMGs etc. etc. I still have no idea if armor rating does anything but I always just put on what clothes I think look nice. I'm sure it matters, especially on higher difficulties but it's no fun to be a tank that one shots everything while moving around like a ninja in the night, double jumping and dodging around.

Anyway TL:DR bug fixes have made a huge difference and I would recommend it if you like the style and genre.

All the glitches aside, which can be annoying (They are working on it!), I love the look of it, All the little things get you thinking of the world that may be, even though I hope people aren't that crazy in the future to draw circuits on there faces, even though it looks cool. This game can be intense at the start, even in easy, but I will admit dying for stupid reasons is boring, but I've realised they've fixed the saving to shorter intervals which is a big plus. Thumbs up, I honestly can't wait for part 2. To me, this my new GTA!!!!!!!

Great game.

So it's now been about a year after the release of Cyberpunk 2077. I bought into the hype and preordered this game like a CLOWN, did a few side quests, finished the main story, and have touched it once or twice to see if it's gotten better. In my opinion it's only slightly. It's got a really good story, lots of cool characters, and a solid atmosphere. It's got the recipe to be an outstanding rpg, except it's all kinda weighed down by it's numerous flaws. 

Enemies are bullet sponges and just feel awful to fight on harder difficulties. It doesn't help that the shooting feels pretty rough. Think Dead Island or Fallout NV without VATS, it's similar feeling to that sort of gun play, which isn't the most flattering of comparisons. 

The world is colorful and vibrant. So it's a shame that you can't do anything immersive like get a hot dog from the numerous food vendors that line the streets, drink at bars, or get a haircut or tattoo. Sure, you may say these are frivolous complaints but that’s what makes “immersion”: frivolous things to do outside of the gameplay loop. Things that have no consequence to the game itself and are there only for you to feel like you’re part of the world. Unfortunately, what little immersion you manage to have is ruined by silly bugs, like cars not loading in when you enter an area so you end up parking inside of another car, or police spawning in three feet in front of you or just around a corner. They say they have patched some of these, but they seem to still happen when I tested it recently. 

The game as a whole has so much potential. That said I doubt it will ever come close to what it could have been and what they hyped it up to be. I can't recommend it in it's current state unless it's on sale. It's not a that it's a bad game, but that it's so average in everything except for it's story and characters and that it was promised to be so much more than it is.

There's a transmog system now, so you can actually dress how you want without looking like an idiot for stats. So far seems like some very solid improvements, but nothing so big as to change my original opinion of the game. I recommend grabbing it on a 50% sale.

[h1] Let this be a letter of my love for this game. [/h1]

I'd like to preface this by saying that in no way is this game perfect. It's far from it, actually. But really? None of that matters to me. I'm not one who is commonly effected by bugs, or glitches or anything like that. I usually play games for stories and characters, and Cyberpunk is no exception from this. Although I do enjoy the gameplay (to an extent), The main, and even side characters, are so damn good. CDPR poured so much love and attention into these characters. The voice actors did such a good job, even on smaller roles. I found myself loving Claire, who makes minimal appearances outside of her own questline, simply because of her charisma and enthusiasm towards V. Things like this truly make or break a game for me. 

That being said, CP77 [b] is not perfect [/b]. There's issues with the police AI, with repetitiveness inside of side gigs, and a bunch more bugs. They aren't game breaking of course, but they're still very noticeable. Despite what Steam says, I've been playing it since launch, and to see CDPR's dedication to making the game better makes me have high hopes for it. I'm a little bummed that the first DLC was just an alternate outfit for Johnny, a car and two jackets that quite frankly aren't the coolest, but I am glad they're putting their time into fixing the bugs already inside the game before attempting any actual DLCs. Some of the side quests were seriously, genuinely fun, like the Delamain quest. 

If you complain about the characters being boring, did you even play the game? There is so much depth and meaning and care put into them, it's something a writer could only ever wish for. A fantastic example of this is the game's deuteraganist, Johnny Silverhand. You meet him after the prologue, and immediately assume that he'll be the villain for the majority of the game (or atleast, that's how I viewed it). But slowly and surely, you start to love him, and trust him, even if V banters with him quite a lot. I found myself loving him so much to the point where I started to buy merch. Keanu put his whole ass into this character and I salute him. (Love u Johnny<3)

There's so much freedom, and creativity, and even if the character creation is a little lacklustre, I still found myself creating a character that meant a lot to me by the end of the game.

Don't take my word as fact, as I have low standards and get attached to characters too quickly, but give this game a chance before you let other reviews sway you. 

And maybe I am just a neurodivergent gay teenager with a little too much time on their hands, who cares? This game and it's universe means so, so much to me, and I'm really excited to see it's future releases and updates.

[h1] REALLY wanted to like this game, but can't overall [/h1]

As a prefix, I'm also hoping (but doubting) that they develop a free DLC/MAJOR update that brings everything they promised their fans. I feel like a clown for sayin it and for pre-ordering it but... One can hope, right?

As a general rule, I try to look at game from multiple standpoints and I try to look for how it might appeal to certain audiences, but... There's just so much to unpack that I honestly won't do too much, because the top reviews kinda already go over it.

My BIGGEST concern with this game outside of their promises it how one dimensional the game feels. Unlike The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, none of your in game experience ever changes the outcome besides 3 endings that might have some slight variant in their options depending on who you save and talk to, but it's all basically the same. Even the secret endings kind of feel like the same and leave you feeling like, "That's it?". One other minor thing you might enjoy, but rather feels lackluster, is the ending credits will show different people for different phone calls and those calls can be different depending on your relationships with them. (Though, I will say, one of the endings... The phone calls made me cry. If you get there, you know which one I'm talking about.)

Now, with this said: If you're okay with a story that you can just play through once or twice before you basically know everything that's going to happen in the end regardless as to your choices; it's a fair game. The combat isn't the most amazing but it's at least interesting in some cases and is otherwise like any other COD FPS game. There are some unique aspects to the game that I will give credit where credit is due, such as the ability to hack your enemies, but it really doesn't feel super impactful to the overall experience.

A lot of this may feel like I actually enjoyed the game, but that's the part of me that wants to like it. Otherwise, there was so many letdowns that it's hard to enjoy. The game had a demo years ago that far surpasses what the game actually gave you. Choices feel like you only have the illusion of choice in that you either 1. Go with the story 2.a. Fight/b. Die. Police just feel like GTA at this point but worse. Fighting styles never change. 

[b] (EDIT:) Can we also talk about the beginning routes?? [/b] Literally NONE of them do anything special for the story line besides give you different conversation topics and maybe, MAYBE some small decision that helps you short term but ultimately leads you back to the same story line as ANY. OTHER. BACKGROUND!

Bugs aside? It's just very monotonous and can eventually feel tedious if you're just trying to explore the world because there's not much variety. Yes, the stories are different but most are all as said before by others, "go into a place, shot things, steal something, leave. . ." In the end there's no replayability and that really hurts it's already damaged reputation.

[b] 4/10. Not the worst but left a lot to be desired. Would only recommend that if you really want to get this: Wait until it's at least half off. Not worth your money otherwise. [/b]

Good Game

Pros:
-An excellent story with a great cast of characters.
-A beautiful setting, the best I've ever seen in a game.
-An excellent soundtrack, perfectly fitting the genre.
-Good voice acting for every character in the game.
-A huge amount of lore behind every megacorp, gang, and, of course, Night City itself.
-Good combat, way better than I was expecting coming off the Witcher 3.
-The story may not be as smart as it's pretending to be, but it still dives into themes that triple A games usually stray away from.

Cons:
-Buggy, but you've heard this before. At the very least it isn't as bad as it used to be, but still, buyer beware.
-Driving sucks, doesn't matter what vehicle you're behind they all feel off.
-The story can feel weirdly paced. A lot of the "side-quests" should probably just have been included in the main-questline.
-Tho gunplay (and to a lesser extent the melee stuff) is good, hacking is generally boring at best.
-Hints of unfinished content all over the place. The devs clearly needed more time to actually finish this game.

Conclusions:
I love Cyberpunk 2077. I've played it since launch, finished the vast majority of the content it has to offer, and have had a great time. Despite all the bugs, I still find myself thinking about Night City, Johnny, Panam, Judy, Jackie, Takemura, and all the rest every-so-often, something only Red Dead Redemption 2 has managed to elicit before. 

However, I won't lie, this game was [i] broken [/i] on release, and, many ways, still is. But I can live with that, after all, I played Skyrim on release and didn't have an issue, so why would I have a problem here? Well, that's because my real issue with the game isn't the bugs, it's the clear evidence of unfinished content, or poorly thought through design decisions. Stuff like (spoilers ahead) [spoiler] Jackie's death occurring so early, you barely got to know him. Or how there is no cosmetic customization after you make your character, not even haircuts! Or how certain areas, despite being highly detailed, have nothing of note occur in them except a boring criminal activity you can stop. Or how all quests are pretty much delivered through sometimes arbitrary phonecalls, instead of random encounters (tho those exist too) or a "help-wanted" board like the witcher had. These are just a couple, I'm sure you'll find more complaints online if you look. [/spoiler] . I could go on, but that would be beating a dead horse. The worst part about this is how I don't think Cyberpunk is a bad game... but it is disappointing to see how much better it could have been if it came out in winter 2021, rather than 2020.

Nonetheless, I am very excited to see what is in store for the future of Night City... so long as CDPR doesn't drop it like a rotten egg instead of putting the time and energy into fixing this game like it deserves. If you loved the Witcher, you'll probably love this at any price, but if not I'd recommend waiting 'till the next sale, at least until they fix it.

(Reviewed as of patch 1.3) This game was always great and it just keeps getting better. Hating on the game in long video essays may be helpful for your tube channel watch hours but it's disingenuous. Cyberpunk is very much cRPG title first and foremost, fully voiced, masterfully scored, surprisingly emotionally gripping with a story that concludes with one of several satisfying endings some 20 or 80 hours later depending on how much side content you want to engage in. What it is not is a mass shooter and cop killing simulator. I love being refused a refund for a game i put at most 2.5 to 3.25 hours, of actual gameplay, over the course of 6 to 8.5-ish hours due to crashes and having to tweak everything from game settings to ram timings to gpu clocks and volts to reinstalling to an ssd(which left the launcher open for like 2 to 4 hours by itself) and caching data in ram cache and restart to see if i could make it more than the bog standard 15 mins before the game eats shit faceplants and doesnt even throw me an error i can look up, just a generic device driver hang message(not sure for which device, tried stoc, UC and OC for cpu, gpu,ram, Bclk/PCIe transfer speeds @ gen 2 and 3 for storage and gpu); And that isn't even counting the original install and it's hours of trouble shouting(No, not a Freudian slip) into over the course of multiple playthroughs usually never making past second main mission(one where jackie dies) without out game breaking crash and ended up with 15.5 hours of play time because steam counts time spent at your launcher trying pick setting that wont cause your game to crash on load or in first 15-45 minutes.

The furthest i ever made it was just before or on my way to the mission with pan am and that was 2 or 3 months after being denied 2-3 different refund requests, where i explained most if not all of this and was told they can't and don't want to do anything to change it (i'm assuming it's less likely they'd have to pay out for a refund when the person spends an hour installing it, and after they play another hour they've already gone over the 2 hour limit), they're going to continue to count time based on launcher.exe's runtime not the actual game.exe's runtime and because my total time played said more than 10-12 hours at the time even though my longest uninterrupted playthough from start of character including time spent in creator until crash during the delamaine ride after 2nd main story mission holding jackie's corpse was only an 1 hour and 18 minutes plus 20-30 or so seconds from desktop to game to desktop again when i stopped my timer due to driver hang crash.

Don't get me wrong, after making it almost 4.5-6 hours in and 3.25-4.5 hours of which was in my character, i can say the first 2-4 hours, depending on your play rate, are some of the best hours in an open world game, the level of detail afforded to linear games is what it feels like, but after 4-6 hours, depending on your play rate, you fall back into 2013-16 gta V level of quality and the immersion goes out the fucking window. Seriously what dafuq, did they even playtest any part of the game past 6 hours in? 
lets review all the tech and coding advancement in gaming CD RED has yet to implement and these are just off the top of my head
halo ce: 2001 - simple AI behavior tree's that can appear complex/almost life-like and can build on other scripted behaviors(e.g. sillt animations like running hands through hair or touching face or inspecting things when player sits idle in specific enviroments and places)
minecraft: 2011 - handled spawning/de-spawning and object permanence infinitely better than cyberpunk(e.g. looks around sees no one for miles turns around mugs old lady and boom entire swat team on location whispering we don't like your kind round here in your ear, or saving civilians from gun toting maniacs to turn around and hundreds of civilians have gone poof and disappeared from this plane of existence)
gta V: 2013 - better cops(kinda goes hand in hand with the above concept) and an interesting implementation of multiplayer mechanics that could be fun for cyberpunk

As you can see most of these ideas are at least 10 years old by now, and im not even going to get started on steam stupid fucking policies, like tracking launcher.exe runtime and not game.exe runtime, they could fix it by just changing the name of the file they monitor to the same name as game.exe instead, problem fixed.

It is 2021 and not 2077 yet, I have only played for about 6 hours and got a chance to see the famous city. 
There is no denying that this is a real  technical achievement and a probably a very successful story line as well.

There is a blade runner like atmosphere and level of details is simply **astonishing**.

I am equipped with a 4K screen basic HDR (600) built-in and an AMD 9600X GPU (Sapphire Toxic Extreme clocked at 2700 MHz and a matching motherboard Asus x570, resizable bar enabled). 

In Game graphics, settings set at max 4K resolutions and details, but without ray tracing, 58 fps at 4K using Sapphire TriX oversampling which works like AMD Super  Resolution FX. 
All textures and other settins are maxes out. There are not anti aliasing, always on by default cannot be turned off.

Is it good with an AMD 9600 ? Definitively way at the top. This game will have you believe that you can only run it with an Nvidia card, well there is some business deals behind the scene.

When I turned on Ray Tracing, performance sinks to very low fps and the worst is that RT does not live up to my expectations, it is nothing like the demo with and without ray tracing although all RT settings are enabled at max.
There are certainly more more detailed reflections and better shadows (graduations) with RT  but not the day and night difference demoed in some YouTube Videos and I do focus on details, believe me.

So I have spent some time admiring all those maps and reviewing the more intricate details, the ads, the water puddles, the neon lights, the city view, the sky, the architecures and this is simply beautiful with or without Ray Tracing, what really makes the difference is the DESIGN, I repeat, the design of the maps.

Anywhere you look, it is full of details, ashes, newspaper that you can read, objects, even rubbish bags, it is in 2021, as near as reality as it gets, I can only imagine what it could look like in VR, if this was available.

It looks like this game was used a marketing POC by Nvidia,RT may be better on Nvidia performance wise but for those who have an AMD cards, have no fear, that will work great.

Super- sampling is mandatory to get decent frame rates with or without RT anyway if you have all options maxed and both Nvidia and AMD cannot currently run this at 4K with full RT enabled. (Radeon 6900 XT and RTX 3090)

As for the games bugs, I may not have played long enough to see them, lots were reported by other gamers, I have not seen any, maybe because the latest patch did resolve a few ?

Let us not forget what the game is, putting aside the beautiful atmosphere and graphics, this is very much a standard RPG, cut scenes which can be skipped, and objectives and missions to do. Maybe I am not so fond of those scripted dialogues but the developers were clever enough to give you an option to skip them even when it is the first time you play, so a non issue as far as I am concerned, a bit like when watching a movie.

Some people criticized saying that it was not the revolutionary game they expected, well they failed to see that the graphics are revolutionary indeed, but the game mechanics remains, well, what an RPG looks like in 2021, what did you expect ?

I expect that a number of people will have been put off by the initial price but at the moment it is 30% off, so that was of course very welcome.

The NPGs are excellent, you can hear conversations a bit like in Assassins Creed but that way 2 levels up, better design, more realistic movements and simulations, so yes that is at the top of what you can get in 2021 that is......

Admittedly, you need very powerful hardware to run a game like this.

I hope that this helps. Enjoy :-)
