I played, and beat, this game ON RELEASE. I'm downloading it again to experience it with less bugs. I would have given it a 4/5 on my original play through. Obviously it wasn't ready for release on day 1. The bugs were plentiful and mostly hilarious. That said, I was able to play the game and I was completely taken in by the story. The visuals, music, and voice acting were quite good. After I powered through the story I kept playing with different builds. The combat had more depth than the enemies really justified exploring. There is a lot of potential to do more with the combat. I found myself wishing there were randomized re-playable missions or raid bosses just to explore and push the combat system to it's limits.

The bottom line really comes down to how much the story will engage you, in my opinion. There are a few different endings, but not too much variation in outcomes. It would have been nice to have your in game choices impact more of the games events. The characters and themes are engaging but not ground breaking. For me, it was the atmosphere. Something about Johnny Silverhand angrily ranting about the "forces of fucking entropy" with the music and setting adding  an emotional weight to his words that they otherwise wouldn't inspire. I don't know, I'm not a story guy typically but this game had me locked in.

I had a 2080ti non OC and a i9 9700k, perhaps that contributed to a smoother on release experience? The game is beautiful but seemed hard to run. I would be a little suspect about using less than mid range hardware.

I want to see more of the world. I want more stories. I want the game to ultimately succeed enough to justify more. More of the potential I saw in it on release day. Be informed about what the game is and try not to worry yourself about the bugs. I'm sure there's still bugs, doubtful anything game breaking at this point. If I could make it through on day 1 and experience an 8/10 game with the potential implied in so many ways for a stunning 10/10, I think you'll enjoy it as well.

Edit 1:
There's something to be said about people who don't recommend the game but have clocked 75 to 100 hours in game. The story is about 30 hours. The people saying "no" are sinking another 50 ish hours into a game they don't think is worth your time? Think about that, what is driving people to play a game for weeks that isn't worth playing? 

It had the skeleton of an amazing game on day 1 and experiencing the world, alone, is likely worth the price of admission.

It hardly needs to be said, but Cyberpunk 2077 obviously had a very rough start.

With that out of the way, the game is fantastic. It offers a large open world, lots of side quests, absolutely wonderful and hilarious dialog, fun gunplay, believable and relatable characters, and an entertaining (if a bit short) main story full of some tough choices. The menus can be a bit clunky and cumbersome, but they're workable. 

It has a reputation of being tough on PC hardware, and it's a well-deserved reputation. However, I'm on an i7-6700k, MSI 1070, and 16GB of DDR4, and I could average 45-60fps with settings mostly on low or medium - and the game still looked great. Not just good enough, but really, really good even on lower settings. 

In terms of stability, it was pretty bad at launch. Over the last few months as I finished my playthrough? The game never crashed on me once. It's definitely still a bit buggy, but certainly no worse than a Bethesda game of comparable scope. Plus, the devs are really putting work in to fix bugs and QoL issues. The last patch was 38GB.

Overall, yes, I would definitely recommend Cyberpunk 2077 to anyone interested. It may not be the best game ever made (looking at you, Witcher 3), but it's a solid 8.5/10 from me.

I was only aware this game existed through osmosis, so none of the hype really affected me. But with that out of the way, I got to say the game is pretty good. Sure its not the Second Coming but you get a lot for what you pay. I have played a lot of AAA games and many of them claim to be next gen, but this game is the only AAA game I played that actually feels next gen. Sure it has some bugs. I was one of the lucky ones, when I bought it at launch, I experience few bugs. And for what its worth I really enjoyed Cyberpunk 2077.  128 hours of entertainment so far. Come into this game with reasonable expectations and I'm sure you wont be disappointed.

New: CD PROJEKT RED has turned this pile of nearly unplayable pixels into an amazing game. Unlike Bethesda, they aren't solely relying on the community to finish this game. They are putting an effort into Cyberpunk 2077 that is living up to the class of games that The Witcher series is a part of. I fully endorse this title now and can't wait to see where this road takes us. 

Original: CD PROJEKT RED gave into cyberbullying, pun intended because this game is a hyped up joke, so now we have a half baked game that's more akin to a beta of a tech demo. Should have stayed in development until they were able to fulfill their promises. Oh, and the free DLC is a mushroom stamp to our faces. Thanks for the hilarious glitch compilations.
I personally love it, but I can understand the frustration when it came out. However, my experience was 9/10

Don't buy anywhere near RRP. RRP is for finished games. Wait for big sale.

Basically open world, budget/knock off Deus Ex Mankind Divided. The environments are all pretty bland, one dimensional and forgettable, as are the unlockable abilities (instead of a cool new ability, usually just a % buff/debuff). The combat is the same as DX with bad AI. Inventory is just plain bad.

If you enjoyed stalking around buildings, learning AI paths and sneaking into an area that has a few skill checks in it, CP77 scratches that itch, albeit barely.

Combat is relatively poorly implemented in vanilla, with all enemies being stupid bullet sponges that have no tactical skills, and weapons all being pea shooters. Realistic combat overhaul is a must for this game, I cannot recommend you even think about playing without it. The enemies are less noticeably dumb when they kill and die in under a minute. 

If you want a coherent, relatable, well written story, you may not be in luck. The story is messy, with badly written dialogue full of impenetrable shorthand that seems awkward by design. The characters range from semi likeable to unlikeable morons who serve as vessels for mission giving and nothing more. Characters are introduced, killed and betrayed so quickly it's all a blur.

The world is insanely unfinished. Large swaths of the map are inaccessible by default due to being abandoned part way through development. Many intended interactive elements are awkwardly removed, like chairs you can't sit on and vendors you can't talk to. 

The intro to the game is a betrayal of several pre launch promises. Your life path is totally irrelevant to the majority of the game, as are all your decisions. You still go to the same places and do the same things no matter what, bar a couple of token variables flipped.

The soundtrack has some real bangers that I listen to outside the game (Dead Pilot anyone?) but there is NO synth wave, which is a huge mistake in a cyberpunk game.

The constant injection of modern politics gets very grating. 

Game is badly optimised even nearly a year after launch. Just runs sloppily and has a whole lot of performance oddities and spikes. Built in AA is lacking, as is the MANDATORY sharpening filter, which is full of grain and noise. Most effects should be disabled and replaced with reshade (including removing green filter). 


tl;dr:
*without mods, 5/10 broken
*with mods, 7.5/10 playable semi broken pseudo RPG
*extreme quality issues, expect possibility of refund for technical reasons
*WAIT FOR BIG SALE, over 25% off at least

WELL now there's a tiny update that breaks all mods every 5 minutes so this game is PERMANENTLY 5/10 broken

not recommended.

Jesus, this game is a mess. I am giving it a positive recommendation but man, this game is a mess. I bought it when it was released, but after several hours decided to wait until I had a better GPU and they fixed most of the bugs. Even after several months, it's still a mess. I never had crashes but audio, quests, characters, items, so much is just buggy. 

The game could have been special but it's just all over the place. The main story line is far too short and the plot/story just wasn't that great. It got far more interesting about mid-to late game with some of the other characters, but the main story line, meh. 

The voice over acting for the main character (both female and male) are bad. I partially blame the VO actors and partly blame the production team. I am sure they gave the actors zero to work on when it came to working off the script considering how hobbled this game is. Most of the other characters did a surprising solid job with the VO, but the the poor main VO's really hurt immersion, especially at the start trying to get into it. 

The game looks great and besides Panam, that might be the main reason I finished it. That being said, you need heavy gear to enjoy it. I have a 3080 and maxed it out and was able to enjoy 45-50 fps. 

Combat, meh. 

The AI. Joke. 

The RPG elements are joke. It's a mess, has absolutely minor impact on character and game play and I stopped caring about it pretty quickly. Same with the crafting elements. The story line is so short, I wasn't able to level up very far. Sure, I could have went through every little side quest and stuff but that stuff was more boring that the main story line. 

I clothing made no sense. So you're saying a ratty old tank top has more armor than a military vest? So random and haphazardly the gear, item and weapon systems are. It felt like a looter shooter but messier. The world is just littered with stuff too. Oh, look next to the bum, a healing thingy. Oh look over there, some ammo. Made no sense. 

At the end of the day, they tried to go too grand. They should have cut down on so much, stayed in their lane and used resources better while building the game. The RPG needs a complete overhaul. 

If you have the hardware and you can get it on sale, it's worth a run through, but keep expectations in check.

Still a broken mess 8 months after release. During my last attempt to play the game on a new rig from the beginning, I somehow encountered more bugs and visual glitches. Items still not collectable, character models popping through walls, corpse physics, broken hacking abilities, NPCs zooming between cars, broken dialogue and audio overlay issues. I actually enjoyed most of my playthrough - despite the frequent bugs - but alas, 9 months of waiting wasn't enough to polish the game, as they are busy focusing on new content rather than fixing the game apparently, with me not being able to finish the game because I could not take or deal any damage - so I just gave up.
Overall: 7/10 (I am being generous, as I am treating it as an animated movie at this point.)
Story&Characters: 8.5/10 This is the strong point of this game, the characters were well thought out, with them having good voice-acting to boot - and the direction that the story takes is pretty interesting.
Graphics: 8.5/10 It doesn't look as good as it was promised in the trailers, but it was pretty close and still looked good. But only at the High&Ultra settings - turning them down makes it look... not so good.
Performance: 6.5/10 For how it looks and plays - it's honestly not that bad, it definitely doesn't run at high fps no matter what, but even with my mid-tier PC - it ran at mid '50s with high&ultra settings at 1080p.
Movement&Combat: 4/10 This is where things the fucky - with V feeling like cardboard flopping in the wind. The animations are crude and stiff with the only good animations being in the cut-scenes, with T-poses, snapping, and twisting being frequent as hell in-game - and relatively common in cut-scenes.
Multiplayer: None. It could have been quite a nice extension in the game if done properly - but it would have been perfect without it - had it been finished properly.

I've had very little problems with the game. It has become one of my favorite games.

Did/does this game have bugs?  Yes.  But so does most every open world RPG.  The Skyrims and Fallouts are chock full of them.  Despite those bugs, this game was perfectly playable for me and I absolutely love it.  This is a fantastic world worth exploring.  The story is passably decent enough to get through, but it's the city itself and the surroundings that are the real star of this show.   As long as they keep making fixes and improvements, I hope everyone gives this a second chance in the future.  Exploring this work of art is absolutely worth it.

Having ignored the overhyped nature of the game, I expected it to not live up to all of its promises. I never expected an actual bug free game. So. Some shoddy writing, contradictions, and a metric dickton of bugs and lack of polish. Yet I still love it. I still like driving around Night City and shooting up the badies who appear on my radar.  I love looking at my character in the mirror and making faces, and I love being able to build who V is to me. While the pricepoint might not be what you want in this game. I can't say it is an unplayable trash heap.

I want to keep this review short and sweet so lets get to it. First and foremost, this game is not terrible, it's not Bubsy 3D level bad, but CD Projekt Red dropped the ball hard with this game. There is a lot missing and it shows. This game in it's current state is not very great, however, there are some good things about it. Sure the story isn't that great, there's no real emotion with V and Jackie's friendship, but you can see a different friendship grow when Silverhand is introduced. Silverhand is the best character in the game in my opinion, I think him and his side quests are the best part of the game, and where I had the most fun. Playing through the game, I had little encounter with bugs, nothing game breaking, except for a glitchy audio issue which needs to be fixed ASAP. This game also is not optimized for the hardware listed. I have a 1660 Ti and a Ryzen 7 3700X and I can barely get 60fps on the highest settings that isn't ray tracing. Some fixes need to happen that will help boost performance incredibly, or they need to change the hardware list on here. So while this game is not very great right now and I wouldn't recommend playing it now, I would recommend it later when it is all fixed and done. It is not bad, but it is also not very good either.

I really enjoy this game especially since upgrading pc's I moved from a laptop rtx 2060 i7 10th gen to a desktop 3070 i7 10700F and now I can enjoy the immersiveness even more. I am completing the story again now with better performance and a lot more bug fixes. The bugs were very minimal before at least for me I'm really looking forward to some actual new content from the developer in the future once all the big fixes are finally all rolled out because I really wanna have more than just the main story and not really having much replayable value. Appart from the intro the game puts you on the same path eventually with slightly different dialogue.
One can only hope this game will be ready to play in 2077...even "hope" is too optimistic..

So, most of the negative reviews that I have read about this game are that they are upset about pre-ordering this game and how many glitches there are. I bought it when it was released on steam, and I have had no issues with this game. I do get the occasional glitch that is to be expected with a massive open world RPG, but I found them more amusing than anything. I never once had the game crash on me never had blue screens that I saw some people post about or anything of the like. Another complaint that I see is that people complain that parts of the map feel empty or abandoned by CD Red. I never got that feeling there are portions of the map that don’t have things going on, but I don’t see why there would be needs to anything in them. If you are worried still, they came with a patch on 17AUG21 so that may help, or you could buy the game on a sale day.
As for the game itself I loved every minute of it! The actual quests were memorable and unique such Coin Operated Boy, Machine Gun, and Epistrophy. The combat was fun and can be approached in many ways with the different skill trees. I loved all the major characters that you work with and their quest lines. The game having romances was something that I didn’t know prior to playing and loved finding it out #Panam. I personally loved exploring the city all the different districts and just running around or flying down the highway in your car.
 Now for some things that I wish they would add to the game in future DLC. 
-Character editing after the game starts, I know its like most RPGs that once you create your character you don’t change them but with the game being about literally swapping out your tech it wouldn’t be too hard to edit your appearance. 
-Repeatable quests, the quests themselves are all unique and I enjoyed them all but once you have done those and all the little crime spots around the city the only thing left to you is the final mission. I would love the addition of some generic repeatable things like more crime spots appearing, a repeatable race, a bounty hunter type mission, or more boxing fights. That would give end game a but more to do to build up skills you might be lacking in, make money to buy cars, or simply to keep playing.
-NPC updates, the NPC’s you find walking around the streets look unique, but they don’t do much. I would love to see some different reaction types when things happen such as people pulling guns on you, or fighting back if you steal their car, or just random drama in the streets between NPC’s.

Installed it yesterday August 2021, a good amount of time to give I think, If I was 8 months late to value on my projects I would be fired, any hoo, I make sure EVERYTHING on my PC is updated because you know Cyberpunk needs all in place as my experience showed me the first run through. I uninstalled, don't bother with tech support I don't plan on installing it again, a true disappointment, enough chances have been given, CD you have now been placed with all the other publishers I will no longer buy from, can't remember the last time I played an EA or Ubisoft game.

This game is just good enough to be frustrating. At every gang fight, plot point, and side quest the game developers wanted to make shines through, providing just enough glimmer of hope to keep playing. 

But that's all it is, a glimmer. The story is linear, without even fleshed out dialogue tree's, let alone branching narrative. The game play is...less than polished. The atmosphere is vast, and empty. Cyberpunk2077 feels and plays like a game it beta. A very good, very promising game that's in beta. On it's own merits I don't think Cyberpunk2077 deserves the flack it's getting. However, just enough of what this game could be shines through to make playing Cyberpunk frustrating. It could have been great, and it turned out a bit less than fine.
It has lots of issues, but it is still a fun game.

With 90 hours of play I cannot recommend this game except if you want to believe that it will be good some day. I bought it because I wanted to experience the hellscape of this buggy mess. Granted, it's way better than when it launched but frankly it shouldn't be the way it is anyway. 

I don't mean to say the game is utterly bad but I have a lot of problem with it in so many places and, to be cut and clean, the version being sold is basically a demo as CDPR is still changing mechanics, spawn points of free stuff, quest rewards and so on. 

My problems with the game are many: The game is not clearly defined if it's an RPG, a looter-shooter or an open world crime sim, because it's not good as any of them. Level cap is too low for the sheer amount of side content. Economy is broken because even at the end game, you may only buy 1 or 2 good cars, which there are no customization for. Crafting is useless as the drops scale as you level up so anything you make before level 50 is bound to be get obsolete.Stealth is a  mechanic that has no place in a game where even when you upgrade the whole skill tree you still can't get a 1 shot kill. Knife throwing obliterates any knife you throw hit or miss. Melee attacks in stealth take you out of stealth. Damage feedback is really bad, for some bosses you take 2 shots without noticing the 1st. Driving is straight up atrocious, vehicles can't do curves. Pedestrians either don't move out of the way or bug out and become a impromptu launch pad. Calling a vehicle either ends with it exploding because it clips into something or blows up with another vehicle it clipped into.

I really want to believe they will fix it, but i'm not hopeful. $60/$70 for a demo is pretty stiff

I've re-written this a handful of times now...
This game just satisfies me... 

The game on its own merit, is.. simply a masterpiece. It follows the dark, despair, tragic, and tough to handle moments of the human condition. This is Black Mirror personified. I LOVE a dystopian cyber future as a genre. For me, it's the best. The story is a huge build up - a twist of fate, romance - and a downfall that leaves you lost. The story is what you wish it to be. I had some very real, cathartic moments from this story. It's not perfectly written, but it feels like it was written for me. 

Gameplay can get stale - you get the same 10 guns with variations of each. the quickhacks are massive powerful, but you can "build" a character in different ways. The game is a bit monotonous at times with the same hacking minigame and run 2 blocks and lose the police.. As long as you can focus on a quest or two at a time, it feels fine. but, this isn't a skyrim, so many things don't feel fleshed out fully. 

That said, I still very much enjoyed the experience, and the gameplay. 
DEFINATELY rush purchase double jump - makes the game WAY more fun, and play the game on hard difficulty. The 1.3 made normal harder, and it feels good, but the extra challenge and faster XP is worth the deadly AI. 

Now playing with a 3080, max settings and DLSS, the game is solid 60-75 fps. The game got better each patch, SLIGHTLY. I'm playing a 5th play through, and have a friend playing their own campaign on my computer. It's so enjoyable for the story alone.
Better since its been updated. A lot of fun to be had.

Let's talk about Cyberpunk 2077. I'll tell you right off the bat, this game did not meet my expectations, but to fair...I never looked up anything on it. Everyone and their Mom is a CD Projekt Red fan except me (I thought the Witcher games were boring and Geralt is really really bland, imo) so I didn't even have the bias from the jump like others. I just heard it was going to be a futuristic open world RPG, which is a genre I love, so I picked it up day one. 

It's very true what they say, there are a lot bugs in this game. I don't even know if I ever ran into a "gamebreaking" bug but I certainly did run into bugs in general. Frankly, I don't care about bugs...I care about bugs that developers don't/can't fix. What I care about is whether or not the video game that I'm picking up will give me a unique experience, this one did. Although the LOOK of the city is inspired by the entire cyberpunk genre, it shows it's own take on not just technology but the culture of the country. Sometimes the game feels like social commentary on where we are headed as a society and I find that super super interesting.

From a gameplay standpoint, guns are limited but still fun and neat. The body upgrades can get stupid levels of both broken and fun. The music is easily one of my favorite parts of the game, I listen to parts of the soundtrack on the regular. And honestly, there's a lot to do in the game besides the main story. My favorite parts of the game actually take place AWAY from the main plotline, which has it's own level of intrigue and there are branching paths depending on your characters origins and decisions. I can honestly say that the only thing I legit cannot fucking stand about the game is that the clothing options are a COMPLETE JOKE because of the lack of selection and to add fuel to that fire...some randomly generated NPCs will be walking around in clothes that you cannot pick up anywhere. 

If you're reading this review so late into this games release, you're probably still interested. Give it a shot. Everyone talks about the bugs, but to keep it real, the more ambitious your game is (especially the larger) the more bugs. Everyone bitched and moaned when they kept delaying it FOR the bugs...it honestly doesn't make any sense to me. I believe I ended up putting something like...70 hours on the launch patch. There's no doubt in my mind that even though this game did not get delivered polished, at least they're still working on it and it's very much still worth $60.

(Update: It makes me insanely happy that they're still working on this game. So many things have been fixed and added, as I expected. Winding down towards finishing my third play-through, cannot wait for the DLC. I truly hope all you Witcher circlejerkers give this game a chance because I want another game in this world.)

I want to keep this review short, because frankly I think overreacting in a review is a disservice to this game.

The game is buggy. NPCs behave strangely, quests break, items aren't interactable, textures freak out, and so on. There was an incredible amount of hype around the game before its release, and it did not live up to that hype due to many issues. The game is undeniably flawed.

However, I think that it still offers a fun gameplay experience. I have personally not run into any game-breaking bugs that corrupt save files (although I know they exist/existed), and because of that I had a lot of fun running around the world and doing random encounters, side missions, and story missions. I chose out a play style I like, and had a great time with it (stealth, cool, silenced pistols, and blades). All in all, it was a fun FPSRPG. Moreover, the devs are continuing to work on the game. The most recent patch, 1.3, introduced a lot of quality of life changes and bug fixes, as well as game balance improvements. The game is and has been improving on a technical level, and I respect that.

I therefore recommend this game. I only hope that the devs are getting to work normal hours when they work on this game, rather than having to crunch for patches nearly a year after the game's release.

Edit: wrote the patch number incorrectly. It is now corrected.

If you don't take yourself too seriously,

If you're not a moral crusader pretentiously trying to bring CDPR to its knees,

If you can appreciate real successes alongside real failures,

If you enjoy cyberpunk (aesthetics and audio as well as themes),

If you like RPG/shooter hybrids,

And if you're not emotionally imbalanced and incapable of saying 'meh, didn't like, refund and moving on'...

Sure, give it a try. 

I enjoyed the story, the music, the characters (including some amazing looking NPCs), the action (I'm an RPG player not a shooter elitist), and most important, I loved Night City. Photomode was a constant companion, and though I don't think that will appeal to everyone, I love that I have a lot of memorable shots of the game, because it looks so damn good and the characters are incredibly expressive and awesome.

I also thought the difficulty was too easy, the balance wasn't great, the character progression could use some work, and the open world wasn't fleshed out enough. All things that didn't ruin my overall enjoyment, but it fell short of the gameplay greatness I'm sure the devs wanted to achieve. 

That said, improvements are being made, modders are doing some great things, and this is just the first instalment of what could be a long-lived and amazing IP (Witcher 1 was certainly no brilliant success). So we'll see what happens.

Concerning technical aspects, I have a strong though not top tier PC, and I had no crashes, FPS was fine (I don't need 100 frames on 4k), bugs were minimal and never game-breaking as far as I made it-- around 60% through before I paused to heal an injury--and I was quite happy with the experience I got. 

I'd give it an 8/10.

It could be a 9/10 or a 10/10 if they continue to polish the rough edges and add expansion content that fleshes out the open world-- particularly stuff like gang faction systems with unique rewards, a survival/high difficulty mode, more random events including more hostile encounters, and as much cosmetic customization as they can stuff into the game. 


Final Note: To all the people going on and on about being lied to: Get some media literacy. CDPR marked the demo and detailed teasers as a work in progress, which frankly should be obvious in the first place. Big games change prior to release in many situations, and if you don't understand that then you are very naive, perhaps wilfully so. Maybe you were a CDPR fanboy, I don't know, but it's kind of hilarious seeing so many hurt feels and rants about ethics, as if these people have never dealt with a complex artistic project (a.k.a. big game), or understood what marketing does.

Which isn't to excuse some of the shittier things CDPR did, like the old gen launch state or review embargo. But those things rarely get the focus for criticism. Instead so many of these gamers complain about the devs talking about what they were working on, and they get so worked up about the fact that a video game disappointed them that they use rhetoric to try to tear down everything the devs have done. 

I swear it's like they were born yesterday.


edit: Ignore my number of hours played, I mod Cyberpunk now so I have a ton of time logged in tinkering stuff. My actual playtime is probably about 150 hours with a good half of that representing exploration with photomode.

Looking beyond its obvious flaws that I probably don't need to reiterate, Cyberpunk 2077 was a great experience. The appeal is in its story and characters, which make the game immersive and bring Night City to life. It is not hard to fall in love with the characters, who are so well developed. The voice acting is incredible, the writing is amazing, the dialogue is realistic. It is foolish to overlook the hard work the team did put into the game, because it is clearly there. The gameplay is good. There are a variety of guns and cybernetic enhancements to play around with, but that variety isn't very large. It is, however, sufficient enough to allow players to choose their own play style. The scenery of the game is beautiful; the map design is very well-planned and CDPR did a great job of bringing 'cyberpunk' to life (and I will add here that there was a satisfactory amount of Blade Runner references in the game, kudos to them). The city is so beautiful and intricate, I often find myself abandoning fast travel to drive my vehicles instead.

I have played this game on both PS4 and PC. On PC, the game runs well. While crashes do occasionally happen, or you run into a humorous bug here and there, it is nothing game-breaking and it doesn't tarnish the experience. It's disappointing to think of just how incredible and successful this game could have been had it not been released so prematurely and with such poor decision-making. Putting that aside, I still recommend this game to those who are more focused on story and lore, because this game does deliver in that department. There are still flaws, I feel like they could have gone a lot further with it. It feels like there was a lot of cut content and that a lot of the characters got abandoned once their missions were over. It is still worth playing in my opinion. Maybe not at full price though.

Don't be deterred by all the negative press this game received on launch. This is a fantastic game. The world-building is so immersive I enjoyed driving around taking in all the sights (although driving mechanics are admittedly a little wonky, although i actually thought it just made it more fun, BECAUSE I THRIVE ON CHAOS OK?!). While some have complained the main story, while compelling, is too short, I would argue that the amazing side quests with memorable characters like Panam, Judy, River, etc. add quite a bit to the story. Sure you can do a quick run and finish the main campaign relatively quickly, but why miss out? There's a reason I have almost 200 hours on record when writing this. There's actually quite a bit to do in Night City. Also, I personally haven't run into any bugs (although I know it's mainly for console players where this has been a problem). 

My biggest criticism would be that I would prefer more character cuztomization, or at the very least the ability to change appearance during the game (seems logical that in a place like Night City, one should be able to go to get a haircut, tattoo, and/or modify body parts whenever they wanted, as long as they have the $). But I can live with that. 

Seriously though, I have really enjoyed this game. It has become one of my favourites :)

Peoples complaints are ridiculous. I play this game on ultra settings in 4k and have had no issues. Half ass hardware equals a half ass game. That goes for any game. To my eyes all I saw was a few bugs quickly fixed and a bunch of impatient crying babies. CDPR put out another masterpiece that has brought me joy and entertainment for over 280 hours now. Summary:
I do not understand how this game got so many bad reviews.  
They did so much right in this game.
I enjoyed it immensely, and felt I got way more than my money's worth from it.  

Games this reminds me of: Fall out and Far Cry

Pros
* Three types of leveling
1. Traditional leveling (level 1 to 50) based on total experience
2. Situational leveling (level 1 to 20) based on using specific skills (ex. pistols)
3. Street credit (level 1 to 50)
* Multiple endings based on your choices
* Rich and picturesque environment
* Lots of the traditional types of weapons (rifles, light machine gun, knife, pipe, etc)
* Weapons can be upgraded, but this is not a large plus as it does not have much impact and upgrading multiple times quickly becomes too expensive.
* Some romance options, although they mimicked real life in that they have one bang at the start, but no significance romance after.  Repeated romance requires repeat payments.
* More adult and gritty environment.   Refreshing with many games being watered down prudish kid level topics.
* Auto travel between map points that you have already gotten too.  Gets rid of drudgery.
* Not a puzzle game.  I play to adventure, not to solve random puzzles, so this realism is a big plus for me.
* Lots of side quests, and options for where to invest your experience.  I felt like I more than got my money's worth.
* Easy mode really IS easy.  I love that they really do offer you an easy button if you like that play style, and plenty of challenge if you prefer.  Makes for both a pleasant initial experience, and for replay as you learn the system.  Some of the other games could learn from this one.
* Quests for the most part are well marked and documented.  I dislike spending $40 on a game, and then spending half my time breaking immersion by looking up who and where I'm supposed to go next to avoid hours circling through the same area talking to everyone.   Cyberpunk 2077 had a good balance for quest guidance.

Cons
* I did experience some bugs.  Only one of them (mission "dredged up") hurt my experience though, by stopping me from completing all the missions in Watson.  A few looting issues for mechanicals, but some of them solvable through reloading.
* Crafting is pretty much a joke.  Don't spend a bunch of skill points to get there.  At end of game, most of the legendary crafting patterns have joke DPS.  The few that have decent DPS take seemingly random rare guns or items I could not find to complete.  You'll be better spending your points elsewhere and buying good items from the stores.
* The game will let you pick up or buy ammo AFTER you are already at max.  If you are at 100 rounds, and you cannot hold more, the game should tell you that.  In real life, you would know if you cannot hold more ammo and would not spend a bunch of money to buy something that never ends up going into your inventory.  Seems like a silly oversight with how much they did get rights.

Neither Pro nor Con
* Sure, some of the doors are perma locked.  I don't really see that as a con.  This is a whole city, not a few caves or wilderness locations.  I feel they provided plenty of content for what I paid, and I don't blame them  for not having fleshed out every single room in every building.  Sure, they could have come up with some random generation system, but that could also mess with the leveling mechanics if those all had weapons or stashes, or it would just be boring if you broke into a bunch of them and there was nothing there.  Bottom line is that this felt open world enough to me.  This is not a linear rail shooter.  You get a lot of choices about where to go next.

Summary:  Loved it.  Good mix of classical leveling, action, and story line.

I understand the negative attitude towards this game and around its' release, but I have been playing since day one and am absolutely just as in love now as I was then, if not more. I'm in a privileged position with Cyberpunk I'm playing on a high end PC with a 3080 so I got to experience it more or less as intended unlike those on console or I presume lower end PCs. In any case, yes I would still recommend this game. The story and characters have had me wrapped up since release, and it just doesn't get old for me. I love the RPG elements, Night City, the cars, etc. No matter what way you slice it, this is a huge curated world with an interesting story and it's all carefully draped over highly compelling gameplay.

There it is... Just reached over 1,000+ hours in Cyberpunk 2077... :)
UPDATE: 2,500+ hours now.

"Can't stop diggin' Night City!" - as Jackie Welles says during the prologue :')

The game could have been better, and I KNOW it will be better, yet I still enjoy it for what it is. Living that mercenary fantasy - a cybernetically-enhanced badass!

EDIT: After Patch 1.5 (and now 1.6) the game is simply stunning! It's fundamentally better. I love the energy of CP2077's new Game Director Gabriel Amatangelo, that man has stepped up, giving the game what it deserves. Soon we'll be getting a complete re-work of the police system, along with vehicle-to-vehicle combat, bigger MaxTac presence and other highly requested features by the community. I can't wait.

Now, I could write a huge, in-depth review of why I love this game so much, despite all the backlash it's gotten from various fans, false promises / false marketing, etc... we all know that story, right?... But my game hours should speak for themselves. This is just my opinion.

In short, this game's graphics (especially when maxed out in 4K, HDR, DLSS and RTX, it becomes a technological marvel. Its atmosphere, immersion, deep & dark story, complex lore, characters, soundtrack, hidden secrets and overall gameplay replay-ability have left their mark on me. There's a certain comfort to Night City that I can't quite describe. Which is strange, because the city itself is a f*cked up place. Driving at night through the city streets, the various districts, the Badlands, etc... feels nostalgic and somehow relatable. It reminds me of the days when I was younger, half-asleep in the backseat of my family's car, feeling safe, subconsciously listening to the radio music playing in the background at midnight as we drove past the busy city streets to our destination, going on a road trip, away on holiday.

I love trying out different builds, tactics, choices, reading everything, looting everything... I like to roleplay my characters' builds based on my chosen lifepaths. There is Nomad, Streetkid and Corpo. Each has a different intro, along with different dialogue options during main / side quests / gigs which either gives more insight when dealing with the respective faction, or unlocks entirely new, unique outcomes. The only other games that have left me in a similar state of passion and addiction have been TESV: Skyrim, Mass Effect trilogy, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, and a few others... Even now, after 2000+ hours, I'm discovering new things!

There are many great games that I've re-played numerous times in the past, but not to this extent! And certainly not in such a short amount of time. There's also mod support, which is pretty cool! UPDATE: As of Patch 1.6, we have official mod tools. REDMod has been released, which, with time, will bring Bethesda-level modding capabilities to CP2077. I've been playing since launch, and somehow I've come across very little bugs / glitches. Also NO crashes! Lucky me, I guess... :) Makes me wonder if the game really is as buggy as it's made out to be... The less Reddits / social media posts I read, the more I enjoy the game. But this is just my personal, biased experience running on a high-end PC.

I'm just here to leave my positive review and show my support. I should have done it a long time ago, but I thought I'd leave it until I hit a big milestone... Which is now, as of this review, 1,000 hours! What a beautiful number! Maybe now my review holds more "weight" ... I hope more people decide to try the game for themselves and not have their experience ruined by the internet... I know CDPR are hard at work with the new patches, free DLC and expansion(s), I've been watching Pawel Sasko's streams (Quest Director at CDPR) and I trust him over any leaks / speculations and other crap you might come across on the internet...

I know for a fact that there's still many more hours left for me in this Cyberpunk 2077 universe. :) Possibly hundreds! Looking forward to the expansion, Phantom Liberty. I hear its size will be in between The Witcher 3's Hearts of Stone / Blood & Wine expansions. For the best news updates with perfect track record, I suggest Tyler McVicker, Kazuliski and LastKnownMeal. Check them out on YouTube. They are also great with lore.

After playing more of this game, and watching several patches come out, I can say that I recommend Cyberpunk. The story is interesting, and while some cutscenes feel like they drag on for too long, if you enjoy story rich games than you will like them. Most of the characters are likeable, though I personally wasn't a fan of Johnny (The actual character, he is very well written and a good character.) The gameplay is very fun imo, and as someone who enjoys running and gunning "DOOM" style, it fit me perfectly. Overall: I recommend Cyberpunk 2077

Cyberpunk is one of the best games I've played since DOOM back in the 90s.
The story  is very original and  you care about the characters or you can play it like a First person shooter. 
There is a lot of variety in the styles of how you play. There is a learning curve  to it, but you can graduate through the missions by difficulty.
As a fan of the stalker series the bugs don't really bother me. It is a joy to play.

SECOND REVIEW:
Still a thumbs up. I've started a second play through, thought I'd played the Hard setting first time but obviously not. It's more difficult than I remember. Snipers are CU next tuesdays, occasionally frame rate drops (when walking through market areas with lots of NPCs), but I'm finding that I'm loving the game - and something I didn't really think about the first time I played it, the sound design is absolutely amazing. Just weird noises as you walk around the city, ebbing and flowing, and tension is well synchronised - lush.

Having the knowledge of how bad things will get so spending a lot of time building V to be tough as nails, but know that he's still going to get wasted every time a sniper gets his sights on him,  the immersion in the game that I'm experiencing this time round is so strong that I can do nothing but recommend this (again).

Players who expect everyone they meet to stop what they're doing and have a conversation with them will be disappointed. Most people in Cyberpunk 2077 will tell you to feck off, which is the level of realism I was looking forward to with this game.
There are downsides. But I'm loving it.

It's like this was written by someone who had read a lot of cyberpunk but had no idea how to write it. The themes, characters and plot elements are all competently regurgitated but offer little depth. One of the game's few original touches is a forced edginess reminiscent of a first-year-philosophy dropout's blog about "fighting the system", and that's about as fun as it sounds. The writing tackles many mature themes but lacks much maturity itself.

Combat's pretty good and the world looks incredible (if you have a decent setup, at least) but many other aspects are underdeveloped - including skill-tree, AI, merchants, driving and the mostly pointless 'life path' options. The lack of access to no-brainers like hair cuts and flying cars is truly baffling.

Overall, I wouldn't recommend it unless you're a hardcore cyberpunk fan - and you can tolerate Keanu Reeves rattling off cynical stoner soundbites every ten minutes.

First, I'd like to point out that I played this game on a new computer with a 3090, so the game was utterly beautiful and ran very smooth.

Tip: Do everything you want to do before the end.  For me, once I finished the main story, my desire to do all the side stuff kinda faded.

I tried very hard to like this game, on the surface there's a lot to praise about it. It's extremely visually impressive, the first couple hours of the story are genuinely good and I found myself being really emotionally invested in the characters the game introduces in that time. However, after a certain point the gameplay loop becomes transparent and repetitive, and it's hard to ignore the sheer array of things CDPR promised that were not incorporated in the final product. If CDPR pulls a Hello Games and works on adding in new mechanics I might change my mind, but for now it will remain uninstalled.

I recommend the game but i would also like to note my disappointment with some aspects of it.
I honestly believe the world is a work of art and every nook and cranny does feel hand crafted and a testiment to the imagination of the studio. Ive not seen such a brilliantly realised world before. However as many in other reviews state its fairly surface level , you cant interact with much of it in any way. and the world crowd npcs seem so weirdly out of place and unconnected . The main npcs and side characters however are all memorable and interesting even if i didnt like all of them bar pan am and jackie. I enjoyed the interactions with silverhand and liked the whole in my head thingy going on.
 A major gripe for me is that crafting felt pointless, skills and upgrades are lacklustre in my opinions. 
Character customization is both good and bad . You can slider and changes alot of face stuff but you cant be a hulking brute or a skinny ninja assassin looking waif. Like i wanted a tall muscle bound fist fighter with silver cyborg arms and my actual character looked like a normal dude . Almost 95% of clothes you can get dont fit the character well at all, and i get the 80s neon aesthetic which i love but i mean the clothes look ill fitting and weirdly sculpted on both male and female and there was a severe lack of variety compared to the npcs i see walking around.
The voice acting is good from all involved overall though i prefer male V's delivery personally. Story is very cool and the major side missions are excellent. The minor side quests are pretty standard but thats ok i guess. Hacking and quick hacks didnt have enough variety and at one point i just stopped bothering and switched to shotgun and just walking calmly around one shotting enemies as their AI was so slow and poorly scripted it didnt matter. ( things might have improved since i last played) but overall the AI from all creatures / characters/ police/ cars/ street crowds was just shockingly poor.
Melee combat was a joke with the death animations triggering all the time and the same way.. made me just again give up and shot people instead. 
Some of my best times in the game were not interacting with combat and systems at all (the games weakest point) and just driving around on my bike exploring and soaking up the amazing sound track trying to forget about my day. So there is a a good game here and i recommend it just to experience the world. Just wait for it to go on sale or when they add more features.  Ive alot of hours put in from a couple of play throughs and again alot of that is just exploring and chilling. 
I hope to return again with a big DLC etc

Here is my take on Cyberpunk 2077.

Before we dive in, a little bit of context to my review. I played this game only very briefly during its initial week of release. I got to the point of meeting Keanu's character, maybe just after, on street kid playthrough, and stopped. Cut forward to a week or so ago, and I have dived back in.

I genuinely enjoy this title.

The reason I enjoy it so much, is the story. Whether it is side quests, main, or whatnot, there is a lot of time and effort put into making sure each moment isn't one of those that make you wish you could skip it. There is the option to do so, which is nice for when you die, but some large titles, have plenty of moments where you are telling your monitor to "shut up" because its dead analogue. This game reminds me a lot of Yakuza for that, in terms of being in a open world scenario,  with the scenery being more high-tech advertisements, buildings, and then other small vendors and stores surrounding nearly all free-space. 

The other connection I bring to the Yakuza series (especially the newer ones, like 0 and 6, even the kiwamis) is the graphics. Yakuza cutscenes are some of the more beautiful cutscenes in all of gaming, and Cyberpunk takes that style of graphics, into the entire gameplay. Ive noticed that it gets even better during cutscenes, as things are being focused, and not just a giant junkyard gunfight (where it can get ugly and laggy sometimes). It is spec relevant, so dont expect a gtx 960 and i3 to give you lifelike visuals, but most should have a great visual experience. 

For me the gameplay is right up there with the graphics. You have large skill trees, weapons and mods, mods for your body, clothing, food items, junk (decoration or meme items for me). The combat is somewhat complex in means of knowing weakness, using correct mods and weapons for the range and scenario, grenade detonation time. I would say also that the rarity system and such for cybermods or weapons and mods, are comparable to that of borderlands and destiny, but with a little extra on top. The quick-hacks also play a large role in the game, as for the most part, unless you are one of those weirdos that grinds out the side quests and comes to the story line already God, you wont be able to just run in and shoot up everything. You will have to take cover, peek that cover to pop enemies, quick hack and short circuit somebody to lower health, reboot optics or memory wipe them to give you some time to think and recover. 

I think to wrap it up, I want to say great job team, on producing an amazing game. My only complaint is the lack of romantic relationship possibilities (not joytoys, those are one and done) like Panam, Judy, Kerry, etc. It would be nice to go corpo route one playthrough and pickup Judy, or another playthrough as Nomad, and find some random city chick, ya know? Something with some story. Also, it would be nice to be able to go back and interact with your "partner" and talk about things, go on a random trip to the city to watch a movie, take a drive and look at the stars. It doesn't have to be more sex, because there are mods for getting different skins for joytoys, but im talking true relationships. Aside from this, I have next to no issues with the game, and for what we were provided here, I think the negatives aren't worth a concern if you are a new player, as you are going to have a blast with the other things. If you had the option to eat some of the best cookies on the planet, but there might be one of the dozen that is half burnt, you wouldn't at least try it?

PS.- My typing is garbage, and my keyboards glitchiness doesn't help. Somethings may be spelled incorrectly, have more letters than it should, bad punctuation, but im not fixing it, so dont comment about it lmao.

Look, I've invested more time than I care to admit in this game, but I really don't recommend it. Unpolished is an understatement, even now, 7 months after release. Things are broken. Essential story characters disappear, or get stuck in hallways. Sidequests get locked off because the NPC simply doesn't exist for no reason. The crafting system is jank. The romance options are literally only 4 characters, 2 per player gender, and the story obviously leans into one, and they just decided not to make one of the critical characters bisexual, or rewrite one of the endings. The background-related options have no impact on the outcomes or story. I honestly only spent this much time because of the sunk cost fallacy, and the hope that it would get less broken as I played. Don't buy this game, especially not for full price.

I'd recommend this game, the storyline and soundtrack is exceptional. Character design is very good. The game looks phenomenal. However it's not without its infamous shortcomings which are exclusively to do with gameplay elements.

To name some creases, vehicle handling is a bit silly and could do with the tweaks. Fist fighting could be worked a bit better although it is playable (Just don't expect it to be like the Witcher series at all or you'll be disappointed as your level does matter in contrast to the Witcher where you could beat the whole lot of fistfights before really levelling up much at all.)
It is also slightly frustrating that you can't necessarily max out your character with all the perks as you don't get enough perk points to max out. While understand this was meant to be more of a class build kinda of system it does mean that there are some parts of the story which will suffer, for example if you invest entirely into combat and your intelligence or tech is low there's some important choices you'll never be able to do so you have no choice in some of the outcomes at all. I would recommend looking at some builds on youtube or elesewhere to help you understand how to make the best of this system.

With a bit of ironing out the creases this game could really be among some of my all time favourites.

So, so... the big controversy at the end of 2020... what can I say?!? What the parties involved did with console version is fraud. No question about it. BUT, I am gaming the PC-version and I have to say, I am NOT disappointed. I will try to keep it short, because it is late, though there is so much to say. Briefly, the great strengths of this game are definitively the production design, in that context the world and at the end of it all the story telling. Never experienced such an immersive story telling from the ego perspective (amazing dialogues, amazing set pieces, especially the more intimate ones) and even Night City itself is much more alive and interactive than I was afraid it would not be. That aspect is certainly connected to the well crafted story telling or let´s say the well directed narrative. What was already a nice feature in GTA, Cyberpunk does even better. Every "casual" encounter within the world is a thought out quest in itself, which in turn let´s your brain experience the world as more interactive, you get the feeling that you can enter a lot of buildings and it is a clever way to let the player explore the world in a more fluent way. Could the game have been more complex in terms of game mechanics? For sure. Though the action feels kinetic, dynamic and very entertaining (I am a huge fan of the guns and also the feeling for your character´s body). Could it have been more ambitious in its implementation of features? Also sure. But is it a disappointment because of that? Not at all. To put it in a nutshell, it is basically The Witcher 3 in a beautifully crafted sci fi / cyberpunk setting. So if you liked The Witcher 3, you are going to like Cyberpunk (or maybe even love?), despite some bugs (nothing near as bad in the PC-version as in the console versions). Forget the controversy and enjoy a very compelling single player experience!

I really enjoyed my time with Cyberpunk 2077. Perhaps my most salient takeaway is: enjoy the game for what it offers, rather than be upset for what it doesn't offer. 

I think the marketing around Cyberpunk 2077 pre-release was too good. The marketing over-hyped the game too much. 

But there's tons to love within the game. Here are a few things I had fun with: 

[list]
    [*][b] Gunplay: [/b] The gunplay is super fun. By the end of the game, I had a crafted legendary handgun, fully upgraded. It completely demolished anything in my way. 
    [*][b] Driving: [/b] The driving is goofy, in a really fun way. Yeah, I was kinda all over the place at times, but I was having fun. Running over curbs and having my car bounce around never got old. 
    [*][b] Main Story: [/b] The main story is good. I didn't quite like the main story as the story arcs within side quests, but there was still bombastic moments that were really cool. 
    [*][b] Side Stories: [/b] The side missions are engaging and worth doing. Yes, the gigs can be a bit of a grind. But the side stories involving other characters were amazing. And all of the characters came to mean something to me. 
    [*][b] Upgrades: [/b] The upgrades, and the upgrade system, was neat. Some upgrades were more meaningful than others. There's a respec available, so it's easy to tune upgrades as you go. 
[/list]

Again, I had fun with the game, enjoying it for what it offered and not being bothered by what it didn't.

I was not hyped for this game, I was not interested, that's not to say I disliked hearing about it, I was sure it would be a great game for its audience. Then the launch day came, I decided to give it a shot and what a good decision that was. Maybe it is because of my lack of hype, or just like making up my own mind about things but Cyberpunk 2077 is now one of my favorite games of all time.

Never before could I get this invested in a singleplayer RPG's story, they usually lost me, it's a genre I could never really get into, but this game pulled me in and glued my eyes to the monitor until I knew how this story ended. The characters are phenomenal, the storytelling is excellent, I care about the characters in the game, I had to know how their story ends, how V's story ends. I enjoyed this game so much that by the end of 2020's December I had all the achievements unlocked. Now 222 hours later I finished my third playthrough, once on every lifepath and I loved it just as much as the first time, I explored other options in the game, other builds, story beats I haven't even seen before and even when I didn't intend to originally, I once again cleared out all the gigs, activities in Night City because I just had so much fun playing the game.

I can wholeheartedly recommend the game to anyone looking for a great story, fun gunplay with interesting abilities and gadgets. System Requirements are steep but given just how next gen this game looks, I cannot fault them for that, at least even on the lowest presets you'll be looking at a game that looks better than some on the highest presets.

if you role play, this is how i might suggest the best experience. 

- pick your combat style and stick to it, in late game you can reset your skill tree at a modest price. try to commit to one main skill tree, and one secondary skill tree. it really does effect each play thru when you focus on your savant combat style and leave room for weaknesses. 

- decide motive for decisions, and remember it. It may change with time, but there is a story reason for you slowly becoming a maniac. A. right/wrong B. self-gain/fame C. friendship/clout. this is the three main decisions factors imo. Not ever decision is easy. own your character flaws. Night City Mercenary Life isn't for the faint of heart. Toughen up. Don't look back. Never apologize.
 
- Throttle your own difficulty. Similar to Skyrim, you can cheat and grind systems to become something god tier. If you enjoy the number crunching route, don't be surprised if combat get's a bit easy, especially on the grind. The ai isn't super smart because it relies on you to be cool and stylish in your performance, and to pace yourself with the difficulty climb of the story.  So if you think about your role as a combatant, don't take it too strategically (3 tour veteran snipers). It's an RPG. your role is to look cool. Keep moving across the beautiful battlefields with style using all the tools you've equipped yourself with. If the combat gets light, switch to a weaker style. The game rewards you with tiers of experience even in dump stats. So when you take out all the gunmen, and all that is left is a knife boi, go toe to toe with him for those brawler mile-marker points to put into your main stats later. 

- your vehicles carry your stash in the trunk. took me way to long to realize this. save "unique" weapons and armor. They are one of a kind. These weapons can grow with you and be the best in the game if you are engineer. Otherwise collect them. Remember their stories.   

- When you go into a new section of town and have some downtime, pay the local fixer a personal visit. Then stick around a while doing patrols in their neighborhood for them. Really spend some time in each section of town. immerse in the local culture.  

- Try to keep your plot journal short as possible. There are a LOT of stories, and going randomly via proximity of a map marker can make those stories dilute. There is a lot of content. If you like story, try to stick to one mission at a time. Some missions have timers before the next event. use this to sleep at your apt. or go do some mercenary work for a fixer to earn street cred while you wait. Don't pick up too many quests at once so you can appreciate the plot beats. 

- people complain about driving. they should drive better! ;) the game has a lot of loading going on. burn rubber in the desert. In town, let off the gas a little. Enjoy the scenery and brake on your turns! lol.

[h1] In a Nutshell [/h1]
Cyberpunk 2077 isn't what I thought it would be, but I definitely enjoyed my time with it regardless. An open world action title with not much in the way of actual roleplaying, still suffering from dull AI, visual and gameplay bugs, and a remarkably short main quest. If you want a Cyberpunk RPG, you'll probably get more out of the two modern Deus Ex titles - but for at least 40 hours worth of enjoyment, give CP77 a chance.

[h1] The Good [/h1]
Cyberpunk's writing ranges from good but melodramatic to really, really good. The plot is relatively tight and well paced, and the side quests are mostly of a very high quality. Visually, it's stunning - Night City's lights and sounds are well-realised, character models for most NPCs are brilliant, and the animations for weapons are top notch. 

Voice acting is pretty good overall, as is the music. Some of the radio tracks are great, particularly the SAMURAI songs on Morro Rock Radio by Refused. The score, with particular reference to the tracks "V" and "The Rebel Path", is great stuff. Combat music is intense and catchy, though you're likely to hear it far too much to keep it fresh. Reeves' performance as Johnny Silverhand initially annoyed me with the gruff voice and what felt like trying too hard to be angsty, but the more you interact with him, the more it falls away and his real character starts coming through. There's some genuinely great character moments in the game, with some thought-provoking bits about mortality, bioaugmentation and allowing corporations to run rampant.

[h1] The Bad [/h1] 
Gameplay wise, CP77 isn't really anything new. The mechanics are slightly varied and there is the option to spec a character to specialise in one area over another, but unless you're on Hard or Very Hard there isn't really much in the way of challenge. Car handling ranges from acceptable to borderline ridiculous - this isn't Forza, and it's not GTA IV. Cars have a tendency to spin wildly out of control if not handled properly, though CP77 doesn't have much in the way of chases or anything like that anyway. A lot of people seemed to think this would be a Cyberpunk GTA game, and it's not. It's more like a Cyberpunk Witcher, now that I think of it: Cyberpsycho hunts are essentially this game's version of Geralt's witcher contracts, for example. 

[h1] The Ugly [/h1]
Seven months after release, the game is still a fair bit buggy. Nothing game breaking in my experience, but enough to cause frustration. Visual effects can break, DLSS can cause a ghosty, blurry mess on your screen, and ray tracing seems to have odd issues with car interiors. An awful (in my opinion) eye-adaptation effect to simulate leaving darkness and going into light can be disabled with mods, as can volumetric fog and bloom, since sometimes these effects can look pixelated and distracting. CDPR seem to have fixed the MAJOR issues, but tons of smaller ones remain - the same happened with Witcher 3, so I'm confident it'll be fixed in due time.

I started playing it in June 2021, and yes it is still noticeably buggy.  However, none of the bugs are significant, and I love this game.  If you like cyberpunk in general and enjoy RPGs with tons of action, dialog, items, upgrades, etc, then you'll love it.  I'm 58 hours of play in and still feel like I'm near the beginning.  The driving is crumby and there are numerous other flaws, but none that significantly harm the game-play.

Cyberpunk is a good game, you just have to temper you expectations. It isn't a sandbox like GTA or RDR, it's an RPG through and through, just set in an open world.

What this means is emergent gameplay is very limited. Like most RPGs, you have a fairly linear set of main quests to complete while there are a few meaty side quests. The rest is simply filler - go here, kill this enemy or go here steal something, you get the drift.

The graphics are fantastic if you have a high end rig. Night city is probably the most detailed open world ever made. This does help with immersiveness and helps offset the fact that the npc ai is non-existent. You can have a gunfight with some thugs and the cops a few meters away won't even react at all for example.

The game also still suffers from bugs and glitches. For example tech weapons sometimes refuse to fire when aiming down sights during combat, a very annoying bug.

With all these problems, why do I still recommend Cyberpunk? Because of the story and characters. The writing is great imo, and as you get to know the characters, they start to grow on you. The main questline explores the concept of transhumanism and also the price of revenge. It is the glue that keeps the game engrossing.

If you value narrative in games and can tolerate some bugs/glitches you will probably enjoy your time with this game. Those looking for the next GTA experience should look elsewhere.

Cyberpunk 2077 is a flawed but fantastic game. I didn't really hear about any of the hype surrounding the game until very late in development so my expectations were low but my excitement was high. Bought the game on launch, played about an hour, got bored, and then didn't touch it until April 2021.
Since April and as of writing this review, I've beaten the game as two different characters, done every ending, beaten the secret ending 5 times, and gotten every achievement in the game. I've figured out how to clip outside the map, explored every part of the city twice over, and sunk way too much time into this game. I loved every second I played. The main story is incredible, and I've never had a story draw me in like this one has. The side missions are awesome, the worldbuilding is top notch, and the environment that Night City has is unmatched. Despite all this, there is a lot missing. I can break it up into two parts.

Part 1. 
The game lacks customization. Don't get me wrong, the character creation section is excessive, but after you've designed your "V", there isn't much customization for the rest of the game. 
Perks and abilities are a major part of the game, but when it comes to things like weapons, armor, clothing, housing, vehicles, there is very little customization. You cannot customize V's apartment, you can't pick the color of your car, you can't modify the way your weapons look (which I know isn't game breaking but it's a missed opportunity.) 
Clothing really comes down to which item has the highest armor rating / other perks, because high level enemies punish you if you are trying to look unique instead of having armor. 
In terms of customization, the game is lacking. An update that allows you to paint your car, or buy an expensive apartment adjacent the Peralezes would do a lot to change the immersion of the game.

Part 2. 
Diverse Missions. Cyberpunk is action action action, basically at all times. Almost every mission is some derivative of a firefight. The game could use some diversity in its mission types. Gigs are fun, NCPD scanners are fun, and organized crime is fun, but it would be interesting to see where the game could go if there were non-violent gigs, or other avenues of income V could go down. The romance options are a great example of this. On my first playthrough, I got so invested in the Panam romance that I put the main story on the backburner to pursue the Aldecaldo quests. However, once you've finished the questline, there is basically nothing that happens afterwards. All the romances are like this. You get a few texts, maybe a call, and a gift or two, but that is it. Dates, further dialogue, round 2 in the bedroom, anything to make the relationships feel immersive rather than just an NPC. Because that is Cyberpunk's greatest strength and weakness. During a quest, the characters are written so well they almost feel like people, but once the spotlight is off them, the immersion breaks and you are reminded that they are NPCs.

Those are my thoughts. I love the game, I've played too many hours already and I intend to play even more. Excited for the DLC. I highly recommend the game, even with the drawbacks.

The story of Cyberpunk 2077 is on par at the least with that of CDPR's Witcher Titles. Relying heavily on the established lore of the cyberpunk universe, CDPR does a fantastic job of bringing to life the beautiful and dangerous Night City for the player to explore and experience.

The Pros:
Story and background are top notch
Visually stunning graphics
Gun Play and Combat are excellent
Quests are immersive and fulfilling

The Cons:
This game has bugs (What open world game doesn't)
Driving is clunky
Night City Residents are kind of just there 

Overall, Cyberpunk is a game that is definitely worth playing and experiencing. Don't let the negative reviews and hate this game got on release take away from the wonderful experience that it is now.

I was first introduced to the game back in the 2012 teaser. From the 2018 demo I was hyping myself up so badly that I literally took a WEEK off of work to pour myself into the game back in the December release. I was really hyped, that I even bought 2 metal displate (not a sponspor) posters and they're currently on my wall.

The game is good, really - For the first time ONLY.
It doesn't have much of replay-ability since the decisions you make usually end up in the same place. There are multiple endings, but the decisions you made a long the way make little matter up until the 'no return' quest.

Afterwards, the game is quite shallow and doesn't have a lot of personality. There are certainly some quests which I will remember for quite a long time (like the Peralez quest and the guy who decided to be Jesus). Most of the game is not really rememberable and to be honest, I've forgotten most of it, unfortunately.

So take the game with a grain of salt. If you're a first time buyer I highly recommend to do EVERYTHING the game has to offer BEFORE getting to the no return point. Because doing it the second time is tiresome.

Good thing that at least the landscape is pretty. :)

I recommend that if you commit to the game, rush through it. Only do what sounds interesting, you'll lose yourself in Night City. But like all cities, if you dig down deep enough, you'll find the places where people are shitting on the streets and doing heroin in the parking lots.

I have not yet seen a single T-pose, nor experienced any other bug in my time playing Cyberpunk 2077 thus far. 

This is a crying shame: I am currently enthralled by this acute, scathing vision of a relentlessly grim, dark and inhumane future in a way that I have not been since I first played Deus Ex, and am looking for any means to escape its grasp.  Like V, I too am trapped in the sprawling forest of monolithic ziggurats that compose Night City. After all, when even the blackest of souls can be saved to disk for the right price, all that is left to exist for is the challenge of surviving another day.

So far, Cyberpunk 2077 has thus far taught me that I cannot save the world. However, it has taught me that I can save myself. 

All it takes are a few eddies.

This game came in a little too late for, GOTY, in 2020 but it should be considered for 2021. Its an open world RPG with great shooting mechanics and a lot of story. Throw in a hint of Hentai and a lot of gore.  
If you like open world first person shooters you are going to like this. There is a lot of RPG elements if you choose to go that way. I suggest bumping it up to hard difficulty once you get a grasp for the game. This will make you consider your actions more when heading into battle. If you are having trouble with the shooting mechanics, just know, you can adjust everything to dial it in to your optimal specs. There is a couple ways to start the game but, as far as I can tell, there really isn't a difference.  Aside from some dialog choices, the story is pretty much the same. To complete most of the game it will take you over 60hrs. My first play through was pretty complete and came in around 75hrs.  I am playing through a 2nd time to unlock different upgrades in the skill tree. I would recommend upgrading things aside from weapons. You seem to be plenty powerful in that regard. I really love this game. Not a lot of things have turned my head recently, and this checked all my boxes. Don't sleep on it because of the BS surrounding Xbox One and PS4. If you have a good PC you are fine. It runs great and looks fantastic. Side quests are not to be ignored. I hope they give us a Multiplayer. The shooting mechanics are on par with any FPS.

What this game done right:
+ You can learn the city by heart and still find hidden nooks and interesting point of interest.
+ Loads fast and allows you to make save (not checkpoint only) during mission or mid roaming.
+ Cyberpunkish existentialism storyline; what it means to be alive and human etc.

What this game done wrong
- No New Game+ in an open-world game
- Game is ambivalent. Torn between having a story and role-playing.

[h1]Spoilerfree Review[/h1]

[b]After ~7 Months (date of this review) people still seem to love/hate this game. If you see this game now during the summer sale and you are still unsure if you should buy it or not, let me help you to decide.[/b]

The game is heavy story focused and I will not say anything about the Story itself. Just let me tell you now: If you are a fan of games that have a big focus on the story. Get it! The story is brilliantly written and keeps you going until the very last minute! 

Let me split this review now a bit up to make this a bit more compact and easy to follow:

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
If you ever played Deus Ex, I don't need to describe it further. Not every Deus Ex tho! I am talking about Mankind Divided. Take that formula (Good and fun RPG elements, talent trees and with minor decision related choices) add some crafting. Voilà - Cyberpunk 2077 

But if you didn't play Deus Ex (and you should) here a short summary:

The shooting mechanic (gunplay) is fun and you can try many builds. You choose how to approach a situation. You can go in with a bang or go complete silent with no casualties. In dialogues you will always get caught off by conversations that are engaging and will change the outcome. The crafting is kept simple and it is indeed optional, but having the ability to craft new gear is always a nice feature.

[b]Graphics:[/b]
I don't really need to say anything about this one, but maybe infoarmations about the performance are nice?!
I run this game on an "Intel e3 1231 v3" (equivalent ot an i7 4790) and a "Nvidia 1060 6G" while only having 8GB Ram. The settings on my side are a mix of medium and high and I can run it at 60 fps most of the time. In fights it can get down of course (too many explosions), but it really didn't kill the immersion for me. The latest patch even boosted the perforamnce so I might even can get higher now! 

Another positive thing is that this game even looks really good on low settings as well. So if you are near the minimal requirements you will still have a stunning looking game!

[b]Soundtrack:[/b]
Eargasm! Enough said!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o5u1sOUlS6U

[b]Atmosphere:[/b]
You know... Once in a while there is this really good idea to make a game that doesn't look as other games before. I am talking here about the aesthetics! This huge open world with its crowded streets and fucked up lore... This game feels like fresh air. It will get you caught off guard. This city breaths! It tells stories in every corner. If you didn't read anything about the world lore before (and you should) you will still get sucked into this world. It is even better as Deus Ex in these regards. You really have to trust me here! Also read every journal you find and try to learn how this "Brave New World" works. It is worth it! 



You might encounter reviewers who say that there is nothing much to do there. But same people also compare this game to GTA.

[b]Which brings me to my last point....[/b]

[i]Stop comparing this game to GTA, Assassins Creed or others!

Maybe compare it to Witcher 3 if you like. The open world is just there to give the player a playground. The real treasure is the story, the characters and all the sidequests. Every quest is different, every sidequest has its own story (some which are even connected) and every character you meet is interesting! There are not that many games who do the same, but always remember that Cyberpunk is not your average open world game![/i]

Soooooo nothing negative?
No... this game is a journey! It is one of a kind and it is fun to play! It was maybe overhyped, but that is all!

First things first, no this game doesn't live up to the pre-release hype. Yes there is clearly a lot of cut content. However, I still enjoy the game and would recommend it especially to fans of cyberpunk settings. There are some bugs and glitches, although I have yet to encounter anything game-breaking.
