Specs:

Windows 10 64bit
Core i9 9900K
ROG RUYO liquid cooler for CPU
2x RTX 2080ti SLI
64GB DDR4 @3200
Samsung 860 EVO SSD 500GB x6
RM 850x PSU
4K monitor @ 144Hz refresh

DISCLAIMER:

This game was never going to match the hype that was built around it, and CDPR have a big share of that blame.  I remain confident that, eventually, it will be finished.  CDPR itself is finished if they don't, but how long that will take is anyone's guess.  If this disappoints you, slap yourself, lower your unrealistic  expectations.  Also, don't play this game on consoles.  Really, don't.  Settle only for the best, like me.

GAMEPLAY:

8/10

It is a fun game, even if it feels empty and unfinished at times.  What's here is enough to justify the pricetag, though if you suspect you might be disappointed, hold off for a sale.  Modders are doing their very best to patch the game and add content, so expect big things from them, as well.  Lots of sliders to adjust certain elements, like vehicle handling.  I highly suggest you tinker with vehicles, get as close to GTA5 as you can.  As for shooting and walking, movement is fluid, and gunplay is about what I expected.  Enemies toss grenades, flank, use cover etc.  Any veteran of FPSes and GTA will slide in quite well.

STORY:

7/10

It's above average, but badly hurt by the early death of a very likeable character.  Johnny Silverhand feels shoehorned in, and V's ailment is a part of that.  Story is long enough, and convincing enough, but it's not something the average gamer will remember a year from now.

VISUALS:

8/10

Perfectly fine for 2020, though glitches hit the rating.  I turned RayTracing off, because even my setup was chugging a little hard on max.

STABILITY:

9/10

This is purely because of my rig.  DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME on anything less than a high end computer if you want a crash-free experience.  Consoles are a joke, so I won't press on this any further.

OVERALL:

7/10

Held back by incomplete state, glitches, and price compared to what we got.  Game will improve with time, but really should've held off on release.

ADDENDUM:

Let this be a lesson to devs everywhere: DO NOT ANNOUNCE YOUR GAME UNTIL AFTER IT'S READY.  Dying Light 2 is a great example.  Dev process crapped itself, so it was (this is the important part) INDEFINITELY DELAYED.  Had CDPR just indefinitely delayed the game, sure, we wouldn't be playing it right now, but it would prevent the disaster that happened.  DEVS, DO NOT RELEASE UNFINISHED PRODUCTS!

19Aug21 - just after v1.3 "Major" patch released

So I had decided to put the game down until the next patch came out - looking at the release notes, which I will not bore you with here, I decided that maybe I should create a new character (nomad!) to see what all the hubbub was about.

Unfortunately, about a quarter second before my character reached out to open the hatch of their car to let Jackie put in the box..the game crashed with zero fanfare and in doing so, corrupting the game to the point where I had to delete it within windows instead of in-game, and create yet another new character. Very disappointing at v1.3 first impressions time.

After a little over 480 hours in gameplay (without ever being able to complete the game), many many new character creations due to bugs, countless promises by CDPR, and all my hopes and dreams of a project with this potential being sliced up into small chunks and fed to the sharks, I have decided to uninstall this game and pray that I develop selective amnesia that this game ever existed.

CDPR has had the time, almost a year now after releasing the game, to fix many glaring issues that the first two-to-three patches SHOULD fully resolve on AAA games. Yes, they have gone through trying times such as lawsuits, cyber breaches, employee defections, investor relations issues, and more - but all of these blockers are due to two things: 1. not releasing a quality product and 2. not following through on empty promises made to rectify the lack of a quality product at release.

Does it stem from bad leadership? I do not know and will not speculate.

Does it stem from a lack of technical industry knowledge and/or development skills? I do not believe so, looking at the pedigree of the initial project leads.

Is it due to COVID? I believe that may have magnified whatever the root cause is, but I do not believe this is the culprit.

There is something systemically wrong during the production of this title, and the continued development lifecycle therein. No idea what it is, but because there was so much potential with this amazing combination of genre/content/venue, something has been lost in translation between vision and production.


CDPR, I wish you Adieu in all things you do, but I will not be purchasing another game from you until lessons learned from this sad trainwreck are performed resolved and most importantly, not repeated in the future. While only one potential customer lost here, I hope you realize this is not only my opinion and the opinion of many others.



Original review below - to add context on how bad some decisions really were and continue to be by CDPR, in my opinion.
___________________________________________________________________

Despite bad decisions by CDPR, and all the bad press - I still enjoy the game.

I hope CDPR gives those of us who pre-ordered and stuck through it all some in-game swag items as a thank you for the support.

I also wish they did not "fix" the component/money vending machine trick. By all appearances, it looked like it was by design the first time around, and allowed the players to maintain their immersion while making the money they desperately needed. If a player chose not to, they had the ability to NOT partake in the action, maintaining their personal level of immersion as well.

There are people who have problems playing games, physically speaking, and in-game tricks like that help them continue to play games in the first place without as much physical pain, Programming things in like this, giving the player the freedom to choose how much they wish to deviate from the developers' path, keeps the sandboxy feel as well as freedom of play, without breaking the game inherently. having money and basic components in this game doesn't destroy immersion at all.

For one of the most controversial games on launch, and with all the frustration everyone had for Cyberpunk 2077, the Playstation store even taking it out of its library, I enjoyed it a lot. I have almost 200 hours on the game and was sucked into the universe. From its interesting side missions, to The Relic main campaign. Losing a friend and making new ones, and even finding love. Even buying a couple joy toy shows. I really did enjoy my time playing Cyberpunk 2077.
      Cyberpunk 2077 is a single player action role-playing game developed by CD Projekt Red. It sets you in Night City, year 2077, where you play as a character named “V”. You can pick from the three starts, Nomad, Street Kid, and Corpo. Each start is different and gives V a different background that will affect the game and gives you special options depending on what start you picked. You become a mercenary for hire, any job you can get it done. You would get these jobs from fixers and the more you do their jobs the more known you are in Night City, and more eddies you will get (Eddies is the currency in the game). 
      My experience was overall good, I chose to be a street kid. It starts you off in a bar with a broken nose, and you fix it. Then a fixer from upstairs has a job offer for you, he wants you to steal a very expensive vehicle from a parking lot nearby.  V takes the job offer and continues outside to go complete the job, but then V runs into El Padre, one of the 8 fixers you get jobs from, you tag on for a ride to your destination and we figure out that V came back from Atlanta recently and is starting over in Night City. El Padre continues to catch you up on things going on in Night City, you get stopped by 6th street gang members and they try to harass El Padre, but V comes in and stops them and they leave you alone. Then the car continues to drive and you reach your destination. Padre gives you his business card and you are on your way. You get to the Parking lot, find the vehicle, and are ready to leave with it, but of course something always goes wrong.
      I got the game at launch and played it non stop after, and there were pros and cons. The pros were that the game was finally out and you can experience it, but the cons were the many bugs in the game. I didn’t experience this a lot, but many said that their game would crash a lot. It was simply not ready for launch, it was for sure rushed and time was running out. So CD Projekt Red was ready for the backlash and hard criticism. The things that bothered me were some of the bugs that made you get stuck in areas or when a fixer called you and they wouldn’t leave the screen or just not talk and stare at you. Another thing that frustrated me was the map itself. You can see certain parts of the map weren’t completed and other parts of the map made it look like a roblox mini-game. I went through all of it tho, I still got immersed with the game, and some of the bugs just made the game funnier. 
      Overall I did complete everything that was offered in the game, it was a grind for sure. I am already starting a new save as a corpo and as female V to see what difference there is. It's already been 6 months since release and some of the main bugs are gone and there are fewer crashes. The game is playable, if you get mods for it, it makes it even more fun. If you are interested in buying Cyberpunk 2077 or on the fence and don’t know what to decide, I highly recommend that you experience the game. It has a good amount of content and it satisfied me. Of course there is more coming to Cyberpunk 2077, so I am excited to see what's coming on the horizon.

"Ugh, What a shame. I am not even pissed about the bugs and glitches really, it's just so much was promised for literal years for this game and only about 1/3 of it made it in to the final product. This game is a TERRIBLE RPG.. As an action game, sure it's fun to shoot things and stuff but this was supposed to be the chosen one. Supposed to bring us the best open world mechanics and relationships and non-braindead NPCs who poof in and out of the world just by turning your back, ever. The story is not bad really, but your decisions in this game have 0.003% affect. They cut so much stuff that they said would be in this game it's really unreal.

This game will go down in history as the biggest scam game of all time. Tricked an entire world in to thinking that it was going to be the most immersive experience you've ever had, and ended up being a Fallout 76 type cash grab. I don't think I can ever forgive CDPR for this. They tricked us all because of how great Witcher 3 was and they knew it. I feel sorry for the actual devs of this game having to deal with their hard work stymied by corpo trash at the top."

Say what you want about this game's horrible launch. The fact is that this IS the best looking game on the market when you are talking about minimum graphics settings.
Due to patch 1.22 the game is actually stable! (Although I have to reinstall after every update) The game runs at a stable and smooth 60FPS even on my GTX980, 16GBs of ram and i5-4460 (clocking in at 3.2Ghz although I can Overclock it to 4Ghz)
Even with my somewhat outdated specs the game looks and runs brilliant with only minor frame drops that only happen once.
As someone who doesn't like 'DEEP IMMERSIVE STORYLINES' this game has a great story that can keep me (with the attention span of a fruit-fly) playing the game. Of course this is greatly enhanced by the gameplay.
The gameplay is brilliant, with the combat making sense (and of course being 'perfectly balanced' (:< ) and the side missions being short, but fun. The dialogue clearly has a lot of effort put into it by all of the voice actors, not at all sounding off in any way, in-fact immersing my fruit-fly brain into the game even more.
Overall this is a great game, hell a modern classic even, although it has minor graphical and small physics/ vehicle spawning bugs, nothing breaks the game to the point that it is unplayable.
This game is a 9/10 from me.

This is definitely my favorite game right now--then again, it should be. it's pretty a marriage of my two favorite things, ghost in the shell and mr robot. That's not to say it doesnt feel original on its own, because it definitely does. The attention to detail is amazing, its clear cdpr really did care about what they were making, and its definitely sad it had to start out the way it did. now that things are largely fixed, my biggest criticism of this game, by far, is that it ends. but that (and this is where some spoilers will happen) is a very real criticism. the main story is amazing (i mean, i cried at times, but i cry very easily so), but it has a lot of urgency. its not the kind of thing you feel eager to put on hold. and thats a problem, because you cant play after the main quest, beyond time-warping back to before the final mission. thats especially annoying because, again, there was a lot put into this beyond the main story. just exploring a plausible future dystopia as deliberately detailed as this one is powerful in itself, not to mention many sidequests to embark on, relationships to forge, gigs to take part in. but feels weird putting off the main quest too much to do these things and in the context of the story it makes no sense to do them afterward. if I die, let me be johnny silverhand. if i upload my mind to the internet, let be upload it back into a puppet like ghost in the shell: innocence, if i join a  corpo again, let be get fired. That, aside from vehicle modification and linux ray tracing, is my biggest hope going forward. for now, having finished the main story, it feels weird returning, but i definitely enjoyed it and continue to impulsively google news of further updates, so.....recommended

I understand that people have had issues with the game, which makes me really sad. In the 446 hours of play I have not encountered a game breaking bug, so going off my own experience I can only judge the game on what is there. I wouldn't have put as many hours into it if I didn't love the game. Characters feel real, scenarios generally have many ways to tackle them, the city feels more alive than any other game I've played before, and the setting is amazing. Is the game too ambitious? Sure, they tried to get so much packed in and it's clear that they were not able to even get everything they wanted in it. Is the game bad because it didn't include everything, not by a long shot. Many people seem to think that this was a malicious attempt at raking in cash, if you know the devs and the previous games they have made it should be clear it is not. They were clearly hamstring by having to release the game on so many platforms that they would have needed much more time to ensure that it was working across the board. They should not have released this game on the PS4 and original Xbone, those systems were under powered for anything that was ever shown by the devs. That's the biggest mistake this game made, and frankly people just don't seem to take that into consideration or don't care and just wan't a good reason to be down on something with so much hype. I understand those that were upset due to bugs, but the hate goes way beyond what the game deserves.

Fun game, even on replay. I held out for the first major patch to purchase and, even a few patches later, there is still some work to do. Granted, the bugs and glitches are just minor annoyances as of 1.22. Graphics are amazing with everything cranked up, and story line and characters are very good, though not Witcher 3 good in my opinion. My only real gripe is the voice acting for the female V falls a bit flat- not a wholly convincing character.

I had high expectations and left completely satisfied with the game. I keep coming back to it and will with every update. In its current state, this is almost my favourite game of all time coming in just behind The Witcher 3. 

Will do a proper review when I feel I have had my fill with the game.

[b]Edited/Updated Review:[/b]
[i]TLDR: This game is awful.[/i]

[b]The gameplay:[/b]
- First of all, this game has the most basic bitch character creation I've seen in a while. Even Dark Souls or Skyrim do it better, barring the genitals which are 4 options total. Hell, if you mod Skyrim you have so many options you'd spend this entire game's playtime perfecting a preset to play that awful game with.
- Secondly, this game is bog standard when it comes to action games (no it's not an RPG that's just background), it's just painfully mediocre at most things and average at best. The RPG elements are tacked on, the shoot n' loot mechanics add SOME variety but they're just re-feeding you barely interesting weapons, there's some fun in hacking and trying out stealth but the stealth only works when it feels like and the hacking quickly becomes overpowered to the point where an entire enemy area can be taken out by a single Contagion hack. 
- The rest of the combat is just your average shooting and meleeing from any FPS, melee combat is Skyrim to the core, with nothing to set it apart but upgrades that slow time when you dodge. Skyrim does that too though. Reason I mention it at all is because it's also an extremely bland experience, only mods make that game okay. The exploration and sandboxy stuff is there. Driving is a nightmare without mods though. There's enough to look at and run parkour about but there's nothing to do in the sandbox. You can't even start rampages like in GTA because the police is horribly inadequate and eventually 1shots you magically or gives up. It's sad.

[b]The story:[/b]
- What story? They had the entire world of Cyberpunk 2020, and 3.0 and they barely did anything with them except pepper you with lore every now and then. Johnny Silverhand is an unlikeable asshole and sure that's the point but it's also Keanu Reeves voicing him and he has the emotional range of plain white drywall. Having him in your head and having him comment on quests is easily the worst part of this game's story. His voice is obnoxious, he sounds like he's never swallowed spit his entire life before speaking and is constantly drowning in it, it's thick and viscous too like cigarette tar. 
- The "romance" options total in a number you can count with one hand, 4+1 fling that vanishes soon after it's over, and they're gender locked so it's 2 per, not that the characters are interesting at all besides Judy and Panam who were clearly written far more than River or the other one. Almost like they expected a certain demographic to bother before anyone else. I know for a fact the only character I wanted to romance was Takemura but can't have that. That'd be interesting. River ends up being a boring idiot, Panam stays sorta relevant though and Judy sticks out because someone actually bothered writing her.
- While we're here, this game has the worst sex scenes I've ever seen in anything. Like seriously, I would consider Ride to Hell's scenes better, at least they're funny. It's fucking awkward in this, Skyrim's sex mods do even first person scenes better. I don't know who greenlit this, to such a limited scope too. There's 3 whole prostitutes and the 4 romance options to fuck with and every scene is just jumpcuts and weird angles and it makes you nauseous. I had to suffer through Keanu trying to act dom and I wrote this review directly after to vent out how fucking mad and disgusted I am.

[b]Bugs/Glitches[/b]
-It's still bad, we're over halfway through 2021 and this game is still barely playable. My original review of this was just complaining that I couldn't play it on my brand new 3070 with a 3700x CPU. I had to tinker for 2 weeks with the settings to get it playable and hooo boy don't even THINK about using RTX. It just won't work. At best with my settings right now I get 70-90FPS. 45 in places like the Japantown Neon Garden. It's nuts. CDPR says they're happy with this though so good enough I guess. Good job. There are times where I walk down a slope and instantly die, there's times where entire sections of map refuse to load and I gotta drive through a flickery seizure-inducing mess of terrain that was supposed to vanish for the actual road to load. I don't know how this happens after so much dev time and so much inhumane employee treatment but here we are. The real dystopia was inside us all along, bois.

Though worthy of much criticism, any review that relegates this game as trash is greatly exaggerating.  Night City itself is nothing short of astonishing.  The detail on the cars is extremely impressive as well.  The story is gripping, and the characters deeply engaging.  Contrary to popular belief, the choices you make DO affect the game's outcome, though not to the extent we see in Witcher 3.  The combat AI is nothing to write home about, but it's not horrible.  The bugs are many and sundry, but it's gradually improving over time.  

The complaints you see in the reviews stem from the glaringly poor decision by CDPR's management to release the game before it was ready, and their desperate lies regarding its performance on legacy platforms.  Many players have allowed this to bias their take on the game itself, and understandably so.  

If you're not the type to let that affect your enjoyment of a game, then there should be nothing stopping you from playing now.  I personally find it enjoyable to tour and explore the city in all its splendor, immersing myself in the world and finding its many hidden secret places skipped by the missions.  If you're the same, I'd highly recommend the game.  Otherwise, I'd wait a year or so before playing it.

I saw the trailer 8 years ago and then stayed away from any and all hype there after, so when I got the game, glitching aside, I enjoyed the quests and characters. I didn't watch any videos from the developers hyping up stuff, so I went in pretty blind just hoping for a Cyberpunk open world rpg. I  came away satisfied enough to recommend the game with the caveat you aren't going into this expecting GTA Cyberpunk, or "the next generation of open world rpg" in mind.

I can totally understand how people can feel burned by this game. Its not a Cyberpunk GTA RPG (god that still sounds so cool....), its more of like "Open World Diet Deus Ex". As a fan of Fallout (1,  2, even 3, and especially New Vegas), I can definitely relate  what it feels like to being majorly let down after getting hyped for a game. I disliked Fallout 4, it felt like a post apocalyptic Far Cry to me more than a Fallout game. So I can totally get the vitriol sent this games way .

I have wanted an open world cyberpunk game since GTA3 came out. I remember thinking, man a Blade Runner / Shadowrun GTA style game would be awesome. This game could have come so close, its hard not to feel somewhat like Obi Wan in Episode 3, "you were the chosen one!" when thinking about this game.

I still had fun, but man what this could have been. I've never played a game where you can almost feel the cut content like  you can in this one, and that's really a shame. Hopefully its patched and fleshed out with dlc, if it has a turn around like No Mans Sky, or heck even Fallout 76 now, that would be great. 

I  want a good open world cyberpunk rpg. Nothing against Tolkien, or high fantasy, but I'm so..so...so sick of slaying dragons with swords and fireballs.... so I hope cdpr is able to polish this into a game they can be proud of. They have a history of improving their games post launch with their Witcher series so hopefully they are able to do the same here.
some glitches but it's fun

So I played throughout this whole game.  It has many creative ideas on a parallel CYBERPUNK world.  The game is interesting and the arts great, but the combat should be improved on and there really isn't as much depth to the game as you would expect from all the hype.  This is an Adventure game.  There are many rpg elements in this game like building your character, collecting powerful loot, and interacting with the world around you.  There really isn't anything too special about this game comparing it to something like Skyrim, but the game does explore interesting ideas that makes it enjoyable and fun to play.  For example, you can do dope shit like getting a smart pistol that homes it's bullets onto enemies, or get enhance robotic panther legs that make your steps silent,  like in watchdogs you can hack the enviroment, you can get a built in grenade launcher into your character's arms, and there are many ways to deal with missions your own way.  Most actions you make in the game affect you in some way, and every mission is unique to the cyberpunk world.  Theres a lot of black mirror shit where the game brings up ideas of what a merc in this world would encounter.  Arts good, acting is good, story is decent, there are some bugs, but those are being hammered out.  Overall, like most games it good to play to enjoy something other than your real life.

There is no customization as most of the vehicles and body appearance are set and stone as soon as the character creation is finished, and once you finish the game once, there is nothing that really comes at you that is "new," as some of the perks you build into DO NOT work. You might find that one new weapon or play with a different weapon for this playthrough, but I feel all of the game play always leads to the same conclusion, no matter how you play.

All in all is good game. Graphics are fantastic, story telling is fantastic, replayablility is a little lacking and the bugs that make some options playthroughs end the same, are all apart of the great blunder that CDPR made, but it was a pretty good blunder imo.

To rip the bandaid off, this is a piece of garbage and not the game you or I waited 8 years for. 

To call this game disappointing is an understatement. I won't chew your ear off about bugs, like everyone else seems content to do. No, rather I'm gonna chew your ear off about literally everything else under the mess. Even if CDPR patches out all the little bugs and critters it's still a boring slog of a hollow game that offers practically nothing interesting, unique, or even just ENJOYABLE. A turd is a turd, no matter how much you refine and polish it.

Words cannot express how disappointing this game is, but I'll sure give it a try. First and foremost, I'd like to ask you something: Who was this game made for? What is it trying to accomplish? Where does the enjoyment come from? I'm gonna break down every aspect of this game and try to explain to you why it's such a dumpster fire. I'll even be nice to CDPR and pretend none of the marketing and lies exist. Just look at the game in a vacuum with an objective mindset.

Is it a good RPG?
Short answer: HAHAHAAHAHAHA NO
Long answer: No. For starters, your lifepath selection hardly affects anything. You play through a different 20 minute long intro sequence at the start, which always culminates in the same montage of you and Jackie, and results in the same exact starting mission. V will always be a smart-mouthed "cool dude" street kid no matter what decisions you try to make. 98% of the dialog choices in the game have zero effect on the plot, world, or characters and it's just flavor text, and what lines do effect the plot basically boil down to "how do you want to reach the same outcome?". The endings aren't based at all on choices made throughout the game, you basically sit down right before the final mission and get to pick which ending you want. If you can make a save game 5 minutes before the end of the game and reload it to see every possible outcome, your "RPG" game is a POS. 

Is it a good FPS?
Short answer: Not really.
Long answer: The weapons are well-animated, sound great, and feel good to shoot, but the crummy half-baked RPG mechanics get in the way constantly. I despise the borderlands-esque way weapons are handled, and the stupid leveling nonsense of enemies. (Why does this assault rifle do less damage than this identical one? Why does this guy eat 500 shotgun shells to the face when the guy I dealt with 2 minutes ago instagibbed when I so much as thought about shooting him?) The enemy AI is also laughably braindead and easy regardless of difficulty. The "hacking" stuff feels like a tacked-on last minute addition because it's not balanced at all, you basically hold TAB and press the "i win" button whenever you see bad guys.

Is it a good open-world/Sandbox game?
Short answer: Not even close.
Long answer: The phrase "Wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle" gets passed around alot when talking about the world of Cyberjunk 2077, and I have to disagree....it's more like "Wide as a puddle, deep as a puddle." Night City looks impressive in a screenshot, but it feels so bland and repetitive with nothing to do in it after only like 20 minutes of exploring. You can't interact with anything except the same copy-pasted vending machines, NPCs just stand staring at things or walking aimlessly, there's nothing particularly interesting or cool to find, side quests are Ubisoft levels of mind-numbingly repetitive "go here, kill baddies" etc. You can't even mess around with civilians like in a GTA game since their AI is so braindead stupid, oh yeah and they LITERALLY VANISH INTO THIN AIR IF THEY LEAVE YOUR VISION FOR EVEN A SINGLE FRAME. The police system is also hilariously awful, like seriously, 8 years and the best they could do was make them literally spawn directly behind you whenever a crime was committed? They couldn't even make them arrive by car, let alone chase the player? Utterly tragic. 

To sum it up, everything about this game on a fundamental level is objectively flawed. Every news publication just drones on and on about bugs and bad performance on console, while they all seem happy to forget the game beneath the bugs is an absolute mess not even worth it if it was free. (It wastes your time.) CDPR went from one of my most loved publishers to easily my most hated, right up there with the likes of EA and Bethesda. Don't waste your time on this garbage. 

Why can't anyone make a decent RPG anymore? *Sigh* well, back to playing Fallout: New Vegas for the 1 millionth time.

EDIT: Patch 1.5 is a joke. 1 year and police AI still spawns out of thin air, player choices still don't matter, ending still is a total blueball that makes the whole game feel pointless, combat still sucks and feels unrewarding, etc. Oh but hey you can change your hair now. Yay! I'm just tired of this game and it feels like it sucked out a part of my soul by getting me so excited and dragging me along for a year. With how lackluster and utterly crap patch 1.5 is I feel like I can finally give up on this game, it will never be enjoyable no matter how long I give the devs to improve it. As the patch 1.5 trailer put it, "you either love it or want to burn it." I say, let it burn.

Night city looks and feels fantastic but Cdpr really need to add more interactivity and the ability for more roleplaying in the city. 
Thanks to changes to the map it feels much more rewarding to explore. Not all Gigs are available from the start, and there is a reward from each fixer when you complete all gigs for them. Also side activities such as crime-in-progress are only shown on the map if you are near them so it feels much more natural and a lot less like busywork.
A newly added transmog system for clothing is a excellent addition to the game.

While I haven't beaten Cyberpunk 2077 yet, currently I don't think I can recommend it to most people and I will update my review once I beat it, but currently...

Cyberpunk 2077 doesn't really do anything new, almost everything you will do in this game has been done in another game. There is nothing game changing about this game at all. Completely middle of the road and as ride as an ocean but as deep as a puddle. New Vegas is still my favourite RPG, Deus Ex is still the king of Cyberpunk media, and Witcher 3 is still the best CDPR game.

I definitely cannot recommend this game to anyone has under a 20-Series card or similar, the performance on even my 3070 is pretty weak at times and my 1070 would flat out not run it ~30fps at all, and 30 series cards might as well be vaporware at this point. Playing it on low is also not really worth it, the gameplay itself is just very... basic and the story while pretty good I don't feel myself engaged much, the companion quests were way more interesting than the main quest, but the main quest was pretty fine from what I played, I know I'm at the final quest currently I just haven't actually started it. I've been telling myself I'm going to but I want to wait for the free content they're adding at some point, as I don't really see myself returning to the game after I beat it between lack of interest and just too much to go back and replay if I were going to, and from what I've gathered choosing your different paths in the intro doesnt really change much between playthroughs apart from some supplemental dialogue here and there and nothing game changing.

I also can't stand the way this game handles its RPG mechanics, in your skill points give you very minor increases most of the time with stipulations to even using that increase and it turns itself into a looter shooter unless you are constantly upgrading your guns. Personally, I cannot STAND this way of handling weapons in games and would rather weapons with static stats more dependant on your skills than the Borderlands style of two visually similar guns where one just happens to have better stats for whatever reason.

Like I said though, the game is gorgeous and the combat can be satisfying, especially playing it like a Street Samurai. If you do choose to pick it up, just don't expect anything deep or game changing. S'alright.

EDIT: I finally did beat the game, and while it is satisfying the ending I chose (Don't Fear The Reaper, Johnny Version), I still don't think I can recommend CP2077. I do plan on doing more playthroughs now, though. I'm interested in what the Free DLC & Paid DLC will offer in the future.

This game was bought for me by a friend not long after launch, but long enough for some of the hotfixes to go through. I played it, enjoyed the atmosphere and the depth behind the side stories and I can look past the occasional UI bug, the goofy driving, etc. I grew up on Garry's Mod, Skyrim, and other games where glitches give a game character.

I left the game then came back to it because it's a great game to play solo when my friends aren't online. Protip: The song Fortune Days (Virtual Boy Remix) (Feat. Virtual Boy) by The Glitch Mob goes great with most parts of the game. Very techy and futura. Anyways, I came back, did tons of side quests (because they're shockingly well fleshed out, and) because I was told to do them first before finishing the main story, and they were RIGHT. As many as you can reasonably stomach make the ending so much more meaningful. 

The main job storyline hits you with a "Point of No Return" warning to let you know that, hey, after this it's main story til the end, so take care of business now. I really appreciated this, did a bunch of side jobs and grinding which helped out a ton. I went with a netrunner build, bolstered my quick hacks which are SUPER fun. I liken it to Skyrim's mage build.

Finally, when it came to the ending I've been let down by a lot of games. Fallout 4, Skyrim even (a little), and others. Some are extremely well written, like Life Is Strange, which is my favorite game of all time for how well written the story is. Rather, it was.

Cyberpunk 2077 has, hands down, the best written story and the most mindblowing ending I have ever seen in a video game. And once you're done, it gives you certain (meaningfully) special items for completing the story, reloads you to a save before the ending so you can play in the open world more and (this is important) REGULARLY go back through the point of No Return and play out all of the ending scenarios with different levels of completion of the side stories without having to grind all the way through the main story again.

People actually sent CDPR death threats because they kept delaying, so I can't blame them for releasing  game before they felt like it was finished. 

That being said, I didn't follow much of the lead up hype and bought this game shortly after launch. I played all the Witcher games, so I figured lets see how CDPR does cyber. I cant help but compare it to Witcher 3, their masterpiece which was comprised of interesting characters, amazing natural scenery, and architecture that blew away the mediocre medieval scenery that of even high budget cinema.

Put simply, Cyberpunk 2077 has one big thing going for it: a ridiculously detailed open world that could have been just a game where you just walk around and look at stuff. Gameplay-wise it lifts aspects of other FPSes but is engrossing enough to keep you playing for hours. 

However as an "RPG" its hard to get to like your character or many other characters for that matter. None of the characters in this game are all that interesting except for one that dies off early in the game and another that is the rebellious country girl archetype.

Like Witcher 3 the main story has its moments but as a whole is mediocre. Its the side missions and all the little encounters in between are what make it fun, funny, disheartening, and cathartic. If you get can around the fact that its called Cyberpunk but the story is not "cyberpunk-genre" conforming then its not an issue. Some condemn it for that, but I don't. Its the dystopian aftermath of an already dystopian cyberpunk world. A double dystopia. Dystopia-squared.
Some heroic cyberpunks tried to fight the power and failed-- thus the culture of this world has become somewhat like that like the movie Idiocracy: base and loud. However unlike Idiocracy the world is tragic instead of funny and people are not lacking for intelligence. They live in a oppressively meaningless world but do the best that they can. Its American/Cosmopolitan society today cranked up to 11 including terrible food that only outsiders notice. Nihilism won. All that matters is cool guns, cool cars, outrageous cosmetics, cybernetic upgrades to your body, picturesque neon scenery, and as much money you can make to get more of it. The story is criticized for being shallow but for me that is the point. People didn't care enough to fix the world so now they pay for it by living a life of just trying to ease the pain of existence any way possible. That almost sounds like good science fiction.

Core-gameplay-wise, I give it a C. Here are some bullet points to support that grade:
The crafting system is a flop. In the Witcher games you needed to find specific ingredients by different means for making epic gear instead of just finding generic parts.
The heart of the gameplay seems to be the FPS combat. The stealth/puzzle parts could have been shored up a little with gadgetry and skills.
Character skill upgrades rarely make you feel satisfied in your choices.  
Bugs have been heavily fixed but driving anything but a motorcycle still sucks - a major shame because of the awesome looking cars/motorcycles it has. 
Hacking is repetitive and low payoff for a "cyber" game.
I would have loved an over-shoulder view option.Why spend all the money and time on the cool cyber cosmetics if you only see them occasionally?
I have yet to come across an FPS with good melee combat, including this one.
The damn phone calls while you're in the middle of things. Apparently in the future the phones in everyones skull cant be set to mute while youre in the middle of a conversation or being shot at.
"Cyberspace" could have been an option for non-FPS gameplay but instead its an interactive cutscene. 

I will still pop back into Witcher 3 after all these years and play it because its my happy place. I will spin up this game from time to time as well but not to play the missions or side quests. I hop on the motorcycle from Akira and drive from one end of the map to the other and get into random battles on the way. I'll hop out and walk around the city and find a new area the core gameplay never took you too/through. Its a cool world to visit but not to stay. For that reason I haven't uninstalled it yet.

I still highly recommend this game despite the negatives. Its awesome just being in the city, looking around, seeing the sights, and I only played it at 1080p with a nearly 6 year old 1070GTX. 

Definitely felt like there was something missing to the main story, but CDPR in the past has delivered with their Witcher 3 expansions, so we shall see if they add anything to this game. Enough people still seem to like Cyberpunk 2077 despite the bad press, lackluster story, and boilerplate gameplay. Including me. It could have been better but at least it wasn't ruined by impatient covid lockdown-crazed gamers who expected a Robinhood technofantasy. CDPR still delivered a viable escapism experience despite the hypocritical public pressure. Nice try, peasants. Despite your efforts to ruin it, CDPR still did it.

Despite the games flaws I loved the story and the characters. The world is crazy beautiful. I put over 150 hrs into a single play through, and if you go looking for it (which I certainly did) there is a rich story with tons to dig into. I highly recommend this game.

[h1] Cyberpunk 2077 was certainly an eye-opener on how harmful massive hype trains can be to a game's final release. [/h1] 

Since I had seen that incredibly vague teaser trailer years ago - the first announcement that it was coming - I was in awe. I have always loved gritty sci-fi settings and I wanted to know more, like many others. Eventually, I too was sucked into the hype for a game we knew nothing about for years.

When the game finally released in December of 2020, everyone was hoping this would finally be something good to come out of a terrible year. Well, let's just say it disappointed a lot of people. However, I am not here to tell you how terrible Cyberpunk is because I actually enjoyed it quite a bit. I want to focus on the good things about the game.

[h1] Cyberpunk 2077 is a great RPG with a captivating story and setting, but it is certainly not revolutionary. [/h1]

Some promised features - or anticipated ones - were not present in the final game, which is why I say this game is nothing groundbreaking. The feature I was most interested in was its [b] branching storyline [/b], which really wasn't as branching as you might think. For starters, when you create your character, you can choose one of three [b] Life Paths [/b] that sets your character's background; Nomad, Street Kid, or Corpo. These choices only affect how your character ties into the main story, but after the intro, you end up in the exact same place. You get some Life Path dialogue options, but nothing else is affected in any way. Also, the choices you make in dialogue scenes can change the direction of conversations you have with characters, but the overall story doesn't change all that much until the end. For certain characters, like Johnny Silverhand, your choices in dialogue may influence the relationship between you and them and they may speak to you with a different tone, but the narrative is largely unaffected.

That being said, and I may just be easy to please, I thoroughly enjoyed the story. I felt pretty immersed in Night City and it was a joy to take in the sites of massive skyscrapers overhead. The game made you feel small, like you really were in a gigantic city, even though the map size wasn't all that big compared to other open world titles. I never played the original TTRPG from the 80s, but I've read lore from classic Cyberpunk and it was cool to see those characters realized in a video game format. I was happy to hear that CDPR let the TTRPG's original creator, Mike Pondsmith, be very involved in creating the game and writing the story. CDPR has always been faithful to the source material for their games, like [i] The Witcher, [/i] and always include references for long-time fans to enjoy and reminisce on.

The gameplay felt pretty standard, but it was fun. This is another big example for "good but not groundbreaking" because there wasn't much in the way of new ideas or concepts. The most interesting part of the gameplay was the Hacking aspect, and I like how you can choose to build your character as a Netrunner and become as strong as someone who specs into a Solo build. Other than that, you have a decent system for core character Ability Scores, and a standard set of perks to choose from. My only issue with the perks is that some of them were flat out useless; if I remember correctly, there was a perk that increased either your stealth stat or damage while you were in water. The problem with that is the only water in the map is along the ocean, and there are rarely any combat encounters near water.

The driving in the game was also okay. It was a little rough around the edges, but since the initial release, CDPR has patches the driving gameplay to feel a lot smoother. As for the cars themselves, all of them have a very unique design that blends sci-fi elements with real cars, as well as hyper-detailed interiors that are really quite stunning. An especially unique car is [spoiler] Johnny SIlverhand's 1977 Porche. [/spoiler] One thing I had wished for, however, was car customization. The game gives you ownership of so many different vehicles by the end on top of many others available for purchase, but you're unable to customize any of them to feel more personalized. One of CDPR's selling points on vehicles before release was the emphasis on actually buying cars instead of stealing them, like in GTA, so I was expecting more incentive to actually buy them. I think I only bought two cars throughout my first playthough; one of them with the reason that I had to as per the game's tutorial, and the other because I needed something faster until I found an even faster car.

The last core gameplay mechanic I'll discuss is general exploration and quests. The map of Cyberpunk isn't as massive as other titles like [i] Breath of the Wild, [/i] but the world feels very lived in with all of its sidequests and activities. There wasn't a single quest or questline I felt unsatisfied upon completion; I think all of them had a really good story attached so that it didn't feel like monotonous grindy bullshit. This goes for questlines for main characters with romance options, like Judy, Panam, and River, but also for other quests you'd think are only worth doing for the money. While they do pay pretty well, you get to learn a lot about Night City and its inner workings, and explore concepts revolving around everyday life in the year 2077 and corporate corruption first-hand. There are plenty of collectible lore texts to read and learn about the world in addition, but it's really interesting to become involved in those concepts.

[h1] Overall, Cyberpunk 2077 is a very good game and I enjoyed playing it. [/h1]

While I think the hype was dragged out for way too long, I think everyone in the gaming industry learned a valuable lesson. You cannot build that much anticipation for your games because it will only result in disappointment. Cyperpunk was obviously rushed and probably needed another year or two to be fleshed out, especially since there's an ungodly amount of bugs. Some of these bugs are game-breaking, but most of them are pretty funny to say the least. It's definitely worth playing, but don't go into it expecting to experience a revolutionary gaming experience.

With all the glitches and trips that this game goes through, the one thing I will say is I have never stopped playing it for one second. I wish that they had release this game a year later than they did but I appreciate the game, nonetheless.

So patch 1.2 fixed a lot of game-breaking bugs and crashes.  It's quite stable, if a little wonky at times.  In my experience, most of the errors I encountered were related to the driving mechanics, or purely visual and had no effect on performance or mechanics.  So, with that out of the way:  It's good, but that's it.  It's not the revolutionary masterpiece everyone was hyping it up to be.  And that's fine.  What's here is rich in background lore, environmental storytelling, and very engrossing once you get deep in the paint.  

I like just about everything that's on offer with Cyberpunk, but I'm just a little let down with it's... depth.  It's a little shallow at times.  Fine-tune the perk system, make some more of the interior environments, add some more side quests that aren't Gigs, you get the idea.  But what IS here is fantastic.  Quickhacking is fun, getting the upper tier Athletics skills and parkouring around is fun, and almost all of the side quests are interesting.  

TL;DR Cyberpunk is good, it just needs to keep up with bugfixes and add a bit... more.

Cyberpunk really screwed me over, i bought it and loved it despite the bugs and horrible optimization because with certain graphic settings the game was at 60 frames for some pretty good graphics.  I had hoped that the game would get even more optimized and easier to run, turns out I was wrong.  Once i hit 53 hours the first big patch got added to the game, ever since the game is unplayable for me at 40 and under frames no matter what graphical setting I use.  I don't know what the hell they did and why it seemed to happen to only me and a few other people but it happened and its literally unplayable.  Every month or so i re-download it to try and see if its fixed but nope nothing.  I gave up, i tried to refund it, but i got screwed since i already had the game longer than 2 weeks and a lot more hours than 2.  I would love a refund, i mean the game went from fine and playable to completely unplayable, i genuinely got robbed and cant get a refund i tried.  Seems like this is a pretty rare case, but if i were you I wouldn't risk it.  Don't waste 60 bucks on a mediocre game that has a chance to just randomly and permanently become unplayable.

edit: The issue has FINALLY been resolved.  After completely reinstalling windows, all my drivers, basically everything, it finally works.  If this happens to you, and nothing else fixes it like me, then just reinstall windows.  Keep in mind took me basically an entire day to reinstall windows and all my divers, plus installing the game itself.

Oooooh Cyberpunk. I love and hate this game. CDPR really dropped the ball here, both in theme, genre and technical aspects of the game. Is it getting better? Kinda. But truth be told it's never going to be the RPG/Sim that it was hyped to be. I recommend the game because I enjoyed my 100+ hours with it, flaws and all. But that comes with a few caveats. 

Do you want an RPG? This ain't it, Chief. Cyberpunk is no more an RPG than FarCry is. You've just traded hunting resources to craft upgrades with, for XP and Money.

Do you want real, world changing choices/consequences? Again- the story has some options/choices, but it sells the illusion of choice. There little if anything you do that actually changes the story, and you end up with a very "Mass Effect" type situation for the rap up. If you wanna really effect the world, this is the wrong game.

Do you expect your game to function properly from start to finish? You might wanna give this a miss. Or at least wait until some of the DLC drops. Maybe by then they'll have the core of the game ironed out.
I have really enjoyed this game. Yes, there are some glitches here and there but not anything that detracts from the game.

Cyberpunk 2077 is flawed, first of all. Some stuff doesn't work still, some stuff feels pretty janky even if it does work, and the game can feel incomplete. Many combinations of combat abilities are completely broken which can make more normal character choices feel super underpowered by comparison. Character choices don't feel meaningful enough - often it's just a throwaway dialogue option related to your skill choices that doesn't change the outcome of a quest at all. It's basically an Elder Scrolls game with even less polish, less overall content, and insane hardware requirements to run smoothly.

It has a lot going for it, however. If you like dystopian sci-fi, Night City is absolutely unmatched as a videogame setting. The world is absolutely incredible and some of the better-designed quests really draw you into it. The core storyline is really interesting and has a variety of endings based on your choices. Certain types of combat builds feel incredibly satisfying and if you're into feeling like a god against powerless enemies there are certainly builds that let you live that fantasy. It's also got very adult themes in a world where you're expecting them, rather than limiting itself to a PG-13 approach that would do a disservice to the setting.  Some of the characters like Judy, Panam, Rogue, Silverhand, and the Arasaka family get a masterful representation with incredible depth and development.

In another year of development this would have been a masterpiece and hopefully it gets that year post-release. The base game is good and the potential is incredible, especially for fans of first-person single player RPG's that also happen to love the Cyberpunk theme. If you're asking if you should buy and play through it the answer is yes if it ticks those boxes for you, and "wait for it to be done" if those aren't huge passions for you. They are for me and it's my favorite game, but in this unfinished state it may not be that for you and definitely is not that for everyone.

Epic. Scope and scale of the city is way beyond anything ever attempted in a game before. This is not a game to rush through. Take your time and enjoy the sights. Now for the review.

1. Ignore the people who have complained. There are no more bugs in this game than any other RPG. As for the frame rate; Fallout 4 and Red Dead Redemption 2 both had absolutely pitiful framerates in cities on PS4/Xbox (where the majority of the complaints are coming from), yet seemed to get a pass. I played this game on console first (PS5) and it was still very good. Follow any game close enough now a days and you will see a disturbing number of people who have complaints for every little thing. There's just no pleasing some folks.

2. The FPS mechanics are average, but competent enough to make the game a lot of fun.

3. The game can be played mainly as a stealth game if you so choose. Also can go for a hacking focused stealth route.

4. The driving mechanics are fine, not great but not bad. Good variety in how different types of cars handle.

5. The city is massive. Like nothing ever seen before in gaming.

6. Story is fairly interesting.

7. Tons of side content. Take your time and explore the city and this is a game that will last you easily 50 hours on your first play through.

8. Ray tracing is not worth the frame rate hit. I have found that turning off screen space reflections also gives you another 10-15 frames and the difference is minimal. The game still looks great. DLSS balanced seems the best way to go to keep a crisp image while maintaining a great frame rate.

9. There is one stretch of road in a specific part of the city where your frame rate will drop a good 30-40 frames. This only lasts for a few seconds and doesn't seem to happen anywhere else.

10. Out in the badlands there is a stream of what I call ghost cars that look to be driving on the highway and then disappear. This is a very annoying bug, and the only one worthy of legitimate criticism in my opinion.


This game is not perfect. I think a lot of people were expecting perfection. It is, however, one of the best single player games of the last few years. I think that is more than enough.

There are a lot of major problems with this game, most of which are being fixed by modders rather than the developer. There are some good things about the game: the city is an impressive complex maze of streets and high rises, vehicle handling is much improved from the early release, and characters look realistic and expressive, but the best things are the story line and main character interactions. I'd say it's worth buying at half price and accepting it for what it's ended up being than for all the pre-release hype, as long as you don't mind downloading and installing installing mods (probably 4 or 5 are essential just to avoid being too irritated by bugs).

I bought this at release, but held back on playing it given all the bugs and bad reviews. Picked it up again after the 1.2 patch, and thoroughly enjoyed it. Pay no mind to the haters that criticize the game just because everyone else is - this is a good first person RPG with plenty of character customization options and lots do see and do. 

The story is more linear than we were led to believe in their marketing, but still kept me interested and at the edge of my seat during many of the set pieces. My benchmark for RPG stories and worlds that stuck with me long after I finished the game include Witcher 3 and Mass Effect 1 - 3. Cyberpunk 2077 isn't at that level, but it is definitely right up there in the top 10 for great RPG stories. Also, those games were series that built up their characters and worlds over multiple games - perhaps future Cyberpunk titles will elevate the series,

I did around 90 hours for a single play through and did all the major side quests and probably 80% of the smaller ones, called "gigs." So its a lengthy game if you see all the sights. Speaking of which - I often found myself just stopping to admire the scenery - it is stunning. Rain swept nights in an industrial area, early morning god rays through dark, imposing skyscrapers, side streets with neon signs and gangsters spraying graffiti... Night City is beautiful if you have modern hardware. 

On a game play note - the gunplay isn't that great initially, but as you level your character and get better gear then it becomes tighter. So be patient if it feels a bit janky in the beginning.

First and foremost: It can't be said enough how incredibly good this game looks. EASILY the nicest looking game out to date. Ultra settings with Ray Tracing on is an absolutely gorgeous experience. 
As for the rest of the game: Impeccable. Dialogue is great, story line is extremely interesting and immersive IMO. The side missions are the same amazing quality like we got in The Witcher 3. Not a bunch of copy/paste garbage like you get with an Ubisoft title. They're original and as fun and rewarding as the main story line is.
Melee combat is extremely satisfying, which was a concern for some from early game play videos. Gun play IMO is very smooth and there are a LOT of different guns in the game to suit different types of play styles.
Hacking is deeper and more fun than it is in Deus Ex or any other game I've personally played where hacking is a "thing".
Not much more to say...CDPR absolutely nailed every aspect of this game and no one has captured the Cyberpunk genre the way they have.

But I did enjoy my time playing this game, and I even teared up in the endings I got. So imma recommend this to the people who just wants a good story.

Let me say this before adding anything further: I did not wait as long for this game as other players have. With that in mind, I do recommend this game. 

While I wasn't waiting for Cyberpunk nearly as long as other users, I do find the game enjoyable. I also want to point out that I did preorder the game, and I have played it since day one.  I'm not sure if it's because of my hardware, but I never had the bugs and issues that other users had. This game has always been playable, and has run smoothly for me. The only criticism I have is this is the one game I cannot run at 2160P. I have to run it at 1440P for it to run smoothly. That being said, it's not a hugely noticeable difference. 

 I enjoy the story of the game. I'll be honest, I play this game like I played Skyrim, or Oblivion. I don't play it all the time, but when I do, it's an all day session. I love the story and the lore to this universe. While the game is not perfect, and does fall short of what may have been promised to users in the past, I still think it is a solid and enjoyable game. If you like story and lore, get this game. If not, it may not be the game for you.

Right. I've got 100 hours on record. I'm in a decent position to write an honest review, so here goes:

Do I recommend this game? Yes, basically - depending, of course, upon your set-up.

*Bugs*
I'm on a 3080, 8700k set up, and it runs really well. 50-60fps with most things turned up to max (and DLSS of course). As far as bugs go, yeah it's got a few, but I haven't encountered anything that renders it unplayable. (Although hotfix 1.22 is causing some crashes.

*Story*
This is where Cyberpunk shines - the story, while not necessarily groundbreaking, is cool. I liked it. I cared about the characters. V i s a bit of a vehicle for the other characters and the story, but everyone else is well written, and with the depth you'd expect from a CD Projekt game. Johnny Silverhand is cool - I loved his role. And Jackie. Ultimately, the story kept me going. It's 100% the game's strength (though don't expect ground-breaking Last of Us story-telling or anything like that. The sidequests vary, but there are some real, extended gems.

*Gameplay*
A mixed bag, to be honest. It's interesting to be able to build different characters - I've had a muscley shotgunning wielding maniac, a cyber ninja, a fast submachiner gunner, a computer freak assassin - it's nice and varied, and the variety of perks allow for quite custom made characters. One thing I did find was that the game was a bit easy. Word of advice: play it on at least hard mode. Driving is fine. Combat feels meaty, if a bit samey.

*World* 
Sadly, and surprisingly, this is where the game falls down. The world is big, bright, beautiful, but ultimately a bit dead, and a bit empty. The NPCs shatter the illusion you're living in a real world, just meandering about with no purpose - carbon-copied cardboard cutouts. Someone else wrote 'wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle' and while I don't think that's fair to say of the whole game, I think the world does feel like that. It doesn't feel like there's adventure round every corner like Witcher did. There's not enough to do around the world sadly, even if it does look great.

*Overall*

I do recommend this game. Yes, it is disappointing when considered alongside the hype, but that doesn't a bad game make. I think it's a solid 8/10, even if we were led to believe it would be an 11/10!

This was a game that I went into expecting some fun and engaging gameplay, but more importantly an epic and interesting story, and that's what I got.  Though the game did have some bugs and issues at launch (to say the least), in my experience they weren't enough to mar that experience (and I beat the entire game by early January before the big patches had really come into play).  With that intro out of the way here's what I found to be pros and cons of the game, and just for fun a few hilarious or annoying glitches I encountered when I first played it:

Pros:
 - The Story and Characters: God did they nail it in this department; while they didn't go as deep as I would have liked in some areas of the main story, the absolutely spectacular voice acting talent and writing on display in the characters more than made up for that.  
 - The World: Night city is beautiful, dilapidated, and mysterious all in equal measure, and I always found myself stumbling on something interesting even when re-visiting areas
 - The Side stories: While there were a few piddly little 'go to the place and shoot the man' quests, these were mostly optional and the more interesting side quests had a unique flair that made me want to play them all just so I could stumble on another gem.
 - The Gameplay: I played this game on a controller so I have no idea of the holds up for mouse and keyboard, but I found the controls and various gameplay options to be pretty smooth and intuitive, and that I had a lot of fun tinkering around with different styles.  I found the various styles also added a lot of room for replayability, e.g. a melee weapon build, a sniper, a hacker, some kind of stealth assassin, some combination of the above.

Cons:
 - No beating around the bush, the performance:  I first played this game on a 1080ti video card and was reliably getting around 40-ish FPS with settings between high and ultra, things have improved since then, but not much.  When this game came out it had a lot, and I mean a lot of glitchiness, some were funny, some were frustrating, and a few were near game breaking.  Save early, save often was my mantra on my first playthrough.  
 - Missed opportunities: This is a weird one, especially since I listed the story as a pro, but there were so many moments in the game where I felt they could have done so much more or gone so much deeper story wise, but didn't (likely due to a time crunch).  There are also side characters who give out side quests who sort of just show up and start giving you jobs, ostensibly because of your street cred, but on subsequent playthroughs I found in some of the background openers you actually meet these characters so it just felt weird to me.
 - First person melee combat: hope you don't have motion sickness, I don't but it still got to me at times...its also super easy to lose enemies if you're attacking fast and dodging up close and in first person.

Funny Glitches:
 - All of the Trees on the ground being completely visible through floor of the air car in the Corpo opening sequence
 - A random serious cutscene where Jackie's pistol glitched into his head and was sticking out of his ear
 - A non-leathal stealth mission where I knocked out a guard to loot a key, then he exploded when I opened his inventory
 - Cars being summoned underneath other cars and sending both vehicles skyrocketing into the air
 - Using leg cybermods to jump high, only to get lodged in a buildings architecture and rocketed backward at something like the land speed record
 - Having bosses getting stuck on a tiny box or just standing there aggressively shouting at me while taking no action to attack me

Overall I seriously enjoyed this game despite its none to insignificant flaws, and I'm very much looking forward to the addition of the new DLC being rumored around.  Between that and all the work that's already been done patching the game CDPR does seem to have their hearts set on building this game into something truly epic.  The game is already head and shoulders above most AAA games, so I feel comfortable recommending it even in its current state, and hope to see it grow and improve even further.

CDPR has released a banger of a game with Cyberpunk 2077, though you may not know it initially. The game has gone down in infamy as what happens when you preorder an unfinished product. But I don't hold that against CPDR. This is the game that made me decide to upgrade from a GTX 970 to an RTX 3070, because I wanted to experience Night City in its full unabashed glory. Unfortunately things didn't go as planned, with launch..But do I regret my decision? Do I feel embarrassed for falling into the hype? No, I don't. And you shouldn't either.

Underneath all the jankiness, performance issues, and bugs is one of my most favorite video game settings to this day, with some compelling gunplay to boot. The gameplay itself isn't revolutionary or groundbreaking.. But I love it, regardless. Still, I decided to wait.. I decided to put this game aside, and refrain from judging it until it was more...Polished. 

It's now a year later, and CDPR has done a tremendous job patching the game and bringing it up to snuff. I recently returned to it, starting a new save game and everything. And I'm glad I waited. Because I liked Cyberpunk 2077 from the beginning. But now that I can truly experience it? I love it. The atmosphere, the vehicles, the beefy gunplay, the provocative story that seems to thin the line between life and death, and how you define what it is to be..You.

I can only hope Cyberpunk 2077 outgrows the reputation it gained at its launch, and that people find something to fall inlove with, in the same way that I did. And I'm hoping that CDPR continues to support it, and adds the quality content that we know they're capable of. The last thing any of us want is for them to feel put off because of this games rocky start.

Update with the Edgerunner Patch and 70+ more hours under my belt:

Well, I guess that final statement of my original review wasn't entirely accurate, since I definitely played it again even before the latest big update. 
But I guess the question is: Is it better? Is it fixed? Does it hold up to the expectations we had of it?

Short answer: Yes, No, No.

It is substantially better than it was, with multiple content additions, performance increases and bug fixes implemented that make it a far more functional title. But its still really not 100% of what it should be. Bugs are still very rampant, performance is still only okay, and there's been no overhaul that fixes the jank the game has.
If you've been interested in trying the game, I'd absolutely say now is a fine time to, but if you were holding out for a true 1.0 feeling, this still isn't it.



-------------------------------------------------------

I know this is always gonna be a controversial upvote, because at the end of the day the game does deserve its reputation of being a buggy mess with a huge amount of neglected features (honestly, almost every single part of the game feels like they planned on being able to spend another year on it, even if it had no bugs) I will have to admit that the 100 or so hours I played the game were actually quite satisfying all the way up to the end.
And while I can't really say if I'll ever play the game again, I am sad to see it go and I'm glad to have had the chance to play it.

A Solid What-A-Shame-It-Wasnt-Better/10

In short - it's a great rpg, despite its flaws (couple of words later). It's not a masterpiece like W3 (yet?), but for me really close. The story is amazing, Night City is beautiful, gameplay is fun, you can approach quests in many different ways, replayability and open world is better than in W3 (there you can play sword & alchemy or sword & signs, here you can play melee, focus on various guns, be a netrunner, play stealthy etc.) Also endings for me are more varied here, they are just easier to pick.

So far I played it twice (2.5 in fact, I started 2nd playthrough in Dec and stopped after a while, I wanted this experience to remain fresh), first one was short 50h mostly with shotgun and focus on main story, now I had almost complete walkthrough of over 100h as a netrunner. And for sure I will play again, probably after these free dlc are released. So for me it's not a question if it's worth buying, only when and for what price. If you are rpg fun and expect to play more than once, buy it now, if you expect one playthrough - wait for complete experience.

Couple of words about flaws. I have a good pc so nothing gamebreaking, but in Dec there was a lot of bugs, mostly visual but I also had to restart 2 or 3 side quests. Now almost nothing, couple of floating objects, couple of cars driving though NPCs or walls and that's all during 100h. Yes, you can feel that the game is rushed, it's not polished like W3, you can see cut content from time to time and it's annoying. Nonetheless, it's still a "must play" in my view. As I said earlier - the only question is when.

Game needed fixes on release and it seems like a lot of content was cut. That being said, patches have been doing wonders and the team seems to at least try to fix issues. This game flopped on release but after it recovers, it will be a must have rpg. The elements of a good rpg are all there, just a diamond in the rough.

Cyberpunk 2077. No charisma, but impressive cocks.

If I was to describe the game with one word, I’d use ‘’Janky’’, as my best friend himself described Cyberpunk, the same person that introduced the game to me.

I personally run the game with an RTX 2060, with DLSS capabilities, therefore I did not encounter any performance issues nor bugs. However I do not doubt the existence of issues, as the majority has reported.

I do believe however that everything can be fixed…eventually.
Question is; Will it be fixed?

The core of the game, the massive open world is incredibly superficial, with basically nothing to do in it.
CDPR has exceeded my expectations, and crafted a beautiful, detailed world. Yet it’s being bottlenecked by the low functioning AI and overly simplistic gameplay.

Roleplaying elements in a cyberpunk 2077’s dystopia do absolutely nothing to reach the roleplaying capability of Deus Ex.
There are no extracurricular activities that don’t involve shooting ads, like Red Dead Redemption 2 provides, a flagship of gaming’s potential, in my firm belief. (a game that released 2 years before cyberpunk, 8 years in development)
There is no tight gunplay, as you would find in the first Watch_Dogs, a game characterised by its John Wick style of fighting (before John Wick was even a thing) (a game that released 6 years before cyberpunk,  5 years in development)

RDR2 is used as an example, since it is the exemplar of modern open world gaming, which CDPR had set out to surpass and revolutionise open world gaming.
Watch_Dogs is used as an example, as it is an open world shooter with cyberpunk elements.

8 years of hype and development, to launch what one would describe as an early access game. Lacking elements, games way before its era, included and even perfected.

The AI lacks any sort of intelligence. Enemies rush at V without any sense of self preservation.
Often-times standing idly allowing V to strike them.
The police force, even after patch 1.2, insists on spawning behind the player, and directly in front of him in certain situations. Police chases are not available unfortunately, as they would prove a
re-playability factor, and a fascinating experience for the player as dynamism of the AI is put to the max in order to stop them, which can lead into numerous intriguing outcomes and last for countless hours.
Instead the enemy and police AI both must have listened to the Caretaker’s Everywhere At The End of Time as they will immediately forget who V is the moment he/she walks away. The world doesn’t interact with you as there is no bounty or police search mechanic. The gunfight can be restarted by simply walking up to a combatant and letting them stare at you for 3 seconds.

Approach methods include guns blazing and quickhacking or a combination of those.
Guns blazing can prove a rather fascinating experience given the arsenal and cyberware that are available to V, although one should not expect tactical combat like in Red Dead or an adrenaline infused shootout like in watch dogs, due to the AI not being dynamic and adaptive.
Quickhacking your way into your objective can be quite intriguing, since there is a multitude of quickhacks to mess your enemy with or their equipment. Unlike Watch_Dogs however, hacking in Cyberpunk is limited to pointing your crosshairs into an object and browsing a trainer menu. Even time slows while V is in netrunning mode. This mechanic renders combat boring as the player will not be put in  immediate danger, forcing them to alter their tactics.
Stealth is decent, despite random bugged situations where enemies can spot V behind cover.

The story is engaging yet its majority forgettable. It is a cyberpunk setting… but only in appearances. There is constant talk of megacorporations assuming control of the world, yet only one corporation takes the stage. There is no political intrigue, no conspiracy theories that turn out to be true, mo investigating into the greater mystery of the corpo world. Keanu Reeves, breathtaking as he is, takes V’s breath away and we must find a way to stop it. 

V’s backstory is utterly irrelevant. A 20 minute prologue, followed by a Dallas Buyers montage and boom you’re now a street kid congratulations. Why is V in Night City? Why do we want to be a living legends? What are V’s motives? Such questions could have been answered by adding a couple of hours to the game, where world building and character development would be included.

The characters definitely carry the narrative, with Johnny’s personal vendetta and Takemura’s strong honor code.

Regardless, I did in fact enjoy the game and was fascinated by its storytelling, especially the ending. 
Music is simply fantastic (OST, environmental and Samurai)
The voice acting and animations are exceptional.

Here’s hoping that CDPR will not let such potential go to waste and the playerbase will not be forced to blow up their headquarters.

After all…It would be a shame for a thing of beauty to fade away.
