Bro, I'll be honest right. I get that a lot of people were sucked into this for a very long while, people went crazy over the promises and went nuts over what was on paper. And better yet it was a well known developer that could have pulled it off, due their reputation. And I completely understand how people feel fucked for believing it. However even with that said, I cannot possibly give this game a bad review.

If you're still on the fence of where you should buy the game, then listen here.
I don't think the stuff that was promised will be all implemented. Maybe some good stuff will eventually with their DLC plans and whatnot, but right now, what you pay for, is still a great game. Call me whatever you want, but I didn't get hyped for this game, I thought it was a good idea when I heard about it ,but I didn't lose my shit, I tempered my expectations. Perhaps you could say that the fact that I tempered my expectations alone is a bad sign to show where the gaming industry is, where the moment you see a game that seems promise so much, you already know that a lot of the stuff being promised won't be in the final product. But in the end that's how it is, and unfortunately it's not the first time it's happened. Do I think that's bad? Yes. Do I think the work people have put into this should be disregarded and that what's on offer already isn't worth the price of admission? No, and here's why.

This game's content, story, visuals, and themes are all, without a doubt, great. I have played many games, and many RPG's, and this is one of the games that I can see myself coming back to to experience it. The city's design alone is fantastic, these guys nailed the cyberpunk aesthetic to a tee and that is worth a lot. The story is also the essence of what being a punk is, wether you accept it or not, and while a lot of people dislike the ending, I for one think it's only fitting for it to end on a note like that. The only problem that I genuinely have with the story, is the pacing device used. The fact that the game constantly reminds you that you have to work as fast as you can to save yourself damages the ability for someone to justify to themselves going out looking for side quests (Which are quite good) on their first run of the game. It constantly left me with a guilty feeling that I should be constantly on the move to find a way to fix the problem. However, it's just an illusion. A very well built illusion, but nothing more than that.

Now, let's talk about the bugs! Oh the horror! I know you've seen all these terrible, horrendous bugs and glitches everywhere! Model LOD's not loading in properly! Cars jettisoning into space at mach 20 speeds! Oh my lord however could we recover!
Honestly, during my 65 hours of game i've had so far, i've never encountered any of these game breaking bugs. And odds are you won't find them just regularly playing it. What I've found were simple bugs that I'd expect from any new release of an open world game nowadays, small stuff that doesn't impede your progress, or will ruin your game. I have a feeling some of these bugs are being blown out of proportion. Not because they don't happen, they very well could, there's videos for that after all! However when you go online and all you see are these videos showing off all the bugs and problems people find, it's not going to give you an honest representation of the game.

Now, before you go and call me a CDPR shill, this is the only game i've ever played from CDPR. And I do have my own problems with the game, but I don't fill they are enough to not warrant a recommendation. Weapon variety is small, you'll find the same model of the same few weapons with a different paint job that somehow shoot harder. Am I saying every gun in game should have their own model? No, I just would have liked to see more weapon designs. Some side quests aren't super interesting, and some side characters seem to be uniquely designed, yet get only used once. And of course, some of the bugs drag down and can break the immersion some times, but like I said, they're nothing you haven't seen before.

All in all the game isn't bad. It's quite good actually with all things considered. It'll give you plenty of enjoyment and with the new planned content, yeah, I can see this becoming more fun. The game was rushed to release due to stupid corporate reasoning and that's well documented, but that isn't an excuse to not review something honestly and give it it's due. While the PC version is fine, ps4 still got shafted hard with it's terrible performance. and last gen consoles aren't doing so good with the game in general, but that's neither here nor there, given we're talking about the PC version of the game.

My final words: It's a good game, it's not an amazing, revolutionary game, but it's a good game, it has it's problems, but every game does. If you look past that, you'll enjoy the experience, and it'll be worth your time and money.

Honestly, this game was released 2 years early despite delays.  Something that will fuel endless YouTube videos analyzing it.

This game is a far cry from what was promised.  There's honestly very little to the game.  There are so many other games that do more, cost less, and will run better.

Every mechanic that's actually in the game is ultimately disappointing.  From driving, combat, hacking, stealth, you name it it's underwhelming.  The story is OK.  However since you can do many things in any order some story elements start to not make sense  especially things around Johnny and considering how critical he is to the story it drags it down.

Every area is honestly super empty.  Visually, if you don't look closely, it might seem like a busy city.  But then you see the same NPC or car 3,4,5 times in a row.  NPCs not actually doing anything.  They finally patched in some rudimentary AI but it still doesn't change the fact if you just look around you see all the buildings as flat facades and the NPCs as just empty shells.  Most other games find ways to work around this, to make a city feel alive.  This game is barren.

It will take several content updates, including expansion packs/DLC to make the game complete.  To make it the game that was promised.

The one good thing I can say.  The art team went above and beyond.  The visual potential of this game will be used as a measuring stick for years.  Sadly, so will it's overall failure.

Overall, I like the game. I don't think it lived up to the hype, and it wasn't perfect on launch, but I didn't find it to be completely unplayable like some others have said.

But please for the love of God, fix the AI. 
Driving in traffic is next to impossible. They stop for no reason, stay stopped at green lights, and just seem to have no control over their vehicles. Makes GTA V traffic look like a driving simulator.
Pedestrians just seem to spawn at random and disappear at random. You look and see someone, look away and look back and they're gone. They also frequently seem to dive out of the way in the wrong direction, so they actually go further into harms way.

Also, I have had a few items spawn too low to pick up, like rolls of cash stuck in the table, or cars stuck in the ground.

The storyline is pretty good, graphics are nice overall, and it has definitely gotten better since launch. Replayability is a bit of a question mark, because the main story is the same pretty much no matter what, and changing the story at the beginning only changes the first 10 minutes, and some dialogue options. Still good for 40+ hours if you take your time.

I played this game on a 3070 with a 5600x with Ultra settings and DLSS on in 1440p and the FPS can really fluctuate depending on how the environment is. In really crowded areas I could easily get drops down to 40-50 FPS but im probably averaging about 80-90 FPS which is decent enough for me. Weirdly enough, my game has NEVER crashed on me. Visual bugs are quite common, sometimes boss names would not disappear after a fight and sometimes my POV get zoomed in after important dialouges (?), those were easy to fix tho with just reloading the game and I didnt find it disturbing.

The best part about this game is the characters, the voice acting and the storytelling. Its very easy to get attatched to the main characters in this game since they feel so real because of their amazing voice acting and their backstories, the missions are very unique and they dont get repetetive at all which is a huge plus. The main story of the game is really short which is quite disappointing but there are many different unique and decent-long side quests that makes up for the short main story, and yes I personally think they are better than the main story itself.

The soundtrack is also awesome in this game and really fits the vibe the city is giving you, maybe for the first time ever in a video game I actually have the radio on in a veichle when im going from point A to B. Graphics are the best ive ever seen in a video game, a couple of times I just stopped whatever I was doing and just wanted to watch the beauty of Night City. I never felt like the need to fast travel to a loaction because I really wanted to have a look at the enviornment and surrondings in this game. Driving has been improved alot in patch 1.2 and it doesnt feel like the fastest cars are driving on ice anymore. One thing i DO HATE tho is the minimap in this game and how small it is, since its so small you cant really drive fast around the city or else you risk missing a turn you are supposed to take. It might not sound like a huge problem, but trust me it really gets on your nerve after a while.

Movement in this game is actually really fun and satisfying once you get used to it. One of the things i enjoyed the most playing this game was to buy the double jump implant to get around the city/the area you are doing a mission in since you are giving alot of freedom in this game when it comes to movement, it added alot to the futuristic experince as a whole. The cyberware system is also very awesome to use in this game and if you create your character in the right way it will feel so satisfying to use if you execute it in the right way. Replayability is quite good in this game when it comes to building out your character different every single time and how you want to build out your relationship with different characters

Combat/gunplay is okay I guess, but that is mostly weighted down by the bad AI in this game. When it comes to the NPC complaint, it didnt really bother me that much since it didnt ruin my experience in the game. Crafting is also pretty bad and I didnt even have any use of it all, completely irrelevant for me. There are ALOT of GIGS/NCPD missions in this game, sadly they get repetetive really quick and its very often: Kill this guy or Steal this data type of job.  The open world aspect of this game is also pretty underdeveloped in my eyes with almost nothing to do if you are not doing missions, especially the romances is a huge let down once you are done with their main quests.

The difficulty can be really inconsistent somtimes and I would even call it broken.In the first half of the game when you are pretty low geared, the difficulty does its job and its pretty challenging. But in the second half of the game once you get better weapons and gear it just becomes too easy, even on the hardest difficulty, idk what it is but this needs to be fixed since its kind of ruining the endgame just plowing right through it and its the same thing every time and im on my 3rd playthrough as of right now writing this review.

Conclusion: 8/10

Cyberpunk 2077 is fun. It's not perfect, as I'm sure you've heard already if you're looking at this in 2021; there are some shallow game systems, some things are poorly explained, and if you look too deep into the clockwork of Night City, some of the façade falls apart. However, this game—in my experience—has not been as buggy as I've been promised it would be by editorial reviews and community content (I played it on PC exclusively). The positives include some excellent writing, gorgeous visuals, and an *absolutely killer* soundtrack.

At the end of the day, what matters is how much I enjoyed the experience. And to give you some idea of that measure, I finished my first playthrough at 107 hours and started a second one as soon as the credits stopped rolling.

Amazing story, side-missions and soundtrack. The overall atmosphere and aesthetic of the game is breathtaking. Buying this after patch 1.2, I experienced minimal bugs, mostly related to the AI acting weird, which is also my only major complaint about this game (Pedestrians all acting similarly and cars randomly stopping in the middle of the road). There isn't as much depth in casually roaming around like in Rockstars' games, but everything else, the futuristic feel, the theme of dystopian capitalism and the narrative especially is great, as one would expect from CD Projekt. From a story perspective, the game has a lot of depth. I know it is popular to clown on Cyberpunk 2077 for the disastrously buggy launch and unplayability on previous gen consoles, but I would definitely recommend this game and I'm sure it will only get better with future patches and DLCs. I played 83 hours of Cyberpunk 2077 in a week and can't wait to play more, that alone should say all that you need to hear.

This game was so unplayable since launch, even after 1 year of patches. I recently started a brand new play through with the latest update after the Anime came out (which I will not watch since Anime is just not something I can enjoy or have an interest in) and the game has improved significantly. Extremely rare encounters of glitches so far and I am 18 hours in to this brand new play through.

The new outfit system makes the game way more immersive as I can look how I want and still upgrade all my gear. I would certainly say Cyberpunk is now at a stage that is worth the money.

I still recommend hitting F5 every now and then, before/after finishing encounters and the dynamic events just in case you do encounter a bug.

Overall, play is very enjoyable.
The primary quest line is a bit of a rail, but can be ignored for stretches while exploring the city and taking on side quests.
Many of the side quests tie in to NPCs encountered in the primary quest. So, they *might* not trigger until you've encountered them along the primary quest rail.
Bugs seem to come and go, depending on the latest patch.

I'd really love to have given Cyberpunk 2077 a positive review, since although there are bugs, and they are definitely noticeable, they never really went past what I had expected for a single player experience. Fairly deep into the game, 2nd playthrough just about over, and Patch 1.2 dropped.

Patch 1.2 has just about killed my entertainment with the game.

In a Single Player game, at least in my opinion, the most critical bugs to patch out are those that harm gameplay or break immersion. It's for this reason that I understand why the painting exploit was removed, and similarly why I do not understand the removal of the Kerenzikov Dodge glitch. This glitch set Cyberpunk 2077 apart from other Single Player experiences, it allowed you to travel significantly faster than your running speed and made getting around Night City an absolute blast. With the release of Patch 1.2, this was removed. The removal of this glitch makes most situations of travel just involve finding the closest Fast Travel station and skipping the entire journey. It causes an awkward disparity between your horizontal and vertical movement and feels unsatisfying to play. There technically is a way to still perform this glitch, but it requires you to use a Sandevistan, which makes the glitch less accessible and have a significantly greater cooldown.

I can't recommend Cyberpunk 2077 after this update, however I would recommend the game if you can downpatch it before 1.2, as I can genuinely say that it is a very fun game, with high mobility firefighting and a semi-fleshed out leveling system.

Cyberpunk 2077 is not a polished game. It is not an optimized game, and overall it's not the best game right now. But I had a ton of fun playing it... once you get around the bugs and performance issues. You absolutely should not try to play this game without at least maybe a 1650 or higher performing graphics card / system. 

But as I said, I had a ton of fun playing Cyberpunk 2077. When the game wasn't breaking, it was clear there was a very in depth RPG open world game here. I think the story with this game is far from over, and I expect that in the near future this game will truly shine.

If you:

1. Have a system with a 1650 or higher graphics card.
2. Can get this game on sale.
3. Enjoy in open world RPG games with in depth RPG mechanics.

Then I would say you will enjoy Cyberpunk 2077.

After playing on Xbox One since its release, I realized I needed to build an PC to experience this game in the best quality. Worth it! I love the story and side missions and it def needed to be updated a lot but now its starting to come together. I can't wait for future updates and dlc.

At first I was upset like anybody else, but after few hours of playing I simply love this game and I definitely recommend it. If I am upset about anything then it is false promises of the management, but not the game itself. Once I backed up a little bit and told to myself - Ok, here is this cyberpunk genre game, let's start again and play it with clean head I actually realized it's unbelievably good. Here is why.

Graphics: Although I have only GTX1650 graphics is quite detailed and wherever I look it tends to focus itself, so the overall impression is very good. I expected much worse.

Music: I love it, really one of the coolest things about this game is soundtrack (JVZL - Circus Minimus is my favorite).

Gameplay: Here is where things come interesting. After playing it a while I started to notice similarities between Wither 3 and CP2k77. Calling for vehicle felt like whistling for Roach. Dialogs had similar feelings. Minimap too. Interestingly its' quite easy to steal (if there is anything like stealing at all, I didn't noticed). Fight also felt similar to W3. Surprisingly enough I actually didn't miss the 3rd person view although I do understand that the overall scenery together with main protagonist would be magnificent. Also the crafting of thins and searching for new schematics felt like wondering around Skellige for better armor. 

These are all just minor thing one notice immediately. Now comes the 'wow' part:

Details.

I haven't seen paying so much attention for details as in this game. To name few:
- characteristic of city landscape changes from part to part relatively naturally, but you can definitely feel the vibe
- different accents of different gang groups
- detailed models of motorcycles (even on lower graphic profiles). For example I had red windshield and when I look through it I could actually see the red world.
- characters really reacts on you depending on how you treat them
- finally someone gave me an option to go down the path of pieces instead of peace if someone really pissed me off, although all story lines up to that moment indicated I won't be able to clean the place
- realistic looking newspapers in the shops
- there are no (at least I didn't noticed) two same shops in the game (like for example food stores or weapons stores)

and many many more. Dev team really put an effort to this, they had to thing about it and that made me actually love the game.

When it comes to cons. You all know that. Occasional glitches. In some missions you remain stuck, e.t.c. I don't need to name them, whole web is full of them and I blame the management of Project Red for pushing the idea that game is basically finished although it wasn't.

Overall I do recommend this game. Don't expect it to be extraordinary and you will be surprised.

I absolutely love this game. 
I decided to order the P.C version, having previously pre-ordered the XBox version. This is the first game I've ever pre-ordered, due to having been excited about it for so long - I'm one of those gamers who generally waits a few months/a year, to allow any kinks to be worked out before I join in, but I just couldn't wait for this. 
In all honesty, I was still half expecting the P.C, version to have a few issues, however, as someone who normally plays on Console (I got a gaming P.C to be able to handle music production) I was very pleasantly surprised.
 At around 67 Hours in, I am so, so, happy with Cyberpunk 2077. I've had 0 hardware issues & only a handful of glitches (nothing major, just the helmet & hair not spawning when I get on a bike & occasionally having to enter the menu to stop my character from targeting). It seems like these issues are being addressed in the latest update which is currently downloading... Which is another thing... I can't believe how quickly so many minor details are being addressed! I love that CDPR have really bothered to make sure everyone has a great experience. 
The storylines are very immersive & the graphics are incredible - Night City is STUNNING! The whole game is just a sight to behold - Never before have I found myself stopping and Screencapturing everything... From scenic views, to city scapes, to just interesting background characters. I find myself invested in the characters we interact with & wanting to stay on that bit longer to find out more about them & where their storyline is heading. Oh, & the map is huge! Even with this many hours put in, I am well aware that there are still some areas I haven't completely explored & which no doubt have more gigs, side jobs & missions to present themselves.
I 100% recommend this game to everyone. It feels as though I am witnessing one of the defining games in History.

fun game of an older generation, despite when it was released. If you look at this game through the lens of a 2020 era game, yeah there is a whole lot about which to complain, but when you consider the development window and look at it as an older game, it is far more enjoyable. It's a fun romp of game design from a bygone era.

I absolutely love this game. I haven't played it much since it launched, yet I still find myself thinking about the story and all of the characters I met. If you only plan on blasting through quests without paying much attention to the story or small details (such as reading what's on the terminals and listening to background conversations), then you probably won't enjoy it as much as I did, but I think it'd still be very fun regardless!

Combat gets progressively more fun and engaging the higher you level up, and there are a lot of different combat paths you can take. If you're like me and you're not sure how to make cool builds, I recommend looking up tutorials on what guns/perks you should use. Make sure you get cybernetics from ripperdocs; there's so much you can do with them. Personally, I found quickhacks to be my favorite part of combat. Once you get legendary quickhacks, there are so many different routes you can take every combat encounter. Want to make the guards outside kill themselves after a delay while you go around back and stab the other enemies with mantis blades? Go ahead! Made a mistake and got caught sneaking? Wipe their memory long enough so you can kill them and hide their body! Etc.

This game especially shines in the characters and lore. You can really tell how much the world is fleshed out when you pay attention to the small details included in different locations. Every single quest has an interesting story to tell (of course, some are more interesting than others), and a lot of the quests have ethical dilemmas that really made me think about my decisions. On a similar note, I love how intercultural Night City is and how the different subdistricts have their own styles and histories. It's fun to go to the different locations and see what languages are being spoken and what topics are being talked about. And Night City is so beautiful and detailed!!! I can't emphasize enough how cool the city looks. Even after all the time I've spent on this game, I sometimes like to just spend time driving around in first-person POV on a motorcycle as I look around at the cityscape.

I thought that the characters in this game were extremely well-written. The animation for body language and facial expressions only enhance how realistically they act in dialogues. They feel like real people - not just NPCs catering to V's actions. And I like that the NPCs you interact with a lot have flaws that don't make them 100% likable all the time. I also appreciate that you can call characters at any nearly any point in the story. Of course, there's going to be limited dialogue (there's never going to be infinite dialogue options in games, unfortunately), but it helps make the characters feel like they have their own shit going on outside of V. This is a very emotional game, and some of the storylines are extremely serious and deal with intense topics. It handled said topics very well, in my opinion, and I loved the dark nature of many of the quests. I haven't played any other open-world video game that made me quite as emotional as this game.

The MUSIC! My God, I love the music in this game. The soundtrack and the radio songs are all bangers (although the Vexelstrom radio station gets played a bit too much for my liking, lol). The combat music is really intense and it always gets me pumped to kill the enemies, and I love the music during the more emotional moments as well. There are a lot of different genres in the radio stations, and I think everyone will find at least one that really caters to their liking. 

Overall, I highly recommend this game if you love the cyberpunk genre and are looking for a gritty story with fleshed out characters. This is very much an RPG similar to Witcher 3, so don't go in expecting to meaningfully interact with random citizens or be able to go into every single building. I think there was a lot of hype for the game (I didn't keep up with it, so I'm not fully aware of what was expected by the general population), but I think the backlash upon initial launch overshadowed the many, many positive aspects this game has. At the time of writing this, there are definitely still at least some visual bugs and awkward NPC movements/interactions, but I have only ever crashed once and none of the bugs have ruined my immersion. 

Seeing as it still isn't a perfect game, I'll settle on a 9/10 because some of the storylines could have been more fleshed out and there are more bugs than I would have wanted. However, Patch 1.2 was just released, and I think the development team is actively working hard to make the game as perfect as it can be in the long-run. I would recommend waiting if you want a mostly bug-free experience (although it seems the recent patch has fixed a decent amount), but if you're like me and don't get bothered too much by occasional glitches, then go ahead and play right now!

Was Cyberpunk released before it was ready?  Definitely.  I think that CD Projekt rushed to the finish line and some crucial stuff was missed when this game was developed, namely optimizations and some basic aspects of an open world game.

HOWEVER:
Despite being undercooked, this game came out like a softboiled egg: potentially messy, but still totally consumable and enjoyable at that.  I loved the story, and every bit of action in between.  Characters feel realized and well-thought-out.  There is so much to do, I literally spent about 25 hours so far just doing side quests and walking around the city looking at things (and I haven't finished them all).  On top of that, CD Projekt didn't waste any time and included a bunch of the game's assets right there in the game folder for you to enjoy: soundtrack, wallpapers, etc.

You can tell that they really want to be proud of this game, and they are still working hard to improve everything about it.  I love it, I appreciate it, and I hope all of you can as well.  It's not The Witcher, but it's definitely approaching equal to it.

I very strongly suggest fans of the cyberpunk genre avoid this game like the plague, in all honesty, i'm kind of embarrassed that I pre-ordered the damn thing.

After playing this game off and on since release, I've warmed up to it. Sort of.

The main plot is interesting and fun but CDPR completely lied about choices mattering, that multiple choice dialogue will give you some different lines but the end result is usually the same. The character path that you choose at the beginning also does NOTHING, you'll still end up with the same cutscene and the same gameplay. There are maybe 2 or 3 important decisions to make through the main plot and even then, they don't change a great deal. 
The best thing about it has actually been the side quests, I've found a lot of them have been incredibly more fun and interesting to play than the main plot missions are. There are some truly amazing detective style questlines to find and they've really stood out because of their unexpected twists and turns, sometimes taking turns to the nightmarish and gruesome. 

After that comes the visuals. It was a buggy game in the beginning but it's started to mature now with the latest patches. I love the experience of driving around at night in the rain, few other games look this good and have such an intoxicating atmosphere. 

Now as for the bad, it's the AI. All of it. Pedestrians are morons, car AI is the worst I've seen and the AI of police and enemies is done so poorly that it's comical. No matter where you are, even standing on top of a streetlight, a cop will teleport behind you if you've gained a wanted level. There are no car chases at all and no pursuit mechanics at all which is a major disappointment in such a large city with plenty of roads to have a chase down.

Buy this on discount and enjoy it for what it is, it doesn't deserve the full price considering all the very blatant lies about the development.
It's worth it.

I know my profile says 9 hours but due to internet tips and tricks i turned off the cloud sync to this game and have actually played closer to 170 hours, in 3 different runs. With that out of the way I want to make one more disclaimer: This game is incredibly flawed, and I don't just mean the technical issues, the city somehow as beautiful and expansive as it is feels dead. There isn't a lot of variation in things to do, enemy AI is non-existent, NPC AI is non existent, Driving ranges from arcade-like to "holy shit i wish they brought back Roach, I know it wouldn't fit but ANYTHING is better than this." That all said, I do recommend this game.

In all my hours playing this game, I think it would be best described as an action adventure title with a little bit of a "choose your own adventure novel" mixed in. The characters are by and large well written and interesting, and this game shines like a diamond in my opinion, with its interactions between V and Johnny Silverhand. The story is alright, i feel like too many things were left ambiguous for the sake of feeling "Sci-fi" however, it is very much a story worth sitting through. I enjoyed this game most as sort of a time waster, it doesn't take a lot of commitment to progress, the world is absolutely gorgeous and I didn't mind sometimes doing nothing more than inhabiting it, also, by the end of the game its just a pure power fantasy and all in all, approaching this game with that expectation might make it significantly more enjoyable. 

The combat is serviceable, not great, shooting actually feels surprisingly tight and melee combat is floaty as all hell but all together the variation in ways you can approach any given combat scenario actually does help keep it engaging. This games side quests can get incredibly repetitive and often times I couldn't remember weather or not I had completed certain sidequests because I was never truly sure what features made it into the game or not (in this instance the street cred system locking you out of lower tiered missions as you advance.) 

I honestly want to love this game, but I just don't. I keep wanting to say somewhere in this review its almost a great game, but that isn't true either. This is a solid game, that should be purchased on sale, that has fleeting moments of brilliance, that almost had me believing through patches they could "fix" the game, but in order to make this go from a pretty good game to a great game, it would need to be a different game. 

If you are looking for a shut your brain off, open world sci-fi experience with a compelling story and a visually stunning world I wholly recommend this game, but honestly it really isn't much more than that. I think I spent most of my 170 hours trying to make it more than that. All in all, I'm glad I gave it the chance I did, but if you were expecting that at some point CDPR would turn this all around and make this game the "next-gen" experience they advertised, this isn't it and it likely never will be. 

I know my review seems mostly negative, but I did enjoy my time in Night City, and if they ever release a proper sequel and managed to stick the landing, there is the framework of a truly great experience here. All in all at the time of writing, I certainly do not mind saying goodbye to it either.

7/10, get in on a decent sale, and play at your leisure.

Cyberpunk 2077 get's a very unfair wrap on the PC at least.  Go in with no expectations and you will be captivated.  There are elements to this game that IMHO deserve the term Masterpiece.  They include: music, graphics, story and characters.  Turns out these are the main things I look for in a game.  Things needing improvement are well publicized: Occasional visual glitches, and NPC and Police AI.  That being said, these things didn't take away from experience for me.  There were moments in this game that made me feel real emotion, more so than any other game I have ever played and rivaling the best movies I have seen.  I recently finished the main story and plan to play through again shortly.  The level of detail to explore in Night City is breathtaking.  Love or hate CDPR: you have to at least acknowledge what they have managed to accomplish here and the issues with the open world aspects of the game should only get better with patches.  I truly wish them success in the future.

Updated Edit 5-26-2021 at the bottom.

This game is extremely disappointing. It is hard to put into words just how flawed this game really is. The corporate decision to release this game early was a massive mistake. This game feels like an early alpha test of the game. So many features are either missing or not working at all.

If you are interested in getting this game and are looking for negative reviews to see how bad the game is, this next part is for you: while the game can be fun at times when you ignore the main story and enjoy whatever quests or just wandering around night city aimless, the main crux of the game is just hindering. At some point in gameplay you can clearly tell the shift in development where the game switched from being an open world rpg to a linear action game. There are so many things that the game hints at and implies for you to do, but be prepared to be disappointed that every single thing you thought might exist in the game simply does not. Because it's locked by behind some door that will never open and dreams never realized.

Quick Q&A:
Would I recommend this game? 
No. 

Should you wait for this game to be updated and fixed? 
Don't get your hopes up for it. So much is wrong with the game that a fundamental rework from the ground up is needed. This game might be good in like 3 years, and great in 5. But I could easily see this game being dropped in about a year's time from ever being updated again.

If you didn't like the game and wrote this review, then why are you still playing it?
Honestly the game is flawed and missing a ton of stuff. Some joy can be found in the game by ignoring the main story quest and doing your own thing, but then the flaws become even more apparent. It can be fun to roam around and do your own thing.

TLDR:
Play this game if you are curious how much content is missing, not working, or other ways you can break the game. Don't get this game if you want a polished AAA open world rpg game.

~~~Update 5-26-2021~~~
As of now I have put in about 100 hours into this game, doubling my previous time since I last wrote to this review. Since my first post to this review, patch 1.2 and hotfixes 1.21 and 1.22 have come out. The biggest improvements that I personally noticed from these updates were: 1) police are not as annoying as they spawn farther away 2) icons being updated in the UI helps to see at a glance what type of grenade or item you are looking at and finally 3) the ability to turn off the annoying dash by double tapping on keyboard in the settings menu. 

I have also as of writing this, completed all the major side gigs and NCPD's on the map (minus one in pacfica that I need to unlock somehow). I have around 50% completion towards achievement, and all I have left in the game is the major side quests, and the story itself. 

Having put in 100 hours into this game, I do sit and wonder to my self why I still keep coming back to this game in its broken state. After all I have much better games in my steam library that I could be playing. Heck most the games I have ever played have not reached 100 hours worth of gameplay. So why do I still keep playing this game while at the same time not recommend it? To answer the first part, it's honestly because I do have fun in the game. To answer the second part: the game itself though still fails on what I want from it. I was sold this game on the idea of a decision heavy rpg game. What I got was an action game with rpg elements. It seems that somewhere during all the advertisements and the development of this game, they had realized that this game could not meet the fan expectations, let alone what they wanted to see in the game themselves. 

I do wonder what the state of this game will look like in a few years. Will this be the next skyrim for modding? Will this game pull a comeback similar to no man's sky? Or will this game simply sink away to oblivion, simply being known as the game that disappointed? It's hard to tell.

I personally want to see this game succeed. After having put so much time into the game, I can see the remains of passion that were once there, but now are washed out by corpo greed. So many areas simply blocked off by invisible barriers that have me wondering what it would have been there. Especially with the teasing message of: "Nothing here for you... yet". It feels like the game wants me to speculate on what was there, why it wasn't finished or put into the game. 

I do feel bad for the people of this project. I don't feel like it was their fault the game got released in this state. It is also a bit sad anytime I see the social media trying to do any sort of basic communication to the fans of this game through either announcements or stats, that the entire comment section is filled with nothing more than just comments saying things along the line of "DeAd GaME!" "FIX THE GAME" "BROKEN GAME".  That being said, I do think it's fair the player base is so mad about this game's state of release. I am too. I mean, that's why I am wrote this review. It's why I'm editing this review right now.

Anyway, I thought I would update this review I wrote some time ago to further put my thoughts out there. I am not the best writer and this really is just more or less my ramblings posted online. I don't know how to end this, but I do intend on writing another update to this at some point. So, a question to future me, how do you like the game now?

~~Update 11/24/2021~~
Had to edit one of my reviews for the steam awards nominations badge, so I choose this one. Since last writing no major updates have come out for the game and the game is still missing a massive amount of content. You want more from the game? Then there are mods. Have a good one!

So I patiently waited to play this game, I avoided pretty much all the trailers and news on it, and I think that is why I was able to enjoy it without any unreasonable expectations. I was looking for a story based rpg, and I got exactly what I ordered. If you went in expecting the second coming of Christ in game form, of course you'll be disappointed. Of course, that doesn't mean I don't have criticisms, but they are realistic based on the genre.

So the nitty gritty, for the price and my love of story rich rpg's I will say I absolutely recommend this game. My first play through was ~87 hours, and I missed a few things. Sure, it could have been longer, but I don't feel it needed to be. It may have even dragged too much in the second chapter with more squeezed in, from a pure story telling standpoint. So I had no issues really with the story, and although some may find the endings bleak, I felt they were right on the money for a dystopian game. 

The characters were so well written, even the minor ones. The voice acting really brought them to life, too. They also did a phenomenal job with animating their facial expressions. I was enamored with their designs as a whole.

The environment felt very alive, walking around with crowds on, in the middle of Night City was very very immersive for me. The AI on random NPC's isn't groundbreaking or anything but the number of people and cars bustling about really drove home the sheer size of the place. With headphones on and everything cranked on high settings, it felt pretty real to me. However I understand that not every machine will be able to have everything cranked up like I did. Even with my rig, I only averaged ~87 fps at 2k resolution, where other games I generally have no issues getting 140's. 

The art department really deserves the highest praise here, the designs from the clothes, to the cars, to the buildings and advertisements were fantastic. I often found myself ogling Npc's on the street, jealous that they seemed to have access to clothes I didn't!

My biggest gripe here is how many pieces of the game fell flat. For instance, the romance; Like most rpg's that have romances, they feel hollow once you've completed the arc with the person you are chasing. On top of that, you are limited to one option per sexuality. I'm fine with them not being "player sexual" meaning they don't care what the pc is, but at least two different options per would have really felt a little better. There are several characters that absolutely should have been romanceable, and maybe were planned but ended up being scrapped? Hell, they flirt with you regardless, but if you return the favor they just shoot you down. Just felt strange at points. 

Character creation/customization seemed very basic and flat too. For a world with tons of cyberware....where the hell are they? Lots of great hairstyles....that you can never change once in game. Why include the mirrors everywhere if they are pointless? Why do I have to go into a shop to buy clothes, when everything else is vending machines, and why is it RNG based? My V spent many days in front of shops trying to get the gear I wanted.  You can't even get more tattoos [spoiler] and the ones you can get, take up a cyberware slot, which takes the fun right out if you are min/maxer at all. [/spoiler]

Also, all those fun buildings and neat places....well you can't get into what felt like most of them. There are plenty of hidden things to find and explore, but it felt like the game gave mixed signals. You'd see a place that looked full of secrets to be met with some impenetrable door, then later find a place the seems innocuous that has cool shit inside. I was never sure when I should take the time to explore. 

Vehicles were super fun to look at, but are horrendous to drive at first. I did get better at it, and figured out I did best on the motorcycles, but still...yikes. Seems like they are trying to tinker with it, and I'm sure it feels better with a controller setup, but I prefer m/k. 

The calling and text messaging system was both neat to me, but also felt a little lazy? On one hand, I loved that they would just randomly call or text, but the in person interactions were so well done it seemed a shame some of the convos weren't in person. However, some of the text chains were a real delight in the way they were written, so I'm very torn there. I also ran into a snag with a call not applying to the quest directive, and had to fix it via the console by forcing the call again. 

The crafting was interesting, and actually making things was gratifying. Being able to rummage materials from crappy items was nice too. What I didn't like, was that there were a very limited amount of designs, and the rarity couldn't be upgraded. Yet iconic items could? Then there is this entirely other upgrading system that uses WAY too many materials that it's barely worth the minuscule gains. I would have much rather they scrapped the shitty upgrade system, and give me a larger variety of crafting patterns that can be upgraded to better rarities, so when you find that jacket or shoes you like you don't have to scrap them for better gear that isn't visually what you want. 

Speaking of that, why wasn't the full body slot used more? For instance, why couldn't I just create an outfit in the mirror or something that uses that slot, and looks like what I want visually, but I can put the actual good gear in the clothing slots? Seemed wasted.

I found the busy quests enjoyable, even the random NCPD ones. If you take the time to actually read the shards and stuff, they are like mini stories that sometimes branched to other ones. I could see others finding them tedious, but I made sure to do every one of them -- sadly one bugged and I couldn't seem to fix it so I didn't get that achievement sadly. 

Ultimately, I feel like there should have been more ways to role play. I mean, it's a role playing game, why can't my V have more chrome, or a see through jacket? It really feels like these things were intended, but the whole game just got out of hand with the things they planned to put in. You could tell some real thought was put into things, like the subway, but just didn't make the cut. 

TL;DR:
Overall, I found lots to enjoy in Night City. I really love single player story driven rpgs, and it was those things. Games are going to have bugs here and there, and there will always be features that you wish were included. I think If you go in with realistic expectations, there is a very fun game here, with lots to do and explore, that it will be worth the ticket price for most gamers. I for one, will be trying a second go round at a higher difficulty, a new romance target and work towards one of the other endings!

====Updated for 1.6====
There have been some changes to the game since my initial review that have all been positive! The biggest being able to transmog your outfit, and crazily enough they pretty much did it exactly how I had described using the outfit slot!! They've also added more quests, more iconics and reworked the builds. The romance lines got some new text messages, and while they are cute, are still pretty hollow. The characters themselves are still very impressive which makes up for this. They added quite a bit more character customization but still no body cyberware options (thank goodness for mods.) You can also now change some of it at the ripperdocs. Otherwise, they have done quite a bit of bug fixing, driving adjustments and AI changes that did help overall. The last few playthroughs have been perfect with no issues for me. Overall I still recommend this game for folks who like story rpgs!

Blade Runner, Deus Ex, The Matrix and Cyberpunk Tabletop all inspired this game.
Each one has a theme it explores, a section of the human life that it taps into.

Blade Runner explores the soul, and what it means to have one. It asks us about our own souls, our own choices, and it uses the Cyberpunk genre and Aesthetics to highlight these questions and themes NOT to make you gawk.

Deus Ex shows us the effects that Augmentation will take on us. Not only could it create class and social divides but it could lead to the government having more and more ways to control the population, it could lead to us forgetting our own humanity.

The Matrix warns us of the dangers of Artificial Intelligence, and of the careful lines we must tow in our pursuit of technology if we wish to avoid creating our own coffin.

Cyberpunk 2077 tells us about: nothing. The game is about nothing. Yes it has a story, a very entertaining one with love-able characters and probably the best designed City in any Open World game so far. Each street of night city is sprawling with detail and story. But what is the purpose of this game? nothing. It could have explored things like self identity in a future age, if you can just buy a personality shard (an idea that lines up perfectly with this being a make your own character RPG) then where do you even start and end as a person? But instead it makes no comments, no observations or warnings. It does not risk that, it risks nothing. 

If you love the Cyberpunk Genre as I have my whole life, then you will love walking through the rain soaked neon lit streets of night city and observing and interacting with the gangs and people and stories that are in there. 
But if you are looking for another thought provoking piece of the genre it is named after then you will be dissapointed.

They can fix all the bugs, and add as many missions and updates as they want. But they cannot give the game a Vision.

7/10

Playing on PC, I did not encounter any serious bugs.  Various little things, but nothing a quick save and dip out to the main menu couldn't fix.  Bugs aside, I thoroughly enjoyed this game.  The writing and storytelling surrounding the main characters (the NPCs who have the most content and impact) was top notch, reminding me of games like Mass Effect 2.  The main quest was also engaging and it felt like each possible ending choice would result in something potentially very different.  Side quests offer a lot of variety and support multiple solutions/pathways, though over time some of the Fixer missions get a bit monotonous.  I played primarily for story but the combat was not bad either.  Plenty of different directions you can build your character, though once you get enough skill points the combat encounters tend to be fairly easy.  I felt I got my money's worth out of the game from enjoying the story and the character interactions.  For me the game is a solid 8/10 just based on the writing, but your personal preferences may vary.  I will definitely replay it at least once to try a totally different character build and different choices, and I can see myself coming back to it again a year or two down the road, similar to The Witcher 3, to remind myself of what I liked about it.

Despite its... rocky launch, personally, I'm having a blast with this game. It runs VERY smoothly, and I've only crashed like once in the 24 hours I've put in! If you love RPG's, open-world games and sci-fi this is a must-play. played through a number of characters, builds, the lot. I honestly cant say the story is necessarily good, at no point was I enthralled or even felt part of it. in fact, most characters are annoying. I also think the driving mechanics are pretty lame unless you get the one good car; the best car isnt even the most expensive one. the saving grace of this game is absolutely the gameplay. Ive rolled stealth, tanks, and another that was almost purely hacking. crafting is essential in my opinion, added just enough to the game to keep playing after youve already beat everything and only had the last mission left. I have faith in it though, I need more content, expansions, DLC, something. the 1.3 update brought the game into an actual playable state fixing a large number of bugs. after the second play through every mission just felt like a chore, theres really no incentive for exploring. at some point in the end the only action youll find is by mowing down pedestrians and fighting off the police until you die, which can be fun, but still not enough reason to stay. 

at this point I feel I got my money's worth but I also see no reason to return outside of going for steam achievements, which I have never cared about. for new comers: I strongly encourage you to read through the skills and think about which direction you wanna go before ever applying a single skill point anywhere. youll get enough to max out 3, within the classes youll have to determine your approach. anyone that says you cant stealth in this game doesnt know how to build a stealth class, Ive completed entire missions without firing a single shot. 

all in all its a good game, nothing close to the hype that went into it, but its good. the gameplay really is the saving grace here. for now, I will be uninstalling it and waiting until more serious DLC/expansions come out if ever. my goal was to have an assortment of builds for the occasion and Ive achieved that goal. is it worth the $60 I paid? maybe, but I would absolutely suggest waiting for it to go on sale. Its good enough to get a recommendation, bad enough that I can say you will get bored during your second play through, theres just no surprises and literally nothing to really explore in depth. big city with nowhere to go. it is pretty fun running/jumping around on rooftops and dismembering people with a sword though. blasting people with the shotgun is super rewarding, lobbing grenades on grenades can be entertaining, I just wish Johnny would shut up. some butt hurt 30yo thats been dead for 50 years or something, complaining about corpos and using this second wind of living for the soul purpose of "GeTtInG tHe BaNd BaCk ToGeThEr", come on, and having to deal with that crap over and over again because there is absolutely no end game other than the game ending. only replay value is in re-rolls.

For context I went into Cyberpunk 2077 totally blind. I didn't watch any of the trailers, I didn't know anything about the world, characters save Keanu Reeves was in a starring role (How could you escape it?). I still knew of the hype of course, and when it finally came time for release I decided to go for it, looked like fun. 

Honestly, as someone who LOVES Bethesda, I thought a few bugs would be manageable and that people were likely overblowing the bugs for clicks etc. Hand on heart, yes its horribly buggy, and yes it is incredibly noticeable and has an adverse effect on the game... but I have in my 100 hours NOT encountered a truly game breaking bug and I was playing from day one. Are the bugs bad? Yes. Do they destroy the game? Not even close. 

I am not a CDPR fanboy, I have not played the Witcher games (Sue me), but this game is excellent. If you can look past the lack of polish (and I mean I don't think this game has even seen a bug tester) then what awaits you is a fantastic world inhabited by some of the best characters I've seen in a recent RPG, I won't wax lyrical about them but they feel well built and fleshed out, surprisingly human even. The world building is top notch, and words like Choom, Eddies Gonk and Corpo somehow feel like things that people would honestly say whereas I find trying to insert slang in these types of games fall flat on their face. The gameplay is a lot of fun, the gun play feels great, and the melee is somehow the most fun I've had in the game (this speaks to me as I tend to despise melee and often try to avoid it). The story is probably one of the weakest areas of the game. I never felt truly engaged within the grander narrative, it felt somehow played out and slightly contrived, but the characters make it totally palatable. 

The strongest part of this game in my opinion is the main character, V. 
I have tried male and female V, and found the latter to fit better (IMO). V is one of those rare characters in a game where I felt truly interested in getting a good ending, and fell victim to the themes of the game, not being able to let go. Despite my initial fear of voice characters in RPGs and how they detract (yes I'm talking about Fallout 4) V manages to avoid that. The voice acting is not only incredible, but almost always feels like every take was perfect, never did I feel like there was a weird line or strange reading in over 100 hours. Furthermore despite having only 2-3 lines per interaction the voice acting is so compelling you tend to move on quickly and really personalise your V. Come for Keanu and stay for V honestly. 

The weakest part of the game by far, is the sheer laziness of the features, or the lack thereof. 
In a game all about modifying your body beyond recognition, you cannot change your hair. Let that sink in. My first V had a normal looking hairstyle and only once I was too far in (and now wanting to look different as the story had progressed) did I realise they... didn't have the option to change it? Baffling. 

The Driving is terrible, every car feels like its on a ice lake and cars themselves are mostly pointless. You get 1-3 special cars and there is never a reason to buy another one. Car customisation was also left on the cutting room floor. 
I have mentioned the bugs already, but I would be remiss if I didn't mention it again. This game is totally unfinished and it shows, cutscenes "Play out" and objects float, if you don't look at someone while in a car their mouth stops moving, things like this really detract from the game, but aren't enough to ruin it. 

I'll wrap up here as that is as brief as one can be about Cyberpunk 2077. I eagerly await further content (and for CDPR to finish the game...) as I think its a gem, a Gem dropped in shit for sure, but give it a proper cleanup and you've got something that is going to really sparkle. I highly recommend this game if you can look past the bugs and general lack of polish.

I suppose I was lucky to have the game run pretty great for me from day one. The bugs I experienced were actually manifesting AFTER the hotfix patches, but they seem to be gone as of now (16/03/2021).

Still, I completed almost all of the endings and I'm on my second playthrough on the max difficulty just to hook up with Panam. The female V voice actor is almost always spot on. She's brilliant. The male V voice seems good too, but I'm early into the game with my male V, so the verdict on that is still out.

When this game is at its best, it's a marvel to behold. When it's at its worst, you really hope they waited with the release for half a year. 

I saw the media campaign on it, and I thought to myself that the game journalists, if I may even call them that, suffer from the game journo disease. They play so many big open world games that they are basically bored with the genre as a whole, and even if the release was bug-free on day 1, they would lambast it just because it's not the second coming of gaming Christ.

For me, who skipped a LOT open world games, just because I have a life outside of gaming, this is a very solid proposal, and I enjoy my time in it very much.

Okay, after more than 100 hours into the game I think I can give an honest opinion now. 

Long and short of it is: I actually recommend this title, jank and all. 
A lot of crybabies whine about how broken the game is but frankly its in better shape than half of the AAA titles of the last decade even after years of patches and fixes. 
It absolutely has problems, name one game this complex and massive that doesn't. Frankly that is a very tall order. 
However if you can accept that there are strange bugs and glitches and frankly some flat out janky coding and design, you will find an extremely fun and engrossing game. 
I actually enjoy the story, and often I find myself just walking around admiring the world they built. I do wish it was more fleshed out and deeper detail because theres a lot to draw you in, but no game is really that expansive. 

Pro's: 
Expansive and lots of customization to get lost in, kindof like mass effect before they made it fit for children who couldn't get the customization systems. 
Genuinely interesting characters and story. I really like a lot of the characters and want to know more about them. 
Excellent soundtrack, but I would like more metal options myself lol. Doom ftw! 
Beutiful design and stunning visuals. 
varied combat to fit your taste

Cons: 
Customization can be cheesed real easy, as in I can become a lethal pistol sniper who is never spotted and take down late game enemies with ease at level ten. Really just needs more balancing as you are either OP beyond belief or get squashed like a bug, very little middle ground. 
I find that there is too little time with the awesome characters, like Jackie. I really wanted to play all the stuff that was in the opening montage as I felt this would have better served the world building and let the player really connect with characters that just get glossed over too quick and we would get some genuine time with Jackie who was done so well. That character reminds me of a homie I grew up with and I like him a lot. 
While the visuals are awesome, theres a looooot of polish and patching needed. bugs are very common and varied. 
varied combat makes it really hard to balance as you can find easy ways to cheese the game no matter what. A more focused gameplay style would have done more to focus the game overall rather than a grab bag. 

And my biggest complaint really is the patches they drop. When I first got the game I didn't really experience many bugs or errors, occasional tpose or fazed character and minor graphical errors here and there. 
With each successive patch my game gets less and less stable. Every time I see more and worse bugs and jank. Things that worked fine have gotten funky and the jank is getting very noticeable. 
I really hope the devs get to focus and just fix things rather than scramble to fix small bugs. I also wish they would work with modders to help improve the game, theres a lot of passionate and skilled people already putting out much needed quality of life and operational improvements but they often get wiped out by a hot fix or deliberately blocked. 

As an aside there are some excellent mods out there and I look forward to them getting even better. 

All in all I can actually recommend this for anyone who enjoys a good story and fun game.

Cyberpunk is a lovely mess of a game. For context, I preordered the game at full price prior to all of the delays and bad press. Despite all that I was rather excited to still play. The game is obviously buggy, and it should not be forgiven that the game was rushed out. But I experienced a minimal amount of bugs in my play-through. Now this game does a lot of good things, but very few great things. First, the soundtrack is amazing. It's not even the big names they had contribute that made the OST great. It's the smaller songs that played on the in-game radio. Absolute banger. Secondly the side stories. One of which is the story for Judy Alvarez. An amazing character with depth, and emotions. I found that the side stories were far more intriguing than the actual campaign story-line. Don't get me wrong, I loved the character development of Johnny Silverhand. But the immersion was broken while doing some quests. Over time you both form a bond. But some quests he's just an edgy butt-head to you for no reason. Other than that, combat felt meh. Melee seems very underpowered. The police are crazy and spawn everywhere and anywhere. My recommendation for this game, is to wait for all of the patches, and/or some DLC. I felt it was worth the full price, but to others probably not.

Wow. Quite some game. VERY mixed things to say here.



First, the Positive Stuff:
This game is awesome! I love the city, the people running around, the ambience. Unbeatable. Whoever made this city come to life: this is astoundingly awesome work!
The gameplay is surprising. First it feels a bit sturdy. Wait until you unlock a few leves in Athletics.
Hacking also seems weak and rather obstructive. Wait until you put some levels into Intelligence.
Most characters you encounter are really cool, stick to their agenda, no weird stupid-acting shit.
Driving your vehicles is also an awesome feeling. Bike handling could be better, sharp turns and braking is odd.
Lots of missions really capture you, make you play slowly, enjoy the stuff.



The Mixed Stuff:
It takes quite a while until you get to the interesting part of the campaign. Around 5-10 hours. Most of my friends quit before that, or it took them weeks to pick it up again. These first hours the game really feels a bit railroady and as if you didn't have much choices. BUT: you actually do. You can have about 15 hours of free play before you enter the campaign missions that get you from "Act 1" to "Act 2". Basically there are no real Acts, because it's only those 2 and the last few railroad-missions at the end of the campaign, "Act 3". In Act 1 you're limited to one of ~7 regions, in Act 2 you can access them all, and Act 3 railoads you through the final missions. Afterwards ("Act 4") is after-campaign-freeplay, just like Act 2.
But after those 5-10 initial hours, the game and campaign become GREAT. Made me play 120 hours in 2 weeks.
Gunplay also gets more interesting with level, blades also. Balancing of difficulty levels is a bit strange.

The Bad Stuff:
First thing that hit me: the menus, inventory etc is QUITE a pain in the ass. It is hindering in so many occasions.
First off, exactly those keybindings that are needed most (access inventory, skills) do not exist, while others are plentiful.
When you scroll halfway down lists and then remove/sell/scrap items, the list rows start jumping, so you cannot click quickly but have to check before each click. Funniest thing: lines do no jump when on line is emptied, but when only one item is left in that line.

Furthermore, item sorting does not really work. In most cases, sorting is simply ignored. Sorting categories are missing. Sorting is mostly NOT saved, so you have to set those filters each time you access your inventory. BUT: sorting of trader inventories is saved. The thing you need least, it works. Still, also here some sorting categories are simply ignored.
Worst of all is that the game tends(tended) to sort items by DPS. Damage per Second. The least interesting stat. "Why least interesting?" you might ask. Because DPS calculations are entirely wrong. Crits and DoT effects are (literally) a 1000 times more meaningful.

Almost the worst "feature" of the inventory is that you cannot lock unique/favorite items. With one of the later patches (1.12 maybe) the game at least asks you if you are sure you wanna sell items you have currently equipped. Other than that, it is highly likely you will sell/scrap a few meaningful guns in the game. In a game where there's only a few items that are really interesting...
In addition to that, the UI makes it quite hard to quickly deconstruct/sell unwanted items, even though after the campaign you will have done that 5000-10000 times...

The crafting/upgrading feature is also a disaster. Each time you upgrade an item, it takes more and more resources. Up to ridiculous numbers. You CANNOT change the painting on weapons. When you want to craft epic armor, you're also fucked. Those few items you can craft at max rank all look quite shite. You cannot set any cosmetics. Event tho you're level 20 master crafter. Worst feature here is: there are certain items you can craft (as often as you like, only limited by your resources), but those items count as quest items, so you cannot remove the from your inventory. Plus they have weight, eventually and ultimately slowing you down.

WORST "feature" I've seen in a video game in the last 15 years: how the game handles mods. The inventory indicates that mods stack. Especially on clothes you get crazy numbers. Displayed. BUT: most clothing mods actually (those with %) do NOT stack (note: most mods with absolute numbers DO stack). Having more than one of those mods on ANY worn piece of gear is a waste. . So even if you had the same mod installed 15 times, only one would count. 
Now the worst part: if you remove a piece of armor with a certain mod, your mod bonus drops to 0, as if you had NO mods of that type equipped. You have to de-/ and re-equip at least one of those mods to get the bonus again.

Another bad feature is for example your email/messaging UI. Whatever you do on the right side (conversations), the left side (contacts/messages overview) will rarely get updated. So if there's a 'reply' tag on the message, you click that message, and reply, the 'reply' tag will not go away, until you exit the messaging UI and re-open it.
Sometimes when clicking through attachments etc the view will get stuck/broken, displaying the wrong items, not changing categories. Close and re-open inventory to fix it.

Another shit "feature" is an old remnant from the Witcher games. The more items you have in you inventory, the slower it gets. Like REALLY slow. Same stupid programmer that already fucked up the Witcher inventories with his mindless stupidity. I don't know what is wrong with people like those. And in 5 years, it has not gotten better. Why?

Another bad thing: looting gets really boring. There's like a million object in the game that you can loot, but they're quite worthless. Same with exploring. You can find a lot of cool stuff while exploring. In obvious places. But a LOTS of cool items can only be reached by exploiting severe bugs, and in location you could never imagine. So there's a bit of exploration that is fun, and the rest you have to follow YT videos. Not as fun as Skyrim, where there were lots of not-so-obvious but realistic locations you could find (without exploiting).

And one thing that also pissed me off: after finishing the campaign, there's no chance of deactivating the mission marker for the final (campaign) mission, even tho you completed it (even all endings)... So that marker always hangs around, whatever you do.

And finally, the saddest fact: once you completed all side missions and alerts, there's hardly anything left to shoot at. Some enemies respawn almost immediately (go away 50-100 meters, come back, they're there again), while in the more interesting locations enemies will not respawn until 24-48 hours later in game... So in the end (after ~100 hours) there's NOTHING left to be done.



Conclusion:
So we see that gameplay and worldbuilding and most of the storytelling were done by amazing people. 
And then there was the team that made the inventory and equipment logic...
I don't know what's going on at CDPR, but it's time they kicked out a few guys head over heels. Even just to make space and stop the idiots bother the geniuses.

Cyberpunk desperately needs some updates. A lot of is shortcomings are very easy to fix. Hope that the DLCs bring some lasting fun. The game could earn that easily. But looking at some of the devs, I got serious doubts that it actually will happen.

Was Cyberpunk 2077 overhyped, overpromised and underdelivered? Yes. It's still an incredible, beautiful, compelling RPG if you just calm the fuck down and enjoy it for what it is? Also yes. Cyberpunk has many flaws but it still feels like a labor of love with tons of detail, great voice acting, incredible lighting & graphics, with an enjoyable story to keep you wanting to see where it goes. 

I feel for everyone that hyped themselves up over the last 8 years, really - marketing did this game no favors because they clearly couldn't speak for the dev team that knew this game needed another year in the oven to be finished, and were tasked with building up a bunch fantastic systems the game could not hope to deliver. It's almost a perfect portrayal of the theme of corporate greed shown within the game. I do not however feel like I got less than I paid for and I'm hopeful CDPR will improve on what they've got here.

If you liked Fallout: New Vegas with all it's jank at release, and you have some serious hardware to turn up all the graphics (it sucks at the low end, no joke) you should find plenty to like in Cyberpunk 2077. Otherwise just wait for a sale with all the (inevitable) DLC at a fat discount.

I deleted my original negative review because I wanted to give the devs more time to work out some of the bugs that had annoyed me during my first play through attempt last year. I had been waiting for a sign that the time was right to try again, the release of Edgerunners seems to have been that sign.

All of the bugs that had been so frustrating for me have been resolved for the most part. Occasionally something wonky happens but it can usually be fixed by either saving and reloading or saving and restarting the game. It's not super common and compared to the annoyance of trying to play something as buggy as a heavily modded New Vegas...well, patience can be learned.

My biggest takeaway from this play through is that V might be my favorite protagonist since Shephard in the Mass Effect trilogy. Same goes for the other characters. I liked the story before, liked the characters, but without some of the bugs to distract me and having a better idea of how to play the game, plus the impact of Edgerunners, this game has well and truly surpassed my expectations.

After Fallout 4's voiced protagonist I was a little skeptical another first person RPG with a similar story. I wanted to play my character, not someone else's version of my character. Thing is, this is V's story; I'm along for the ride like Johnny (albeit with more control over how things play out). I don't feel like I'm V, I feel like I'm going through their story with them. It really hits a lot harder than it did before, and I'm the sappy goofball who got a bit weepy when a certain character died near the start of the game the first time. Been even more impactful this time.

The person who recommended it to me said this is the next Skyrim, in the sense that you can play it endlessly and it's mod friendly. If anything he's undersold it because the story is much better than anything put out by Bethesda. What happened at launch was tragic, but the devs have gone beyond redemption with this. Yeah, preorders are still a bad idea, yeah, corporate shenanigans led to the game being pushed out before it was ready and there are no doubt countless lessons to learn from this game's development.

But the biggest one is that sometimes people deserve to have their faith rewarded. The faith the players had that the game would be amazing and worth their time. The faith the devs had their audience would "get" what they were trying to do here and would grow to love this game.

I highly recommend this game.

I have a decent rig but not a NASA level pc, i7-8700 and an RTX2070 but I'm sure this game runs less favorably with a lesser rig as it is a 2021 game with some decent technology.

Reviews in general don't always tell the story. I do read them and write a few on products in general including games but I find some people complain regardless. I would have missed out on some good products over the years if I strictly went by reviews. Tastes are different and so are mindsets and temperaments.

That said I noticed a campaign of sorts by those who hate this game to actually bring the overall rating of this game down. Yes some in the forums have been pushing for bad reviews. Enjoy the game and if it's not for you move on, or vent and move on. But don't bust on other people who like the game just because you don't like the game. When you do that I can't take your original opinion with any degree of seriousness.

Edit: 1 more thing. The are countless "Let's Play" videos or quest walkthroughs and how to videos on the web. You'll see that the game runs just fine. And I am enjoying this game. Btw, it is an action Adventure with some RPG elements.

2nd update: So 190 hrs in and I have to say this game is fun and has been running very well for me. No freezes, no crashes, no issues completing missing, no issues with achievements (if that's your thing) although I'm not really an achievement hunter. The game looks amazing.

The game might not be equal to all the hype but not many if any could hurdle the bar that was set for this game. Make no mistake it's a good game if Action Adventure games with some RPG elements are your thing. I give it a 7 1/2 out of 10 on PC but on console forget it from what I've seen and heard. More patches coming for both. Enjoy, I know I am.

3rd Update. Finished the game on two different endings and I have to say there is much I really like about this game. Really took my time exploring this game plus I focused heavy on crafting and that can be time consuming if you let it be which I did. 

Fortunately when you get to the point of no return the game auto pauses and let's you know while also autosaving at that point then will throw you back there after you beat the game if you say yes to that option which I did. 

I love the Crafting, the weapons, the gameplay fighting mechanics, and of course the story. You can really get attached to some of the characters.

As far as glitches go nothing really stopped me from completing the game and although I am not an Achievement hunter I don't feel like I was glitched out of any except maybe one but I can't say for sure as in the beginning before I really had a grasp for the game I messed up a side job and that job cost me 1 achievement.

This game is worth buying, but if you have a potato for a computer I would hold off until more patches come out and then make sure you meet the min requirements of course. Oh, I am also now modding a second character (playthru) with Nexus mods and they have many many mods already including a couple of game fix mods but I did not use mods on my first playthru.

I'm revising my overall score on this game of which I am so glad I played to an 8 although I'm tempted to go 8 1/2. I'll be playing more characters as time goes on.

What it's not: It's not perfection. If you expect that, and if you're gonna nitpick everything, this game is horrible for you. You'll hate the never-constructed train system, the cars that bug out, the naked T on the bike, enemies appearing out of nowhere behind you, etc.

What it is: Gorgeous, rich story and characters that make you care. I'm getting old, I already expect a lot from games, and I expect them to be fun out of the box without a lot of input from me. But this game actually delivered that. It was fun from the very start.
