As you may have guessed by my play time, I like this game... a lot.  Cyberpunk 2077 is, by far, one of my new favorite games of all times.  The world-building, storytelling, characters, and expansive lore to be found exploring Night City are some of the best I've ever seen in a video game, and I simply cannot get enough, even on a third playthrough.

You may have heard that Cyberpunk has bugs, dumb enemy AI, and technical issues.  These issues do exist, and Cyberpunk was released sooner than it should have been, making it truly a flawed gem in my eyes.  However, a gem is still a gem, and despite all of these problems being present, the core of this game is a treasure, especially if you are a fan of the Cyberpunk genre.

If bugs and technical issues can make or break a game for you, then I would suggest waiting a while and giving Cyberpunk a shot when it's in a more polished state.  But if some jank and occasionally hilarious glitches haven't ruined the core experience of a game for you before, then I can't recommend Cyberpunk 2077 enough, and I'm starving to see more of this franchise in the future.

Edit:  Still love it.  No regrets.

An absolutely phenomenal experience. When I first played this game I went in to it not being hyped out of my mind, but being hyped, and I left being certain I just played one of the best games I had ever played. This game does atmosphere better than any other game. There's so many different situations you can be in, from a sunny beach house, a dimly lit hotel room, a parade and everything feels so good and like you are actually there. The voice acting in this game is probably the best I have ever heard, the story is so, so incredible. The story had me laughing, crying, celebrating, yelling, it's one hell of a ride which is complimented by the games characters. The characters are so well fleshed out and all feel like real people that you truly do care about and want to be around. A big part of that is the games facial and body animations on characters during dialogue is the best I have ever seen. Even Night City is probably the best looking open world/city I have ever seen in a game. I haven't seen a game capture the density of a real city as much as this game has. The music as well, the music is one of the best parts of the entire game, the games score is incredible and the original songs played over the radio capture the feeling of Night City perfectly and are also just great songs to listen to when not playing the game.  

The gameplay in Cyberpunk 2077 is also incredibly fun with the variety of ways you can go about it. Sniping from a distance, close quarters with smgs and pistols, melee weapons, hacking, stealth, guns blazing, not using weapons at all, being non-lethal, being overly lethal, it's all there and it's all great. On the topic of gameplay, this game does decision making through gameplay that I believe a lot of plays miss out on and it's done so well. During quests when tasked with taking out an NPC, even though the game doesn't tell you this at all, you can chose to kill them or just knock the out, and the quests dialogue will change depending on what you do, you can chose to do some steps of quests out of order and the quest NPCs will respond according, you can chose to kill NPCs involved in quests even if the game never asks you to and there will be dialogue about it later in the quest. I absolutely love how not ALL decisions in this game are through dialogue options and not ALL decisions are just put right up in your face like "do this OR this! Make your decision right now!"

And of course, I'm not going to pretend the game is bug free, it's not, but it's not nearly as bad as some people were making it out to be. I played this game from release day until I had 100%'d the game twice in a row. Another game I had played on release day was Fallout: New Vegas and that game was WAY more buggy than Cyberpunk has ever been at any state post-release. Fallout: New Vegas is still the only game I had to put down and come back to at a later date because it was so buggy I could not enjoy it. Now fast forward to today and look at how Fallout: New Vegas is looked at, people treat it like it's one of the greatest games that has ever graced us. Obviously that is because (even though people don't want to admit it) people had hyped Cyberpunk 2077 WAY beyond what CD Projekt RED did and thought the game was going to come out and be twice as big and 10 times as good as anything anyone had ever played before, which was never going to happen, obviously. I see people constantly saying "CD Projekt RED did this to themselves by hyping it up way too much". CDPR didn't hyped this game up that much more than any developer hypes their own game up, they just went along with the overhype the fans did to themselves, because as a developer, why wouldn't you. The amount of times I have seen someone say that "CDPR hyped it up too much by promising............" and then immediately saying something that CDPR had never promised and was something the fans themselves had made up was going to be in the game is insane.

But, all in all, as someone who plays A LOT of singleplayer games and doesn't take games being in my top of all time lightly. Cyberpunk 2077 has EASILY shot itself into my top 5 games, possibly top 3 I have ever played. It was, in my opinion, the best game to come out in 2020 no contest. The game IS buggy, but no more buggy than your average Bethesda game, with the developers actively fixing it and bettering it. I truly believe that once CDPR has the game in a state they are proud of this game will be remembered as one of the best ever released. I truly, truly, sincerely, pity anybody who has bought into the YouTuber circlejerk of hating on this game because it gets them viewers and is going to miss out on this game, because it is one that should not be missed.

Great Game Overall.

- The game is worth it for it's main story line.
- Voice acting performance was great.
- Side quests were good but varied from detailed and story enhancing, to simple stat boosting quests that became repetitive after doing the same thing over an over.
- Combat and gunplay was very simple, though the sneaking combat option did add variety to gameplay.
- The game's potential and what Cyberpunk could actually have been is noticeable within the game with many "locked" doors, story branches that seem to have been cut, and possibly a whole train system missing.
- Bugs occur sometimes but only became very noticeable when I was later in the game.

All in all a great game. Buy this to experience the story and atmosphere. Game has a lot of potential. I suggest to wait fro a few more patch notes If you care about the game being fully optimized and polished.

And the great times I've had slaying, lying, and sleuthing my way through its charming sci-fi world got me wondering why it took so long for this sort of game to catch on. There are still a few technical hitches to be worked out, just like the fussy engines on the Skeld, but that hasn't kept me from coming back to it again and again in my down time.

After doing pretty much everything in the game and as someone who wasn't apart of the hype for this game and didn't think this game would be the savior of the gaming industry, it's a pretty good game to just sit back and chill with.

Story: Pretty well written, just wish it was longer. The Silverhand scenes are some of the most BA scenes in a game. 7.5/10

Weapons: Mantis blades and revolvers are super fun to use. 8/10

Crafting: Make sure you hold onto some iconic weapons, as you can craft them into some insanely OP weapons late game. Other than that I don't think I ever crafted anything else and crafting seems mostly useless. 5/10

Vehicles: Don't even bother with cars the driving is awful, just use motorcycles or fast travel 3/10

Music: Fits the game well and does add a lot to it. 9/10

Bugs: As of 1.12 there are still a ton of bugs, however most of them are pretty funny and non game breaking. The bug where you randomly drop dead for no reason is annoying, and then when the game crashes is also annoying because it will take steam 30 years to realize the game has crashed and is no longer running. 5/10

Perks/ Upgrades: With a game that has this many perks and upgrades, why can't I max out my character and be able to unlock all perks? Most of them are pretty useless, but with a Lvl cap of 50 you can only get about 25-30% of perks I'd say. 3/10

Keanu Reeves: It's Keanu Reeves. 100/10

Side Quests: Some of the side quests can feel a bit grindy, but as a whole I definitely recommend doing the side missions and not just sticking to the story only, as they add quite a lot to the experience. 7/10

Overall I'd rate this game a solid 7/10 if you don't take it too seriously. If you were apart of the hype and were expecting the savior of the gaming industry then I wouldn't recommend this game for you.

This game is incredible, truly a masterpiece. Every detail of the game pulls you into its dystopic atmosphere. You can do anything be anything and only you can make your dreams come true.

I've played a lot of games that made you feel like nothing in a world that doesn't care whether you exist. Cyberpunk is all about that. It's not like some other games where you kill one boss and everybody likes you/ fears you. You start as nothing, your entire goal is to make a dent, make your own legacy.

The story is extremely heavy handed and it doesn't go out of its way to be nice to you. It tells you the stakes pretty early on and makes it clear what you're supposed to do about it.

Back to the atmosphere. Yes the world is gritty, dirty, depressing and bleeding with satire. Every block, every store front, every vending machine, just pulls you into a living world that really doesn't give a living howdy-do about you and that's great cause you get to be a complete jerk and feel justified doing it.

The conversations are in depth and its obvious mo-cap was used. Characters move, sit down, get up, wave their arms around. One conversation, you're sitting at a food stand with some meatballs sitting in front of you. You can choose to respond to the conversation, or simply take another bite of your food, then answer. The game makes it quite clear that your answers carry weight, and more often then not, those answers are completely ambiguous. 

I can't overstate this, you are not the good guy. You are not the savior of Night City. Then again, you aren't the bad guy either. Things such as law and morals are completely up to you. Even the cops are on the payroll. Heck, even you are on the payroll.

Combat is visceral, violent, and smooth as stainless steel. Your punches carry weight, your katana is quick and lethal, your sniper rifle is accurate and your assault rifle feels just as good as any(pick your favorite) fps should. I recommend a controller for driving, because the physics are there but are more akin to GTA or NFS. And you can buy cars with all the money you got from wiping out gang members or cops or whatever suits you. 

Cyberpunk makes no apologies about what it is. This is not a happy world, you are not a knight in shining armor. This is edgy, graphic, violent and unapologetic. Oh and Keanu.

While I was playing cyberpunk, I could not avoid the feeling that everything around is like some kind of puppet theatre play, while his poster tries to convince us that everything around is realistic. This feeling will follow you always and everywhere, except prologue and epilogue. Unfortunately, the open world of cyberpunk lacks a sense of believability, logic, common sense and predictable response. Night City is like trying to be alive, but still have not enough forces for it. Strange physics and ballistics in this sense, pushes the desire to explore the world and go deeper inside this beautiful city. It is also a very weak/poor RPG component, without deep relationships with the outside world and without reaction to your different actions, without variety of bosses.

The review will be RED, because I want to make it clear to all of you, and most importantly to game developers, that the open world should not be like this. I hope you agree with me a lot. But still, the game has many positive aspects such as music, plot, elaboration of the main characters and, of course, future design and architecture of cyberpunk city, about the city, we can still see how much work has been done in this direction.

Personally, I LOVE this game. Though I am glad i got it on PC rather than console. It's still buggy in places, but what can you really expect from a game that was released seriously early due to irate fans unable to be patient and wait for a properly finished version. They've made some patches which have fixed a lot of the major issues. But I find the story compelling, many of the characters well portrayed, and the world very solidly built. Plenty of fun little things to find and do, choices that do make a difference to how certain things play out. It's no Fable or Mass Effect in that regard (they made your decisions have real weight behind them even before the final missions) but it does a decent job of making you think about what you're going to do. Many choices are fairly inconsequential, only changing rewards or narrative from news stations based on who you chose to save or wipe out. But the gunplay is excellent. The options for character build are pretty good as well. Overall, tons of fun to play and I can't wait for some DLC releases once they get the main game properly polished.

175 hours in, no crashes or quest breaking bugs.  This shares a lot in common with the Witcher 3 in terms of mechanics and gameplay systems.  The story has been fantastic so far, the side quests very enjoyable too.  I've ended up feeling attached to the characters I've met, much like in the Witcher.  I did like Geralt as a protagonist but I'm happy CDPR let us create our own character this time.  I find the first person gameplay to be a strength here rather than a weakness, CDPR nailed the gunplay, it's more enjoyable to me than the 3rd person sword play of the Witcher series.  Overall I'm very happy with the game and I look forward to seeing what will come in the future through patches, DLCs and modding.  Night City is an amazing creation and milestone for PC gaming, it will only get better with time.

All the shit talk about this game,, some is understandable. This is a very good game, released a few years too early but you are doing nothing but lying if you say you've never blown your load too quick. It left me wishing rockstar made it though, honest opinion.

If you can get past the game's numerous technical issues, I would argue it's best-in class as a Western RPG (Skyrim, The Witcher, Fallout, etc) and as an open-world sandbox, (GTA, Yakuza, etc.).

So much love and thought has been put into the content in this game. There's an immense amount of worldbuilding and detail put into every level.

Your character build will DRASTICALLY change how the game plays out for you, and for the people interested in the RP parts of an RPG, you have options far beyond [yes], [yes], [sarcastic yes] and [no], some even dependent on your initial life path choice or, again, your character's build.

I could go on and on about how each aspect I think of (the music, ambience, visual design, clarity, culture/worldbuilding, etc.) being great in their own respect, but I think it speaks more that they come together as a full product.

tl;dr - Give it a try if
 - you have beefy hardware / easy access to a game streaming service (e.g. GeForce Now)
 - You can look past numerous bugs/technical issues
 - TES / Fallout games feel like missed opportunities

Yes, this game has some issues. The driving has no features and pursuits are nonexistent, glitches happen, frame rate suffers sometimes unless you have a decent computer. But I absolutely love this game. It is still a technological miracle. When I started playing, I literally could not stop because I felt like a kid playing video games for the first time again. The story and characters, very very well written and CDPR definitely understands what makes good science fiction. The premise seem pretty realistic for what the future will be like, and the stories and characters actually made me FEEL things. When I finished the main questline for the first time I couldnt think about anything else for the next few days. Truly memorable.

 I'm the type of person who loves to grind side content, and doing these missions and dicing people with a katana or ripping them apart with a shotgun (which im now doing on my second playthrough, 114 hours total) never got old for me. I didn't even touch the other skill trees involving hacking and stealth, and people who play that way seem to really like it as well. Earned "eurodollars" actually have a purpose in the game and earning money is incredibly satisfying. This is the type of game you can leave the main story, descend into night city for 60 hours and become a god-level badass before mission 2, and I really really appreciate that. 

Finally, the atmosphere and music. Even if you're not a huge hard rock or electronic fan, the combat music just fucking slaps. Fighting a base of enemies by yourself with that music seriously gives me serotonin. The setting is simply magical. It can be beautiful, gritty, weird, or all at the same time. And people, I know most of you dont care about this but the graphics are fantastic. Literally ive wasted so much time in photo mode dressing my character up in all these dope outfits and cool poses next to my nice ass cars. In summary, the game is not perfect. But for me personally, it's my favorite type of game made on a massive scale with incredible attention to detail (the vast majority of the time). Thank you for reading.

The game overall is excellent.  Its like walking around in a mix of the world of Blade Runner and Fifth Element.  Only much ruder and hyper-sexualized.  While I played in the early going the game was glitchy.  Seems especially weird with sound on my setup but I think that may be partially on my end with the way I have my audio running via ARC on an HDMI cable going into my AV receiver from a gaming laptop.  Should be noted that I am running this on PC and so have no opinion on how its going on consoles.  Otherwise, the game is very solid with 99% of the mechanics for me.  Driving takes a bit of getting used to and is fairly sensitive.  I found bikes to be easiest to deal with and the one that looks like the one from Akira is cool.  I guess it should also be noted that I'm a simple fella and prefer a controller over keyboard and mouse.  Its just way more natural for me and at this point I'm not likely to change.  So I have been playing this using the xbox elite controller wired to my gaming laptop.  Since all the xbox controllers in my life have decided they like to randomly disconnect a lot now.  That's at least three different controllers on a console and a laptop all losing BT connection repeatedly.  Straying from the point here.  Great game that is gorgeous and fun to play for hours without need of multi player.  Story has been engrossing too, so I have slow played it and burned through most of the side quests before fully finishing the main storyline.  Set it down for a couple of weeks but am back again for more.  You'll get your money's worth out of this one.

This game... for all its flaws, is pretty good. Can't stop playing it. So much social-economic-political commentary all wrapped around a dark slightly-noir cyberpunk world. Where murder, suicide, and manslaughter are the norm (let alone the mistreatment of ALL workers not just the sex workers, although they definitely get shafted far more often). With rampant capitalism in every aspect of society and constant destruction of the earth that has become so common place that nobody talks about it anymore. The two moments in the game where you are encouraged to take the message of change seriously are quickly unraveled. If your attempts at a change aren't straight up undermined or twisted in on itself by a selfish ally, then you're being trolled by someone who wants to make you believe otherwise. That leads me to my other thoughts on this game. It's beyond pessismistic and cynical. With everything in the game. To the point where... I wouldn't call it necessarily punk unless you choose a specific ending (those punksters out there will know it when they see it). The "Punk" in this game is the decisions within the game that you make. Those who choose not to slaughter every person they come across will probably know that.

Finally let's talk about the elephant in the room, the reason why this game isn't going to be Game of the Year 2020 or something like that bs. Because of its release in such a horrible state for all platforms (consoles especially). This is relevant because it's ironic. The game itself wants you to hate Corpos and that worlds captialism in general (which I personally do despise) yet... The corpos who made this game did a lot of the same shit this game claims to be evil. Exploited their workers dedication through practices like crunch only to release this game long before it should have been released. Not to mention the fact that, unlike the game, there are instances of sexual harassment within the real life Corps (Though the Evelyn story line can show the outcome of that). Although I'm sure they're there in game, they are either not the main focus (background noise of the npcs complaining about something to make it seem more real) or just isn't there. 

In conclusion the story of this game is subversion incarnate. Not just in the game but in the production leading up to its making, it's delays, it's failed promises, and even actual release. Cyberpunk 2077 in it's entirety is an example of Capital's greed both in universe and in production. That is what makes this game an accidental masterpiece to me. IF CDPRJKT Red just treated their workers well, hell if the workers just had a union or some kind of bargaining power, and if this game took it's development time instead of listening to the impatient masses who were going to complain regardless. It would have been beyond masterful. IT would have been legendary.

And I think that's the real tragedy of this game. It's AAA game, just like any other. Sure story is great, combat's fun, characters are lively and entertaining, setting is awesome though dark, premise is fascinating, and it sometimes feels very natural. Like I am that character. But... seen these things a million times. Bethesda, Bioware, hell even the Witcher 3 (which I haven't personally played but heard "good" things about). And considering it's development cycle... it couldn't have turned out any more bog standard, despite it's accident of enhancing the view of capitalism's faults in it's many stories. 

Tl:dr Buy this game... for sale. It's a masterpiece only in how it's design and story relates to it's production hell and terrible real life Corpos. Much like The Room. If it weren't for that symmetry it's just a pretty solid "AAA" video game to play when you're bored. Like Mass Effect or Skyrim or Witcher 3 or Fallout 4 were before it. Bugs, weird story decisions, sexual harassment, and worker exploitation through practices like crunch in all. First review so... Let's call it 7/10? Idk.

If you watched and read all the hype before this game was released, you will be disappointed. 
If, like me, you just saw CDPR were making a game that looked to be The Witcher 3 meets Deus Ex meets GTA V and just play it with that expectation, its pretty damn good.

Turn up the Graphics and go do the side quests where the real story gold is.

Cyberpunk 2077 - A hidden gem game.

After finishing all the endings completely in my first play-through, I can safely say that the game is phenomenal. I have never felt genuinely connected to a game that I can relate to since Dragon Age: Origins. Yes, there are still some bugs and other technical issues that needs to be fixed over time (despite the many patches they had), but the content in the game is a pure masterpiece. 

The characters, the story, and the music are the three aspects that makes Cyberpunk 2077 shines. Game-play and Graphics are overall good but pales in comparison to both the Witcher 3 and Red Dead Redemption 2. 

Bugs in games are fairly common in the gaming industry. It was expected. So, I am fine with the technical issues in this game. My one and only biggest disappointment that I have for this game, however, is the lack of content as an 'Open World' genre. As a game explorer, I considered this as 'the worst' open world that I ever played. There is nothing to do except completing every main and side quests, gigs, and chasing down NCPD Hustle quests. Life-path seems redundant and an illusion as it does not provide any major changes, except with a few extra dialogues, to your in-game. There is no 'catching-up' with your NPC characters (romance or not) after you finish their quests, except repetitive dialogues (Thankfully, there is Judy's text messages after her romance, at least.) that you can grew bore over time (I will have to apply the mods to add the immersion in it, instead) . 

Hence, I am feeling that this game is more like a 'semi-linear' genre rather than an 'open world' genre. If CD Project Red wants to create a better open world, they should follow other games' examples like Red Dead Redemption 2 and make a better comeback to this game towards its greatness.  

Am I still replaying Cyberpunk 2077? 

Hell, yeah. Because this game has the best NPC characters (Judy and Panam), music and story missions that I ever encountered in my gaming years. Also, we have the modding community to thank who are actually fixing and adding customization to the game more than the developers did which thus, making the game to what it is meant to be. Because of the modding community, I am able to have fun adding stuffs like hanging out with the characters (simping for Judy & Panam), taking amazing screenshots, and many more. 

After many patch updates, is it still worth buying Cyberpunk 2077? 

My answer: 

Although that I love this game a lot (it is my current No.1 favorite game), and yes, I believe that I am one of the minority group that favors Cyberpunk 2077 more, but I highly recommend to buy it once the game is fully repaired which includes DLC expansions and bug fixes, and purchase it on sales, in order to achieve a full gaming experience. In its current state, I reckon this game requires at least 3 to 5 years or more in order to fix the game and most importantly, having CD Project Red to regain its trust from the people they lost. I may be late for the hype train before it's pre-launch previously, however, I completely understand the hate and mistrust for this game due to the manipulation via marketing tools that the developers had toward their people. Hopefully, this will be a lesson to everyone for both customers and the developers from this and improve better in the future. :)

Let's be real, the game is buggy. But when you put aside the bugs, the game, graphics, and story line itself are beautiful. I honestly haven't seen many bugs in the game other than some missing assets and floating characters. CDPR is still actively working on fixing these bugs on top of hundreds of others and its clear that they are no where close to stopping their support and bug fixes in this game. I didn't think I would really like this game other than the graphics, but the more I played, the more I fell in love with this game. 

When I first played this game, my father was admitted into the hospital. I played Cyberpunk to try to distract from everything that was happening. It's sad to say that a month later my dad never came home. That being said, if I hadn't played Cyberpunk, I would be struggling a lot more. My first run through of the game allowed me to work through some very personal and tough decisions, both in the game, and in my own life. This game has a lot of tough decisions you have to choose and will possibly impact how you interact in the real world.

In short, should you buy it now? If you don't mind a few bugs, go ahead. But if you want a 'complete game' with little to no bugs, come back in a few months. The game is beautiful and bugs shouldn't define the quality of the game.

The second you go off and try to explore the city without a quest guiding you it becomes painfully obvious the game was nowhere near completion. Whole sections of the city that are unused, broken AI, snore-worthy combat, hacking, apparently, but it's boring, vast, brutalist architectural wastelands scream of unused potential and scrapped ideas. The city is a ghost town, the desert is lifeless, the ghost towns are somehow just that, uninteresting ghost towns. The game is nothing but lifeless NPCs staring at you with their dead little eyes screaming their pre-programmed voice  lines at you before they de-spawn into the eternal void forever the second you turn your back to them. Meanwhile you click your mouse to fire the hilariously overpowered gun you found because the game has 0 balance in regards to combat, and an excessive skill tree that feels like it does next to nothing outside of extremely specific situations. 

It's obvious the project managers weren't doing much project managing on this game. Over-hype ballooned expectations out of control, the devs crammed every last idea they had in there from nipple physics to hilariously terrible dialogue from an A list celebrity to try and live up to the hype. Like loading a wooden bridge with trucks filled with concrete... It's going to collapse at some point. 

Despite this, I still bought the game because it couldn't be that bad, right? And it wasn't... But it also wasn't good. It's just a solid "meh." Toward the middle of the second act I got so bored that i uninstalled it. Nothing there was keeping my interest. I could ramble on, but I'm getting to the part of this review where, just like Cyberunk 2077, anything past the main points would turn this into incoherent rambling attempts at trying to reach an audience.

A few Patch's later and it's totally playable.

I've tried out several builds and by far the charge in solo, either melee/weapons or close range weapon is the most fun. Hacking mini game is a bit underwhelming. The Quickhacking in combat is kinda fun, having your enemies go blind, weapons glitch and their cybermods all fail as you charge in is pretty cool.

I Definitely Recommend for PC. Cant wait for all the free dlc then hopefully they still add a bunch of expansion/dlc too the game.
On the PC this game is very nice, while it lacks all that was touted in the promo it's a very enjoyable playthrough. I'm hoping DLC's and patches will make it even better.

There are a lot of reviews for this game but I still thought that I'd give my own personal opinion and boy do I have a lot to say about this game.

CP2077 has a great core. I was really intrigued once the first trailer came out and I was very excited for it to be released. The first person perspective is unique and I as many others hoped for a revolutionary open world RPG. So let me start with giving the game some praise. 

I'd lie if I said that there weren't at LEAST a couple of good things about this game. The music, the city, the characters, are all very well crafted and they only really clicked together since they were made BEFORE CDPR decided to throw it all in the dump and start from scratch. 

The city is well thought out and feels hand-crafted instead of just a couple of messily bunched together tile sets and it's absolutely beautiful. However, it's probably just about the only compliment that I can give this game without feeling like I'm ignoring some kind of negative in this mess of a game. However, while it might be gorgeous to look at, the city is quite void of things to do. It might look jam-packed with content from a distance but when it actually comes down to exploring the city, it feels kind of dead despite bustling with neon lights, civilians, traffic etc, etc. With no activities like minigames and such, it's quite boring. The tall skyscrapers connected by a series of tunnels and bridges feel like they only serve as a tease of what we could've gotten since there is absolutely no real vertical element in the game. In the year that this game is set and with the technology that is all around NC, you would think that there would at least be a parachuting mechanic and some kind of climbing, yet there isn't. 

The characters are generally also very interesting, yet I feel like the game is lacking in that aspect too. The only character I really found myself intrigued by was Judy, and that says a lot about the games other ones. I lack empathy for other characters that directly influence V because of how bland they were. Their side jobs became more of a chore than something I felt excited to do and I found myself skipping through most of the dialogue with them because I just didn't care. The romance option gives you four characters in total to try to build some kind of relationship with but I'd say that only one of them is worth spending your time with, but you also need to meet certain criteria for that to work out. I like the fact that these characters have a preference and that CDPR took time to really try to bring that aspect out, yet I also felt like I was missing out since the romance options for a male V are absolutely terrible. Besides that, the game seems to really want to push that PG18 title so most of these supposedly relationships only feel like a one night stand since you can't really do much other than that.

The AI system is horrendous and some of the NPC's are outright terrifying. As soon as you commit any type of crime, cops spawn around you which isn't only bad design, it feels cheap and unrealistic. To lose the cops all you have to do is run or drive down the street in a single straight line and they'll lose your trail in mere seconds, no matter what difficulty level or wanted level. No police chase, nothing. You would've thought that they'd at least put some kind of backup in front of you but the game lacks that as well. The games cars only really serves as a purpose to give speed junkies as myself some thrill when driving but that's about it since you won't really experience any kind of NCPD chase. I also found out that jumping into a body of water confuses the police so badly that they instantly lose track and you're off the hook. Comparing this to GTA which came out years ago, it's an extreme letdown. Now to the NPC's that walk the streets of NC, I feel like the only purpose they serve is to try to make the city feel more alive, yet I find it struggling with that as well. The kids strolling around are creepy and they walk around completely alone without the presence of a guardian. Their voices don't match their supposed ages and it's very unrealistic. Don't even get me started on all the traffic in NC. Sure, a city this size must have a LOT of traffic, that's no surprise, but the amount of times I've accidentally totalled my car because some dingus decided to suddenly create traffic jam is uncountable. 

The game's system for building your character around your own preferred play-style is an interesting concept, yet that is also horribly executed. Even when focusing on the stealthily perks I still found that the most effective method for any kind of gig or side job was running and gunning the whole place. The ability to throw knives to stealthily take out a target sounds interesting at first but it's not as effective as it seems since you lose your knives after only one throw. I've never been much of a stealth focused person but most of the times I try it, things work out. This wasn't the case for CP2077. I've lost count of amount of times I've been detected for some unknown reason or by enemies with vision that allows them to see through walls, and I feel extremely sorry for the people that favours stealth.

The gigs and side jobs lack in so much content that I get bored easily and most of them feel like things I have to do instead of want to do for fun. 

Also, the whole Johnny Silverhand thing feels to me like the devs trying to force Keanu Reeves into a role that doesn't even fit him because of the time crunch and tight deadlines. 

Now this is without mentioning all the games glitches and bugs that have driven me crazy. The texture pop-ins of trees, t-posing NPCs, sudden cars just spawning in and exploding, NPCs from gigs that I played (and failed) early on in the story still following me in the late game, objectives not being fulfilled because of some weird glitch despite me making sure multiple times that I've done exactly like the game wants me to, glitches that involve me not being able to pick up weapons. These aren't even all of them and they've happened so many times that I've almost given up entirely. 

Even if the game started to suddenly work properly, there are too much missing content and too many holes in the game for me to call it a good game. The 60 euro price tag really doesn't reflect the games quality at all. Overall, the game is a letdown to all the hype it built up and considering the amount of people that worked on this, I just can't call it good. You're honestly just better off spending the 60 euros on something else because this game is disappointing and not worth the money.

Cyberpunk 2077 94.2 hours clocked in. 
(SPOILER-FREE)

Before I say anything, let me get this out of the way. You will not play this game without encountering some kind of glitch or bug. Expect to see someone pop out of existence, float in midair, or spontaneously combust every once in a while. If this is a deal-breaker for you, do not buy this game. Even more so, if you are a completionist and looking to 100% this game, I cannot stress enough do NOT buy this game. There are multiple side quests I was unable to complete (a main quest being one of them, though it decided to work one day for some reason) due to the fixer never calling you, or characters texting me about how I didn't finish the mission when they had just thanked me for completing it 2 minutes earlier. 100% this game will likely require you to restart a quest a few times, or spend hours just hoping it works this time, if this is a deal-breaker for you, do not buy this game. Now, with that out of the way, if you're a casual gamer that is willing to look past or even have a good laugh at the common place bugs, and don't care whether or not you miss a quest or two, please continue. 

Combat: This game is first and foremost an rpg. Head-shots will not auto kill like in other FPS, and shooting at the enemy's legs or arms won't slow them down. The enemies are essentially sponges until their health drops to zero. The only real variety between enemies is their death animation. If you use a sword or sharp weapon there's a chance for their head's to come off, if you use a strong enough gun you can blow their heads clean off, and if you use some kind of explosive they'll blow to bits. Admittedly, seeing this happen is badass, but in reality its all icing and no substance. The enemies, besides some bosses, all act the same and because of this fighting can become boring or tedious. That leads into another gripe I have with this game, the armor and evasion stats feel almost non-existent. It doesn't matter how much armor you get, or how much evasion you rack up, you'll still die in the same three hits to the same enemy over and over again. There is no "tank" build, you're either all damage and hope you can kill your enemy before they get a shot in, or you sneak around and silently kill everyone before you're spotted. CDPR acts like there's a lot of variety in in your builds but it all comes down to these two tactics. However, the stealth missions in this game are really fun. The way you can hack the cameras to disable them or even look for enemies through its lens is really cool and its one of the game's high points. You can even get enemies to fight each other through a certain skill, and sneak by them while they're going at it. In short, though there may not be many "builds" so to speak this one aspect of the game gives a lot of variety. 

TLDR: Enemies are like sponges, doesn't matter where you shoot them they die all the same, dont expect an enemy to limp after you shoot them in the leg, they'll still run a marathon.

Cars/vehicles: The driving as other people have mentioned feels like you're on ice. Its almost impossible to make a turn with any care if you're going more than 80 mph. There are really cool and fast cars I couldn't use because I'd always end up crashing and blowing my car up or getting chased by the cops after hitting a family of four at 200 mph. The motorcycles are a lot more tolerable, but it can still be annoying at times. Because of this, I found myself using the game's teleporters more often than not which is really disappointing. The game is beautiful, and driving around, especially at night was amazing, it just isn't practical if you're actually trying to get somewhere. The fact that you can't customize your car is also really lame but there are so many in this game it was easy to find one that fit my "style" so I can't complain too much.

TLDR: This is not GTA 5 driving, it feels like you're driving on ice

Quests: This is where the game shines. This is why you buy the game and are able to look past all its flaws, the missions in this game, although can tend to pile up, are without a doubt its greatest strong suit. Its almost like all the features and character arcs the devs couldn't implement/flesh out in the main storyline were done justice. You feel genuinely invested in the mission, you're given ACTUAL choices that affect how it ends (more on that later) and it gives you a chance to really care about the characters brushed aside in the main story. I don't want to give too much away, but one of my favorite side quests (I know I said spoiler free but this is one small side quest out of MANY that in no way ties to the main story, if you truly care skip past this) is one where you're tasked with saving a doctor. When you get there, guns blazing or however you want to do it, the doctor refuses to leave. Its revealed that she was kidnapped to save the life of a gang leader and will not come with you until she saves her patient. You can do a lot of things here, personally I helped her save the patient so I can end the job on good terms, but I recommend you look through all the options yourself. These kind of missions, the ones that make you question whether what you're doing is right, and compels you to load a save and try it again is what makes Cyberpunk so addicting at times. But again, the incredible characters lead into another complaint I have, dead-ends. Its really frustrating to be invested in a side quest only for it to end so abruptly. At times it feels unfinished and you almost feel like a side character in your own story, a character brushed aside/forgotten about when things really get juicy. But most quests don't feel like this, they feel truly fleshed out, its just very noticeable and hard to brush aside when it does happen. 

Choices: After a certain early mainline quest, there is almost no variety in the main story. No matter what you say, or how you do it, things will play out the exact same every time. The only real choice you have is whether or not to be a dick. Even the game's endings are pretty straightforward. When it comes down to it, you basically have three endings, and the extra four are just, again, variations of those three whether or not you were a dick. The E3 demo REALLY overplayed just how much control you have over your own story. But I will say, the endings are great, and you'll feel invested in whatever ending you choose.

Alright, this might end a little abrupt but I feel like I got my main points across. Cyberpunk is a flawed game. It's glitched, tedious, and at times even frustrating; but if there's one thing CDPR did right, its made you give two shits about Night City. 

I recommend, at least after a few more patches, that you buy Cyberpunk 2077.

I again wish that there was a neutral review type, because this game is fun, for the first 30 hours. All the hours i put in after that was just me trying to feel like i got my money's worth out of Cyberpunk for 60 dollars. First 30 hours in cyberpunk, are an artistic masterpiece. Semi-memorable, and interesting characters. high stakes plot line, and oh man the city itself is freaking amazing artistically. CD Projekt Red stated before launch that while the main story was going to be short, that they were going to focus most of their energy into side quests. This was not the case. After the 25 hr main story, there are maybe 10  side quests tops with story that is fleshed out. The game just feels gutted, and if i had been told honestly that i was going to be paying for a 30 hour cyberpunk action-adventure story, with skill trees, but minimal roleplay elements. I would have just waited for a sale.
CD Projekt Red straight up lied about how much content there would be, very closely before the launch. Side quests, in the lens of their previous work (the witcher), was assumed by gamers to mean roleplay heavy story quests. People did not think that would mean a bunch of blips on a map, that are either Kill/steal/rescue missions with nothing more for interaction than a one-way phone conversation from an npc.
50 hours later, its decent for now

So this is a conditional yes recommendation.

The good:
The world building and content in the side quests is pretty amazing, and despite the bugs I've really enjoyed playing through Cyberpunk as a Nomad - that felt complete.  While I haven't experimented with other builds, I was able to put together a build that allowed me to progress through the game and do basically all of the quests open to me.  The city is also extremely well rendered and they managed to generally capture the feeling of being in a dense urban environment, along with subrubia and being out in the sticks.

The bad:
Primary quest chain is really short, and Acts 1 and 3 aren't all that long as you will spend the overwhelming majority of the game in Act 2.  Bugs are everywhere, and there's a lot of hooks for additional content (like rooms and what not) that isn't implemented.  Cop AI is bad, traffic AI has problems.  Stealth system isn't very deep as a low investment will get you through most of the game with stealth.

Overall recommendation:
Yes if it's on sale.  As of right now, this game is not worth the full ticket price for most people.  I don't regret my preorder because I have logged enough time and enjoyed doing stuff in the game world that I feel it was worth the money, but YMMV on that point.

Performance issues aside the story is really effecting, and the side quests are far deeper than most RPG's I've played.  The world feels incredibly fleshed out.  It's the most invested in a RPG story in a very long time.

The credits have stopped rolling for the final time, and after having seen every ending I can say my experience was positive. The story and writing were generally well executed, and even some 'side jobs' had main quest quality with unique models, environments, and decisions. The characters felt very real and memorable, and though I wish they had more content I definitely 'felt' for Johnny, Panam, Judy, River, etc and enjoyed making their destinies in Night City with them. I play games mostly for the story, so that's why this is a positive review - it was a total blast, if short. Great ending variety and some surprisingly introspective moments worthy of the 'cyberpunk' name. As always a sucker for romance options, Judy's romance felt meaningful if a bit melancholy, but those two words fit in with the plot in general.

Just finished the main quest. This game is like a ghost. It has some serious unfinished business. In almost every department. Graphics. Story. Sidequests. Music. NPC interaction. Voice acting. My impression is that at some point, the devs realized that the game was just too big and ambitious to be able to finished within a realistic timeline. So they made do with what they had.

The gameplay is really what will save the game while it continues getting patched. The gunplay and fighting is fun and fresh. But the game needs more music, more story, more sidequests, more wacky NPCs like in the Witcher. If the devs continue to work on this in DLCs, the game will gradually reach the status people hoped of it. But for the time being, the world feels unfinished and punching below its weight. The devs promised an ultra dense world. Architecturally, the city is spectacular. But once you get outside of the city and into the desert, you realize how many more details should have been included for the game to be on par with what was promised. Also I was disappointed that it is not very possible to explore any of the skyscrapers in the way I imagined it being. And I guess that is normal, because there are too many of them. But this is what happens when you make a world too big and ambitious. I hope they begin seriously cranking out DLCs because the world and the game is fun and fascinating.

If they don't give up on it, with a bunch of DLCs, this game will be a masterpiece in 5 years. But right now it is just a good game.
Fantastic world building, even with the occasional glitch (although quite minimal to what happens and what it affects in my experience), it is a great game.
Probably the best game I have ever played.

Now the Patch 1.5, THIS IS GAME CHANGING, like literally. The experience to play this game now is much different than before. The new NPC AI, reworked driving stability, reworked maps, new customization, game physics, and much more, just like what we wish this game should be on our expectation in the release date.

This new Patch 1.5 and 50% sale discount, that's definitely a steal, really recommended.

There's a lot I could say about Cyberpunk but I will try and keep this semi-brief. There are some things very well done and others not so much in this game. Personally if I could go back I'd wait for the price to drop and the promised patches before buying. (some tagged out of context, vague spoilers ahead)

Let's start with the bad (and I'll try to be brief):
Gameplay wise
--Buggy af (as we all know). Game crashes, UI bugs, 3D model/rigging bugs, quests bug (constantly), physics bugs. So many bugs.
--The stealth mechanic is finicky and rarely works
-- The "hacking" mechanic disrupts the flow of combat and gameplay severely. Forcing you to stop and play sudoku. 
--Vehicle controls are wonky. I'd put them slightly above Saints Row 3 vehicles. So not great but easy enough to get the hang of.
--Enemies can be a bit bullet spongy and ammo can be a pain to come by. 
Other than that overall gameplay flows well and feels pretty similar to most FPSs. 

The bad story wise and ngl I have a lot of issues with the story:
--Story content (w/ no side quests or exploration) is only 20 some hours. Extremely short and imo the story really never goes anywhere. 
--Overall plot/story quality. I am left wondering how the studio that produced the Witcher 3 somehow also made 2077. Overall story is all over the place and ends super predictably but not in a satisfying way. In an extremely disappointing, lame way. 
--4 basic endings that are just bad. Gave me flashbacks to Mass Effect 3's blue, green and red endings. 
--Telling and never showing. Most lore is given via a codex/lore entries. Important concepts are talked about in game but [i]never[/i] actually explained to the PC. I don't mind codex/lore entries in games as supplementary but in no way was is it supplementary in Cyberpunk. Unless you are familiar with the ttrpg source material you'll be left in the dark without spending a chunk of time in the codex. 
--Tries so hard to hit every cyberpunk genre bullet in a meaningful way that is just fails completely. It touches on so many themes of the genre but with such bad takes/ themes that it's laughable. I mean for real there are  quests where I laughed all the way through because of how hard the game is trying to be edgy and deep. I mean there is legit a mission that attempts to tackle religion [spoiler]and it ends with you literally nailing a man to a cross. [/spoiler]. So painfully on the nose and in your face. 
--Other thematic issues I have mostly involve the game using the cyberpunk genre to try and make the societal commentary the genre is known for but doing it in a way that is fundamentally not punk and especially not cyberpunk. 
--Not a ton of player agency. Choices/dialogue don't really matter which was a bit of a bummer. Story plays out pretty much identically regardless of what you say and do. 

Okay! So now the good!
--Visually stunning game! The environment is extremely rich and beautiful 
--Aesthetically hits every button in the genre. Very well done visuals
--The voice acting! Wow do I love some of the the voice actors in this game. Feminine voice V's actor does a stunning job. I mean a performance on par with Jennifer Hale's femshep. 
--Some really compelling characters and character arcs, that the main plot cannot seem to match. Characters (including PC) deal with some heavy, hard hitting topics like [spoiler] suicide, terminal illness, death, betrayal, loss[/spoiler] and some of it is done really really well. There are some solid emotional impacts from the game and its characters. 
--Keanu Reeve's character. I truly was expecting Johnny Silverhand to be a memey- just there for the novelty character. Instead we get a nuanced character with an amazing performance. 
--Character models and facial expressions are all solid. I've seen some people claim 2077 falls into uncanny valley bad but honestly I thought they did a great job on character models/rigging of side characters (not so much random NPCs)
--Some really solid LGBTQ+ characters. I know there was some major controversy before release and a number of frankly problematic things in the game regarding gender and gender equality [i]but[/i] there are some great LGBTQ+ characters
--Fun. This game is straight up fun. Despite the meh story. Unfortunately the bad story/questlines and gamebreaking bugs all contribute to the ridiculous fun this game can be. Possibly borders on a game so bad it's good. 

Ultimately Cyberpunk 2077 [i]is[/i] a fun game. I have had a ton of fun playing it but I [i]do[/i] feel like it's because I gave up on the main plot to focus on enjoying the side quests, characters and exploration. It just did not meet the expectations and hype the game had built up. The game feels extremely catered to cishet male players which is kind of a bummer for a game attempting to encapsulate the cyberpunk genre. And honesty I felt that Projekt Red just couldn't quite figure out what type of story they wanted to tell with Cyberpunk 2077 and ended up with something along the lines of [spoiler]"Die historic on fury road" but make it Night City[/spoiler], and did not live up to the game and story promised that was originally promised.

Overall this isn't bad, it's just boring and not very immersive or rewarding to play. I honestly didn't have as much trouble with the bugs as some of the other reviewers,* I just lost interest. 

The combat has no impact. Both combat and stealth repetitive while hacking is clunky, dull and disruptive (also repetitive). The user interface for menus is also clunky and counter-intuitive. Exploration feels pointless because you can't interact with the environment in any meaningful way and there's no attention to detail. Every NPC and every item you find is generic, randomly generated according to finite parameters. The city looks impressive at first, but after a couple hours you realize you're running around in a giant wax museum. There's nothing to discover except another generic building with a slightly differentiated floor plan and two dozen doors that don't open. It's like trying to swim in an inch deep ocean: I don't care if I can see water for miles if I can't drink it or immerse myself in it. 

You can break into somebody's house swinging a baseball bat and wearing nothing but combat boots and a banana hammock and get no reaction. You can set off a bomb on one street, run into a store and rob the owner blind, then steal a car and get basically no response.  You want to claim a bounty? Scan them, kill them and watch numbers appear on the top right corner of your screen as your character magically generates wealth. Nobody much seems to mind. 

Because the items you get are all generic with randomly generated stats, it doesn't even feel rewarding. Worse yet, it ruins the immersion. You'll find yourself in what's supposed to be a serious, corporate-espionage mission and you have to switch from your carbon-fiber military grade sneaking suit to a neon pink gimp-suit and orange tennis shoes so that you don't have get killed. 

It's an ambitious project with some genuine beauty that doesn't go any deeper than the skin. And even that cosmetic appeal wears thin after you've heard the same line of dialogue or the same elevator broadcast for the 10,00th time. 

The driving is also terrible. Trying to navigate Night City is thoroughly aggravating, though it helps that there're are absolutely no real consequences for any of your actions and you're therefore free to run down pedestrians with impunity.

A fabulous game, I am obviously hooked, as you can see by my playtime. Not going into a long assay about the game, so I am gonna try to condense this review as much as possible.
As any game game there are issues. Unfortunately this one has a considerable number of bugs. I've heard there are many problems in old consoles, but this is not the case with me. I have a relatively good computer, and I am afraid you will need to have one in order to play smoothly and without crashes. Had 5 of those in 580 hours, all while tying to load a save, so no big issue for me. Some FPS drops while driving downtown, but again, just notice the number of cars, pedestrians and lights there,so, I am not shocked. it´s a heavy game. I've said it before. Most bugs are graphical in nature, some are due to poor/IA implementation. I reckon the game was rushed due to publisher and/or investor pressure, but even so, due to the level of things in the game and it´s complexity, let´s give the developers a break, shall we? Enough vitriol over an excellent game. I am positive, given enough time, these issues will be overcome.
Now, the story is enticing, very well written, with lots of character depth. If you are into this kind of thing, this game is for you. For RPG lovers, this title is also very good, although the game has not the best character development considering perks/feats  and so one, it does a good enough job. Combat is fluid, shooting with a silenced weapon with a scope, slashing enemies with your katana or whatever fells very rewarding. Some have complained about the driving experience, but there are mods out there that improve upon the experience and give up extra options. Clothing selections, mods and a plethora of different weapon add to the depth of the game.
 To be frank, the worst part of this game is the length of the main story. it could be about 30% longer, at least. Also, there could be more side quests and gigs in general. I understand content was cut due to lack of time and pressure to release the game. So, here is the cause of all problems. Time. CDPR is now working on bug fixes and stability, but I anxiously wait for more content. let the DLCs come. Maybe  multiplayer in the future? One can only hope for.

After playing a bit, I can recommend this game. 

You likely already know all about it - but from my perspective there should be more praise for the variety of play styles on offer. Leveling up to the point where you have these options is time consuming [you start off pretty weak and the RPG approach of leveling is unavoidable] but I enjoyed the open world, story and voice acting the whole time it took to get strong enough for the game to really open up. 

Mid-to-late game you have an enjoyable variety of solid play options. Pure melee is a valid way to play through the entirety of the game and it's fun. So is pure guns. You can make your character faster, with double jumps, and with bonuses for charging in guns ablazin' and all of a sudden you're playing a traditional DOOM-style FPS. Slowing down time and dodging while shooting is reminiscent of Max Payne. You can go stealth and silenced weapons with just a bit of ranged tech abilities and the game plays like Deus Ex. Focus on hacking and you're playing Watch Dogs. 

That's not to say the game is just a mix of old ideas. Open world games are often "stealth or strength" "ranged or melee" or "swords, arrows or magic" but it's rare when a game can find a balance with all the options valid, deep and enjoyable without a defined class - so you can end up with a unique mix of whatever abilities you're in the mood for and still have a good time. 

I can mention the beautifully realized world, temper my recommendation with warnings about the bugs (I'd have every achievement if it wasn't for one), weak AI, and the current lack of promised multiplayer (or a bunch of other stuff you already know), but I haven't seen enough attention brought to the fact that you can play however you want. It's what I dig the most. 

I suspect this achievement in variety makes some bugs (WHY DOES DRIVING SUCK?) seem especially odd. Still, overall, easy to recommend. Fun to get lost in. Plenty to do for 150hrs. Not perfect but I'm ok with a touch of the 'ol jank.

Honestly wasn't worth my money and would refund it if I could. Its hard to describe the core issue I have with the game but one way of saying it is this game treats the cyberpunk genre as just an aesthetic for a mediocre rpg/fps, instead of an ideology (not quite the right word but I can't find it rn) with themes of anti-capitalism, corporations taking over, transhumanism, etc. Not to say the game doesn't touch on or mention that stuff, but it never goes into to anything in enough detail to actually say something about those topics. This isn't even mentioning the graphical/gameplay glitches but that stuff is secondary to my real issue. Maybe I expected too much but the trailers made it seem like a game that meant something more than "yay shooting and the occasional decision".

TL;DR- If you want to play a game in the cyberpunk genre that actually means something (unlike this one), try 2064 Read Only Memories.

Hi I am going to go with a pros and cons list about this game. I am new to reviews and will try to use the style of reviewers that I respect.

First I will state that I am a PC gamer so I cannot speak for console versions.

Second my PC specs are as follows:

9th gen Intel I5 processor
16 GB RAM
Ti 1050 4 GB graphics card
SSD hard drive

So on with my review

Game 8.5/10

Pros

Graphics are really nice, running 2K at nearly max settings (I disable stuff like motion blur. Anti aliasing is a relic from low res monitors from years ago).

Story haven't finished yet (at 75% I think) but compelling, immersive, great characters, I disagree that Keanu is wooden I like his performance it fits the setting. Anybody who liked Mass Effect will like this. This has those big moments of WTF that mass effect had.

Game world FRICKING AWESOME I thought Boston in Fallout 4 was amazing, same with Novigrad in The Witcher 3. Night City and it's surroundings just mind blowing. In the Witcher 3 you soon just used fast travel (same mechanic here) but I don't I want to roam the city.

Game stability I might be lucky, I have only had one CTD.

Okay on with the cons

World A lot of placeholder stuff such as empty gamezones in a couple of places which are immersion breaking (no NPC's in an industrial zone). AI of traffic and pedestrians is poor

Some quests cannot be completed as the trigger does not happen, few I have only had a problem with sidequests (3 of many)

Any other problem I have with this game in it's current state is just quality of life and customization of character and range of equipment.

This should never have been released for last gen consoles. The money people got greedy and diverted the dev team from doing the full game.

But Buy this game, it's still awesome and it will get better.

Update after patch 1.52 and upgrading to an RTX 3050.

All (or, at the very least most) of the truly game-breaking bugs have now been ironed out, and overall performance has been improved accross the board. The game is still not perfect, in that it still does not contain every feature that was promised by the devs before release, but it is a LOT better than it was when it was first launched. Recommended, if your system has the chops to run it.

He had to build a simple text game for school last year and it took him 2 and a half weeks to smooth out the errors and make it playable. Fix one bug, 99 more shall appear...
I feel for the devs that had so many more plans for this game and it was ripped away from them before it was ready. and you know they probably had to work overtime during the holidays to fix it because management decided it was ready and to release it to the public. I can't say I know for sure that's what happened, but in these situations, that's usually what happens. 
I have already noticed a lot of the bugs I have experienced being fixed (one of my first complaints was getting a tarot reading from Misty and she placed down invisible cards, that's not an issue anymore! I noticed it fixed like 2 days later)

All in all, not a bad experience. Would recommend, 9/10

I'm so disappointed. It's a really mediocre game, with a generally interesting main story and some of the side missions are okay, but none of the hundreds of mini-distractions really have any meaning or impact in the lifeless city. 

The shooting is crap, the melee is much worse than Skyrim, and the arbitrary stealth system isn't satisfying either, especially when entering sudden hostile areas with no warning whatsoever. It'd be nice to highlight these areas on the minimap or something.

Driving is absolutely joyless, and it takes forever to get anywhere - even at an indicated 150mph, the metres on the HUD creep by with depressing lethargy.

There are lots of immersion-breaking glitches, and the ending of the main story makes no sense whatsoever - it feels like there is so much left unexplained.

It's hard to care for any of the characters, as most of the time I have no idea who on earth they are. They are catapulted into the story with little or no introduction, and then disappear equally quickly. The supposed nemesis Adam Smasher is an absolute bit part at best, and yet we're supposed to have some kind of internal monologue to decide his fate... I couldn't care less!

I wouldn't recommend this game I'm afraid - it could have been really good, but it's bland and fairly soulless. The mechanics are most to blame for this, but the character exposition is also pretty naff.

SPOILERS BEWARE!!!! If you see [spoiler] this [/spoiler] it's because it is serious spoiler material!

Bugs, glitches and other gameplay issues aside, the game is great! I'm disappointed with how certain characters were treated (Takemura, Dex, T-Bug, Evelyn Parker and Jackie). It felt that they were used only to progress the story and nothing else they didn't matter beyond their use. 

Jackie is your friend [spoiler] who gets killed during a big mission he is mentioned every once and awhile and yes you can have moments where his death affects you but [/spoiler] he is put in the backseat for most of the story. 

Takemura is an interesting character as he was the personal bodyguard of the leader of Arasaka, [spoiler] who gets killed by his son, which you witnessed. He ends up saving you as he suspects that the son was the one who killed him. [strike] He dies anti-climatically as well, you don't even get to see him die either [/strike] [/spoiler] [strike] which may be something explored in a later DLC. [/strike]

Dexter is the guy who sets you up with the job to steal from Arasaka. [spoiler] After it all goes tits up he kills you....or tries at least. He ends up getting killed rather anti-climatically by Takemura. [/spoiler]

T-Bug is a netrunner whom you know through past missions that you never get to play she helps with the heist at the beginning of the story. [spoiler] Shes killed during the heist [/spoiler] unfortunately, her exact fate is never revealed (Perhaps future DLC?).

Evelyn Parker is the woman who requests the heist from Dexter. [spoiler] She ends up dying after a long series of missions that result in her suicide. [/spoiler] The sad part is that she could've easily done far more in the story. I actually kinda liked her.

These five seemed integral to the story yet I felt that they weren't used to their full potential. 

Jackie was used as a motivator for V. [spoiler] His death [/spoiler] is seemingly meant to push V to accomplish the goal of removing the [spoiler] biochip [/spoiler] from your head he should've been popping into V's head far more throughout the story. 

T-Bug could've been used for much more than a throwaway character. She could've been your contact at the Voodoo Boys. Her [spoiler] death [/spoiler] is fairly wide open so my guess is DLC or maybe not. 

Dexter could been an easy side gig in tracking him down [spoiler] and giving V the satisfaction of killing him for what he did to you. Let's not forget that the reason you have the biochip issue in the first place is because Dex decided to attempt to kill you which caused the biochip to activate and boom the story begins. V deserved to be the one to kill Dex in a satisfying side gig. [/spoiler]

Evelyn Parker is a big one [spoiler] that was very surprising the way that she died. I thought she could've easily been used far more in the story perhaps not only helping you figure out what to do about the Voodoo boys but also with the final heist perhaps she could've used her connections with Yorinobu (Saburo's son) to get you a way in the tower. [/spoiler]

Edit: Some of my information is incorrect as the outcome of a certain character [spoiler] Takemura [/spoiler] can be changed if certain decisions are made. I have learned this after a second playthrough. Although this only affects the outcome of one character. My opinion on other characters still stands. Glitch on chooms!

Update as of 1.6.1

Buy it. 

FSR 2.0 is there, game runs really well, most bugs ( minus the cops... ) have been ironed out, it's absolutely a blast to play. Crashing issues have been resolved, everything that's there does work now, no bugged abilities or stats that don't do anything. 

Would absolutely recommend, CDPR has actually gotten this to where it needs to be for a recommendation, even at full price, all the better if it goes on sale. 

Update as of 1.5 Patch:

It's...better. 

The fixes are there, and the product is a lot more stable. They're slowly bringing in what they promised during development and the game is basically where it should have been at launch. 

That being said. 

There's still swathes of stuff missing, though that is changing and CDPR are putting their money where their mouth is and not charging for DLC until the game's done. Bravo, good for them, I do have to applaud that. 

Still wouldn't recommend this title if you don't already own it, but if you do, and gave up around launch, it's worth another shot.

They've swapped story, gameplay, worldbuilding, for sex scenes, shitty dialogue, and poor pathing and level design, they lied about the levels customisation, and none of the backgrounds have any affect on the story whatsoever. 

No you can't:

And by GTA I mean San Andreas, not V, that comparison is an insult to GTA V.

A long while ago I played the PC version of Cyberpunk and wrote a pretty scathing review of it. The game was completely broken, and the majority of the review was a lengthy list of game breaking bugs I encountered. Stuff such as being unable to select anything but the first dialog option, characters rising from the dead only to wander over to a chair and die officially, and in one instance being launched into space upon completion of a side mission and having to wait quite a while to actually return to the ground.

With the release of the Netflix anime Edgerunners, I was inspired to go through the game a second time in a morbid curiosity of if the game was finally playable. To my surprise the answer was mostly yes. Now, that's not to say we're dealing with a 10 out of 10 game here. Nothing Cyberpunk does is something we haven't seen in other games, and more often than not the other game accomplishes doing it quite a bit better. However, the game no longer feels like it's actively battling your attempts to play it.

Now that's not to say bugs don't still exist. They do. However for the most part these are very minor glitches like an NPC resetting their sitting position in mid dialog. The only bad glitch that required me to save, close the game, and reopen it to fix was after doing a specific mission my scan button ceased to function.

The side quests in this game are mostly all good. The main quest is fairly enjoyable as well. But the majority of your time will be in open world experience of running around killing groups of enemy gang members, and doing other menial tasks (called gigs). It's fairly mindless. But if you're seeing a time wasting open world Assassin Creedy kinda game, it's not the worst option.

The abusive practices the company did to the devs is still a problem, and one can hope the whole debacle made CD Project Red actually learn from it all. Both treating their crew better, and not rushing games out when they're basically still in alpha. But that is a question to answer in the future. For now, the game is at least worth checking out if you're bored. So I'll change my review to recommended.

I just hope they put a little bit more TLC in their upcoming DLC plans if they hope to actually sell it.

Biggest frustration I had was with not being able to rebind the dash, which made being stealthy/not having pedestrians randomly run in fear annoying. You can get a mod for this of course, I'm just wary of mods for now being the amount of patches and updates coming as seen with the engine tweaks mod. Inventory is rough, crafting system is meh, but perk tree seemed pretty good to me though.

Sure you're on a hero's journey, but most of the time you are doing what's in your best interest. You can choose to try and do the greater good, but even when you try to do this there can be unintended consequences. Choices felt impactful at times as well. Would recommend.

So I originally thought my headache was the style of the game. While I hadn't played an FPS in years I grew up playing them, so clearly it was the lights and coloring.... WRONG!!! Then my partner looked at me and was like "well of course, you're moving your head around like crazy trying to watch everything!!!" OOPS

With that, back into CyberPunk as my current binge game while I wait for the next BG3 patch. Can now play for hours on end with no headache. Occasionally find graphical glitches and bugs, but I never expect to be 100% free of those. Only found one quest breaking bug so far. My earlier comments about enjoying the story and thinking the world looks stunning still stands. I'm also still annoyed by clicking a dialogue option and having V not say exactly what the option said. Picked me a few fights I didn't want to pick because of the tone and attitude difference.

Overall, is it perfect, no. But is it *bad* also no. Just has a bunch of room to grow.
