I am recommending 2077...but with a huge caveat. 

I played through the game before writing this. I did not experience the game stopping bugs or horrible issues that most faced, but that is not to say i didn't experience many, many, many bugs, glitches and issues throughout. I really, really wanted to like this game, I did enjoy much of it. 

My biggest issue wasn't the glitches and bugs, it wasn't the deceptive tactics used in its promotion, it is the dialogue, story and quality of life as a player in the game. 

No, I won't be playing it over and over to see different ends or even different beginnings ( like I did with fallout or the mass effect franchises)  because none of the choices seem like good ones, or meaningful, or even like choices at all. Most of the game functions like this, and with Keanu in it - it harkins back to the idea of choice from another franchise of his. 

It's a tromp through tropes, but at least i got this cool Trauma Team vest out of it.

In game, I talk like a 20 year old dim-witted punk kid ( even as a corpo) with few and far between, scattered lines that are actually intelligent. I befriend people who make really poor and rash decisions while spilling their life story like we are in a CW show, and worse, they all speak in some rather superficial heavy accents and use their obvious culture as a prop rather than a motivation, which is exacerbated by some rather racist economic, ethnic and geographic separations in Night City. 

For some reason Night City, and society in general, has become an over-sexed, over-served, wildly obnoxious, rude, and vacuous hive of alcoholics and warlords who either are guilting you into drinking every conversation, trying to kill you, or simply harassing you with the same obscure line of dialogue every time they see you.

 You end up more at strip clubs, brothels and back alleys, than anywhere else and though you can dress like anything, get tons of street cred, and carry an arsenal on your person that wouldn't fit in a closet, it never makes any real difference in how people treat you.( unless you start shooting- then they beg for their lives which gave me horrific flashbacks to the 5 minutes of Postal i played)

Among the many things littering the world, the worst are the countless shards that beg for you to take them, and even have to be read to progress some gigs. While you have a small and tidy phone book, you will pick up hundreds( literally) of these small shards that are more about exposition and attempts to fill out the back story of the world than something relevant and engaging. they are all accessible through a list that provides neither context nor any real incentive to read them. Many times these shards are just variations of the same too-cool-for-school dialogue between two unknown people with little or no clue as to what they are talking about. If you don't stop in the middle of a mission to read the essay on why Night City, it's inhabitants, and it's AIs are so dysfunctional, then maybe you can read it later while you crouch waiting for the cool-down on System Reset. 

Speaking of non lethal, Let's talk about the idea of non-lethal game play. Shooting someone is pretty lethal. Shooting someone a few dozen times with an assault rifle is definitely lethal and no implant in YOUR head changes that, now or in the future. Deus Ex had a variety of non lethal weapons, but in 2077, there are only non-lethal melee and a pretend idea that shooting someone with a gun can be "safe". This choice of being non-lethal plays out basically the same as lethal, they just don't actually die, but they don't wake up either.

Day, night, 3 am or 6pm , today, tomorrow, yesterday - time is talked about, meeting are set, but sometimes they don't really mean it and other times they do. You get to guess if their urgency should be headed or not. 
This "mean-it-but-don't" kinda of emphasis is so wide spread and erratic you are never sure if you know if you have time to go see if the clothing vendor finally has a purple Bitch shirt in stock or if they are still just are selling more ripped t-shirts that have more armor than the orange ballistic vest you've wearing for 10 levels.
 
The only vehicles that seem reasonably drivable on PC are the bikes. This works to the player's advantage because the traffic and traffic systems in Night city are random at best, and non-sensibly chaotic at worse. By the way. crosswalks mean nothing to the driver who will run you down in the street like a dog. 

This game can certainly push into 100 hours. So if you only want to play it once, then why not allow far more choice and accessibility to clothes, crafting recipes, and such in the game in one play through?  Crafting is near meaningless for clothes, and very stingy for any decent weapon until you get to a pretty high crafting level. I didn't choose to mod, farm or exploit, and though i spent way too much on clothes, much of it was pointless - I wore the same glasses for 40 levels because i couldn't find any with better stats. How could i justify spending 120K on a gun that i  will be out of in a couple missions ?

So with all these issues i had, what was good? The combat system, parts of Night City, the skill system, about half of the clothes, most of the weapons, and about half of the crafting mechanics.  I recommend it because there is some really nice work cobbled into the very broken framework. There are beautiful moments and some really fun gigs. There are diverse skill paths, and the world is reminiscent of some of my favorite sci fi ( and likely yours too). There are some beautiful vistas, some fun hidden gems, and the enjoyment and recognition of the many, many hours of some very talented people trying to make this game great. 

So... i do recommend it to PC players- but read the posts, watch the reviews and know exactly what you are getting into.

Cyberpunk 2077 is what I've seen being referred to as an "unfinished masterpiece". Playing through the game twice, while also exploring multiple endings, I would have to say I agree with this description of the game. It is important to look at the game from at least two aspects while assessing it - the "Core" aspects of the game, as well as the "Technical" aspects. 

Starting with the Core aspects ( story, quests, characters, immersion, world design/building) CDPR has done an absolutely terrific job in this regard. It is rare for me to play a game and become completely absorbed in its story. The main storyline is interesting, dark, and bittersweet (depending on how you end things - there are many different ways to complete the game). All of your choices in regard to the main story line has an effect on the way things play out. Remember that decision you made 20 hours? Yeah, that could/will affect your choices/options later down the road. Even playing through the game a second time, while only really making small changes to the way I played made me have a different experience. 
It is unfortunate that the backstory you pick never really has any impact on the main story apart from certain dialogue options. The first 20 minutes are different and unique, but it ultimately terminates into the same story and if you've played through the game more than once, you will quickly be "back to the usual". That's not to say it's bad - the story is really great and immersive, exploring a dark future where no matter how desperately one fights against oppressive systems and individuals, the world still wins.
The characters that are the heavy, narrative driven storylines are among some of the best I've ever come across. All of them go through a series of quests where your choices greatly impact the outcome (and also their relationship to you). Some of these characters are romanceable, something which was crafted in a really great manner. Again, these choices and whatnot will impact your playthrough, adding more ambiguity to how you play your game. I'm not a "creative" or "art-enjoying" individual, but the stories these characters go through are art to me. Their stories are immersive, and the development they go through feels “believable”. I sincerely hope that we get to experience more in future content or DLCs. 
The world design is beautiful - exploring its many secrets and worlds is awesome. From the Corpos of the City Center, to the Streetkids in the slums of Kabuki, to the beautiful but unforgiving Badlands and its Nomad clans. At times the game would feel somewhat empty, probably due to the (supposedly) cut content. The world is graphically amazing, actually making go out and purchase a new GPU to experience the beauty of the game to a greater potential. Finally, the last Core aspect I will touch upon before moving on - the music. "Wow" - that's the first word that comes to mind. Throughout the game, the soundtrack is absolutely one of the best parts of the game. The in-game radio with its various music types and artists, the story related band Samurai and their punk rock songs (these are absolutely amazing and I cannot get enough of it!), but also the gameplay soundtrack - just wow. Music is used expertly in this game to immerse you, but also to emphasize story-critical moments while also making your choices "weigh" more heavily on you. Sometimes it makes you feel like a badass. Sometimes it puts you at a crossroads for whatever decisions you're gonna make. Sometimes you just forget that it's a game, and when music does that, it means it's on a different level.

Sadly, the Technical aspects of Cyberpunk 2077 cannot be ignored. The lackluster AI, the catastrophic launch, the in-game bugs, and the driving. The NPC AI is one of the most life-absent AI I've experienced - NPCs don't act human, they will react to you in a way that will definitely break your immersion, make you laugh, or perhaps just frustrate you. The police are a joke in the game, never chasing after you when a crime has been committed (if you run far enough), and if you decide to fight them they will spawn behind you in wasp-like swarms, easily overpowering you unless you know what you’re doing. 99% of the time I found myself running far enough away from them so they'd despawn, and the 1% of time I decided to fight them I was powerful enough to defeat them to the point where they just gave up after a while. 
The various gangs and its AI around the world aren't much better. Most of the time you end up going to an objective where you're supposed to "dispose of the criminals". A reputation system with the gangs and the police which would affect your interactions with other gangs or whatnot would've been super cool. Unfortunately, it all feels like copy-pasted side missions whose purpose is to give the player an option to grind out XP and materials. They all feel the same/extremely similar so if you end up wanting to skip them, I wouldn't blame you. At a certain level and skill-build, the game just “breaks” and you will easily be able to complete the game.
My playthroughs have been relatively bug-free. Rarely did I encounter a bug which forced me to reload a previous save, but there will be things like the AI acting stupidly, T-posing, glitching through the world and random deaths. This is something I hope will be fixed, because it greatly impacts the many Core strengths of the game. Driving feels unpolished - I'd spin out frequently and the NPC's driving also feels underwhelming. I don't think I saw a single NPC drive a bike apart from myself, so what's the point of having bikes in the game? Also, no train/subway system? Then why are there stations and trains going around the city? 
There is, however, one great Technical aspect of the game - the combat. Yes, it will become "easy" and you'll feel like an absolute boss, but at least in my opinion that's good. It's a story-driven game, and the last thing I want is for this to turn into DOOM Eternal on Ultra Nightmare where I rip my hair out over the combat after spending three hours on one part of the game. There are so many ways to play the game, many of which I have yet to experience for myself. I first opted for a stealth build while using a silenced revolver. I also spliced in some light-netrunning there as well. My second playthrough I went for a more combat-oriented build. Shotguns, rifles, and snipers - no hacking just brute force. Both builds were incredibly fun to play and gave the game a fresh feeling when tackling quests, missions, and gigs. I feel like this is one Technical aspect CDPR really nailed - the combat starts out difficult, but as you grow in the game, your power also grows. It just feels natural, and makes it possible to focus on the main focus of the game - the story. There are combat bugs like I mentioned, but nothing that makes it impossible to play. 


So how would I shortly assess this game? Well like I alluded to in the beginning - it's an "unfinished masterpiece". An RPG game which Core elements are absolutely stellar, but a game which Technical aspects falls incredibly short. To anyone with the hardware to run the game at decent graphical settings and framerate, I would recommend it. To anyone else, wait. Wait and see if CDPR will deliver on "fixing" the game after its lackluster launch. I never joined the hype-train and thus didn't have any expectations for the game. Even after the early reviews, I still bought the game, but I am glad I did. I've fallen in love with the story, characters, and world-design. The Technical aspects of the game do not out-weigh the positive Core aspects of the game for me.
It is one of the best games I've ever played, despite its glaring issues. Bittersweet, just like the story of the game. I happened to enjoy the game, but it’s not guaranteed that you will. Take this review for what it is - one man’s opinion of the game.

First of all, it'll be tough to review this game without addressing the controversy. I'm not making the claim that the game is bug/glitch-free. I can think of 2-3 memorable glitches in 60 hours of playing this game, and none of them have put me out more than 3-5 minutes after reloading a save. They also cropped up in typically-extreme circumstances. In one case, while visiting Misty's store for the first time, I forgot to pause the game before going to work, and came back 9 IRL hours later to find V still standing in the same spot I left him, with Jackie stuck in the car and unable to move. I reloaded to the previous auto-save and was back in business a couple of minutes later. 
There were a couple of other incidents which were easily solved in minutes through the use of the Dev console on the PC version of the game (an item glitching through a wall and being out of reach, etc). All of those glitches were roughly 10-20 hours apart and I had to search my memory to even remember some of them. 
Perhaps I'm lucky, or maybe the PC version of the game is just more stable. (My GPU is 6 years old so it's not my hot tech running circles around the last-gen console versions of the game)
All I know is that when millions of people play a game and upload footage, it's easy to make a 20-minute compilation of relatively rare glitches. My experience has been vastly different. 
Also, in the latest 1.1 patch, I almost doubled my framerate without touching any settings. (granted I also did a fresh update of my GPU drivers which may have helped a little). The game is rapidly fixing it's flaws, thanks to that insane Polish work-ethic. 

Now, for the actual review. 

The game is beautiful. Granted NC is pretty filthy, but it is the most beautiful filth ever rendered in a PC game. Every building and area of the game has it's own distinct character, and the level of detail, right down to the stickers/graffiti and mountains of trash, is beyond compare. If the game took 8 years to come out, it definitely shows. 
There's also a fair bit of variety to the gameplay. Even in just the combat alone, I can think of a half dozen viable builds off the top of my head, which I discovered largely through trial and error, and with a few tips from a friend. If you want to create a fast, durable character with a shotgun that turns enemies in to a chunky red mist, you can do it fairly early. After level 20 or so, you can start adding body augmentations that can further help the play style, like smart rockets firing out of your forearm, or the mantis blades that chop people up in to bite sized portions. I've got a friend that uses a fairly stacked sniper build that can ping people through walls and shoot them in the head for massive crit damage, without ever entering a building. I'm currently running a build with a smart gun (skippy) that automatically aims for the head and is stacked with crit mods for outrageous damage (all viable without duplication glitches or console commands). I've barely touched the stealth side of the game because I've still got a few combat builds I want to try, and the gun-play is (so far) endlessly entertaining.
The writing and characters are also quite solid, although for spoiler purposes, I won't give away too much. Granted it's got a rather campy vibe in certain parts, but if you like/expect that style of writing and humour, you will be pleasantly surprised. In typical CDPR fashion, the lines between good and bad are blurred in the majority of decisions you make. If you're as invested as I am, you will lie awake at night and question your morals. I only just inadvertently caused a minor genocide in Pacifica and I'm writing this review to avoid confronting the fact that I'm basically a cyberpunk Hitler. 

There are a few downsides, of course. The game isn't all sunshine and rainbows. It took me 3 separate playthroughs of the tutorial to fully understand a substantial amount of the games mechanics. They certainly don't hold your hand when teaching you how to play. You can also accidentally skip vital parts of the tutorials and wind up lost and confused at certain points further down the line. I would recommend paying close attention in the first 4 hours or so if you don't want to repeat the beginning of the game. 

My other major hitch at the moment is having a dense map that still feels somewhat empty. I've walked past numerous street vendors selling food and haven't been able to interact with any of them. Also, the vast majority of NPC's have very limited interactions. (outside of essential characters, obviously). Granted, it does a much better job of making the city feel "alive" than most other games, but it's not quite on the level of something like GTAV/RDR2. Fingers crossed for a future patch that allows for more detailed interactions with the world around us. 

Look, at the end of the day, I'm having a great deal of fun in this game. It's easy to remember the bad aspects of a game, while totally glossing over the really good aspects that an amazing studio and dev team have created. While nothing in this world is perfect, CDPR was at least ambitious enough to try and be. While falling short in many regards, it's still leagues of other AAA games in many ways. 

Did they deliver on ALL of their promises? No... (RIP mantis-blade wall-climbing)
But did they deliver a kick-ass RPG-shooter that doesn't turn in to "Bullet-sponge Simulator 2021"? ABSOLUTELY. (*cough* The Division *cough*)

Controversy aside, this game has been an absolute blast to play. I would recommend this to anyone familiar with the Witcher games. If you're still skeptical after reading this, then wait for the GOTY edition to come out with all the DLC's and patches. Either way, make room for this game in your future :)

The weapons quickly become bland though as you get a few that are extremely powerful (cough widowmaker.. cough) and the rest just don't hold up. It could also be my playstyle. I dumped a lot of points into handguns then started swapping to different weapons as I found them more fun.

The character customization is pretty good, it's no skyrim though. You can respec your perk points, but it costs 100k in game and I find myself farming to fix mistakes I made going in new. 

The writing and voice acting is amazing. There were two sidequests I did called "Sinnerman" and "Happy Together" that has stuck with me as some of the more emotional things I've ever seen in a game. Moreso than Heavy Rain's emotional story.

All in all, it's worth it. If CDPR fixes the bugs, even more.

Edit:

Okay, so, the game no longer gives me black screens, whether that's by CDPR fixing a bug that gets ignored for AMD's mesa drivers, or nvidia fixed the mutable. It works now.

So I played it, a LOT more again, started over, of course.

A few things, some of the problems are ingrained deeply, like police AI, traffic, people. These things are still very bad. They don't bother me, personally, but I felt it important to mention

The things that can be fixed, through patches or DLC are, for me, a lot more important.

Apartments, I want a lot of choices, both for picking the apartment, and decorating it. As things stand, you just have V's shitty apartment with no customisation.

Metro system, taxi, etc. Whilst I don't mind fast travel as it is. I loved the scenes where Jackie drives me, or the Delemain, or even Judy  etc. I would love to have things like that in, being driven through Night City. Or flown, like the corpo start vehicle.

Shops, the world feels a bit barebones and empty. Wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle, as they say. Most stores, even those with signs that say "OPEN" in neon letters, are always closed, or not even interactable. This makes it all feel a lot more shallow. There are food stands all over the place, but none of them actually sell you food. This needs to change. It's silly.

Braindances. A big thing, within this world. Whole gangs and storyline is devoted to it. You see people on the street, or in bars watching these things. I purchased all Braindances I could find. Alas, outside of story missions (where BD's are an essential tool to further the plot) you cannot use them. Which is a huge shame.

You'll notice the things can get fixed easily.  

The game is very barebones at the moment. Is it what they  promised? No, not even close. It's still a pretty decent RPG, all things considered. But it has the potential to be so much more.
The story is good, it has problems, I don't like certain directions, or that my relationship with certain NPCs is tied to the story. I would love to say that outside the main mission you could just live your life, so to speak. But the vast majority of side missions are the same. If they keep building on it, and adding to it. RPG things, relationships, customisation for everything, apartments included, more unique side missions with story elements. The ability to roleplay, make your own narrative. Then this game -can- be one of the best games ever. As it stands though, it's decidedly average. With a lot of untapped potential, but it's good, and playable. So I can now recommend the game, at least. Even on Linux (which is what I play on, it's ironically faster for me then on Windows now.)

1/24/21:
This game is a mess. From the cars in traffic that simply run you over if you cross the street, to objects clipping into the world, and not being clickable (especially when they are in the grass). The marketing had this excellent gallows humor to it, and even before booting up the game all of the wild videos betray the game you eventually end up playing.

There is something there in this game that could become something, but it ultimately is just a sad attempt at a Ubisoft open-world action/adventure.

There is only 1(?) apartment to own, cars can be bought but never modded. Even the system for purchasing them is tedious and completely boring. 

Additionally, I think this game is the nail in the coffin for the "RPG" title for me. Sure, there are RPGs out there, but I believe that most action-adventure games have RPG elements in them. So it strikes me as a silly marketing ploy.

An amazing game under-minded by poor management. 

I had an outdated gaming pc when I first bought this game on release, and like many others, was disappointed on the horrible state it was and still is in. However, I wasn't disappointed because the game was bad, because it's not. What the game IS however, is poorly optimized and underdeveloped. THAT is what disappointed me. I then, a few weeks later, decided to play on Geforce Now, and afterwords built a good gaming pc that could handle it. Though I haven't completed the game I was and still am captivated by how beautiful it looks, the great voice acting, gameplay, characters, and the story. I'm about a quarter way through the game and I can safely say it's one of the best RPG experiences I've had in a while. 
In all honesty though, this game needed at least 5-8 more months (maybe even another year) for it to be fully polished. Their first mistake was giving a release date. Their second, creating huge expectations. I'm sure if that it were up to the Devs, they wouldn't have released it like this and would have waited. So I can't fault them for it too much. 
Regardless of who you want to point fingers at the fact remains, that only a small chunk of the gaming community (like me) are able to truly enjoy this game right now, while the rest paid $60 for a trip to Bug city. If you haven't bought it yet but would like to, I'd say wait until it's optimized and playable if your system can't handle it. If you have it but can't get it to run or can't afford to drop $2,000 on a pc then I suggest using Geforce Now to hold you over until you do. Or just beat the game through that and call it a day (may save more money that way). 

TL;DR:  The game is good but needed more time in development. Only the people who have the Specs to run it are able to enjoy it right now. Either wait for patches for it to be playable, Use Geforce Now to compensate, or Buy a good pc if you REALLY want to play it right now.

Update for 1.5x patch: Still a buggy mess alas; stuff vanishing when you turn round, trains of cars still appear in the middle of the desert, characters spinning around in cut-scenes etc... There are 'less' issues now, but the base of the game is still deeply flawed and unsatisfying - and taking this long to add really basic stuff like in-game character customisation that should have been in at release is just not good enough.

By now, you've probably already heard about the bugs in this game, I won't go over those except to say: it is still VERY buggy, even at the time of the current patch 1.1. The bugs may not be as obvious as they were at launch, but they are still there, and in large quantities.

To quickly summarise for those who don't like to read: once you have finished the main story, you are left with what is in essence a reskinned Grand Theft Auto V with no multiplayer, no sense of humour, and a bunch of game mechanics that are a hindrance to your enjoyment of the setting. 

The city itself looks great, the art style overall is really good especially the cars. The content within is like a nerd's techno sex-fantasy, the outfits are straight out of a BDSM magazine (all shiny and skin-tight), the atmosphere is one of complete sexual deviancy which the billboards all over the city keep reminding you. I mean, the first time you see some of it, yeah, it's quite funny, but seriously 'Milfguard'? A thousand variations on sexual performance enhancements? Whoever thought up some of this seems to be a pubescent William Gibson or Piers Anthony fan. It feels like it's trying to be funny, but then it's not, and is actually taking itself seriously, very seriously. There's no objectivity shown here at all, if this is CDPR's vision of a dystopian future then I'm just embarrassed for them, it's childish and puerile.

The story is okay, it has a few alternate endings, some of which make more sense than others. The Keanu Reeves performance is typical for him, it's mostly deadpan with some good moments. The other performances from the voice actors etc is pretty good. The material is really predictable however, and it's very difficult to get attached to any of the character's predicaments outside of your own (and that's because you have no choice on your own path). Some of the set piece combat/stealth missions are pretty fun the first time. There are also a bunch of potential sex scenes (which you can't skip btw), so if watching some really bad animated sex is your thing then there's plenty for you to rub one out to.

One of the big things that CP2077 was hyped up for was it's character creator. Well, yes, you can customise your genitals, if you can call having three options for each gender customisation. This 'customisation' is the theme of the whole thing, there's no sliders just a bunch of presets for various attributes: nose, eyes, jaw, and so on. And whilst 30+ hairstyles might seem a lot, it's actually more like variations on 3 or 4 styles plus bald. You also get tattoos, for face and body, 4 or 5 choices for each and no way to change the colours from a dark sickly green. There are no body shape options here either, so if you wanted to make a fatty from 2001AD then you are out of luck. You can get some good looks from it, but ultimately they all feel the same.

In conclusion, if you remember the launch of No Mans Sky, then it's worse than that. NMS had the game but not the content when it launched, and has now matured into a great all round game. CP2077 has the content (just) but not the game, and I have no hope that without a complete rewrite of the basic game mechanics that we'll get any more from this than just a bunch of bug fixes and some opening up of closed areas in future DLC. 

Just avoid, you can be disappointed at your own sexual performance IRL without also watching it unfold in a game.

One of the buggiest AAA games I've ever played if you don't count all the Ubisoft games. I didn't believe in the hype which most of the people seem to have bought with blue eyes. We've been lied by gaming companies for years in E3 presentations and reveals, so why should we believe hype. Has there ever been a game that lives up to the hype 100%? It's like here in Finland where we know that snow will come at some point during winter, yet every year we are taken by surprise when the winter finally comes.


 Cyberpunk 2077 is  an open world game where if you go explore the open world you find bugs, glitches and break the game.  Even though I didn't really encounter any of the game breaking bugs there were times that some bugs really frustrated me during some side missions. Speaking of side missions there is story related side missions with real content and then some "fetch this",  "kill this" "steal that" kind of missions that are boring and just there to fill the world.  I left most of those undone after my 128 hour playthrough of the story.  And I won't be playing this again until there is more content.

The life paths seem like you were supposed to pick street kid and progress through the ranks to corpo and then end up as a nomad. The game is full of potential that was wasted to make Johnny's Porsche look as authentic as possible and adding pointless youtubers and twitchers in the game.  

Fortunatelly for the game the story is good and saves the game. Even though it feels a bit rushed and it lacks the urgency the story want's you to think there is. 

The game needs patching and while it works on PC if you have proper hardware and not some ancient things you run Fortnite on, the game just isn't worth the price at the moment. Maybe after they release few patches, the promised free dlc that hopefully adds lots of the missing and cut content it will be worth the price.

So If you have decent enough computer and are willing to spend money on an unfinished game that might bring you enjoyment then go ahead by the game I recommend it to you. But if you lack the decent hardware and can't stand on buggy games. Well just go and play those graphic hentai novels. I don't really care. I liked the game well enough to actually recommend it here in Steam.
The Game came back just like how V came back from the dead.. Keep up the good work!

Has a lot of bugs and glitches, but you try making a game of this scale during the 2020 pandemic. Most critics of this game (both "professional" or otherwise) drive the point that it's not what CD Projekt Red claimed it would be, which is a fair point. However, despite all its flaws the gameplay is fun, the story is well written, and its packed to the brim with cool stuff; many of the side-quests are extremely interesting and memorable.

Bottom line: despite being unfinished, the game is still very fun and if you are willing to wait for the day it's 100% done and finished, I predict that you won't be disappointed.

Cyberpunk does so many things great. I love it. I just wish the story was longer because that's where it really shines. Honestly, that's kind of the case with so much of this game: I wish they would have gone deeper and let you have more than just surface interactions with Night City and NPCs. They created this huge city but for all that work and for all that you see, you only just start to interact with it on a truly meaningful level. I really liked this game but I just think it could have been so much better and I can't help but feel disappointed about that. It's like having an incredible new sports car you can't drive past 50 MPH.

It's an unfinished product. I'm in my third playthrough with over 180 hours of gameplay and I've explored almost every spot in the game. I've noticed that a lot of things were left accessible without any purpose, some areas that lead to a pitfall into the void and some stories are left without a conclusion. Those aspects of the game are either left unfinished or have been removed. I'm getting the idea that the project was mismanaged.

Many scenes which would have had a stat-check like in the videos presented by CDPR have been removed. Areas blocked off by an invisible wall for developer convenience. Unkillable characters for unknown reasons.

Yes, I would have liked to kill Meredith Stout, explored Biotechnica, ripped the gorilla arms off of any dumbass gonk (idiot in C2077 jargon) and heck, even refuse doing the Dex heist. All of this, is possible without breaking the main questline and the game, but it's not available to the players because...? We don't know. Due to the lack of openness from CDPR, the community is left to wonder about the future of Cyberpunk 2077.

The main storyline is beautiful but inconclusive. The game mechanics are fun but glitchy. The overall experience is fantastic but at the same time, frustrating. I cannot recommend this game because CDPR promised something and did not deliver it to the standard of that promise. It's unfortunate but I strongly suggest they, CDPR, forget making the game playable on console and focus on finishing the game on PC.

Avoid this game. It's not ready yet.
bugs aside, simply a must play. whoever gets to play this for the first time a few months/years down the line, will have the best experience.
